      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>26</tei:p>
         <tei:p>R. P. LANE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Egypt. 2 cf , 4 $, Gaza, vii.1940 (0. Theodor}.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Yugoslavia, Turkey, Lebanon, Syria, Israel, Cyprus, Egypt, Iraq, Iran, Pakistan, N. India,<tei:lb/>Afghanistan. This is the first record of this species from Egypt.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sergentomyia tiberiadis (Adler , Theodor &amp; Lourie)<tei:lb/>(Figs 74-77)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phlebotomus tiberiadis Adler, Theodor &amp; Lourie, 1930: 537 [cf ?]. Lectotype &lt;j&gt;, PALESTINE (BMNH),<tei:lb/>designated by Lewis &amp; Biittiker (1982: 367).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species is currently placed in the subgenus Sintonius.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FEMALE. Head narrow. Cibarium with straight row of about 16 strong, curved, closely packed horizontal<tei:lb/>teeth; these characteristic teeth may appear straight in some poorly mounted specimens; two or three rows<tei:lb/>of distinct vertical teeth; pigment patch broad, almost as wide as tooth row (Fig. 77). Pharynx slender with<tei:lb/>barely discernible armature in form of transverse striations. Spermatheca with 6-8 segments.<tei:lb/>MALE. Cibarium with a row of 12-14 curved horizontal teeth and one or two rows of vertical teeth (Fig. 74);<tei:lb/>pigment patch vague, almost as wide as tooth row. Pharynx slender, gently narrowing after bulge;<tei:lb/>armature a series of indistinct ridges (Fig. 75). Paramere with distinct beak apically (Fig. 76). Style with two<tei:lb/>apical, two subapical spines. Aedeagus slender, tapering from base.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Egypt: 1 cf, Aswan Governate, Aswan, Elephantine Island, 3-5. x. 1983, sticky traps amongst rocks<tei:lb/>(R.P.L.); 2 cf , Aswan, xi.1967 (M.A.R.); 2 cf , Luxor, 8.xi.l966 (Z.A.H.).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Egypt, Israel, Djibouti, Ethiopia, South &amp; North Yemen, Sudan. Rifaat et al. (1968) record<tei:lb/>this species from Egypt but give no specific locality.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species is easily distinguished from 5. christophersi and S. clydei by the shape and number of cibarial<tei:lb/>teeth in the male and female. The Oriental subspecies S. tiberiadis pakistanica Artemiev &amp; Saf yanova<tei:lb/>differs from the nominate subspecies in the spermathecal capsule which narrows towards the tip and has<tei:lb/>more segments (9-12), and the lower mean number of cibarial teeth (13 compared to 17-18). The<tei:lb/>subspecies pakistanica is restricted to Pakistan and Afghanistan.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>76</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 75-77 Sergentomyia tiberiadis. 75, cf, pharynx; 76, paramere; 77, $ , cibarium. (Aswan.)</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>SANDFLIES OF EGYPT 27</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Faunal associations</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Based on the distributions of sandflies collected in Egypt and described above, the fauna can be<tei:lb/>divided into three distinct elements. Each element has affinities to faunas in areas outside Egypt<tei:lb/>and these are discussed below and compared to the distribution of other insects.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Elements of the Egyptian sandfly fauna</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Each of the three faunal elements is composed of a characteristic, although not mutually<tei:lb/>exclusive, group of species. The areas occupied by these three faunal elements are:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mediterranean/Lower Egypt element: coastal Egypt, Siwa Oasis, the Delta and Nile valley as</tei:p>
         <tei:p>far south as Asyut, and northern Sinai.<tei:lb/>Upper Egypt: Nile valley to Lake Nasser and the oases of Bahariya, Farafra, Dakhla and</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Kharga.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>S. Sinai: the mountain system from Gebel el Igma southwards to Sharm el Sheikh.<tei:lb/>The fauna of the mountainous southern Sinai is clearly distinct from that of northern Sinai,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>which has a typical lowland Middle Eastern fauna composed of P. papatasi and 5.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>antennata.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The species representing each of the three faunal elements are listed on pages 4-5. All are<tei:lb/>restricted to their component areas except P. papatasi, P. sergenti and 5. palestinensis , which are<tei:lb/>widespread in distribution. P. papatasi is the only species found predominantly in peridomestic<tei:lb/>habitats.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clearly, this division of the fauna into three elements is greatly influenced by the distribution<tei:lb/>of collecting sites, and at present it is not possible to delimit precisely each area. For example,<tei:lb/>the Upper Egypt component is based on collecting around Aswan and in the Kharga and Dakhla<tei:lb/>oases, but the extent to which the species of this area penetrate northwards along the narrow<tei:lb/>riverine vegetation to Beni Suef and Faiyum in Lower Egypt is unknown. The faunas of Upper<tei:lb/>and Lower Egypt (including northern Sinai) are more similar (i.e. have more species in<tei:lb/>common) to each other than either is to the southern Sinai fauna, presumably because of the<tei:lb/>Nilotic connection suggested above, and the presence of high mountains in southern Sinai and<tei:lb/>associated habitats not available in the rest of Egypt. Several geographically important areas<tei:lb/>need to be surveyed to complete the faunistic picture of Egyptian sandflies, particularly the<tei:lb/>remote wadi systems of the southern Sinai and Upper Egypt, the oases of Siwa and Farafra, and<tei:lb/>the Red Sea Hills.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The largest and most diverse faunal component in Egypt is that of the southern Sinai, with 12<tei:lb/>species (6 Phlebotomus , 6 Sergentomyia) compared to the six (1 Phlebotomus, 5 Sergentomyia)<tei:lb/>found in Upper Egypt and eight (3 Phlebotomus, 5 Sergentomyia) in the Mediterranean/Lower<tei:lb/>Egypt component.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is not clear which environmental factors have the greatest effect on the distribution of<tei:lb/>different sandfly species, although it is clear that some species have a marked association with a<tei:lb/>particular habitat. Vegetation affects sandfly distribution indirectly through its effect on the<tei:lb/>hosts of sandflies, which can be either carnivores (dogs, foxes etc.), herbivores (rodents) or man<tei:lb/>and domestic animals (goats, poultry). However, the presence of some plants may be important<tei:lb/>as sources of sugar meals for the adults. The shade provided by vegetation probably has a<tei:lb/>minimal direct effect on sandfly distribution as sandflies rarely use plants as resting sites (e.g.<tei:lb/>tree holes) in arid regions, although vegetation structure clearly has an effect on some sandfly<tei:lb/>hosts. Temperature has some role in governing distribution because some species found in the<tei:lb/>high mountains of the southern Sinai (e.g. Gebel Katherina which rises to 2637 m) are exposed,<tei:lb/>during the winter snowfall, to low temperatures which would be fatal to other species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Association of Egyptian fauna with neighbouring areas</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Throughout this discussion, the affinity of the different elements of the Egyptian fauna with the<tei:lb/>faunas of neighbouring areas is measured by the number of species they share. Figs 78-80</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>28 R. P. LANE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>summarise the proportion of each faunal element found in seven neighbouring areas. Several<tei:lb/>factors affect these estimates of affinity, including the number of species in a faunal element,<tei:lb/>differences in the taxonomic status of a species (e.g. S. cintus is treated as a distinct species here<tei:lb/>but as a synonym by some authors) and differences in sampling (some areas are better known<tei:lb/>than others). Hence, such estimates, like so many others which take no account of relative<tei:lb/>abundance of species or the range of habitats available in an area, can only be used to give a<tei:lb/>general impression of the affinity of faunas.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Southern Sinai is known as an area of endemicity in some groups, e.g. Lepidoptera and<tei:lb/>Orthoptera, but it does not have any endemic sandflies. However, the Sinai populations of some<tei:lb/>species show subtle morphological differences from populations in other parts of their range,<tei:lb/>e.g. P. orientalis and P. major. More refined taxonomic techniques may demonstrate substantial<tei:lb/>differences, the lack of endemicity in sandflies may be because the group is well adapted, even<tei:lb/>common, in arid areas and therefore the deserts of the region do not pose a very significant<tei:lb/>barrier to dispersal and introgression of populations as they do in most other groups of insects.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The sandfly fauna of the southern Sinai shows a marked affinity with the fauna of the Arabian<tei:lb/>Peninsula (see Lewis &amp; Buttiker, 1982), particularly Asir, Yemen (in Lewis, 1974ft) and, to a<tei:lb/>lesser but still significant extent, to the highlands of eastern Africa (Table 4; Fig. 80). The<tei:lb/>mountains of the southern Sinai represent an isolated part of a tongue of the Afrotropical<tei:lb/>Region extending northwards to the end of the Rift Valley System in northern Israel (Upper<tei:lb/>Galilee). The principal species indicating this association are P. arabicus, P. orientalis, P.<tei:lb/>kazeruni, S. taizi and S. adleri, which dominate the fauna of south-west of the Arabian Peninsula<tei:lb/>and are closely related to species in the Afrotropical Region. The absence of the common<tei:lb/>Palaearctic P. papatasi further supports this association and the conclusion that sandflies of these<tei:lb/>highland areas are a distinct part of the Afrotropical fauna and not a relict intrusion of the<tei:lb/>Palaearctic fauna. S. taizi has only been found in the mountains of Yemen (near Ta'izz) and at<tei:lb/>the top of Gebel Katherina. Unlike parts of the sandfly fauna of the Arabian Peninsula, the Sinai<tei:lb/>fauna does not contain any Oriental species, although some species are east European/west<tei:lb/>Asian (P. alexandri, P. kazeruni). Therefore the southern Sinai does not constitute part of the<tei:lb/>Triad Zone as defined by Lewis &amp; Buttiker (1980).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The sandfly fauna of Upper Egypt has affinities with both the Arabian peninsula and the Sahel<tei:lb/>of Africa, through species such as S. christophersi, S. clydei, S. adleri, S. schwetzi and 5.<tei:lb/>tiberiadis (Table 4; Fig. 79). P. papatasi is not typically African and its presence in Upper Egypt<tei:lb/>is part of a southernly extension of its range along the Nile Valley as far as northern Sudan.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sandflies of Lower Egypt and the northern Sinai are typical of the North African and eastern<tei:lb/>Mediterranean faunas (Table 4; Fig. 78). The rarity of P. langeroni has already been noted<tei:lb/>(p. 11). Its presence in Egypt indicates that it may be widely distributed along the North African<tei:lb/>coast, perhaps in association with outcrops of limestone which are such a feature of the area in<tei:lb/>Egypt where it is comparatively common. 5. squamipleuris is a member of a species group widely<tei:lb/>distributed along a band south of the Sahara, through the Arabian Peninsula and into northern<tei:lb/>India. Its presence in Lower Egypt represents a northerly extension of its range, in contrast to<tei:lb/>that postulated above for other species (e.g. P. papatasi). S. squamipleuris is more rigidly<tei:lb/>confined to the riverine vegetation along the Nile than are many other sandflies, where it feeds<tei:lb/>on amphibians.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Distribution of insects other than sandflies</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The comparison of distribution patterns of sandflies with those of other biting flies (Simuliidae,<tei:lb/>Ceratopogonidae and Culicidae) is germane to understanding sandfly faunal associations,<tei:lb/>because these other flies also are influenced by the search for hosts. However, other biting flies<tei:lb/>are restricted environmentally by the need for free water (running water in Simuliidae) for the<tei:lb/>development of the immature stages.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The mosquito Culex sinaiticus Kirkpatrick was thought to be confined to southern Sinai, but<tei:lb/>was later found in Eritrea and northern Sudan (Red Sea coast around Port Sudan and in central<tei:lb/>Sudan) (Lewis, 1956), although it has not been found elsewhere in Egypt. A similar situation is<tei:lb/>found in Culex arbieeni de Meillon which is known from southern Sinai and the upper slopes of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>Lower Egypt</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SANDFLIES OF EGYPT</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Upper Egypt</tei:p>
         <tei:p>29</tei:p>
         <tei:p>S. Sinai</tei:p>
         <tei:p>100</tei:p>
         <tei:p>80</tei:p>
         <tei:p>60</tei:p>
         <tei:p>40</tei:p>
         <tei:p>20</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A B C D E F G</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A B C D E F G</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A B C D E F G</tei:p>
         <tei:p>78</tei:p>
         <tei:p>79</tei:p>
         <tei:p>80</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 78-80 Histograms showing the percentage of the species from Lower Egypt (78), Upper Egypt (79)<tei:lb/>and southern Sinai (80) which also occur in neighbouring areas.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A = east Saudi Arabia + Iran; B = south-west Saudi Arabia + Yemen + Ethiopia; C = Sudan; D =<tei:lb/>Sahel; E = north Africa; F = Israel; G = east Mediterranean. X = one species as percentage of total<tei:lb/>number in faunal element.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the Marra mountains in west Sudan (Lewis, 1954). In the Simuliidae, only two species are known<tei:lb/>from Egypt. Simulium griseicolle Becker which breeds in large rivers in Africa, has only been<tei:lb/>found once in Egypt, at Aswan, its type-locality. The second species, Simulium ruficorne<tei:lb/>Macquart, has a very wide distribution throughout the savannah areas of Africa (south of the<tei:lb/>Sahara), North Africa, Spain and African islands. It is not clear whether it is an Afrotropical or<tei:lb/>Palaearctic species but it probably represents a species complex. Specimens of S. ruficorne from<tei:lb/>Feiran Oasis in southern Sinai are similar in their pupal gill structure (Crosskey , pers. comm.) to<tei:lb/>specimens from Israel and the Hejaz. Unfortunately very little is known of the Egyptian<tei:lb/>Ceratopogonidae, particularly Culicoides, but the known fauna, based on collecting in the<tei:lb/>Delta, is Palaearctic. Thus the faunal associations of other biting flies are broadly concordant<tei:lb/>with those of the Egyptian sandflies, showing connections between Sinai and the Afrotropical<tei:lb/>Region, and Lower Egypt and the Palaearctic Region.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As noted above, southern Sinai is a known area of endemicity in other insect orders. For<tei:lb/>example, Uvarov (1929) studied a small collection of Orthoptera from southern Sinai and drew<tei:lb/>the following conclusions: 'in general composition the known fauna of the Sinai peninsula is<tei:lb/>clearly a local division of the Palaearctic eremian fauna ... it possesses certain features of its<tei:lb/>own [endemics]. The Sinai peninsula must be regarded as one of the dry mountainous centres<tei:lb/>where an ancient Mediterranean fauna survives, where the present eremian fauna was born and<tei:lb/>developed and from where it spread over the whole great desert belts . . . the Sinai fauna has a<tei:lb/>close similarity, perhaps an intimate relation to that of Arabia' [although at the time the latter<tei:lb/>fauna was very poorly known].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In a comprehensive account of the biogeography of Arabian butterflies, Larsen (1984) makes<tei:lb/>relatively little comment on the Egyptian fauna other than that it is typical of the 'Palaearctic<tei:lb/>eremic zone'. However, there are several endemic species of butterflies in the southern Sinai<tei:lb/>massif.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In conclusion, the sandfly fauna of Egypt is exceptional, compared to the sandfly fauna of<tei:lb/>other countries, in being so clearly divided into Afrotropical and Palaearctic elements. Whether<tei:lb/>Egypt and surrounding areas have always been a point of faunal exchange of sandflies between<tei:lb/>the two zoogeographic regions, with the Nile valley and the mountains of the Red Sea coast and<tei:lb/>Sinai acting as major dispersal routes, is not clear. Lewis (1982) has suggested that the genus<tei:lb/>Phlebotomus is Palaearctic in origin and subsequently extended southwards into Africa during<tei:lb/>the pluvial periods, presumably through the Nile and Rift valleys. However, the Sahara desert</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>30 R. P. LANE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 4 Comparison of the species shared between each of the three components of the Egyptian sandfly<tei:lb/>fauna and the faunas of neighbouring areas.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>has not always been such a barrier to dispersal and possibly, in an arid-adapted group such as the<tei:lb/>sandflies, substantial dispersal may have taken place either through or around the Sahara. A<tei:lb/>more comprehensive study of sandflies throughout the whole of the Eremic Zone (Morocco to<tei:lb/>Afghanistan) is required to answer these questions fully.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I am grateful to: staff of the Research and Training Centre on Vectors of Disease at Ain Shams University,<tei:lb/>Cairo, particularly Dr S. El Said, Professor B. El Sawaf and Dr J. Beier, for assistance during visits to<tei:lb/>Egypt; Dr Y. Braverman, Israel, for valuable material from Sinai; the UNDP/World Bank/WHO Special<tei:lb/>Programme for Research and Training in Tropical Diseases, and the National Institutes of Health<tei:lb/>(National Institute for Allergy and Infectious Diseases) for financial assistance; and my wife for the<tei:lb/>illustrations.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Some other works on Diptera</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The following papers were published in the Bulletin of the British Museum (Natural History)<tei:lb/>Entomology series. Copies are still available: each is virtually a monograph and complete in<tei:lb/>itself with paper covers.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vol. 4 No. 3 The mosquitoes of Arabia. I. P. F. Mattingly and K. L. Knight. 1956. pp. 89-141. 4 text<tei:lb/>figures 3. 70</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Vol. 21 No. 6 A revision of the Ethiopian species of the tribe Notiphilini (Diptera: Ephydridae). B. H.<tei:lb/>Cogan. 1968. pp. 279-365. 1 plate, 96 text figures 6.25</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vol. 24 No. 7 Studies of African Asilidae (Diptera) I. Asilidae of the Congo Basin. H. Oldroyd. 1970.<tei:lb/>pp. 207-334. 96 text figures 8.95</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vol. 26 No. 8 A revision of Francis Walker's types of North American Empididae (Diptera). K. G. V.<tei:lb/>Smith. 1971. pp. 345-370. 3 plates, 16 text figures 2.25</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vol. 30 No. 7 A revision of the genus Passeromyia Rodhain and Villeneuve (Diptera: Muscidae). A. C.<tei:lb/>Pont. 1974. pp. 339-372. 9 text figures 2.40</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vol. 36 No. 1 A review of the Rhinophoridae (Diptera), and a revision of the Afrotropical species.<tei:lb/>R. W. Crosskey. 1979. pp. 1-66. 46 figs 8.35</tei:p>

         <tei:p>BRr</tei:p>
         <tei:p>.(N</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PRESENTED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bulletin of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fungus moths: a review of the<tei:lb/>Scardiinae (Lepidoptera: Tineidae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>G. S. Robinson</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Entomology series</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vol52 No 2 24 April 1986</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>The Bulletin of the British Museum (Natural History), instituted in 1949, is issued in four<tei:lb/>scientific series, Botany, Entomology, Geology (incorporating Mineralogy) and Zoology,<tei:lb/>and an Historical series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Papers in the Bulletin are primarily the results of research carried out on the unique and<tei:lb/>ever-growing collections of the Museum, both by the scientific staff of the Museum and by<tei:lb/>specialists from elsewhere who make use of the Museum's resources. Many of the papers are<tei:lb/>works of reference that will remain indispensable for years to come.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parts are published at irregular intervals as they become ready, each is complete in itself,<tei:lb/>available separately, and individually priced. Volumes contain about 300 pages and several<tei:lb/>volumes may appear within a calendar year. Subscriptions may be placed for one or more of<tei:lb/>the series on either an Annual or Per Volume basis. Prices vary according to the contents of<tei:lb/>the individual parts. Orders and enquiries should be sent to:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Publications Sales,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History) ,<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>London SW75BD,<tei:lb/>England.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>World List abbreviation: Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Ent.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trustees of the British Museum (Natural History), 1986</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Entomology series is produced under the general editorship of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Keeper of Entomology: Laurence A. Mound</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Assistant Editor: W. Gerald Tremewan</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ISBN 565 06016 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ISSN 0524-6431 Entomology series</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vol52No2pp37-181<tei:lb/>British Museum (Natural History)<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road<tei:lb/>London SW7 5BD Issued 24 April 1 986</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>Fungus moths: a review of the Scardiinae<tei:lb/>(Lepidoptera: Tineidae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gaden S. Robinson</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Department of Entomology, British Museum (Natural History), Cromwell Road, London<tei:lb/>SW7 5BD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>StiM ! hU</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ARY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contents</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis 37</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction 37</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Techniques 40</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Check-list of Scardiinae 41</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxa excluded from the Scardiinae 43</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Classification and characters - but phylogeny? 43</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Objectives 43</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Methods 43</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Supraspecific groups (OTUs) classified 46</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Characters used in classification 46</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Results 50</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Geographical distribution 58</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abbreviations 60</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements 60</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scardiinae Eyer 61</tei:p>
         <tei:p>References 135</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Index to hostplants and fungi 180</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Index to Lepidoptera 180</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This paper gives an account of the subfamily Scardiinae, the fungus moths. The group is redefined and 111<tei:lb/>species in 23 genera are ascribed to it. Its previous taxonomic history and its biological and morphological<tei:lb/>characteristics are reviewed. Le Quesne tests show homoplasy to be rampant in the Scardiinae. Numerical<tei:lb/>phylogenetic methods are used with the aim of deriving a phylogenetic classification; their results are<tei:lb/>contrasted with those from various phenetic methods. Character-compatibility analysis is used to pinpoint<tei:lb/>'robust' characters with minimal homoplasy. Groups defined by such characters are found to be also<tei:lb/>'robust', being revealed by most of the analytical methods employed. The shortest optimized Wagner tree<tei:lb/>is adopted as the classification but the limited phylogenetic implications of this classification are stressed.<tei:lb/>The biogeography of the group is reviewed. Keys are provided to genera and species. Eight genera are<tei:lb/>described as new and one genus is recalled from synonymy. Twenty-six new species are described and 18<tei:lb/>species are placed in new generic combinations; four new synonymies are established.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The subfamily Scardiinae includes more than one hundred species of generally large and robust<tei:lb/>tineid moths. While the smallest species have a wingspan of only about 12 mm, the largest<tei:lb/>Scardiinae are among the biggest ditrysian Microlepidoptera, with wingspans of up to 60 mm.<tei:lb/>Despite their size, however, Scardiinae are not conspicuous.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is the biology of the Scardiinae that sets them apart, with one exception, from all other<tei:lb/>subfamilies of Lepidoptera. The larvae feed in either the fruiting body (sporophore) of<tei:lb/>persistent (hard) bracket-fungi, or in the wood of dead or moribund trees that has been<tei:lb/>permeated by the hyphae of such fungi. The traces left by feeding scardiinae larvae are<tei:lb/>characteristic - ramifying accretions of loosely webbed coarse frass forming a cover for surface<tei:lb/>and sub-surface feeding, usually combined with similar volcano-shaped accretions of frass or</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Ent.) 52 (2): 37-181 Issued 24 April 1986</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>38 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>loose mounds above deeper tunnels. Larvae pupate just below the surface of the food-substrate.<tei:lb/>The mobile pupa is protruded half-way out of the substrate (using two rows of backward-pointed<tei:lb/>spines on each abdominal segment to force its exit) before it ruptures and the adult emerges.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fungus-feeding Lepidoptera</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Examples of fungivory are found throughout the Lepidoptera and the reader is referred to the<tei:lb/>recent review by Rawlins (1984) for further details. Within the Tineoidea fungivores are found<tei:lb/>possibly among the species of Compsoctena (Eriocottidae). Lichenivory, a form of fungivory, is<tei:lb/>widespread among Psychidae. The biology of one of the eight species of Arrhenophanidae is<tei:lb/>known and it is a fungivore, feeding on 'Polyporus sp.' (Costa Lima, 1945; Becker, pers.<tei:lb/>comm.). Within the Tineidae fungivory is found in the subfamilies Hieroxestinae, Tineinae and<tei:lb/>Meessiinae (Lawrence &amp; Powell, 1969); many other species of Meessiinae are lichenivores.<tei:lb/>However, apart from the Scardiinae, the tineid subfamily Nemapogoninae is the only other<tei:lb/>subfamily of Lepidoptera that feeds exclusively on fungi. Nemapogoninae are virtually restricted<tei:lb/>to the Holarctic region whereas Scardiinae are found also in both the Old and New World<tei:lb/>tropics. There is no obvious division of niche between the two groups but there is a considerable<tei:lb/>size difference, most adult Nemapogoninae having a wingspan of less than 18 mm, with the<tei:lb/>larvae being correspondingly smaller than those of Scardiinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>General morphology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The wing patterns of most genera of Scardiinae are cryptic, taking the form of a mottled cream<tei:lb/>and brown pattern resembling moss or tree-bark. Other genera have disruptive patterns: the<tei:lb/>brown fore wing with a pale apex and dorsum. A few genera have a bronze or golden forewing<tei:lb/>ground-colour blotched with dark brown. The Morophaga bucephala-group is quite atypical in<tei:lb/>having a conspicuously white forewing ground-colour with bold purple-brown markings. In<tei:lb/>Amorophaga the cryptic wing-pattern is corrupted by being drawn into longitudinal streaks.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The scardiine head carries the erect scales on frons and vertex typical of most tineid groups.<tei:lb/>The maxillary palpus is 5-segmented, elongate and folded in most species. The labial palpus is<tei:lb/>cylindrical, the second segment with only lateral bristles rather than lateral and terminal bristles<tei:lb/>as in, for example, the Tineinae. The antennal pecten may be very large with up to about 40<tei:lb/>strong, bristle-like scales.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Most species are broad-winged and have all veins present. However, some have narrow<tei:lb/>fore wings and in these one or two pairs of veins are stalked. The narrowing of the forewing is<tei:lb/>most extreme in Diataga, in which two pairs of veins are stalked. Externally, however, the<tei:lb/>morphology of adult Scardiinae is conservative and, with the exception of the enlarged antennal<tei:lb/>pecten (not found in all scardiinae genera but not known from any other tineid), no adult<tei:lb/>character or combination of characters can be used to define the group. It is the larva that<tei:lb/>provides the single defining character of the Scardiinae (see below).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>History of classification of the Scardiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although Eyer (1924) is the first recorded user of the family-group name Scardiinae, the<tei:lb/>association of typical scardiine taxa was well-established by earlier authors (e.g., for the New<tei:lb/>World, by Dietz, 1905, and Walsingham, 1914). No significant usage of the family-group name<tei:lb/>occurred again, however, until Hinton (1955; 1956) emphasized the characteristic for defining<tei:lb/>Scardia (i.e., Scardia s.l: Morophaga + Scardia + Morophagoides) and its allies as a discrete<tei:lb/>group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The larvae of Scardiinae differ from those of all other Tineoidea in that the prothorax bears<tei:lb/>only two L-group setae. All other known tineid larvae have three L-group setae. The generality<tei:lb/>of this important character within the Scardiinae is, however, uncertain as larvae of only<tei:lb/>Morophaga, Diataga, Scardia, Daviscardia and Morophagoides are known. The characteristic<tei:lb/>larval setation was first noted by Gerasimov (1937) in Scardia. Fracker (1915) had earlier figured<tei:lb/>the larva of Scardia anatomella but with three prothoracic L-group setae. However, this was</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 39</tei:p>
         <tei:p>probably an error as later workers (Kuznetzov, 1941; Hinton, 1956) found only two. Kuznetzov<tei:lb/>(1941), finding a fossil larva with only two L-group setae, searched for this character among<tei:lb/>other Tineidae and confirmed it in Morophaga choragella (as boleti), Scardia boletella, S.<tei:lb/>anatomella and Daviscardia coloradella. Strangely, his mention en passant of coloradella is the<tei:lb/>only reference to the setal pattern of this species and confirms the bisetose prothoracic L-group<tei:lb/>in Daviscardia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amsel (1952) figured the genitalia of the few European species of Scardiinae. Petersen (1957)<tei:lb/>placed together all those Palaearctic species of Scardiinae then recognized and described the<tei:lb/>genitalia. He later (Petersen, 1959; 1960) described two new species and revised those known to<tei:lb/>him.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Zagulajev (1965; 1966; 1968) described a number of new species from the Caucasus and from<tei:lb/>the easternmost provinces of the U.S.S.R. and later (Zagulajev, 1973) combined and expanded<tei:lb/>his earlier work into a full-scale monograph of the Palaearctic Scardiinae . This work remains the<tei:lb/>primary reference to the group in this area and no attempt is made here to duplicate its content.<tei:lb/>Gozmany &amp; Vari (1973), in their monograph of the Afrotropical Tineidae, also recognized the<tei:lb/>subfamily as discrete and revised the Afrotropical species. Their concept of the Scardiinae was,<tei:lb/>however, broader than that of other authors. They included Afrocelestis , Ateliotum and<tei:lb/>Pelecystola, genera placed by other authors as Meessiinae (Afrocelestis) and Myrmecozelinae<tei:lb/>(Ateliotum and Pelecystola), placements that I endorse. They also erected a further subfamily,<tei:lb/>the Tinissinae. Three years later I revised this diverse group of predominantly south-east Asian<tei:lb/>species (Robinson, I916a) and later proposed a phytogeny for the group, drawing attention to its<tei:lb/>morphological similarities to the Scardiinae and suggesting that the Scardiinae might be<tei:lb/>paraphyletic with respect to the Tinissinae (Robinson, 1981). This suggestion is supported in the<tei:lb/>present work and the Tinissinae are synonymized with the Scardiinae below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Davis (1983) has provided an up-to-date list of the North American Scardiinae, including new<tei:lb/>synonymy: work in progress includes redescription of the North American Scardiinae (Davis,<tei:lb/>pers. comm.).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The action of Capue (1971) in erecting the tribe Semeolonchini for the single genus<tei:lb/>Semeoloncha is based on no more than Gozmany's original description of the genus (Gozmany,<tei:lb/>1968); no characteristics are offered to define the tribe and it is not placed in any higher<tei:lb/>taxonomic category.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fossil 'Scardiinae'</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Kuznetzov (1941), in his revision of the Lepidoptera of Baltic amber (~40 million years BP),<tei:lb/>described four genera (Scardiites, Proscardiites, Palaeoscardiites and Glessoscardia) and allied<tei:lb/>them with Scardia (and thus with the Scardiinae). Zagulajev (1966; 1973) agreed with Kuznet-<tei:lb/>zov's placement. The first three genera were described from single adults, the last from a larva.<tei:lb/>The possibility that Scardiites is a monotrysian is suggested by a row of postfrenular bristles in<tei:lb/>Kuznetzov's illustration, the shape of the apex of the abdomen of Proscardiites suggests the<tei:lb/>possibility of its being a yponomeutoid (although the length of the maxillary palpi suggests<tei:lb/>otherwise), and the outline of the valva of Palaeoscardiites as figured by Kuznetzov is<tei:lb/>reminiscent of Compsoctena (Eriocottidae). There are no characters figured or cited by<tei:lb/>Kuznetzov to suggest affinity of Scardiites, Proscardiites or Palaeoscardiites to the Scardiinae.<tei:lb/>However, the larva, Glessoscardia, could well be a Scardiinae although from its size (only 9 mm<tei:lb/>long) it is unlikely to be mature. Kuznetzov noted that it had only two prothoracic L-group<tei:lb/>('prestigmatal') setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>General biology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A summary of the biologies of the Palaearctic Scardiinae (including novel information on some<tei:lb/>species, and figures of the larva and pupa of Scardia boletella) has been given by Zagulajev<tei:lb/>(1973). Powell ([1968]) and Lawrence &amp; Powell (1969) bred Lepidoptera from a variety of dead<tei:lb/>wood and fungus samples in California. This rearing programme yielded a large number of new<tei:lb/>host records for North American Scardiinae. Much earlier, Walsingham (1882) described his</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>40 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>experiences rearing Scardia anatomella in Oregon. Hinton (1956) has noted the few detailed<tei:lb/>descriptions of the biology of European species. Petersen (1969) has summarized records of the<tei:lb/>biology of Morophaga choragella (as boleti}. More recently, Moriuti (1976) has described the<tei:lb/>life history of Morophagoides moriutii (as ussuriensis) and figured the larva and pupa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scardiinae are only rarely encountered in collections made at light (Robinson, 1981 - Tinissd).<tei:lb/>Sixteen nights' collecting at light in Brunei in 1982, for example, yielded 260 Tineidae of about<tei:lb/>60 species: only six species and eight individuals were Scardiinae and all but one of those were<tei:lb/>Tinissa (Robinson, 1984). Species of Scardiinae of which large numbers are available have<tei:lb/>almost invariably been bred. Zagulajev (1973) has collected numbers of Morophagoides<tei:lb/>iranensis swarming at dusk near fungus-riddled trees and Fletcher (1933) collected Morophaga<tei:lb/>cremnarcha (q.v.) under similar circumstances. Other specimens have been collected at rest by<tei:lb/>day close to a putative food-substrate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scope and aims of the present study</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The present study is intended to complement existing studies of the Palaearctic Scardiinae,<tei:lb/>notably that of Zagulajev (1973), by integrating the comparatively unstudied species and genera<tei:lb/>of the Old World tropics and of the New World with the Palaearctic taxa. In so doing, it has been<tei:lb/>necessary to revise substantially the existing classification of the Scardiinae and, to some extent,<tei:lb/>to adapt the restricted definition of the sub-family to accommodate the morphological differ-<tei:lb/>ences of the extra-Palaearctic taxa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The bibliography provided is limited in that references providing only minimal information<tei:lb/>(such as mention in checklists, or parochial distribution records of common European species)<tei:lb/>have been omitted. Zagulajev (1973) has collected together many references to European<tei:lb/>species and others are given by Petersen (see bibliography): they are not reiterated here.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This review is based primarily upon the collections of the British Museum (Natural History)<tei:lb/>but most specimens in the National Museum of Natural History, Washington, the University of<tei:lb/>California, Berkeley, and the Zoological Institute of the Academy of Sciences, Leningrad, have<tei:lb/>also been studied. Material in other institutions was requested selectively. Specimens in<tei:lb/>Leningrad and California and some of those in Washington were examined early on in the<tei:lb/>project and, at that time, not all the characters finally adopted for use in classification had been<tei:lb/>recognized. Where observations are deficient, this is stated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Attempts to resolve a phylogeny for the Scardiinae have highlighted the problems caused by<tei:lb/>the high degree of homoplasy encountered. Gauld &amp; Mound (1982) have drawn attention to this<tei:lb/>as a feature of several other insect groups and emphasized the difficulty in providing an<tei:lb/>acceptable generic classification in these circumstances.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The data set obtained in the course of this study has been used in the exploration of techniques<tei:lb/>for numerical classification by phenetic and cladistic methods using a microcomputer.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Terminology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The external and genital morphology of the Scardiinae is unexceptional and the terminology<tei:lb/>used here follows that of Common (1970) and Klots (1956). Further discussion of certain of the<tei:lb/>features examined is given under 'Characters used in classification'. In the male genitalia the<tei:lb/>uncus is composed of a pair of soft lobes: these may be more or less strongly sclerotized, may be<tei:lb/>fused with each other and/or with the tegumen, or may be widely separated. In my previous<tei:lb/>paper (Robinson, 1981) I adopted Kuznetzov &amp; Stekolnikov's (1976; 1977) term 'tegumen<tei:lb/>lobes' for these, but their clear differentiation from the tegumen in all taxa examined, and their<tei:lb/>evident homology with the uncus of, for example, the Tineinae, make this term inappropriate<tei:lb/>and I here revert to my earlier (19760) usage of 'uncus lobes'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Techniques</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pinned adult specimens were examined at magnifications of x 6 to x 50 in artificial light using a</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>41</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wild M5 microscope. Venation, if not visible in oblique light, was examined by transmitted light<tei:lb/>after the wing had been wetted with toluene.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Size measurements given were made with a ruler and are those of a specimen set in<tei:lb/>conventional fashion; other comparative measurements were made using an eyepiece graticule<tei:lb/>on a Wild M5 microscope.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The variety of male genital types in the Scardiinae required the utilization of a variety of<tei:lb/>techniques to display the characters adequately. General methods for the preparation of<tei:lb/>genitalia slides have been described by Clarke (1941) and Robinson (1976b). For certain<tei:lb/>Scardiinae it was necessary to employ the technique of cutting the vinculum laterally and<tei:lb/>unrolling the genital armature as described previously for Tinissa (Robinson, 1976a). In other<tei:lb/>groups the internal surface of the uncus lobes and valvae could be displayed simply by folding the<tei:lb/>valvae ventrad and forward and splaying them slightly. In other groups it was necessary to<tei:lb/>dissect away one valva and mount it separately. Chlorazol Black E (Azo Black) was employed as<tei:lb/>a stain for preparations made early on in this study but this was superseded by Mercurochrome. I<tei:lb/>now prefer the latter stain as it is more controllable and consistent. Although not applicable to<tei:lb/>this study, it also offers better photomicrographic results.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Preparations were examined and drawn using a Wild M5 stereoscopic microscope with<tei:lb/>camera lucida drawing attachment. More detailed examination was carried out with a Leitz<tei:lb/>Ortholux microscope using phase-contrast and magnifications to x600. Phase-contrast was<tei:lb/>particularly useful in identifying microtrichia lining the vesica or the ductus bursae, in identify-<tei:lb/>ing the sensilla on the eighth tergite of females, and in locating and counting the setae on the<tei:lb/>abdominal sternites.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Numerical analysis was carried out using a Commodore 64 microcomputer. Programs written<tei:lb/>by the author are in CBM BASIC; copies are available on request.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>When a draft of this paper was completed, David Swofford's computer program 'PAUP'<tei:lb/>(Phylogenetic Analysis Using Parsimony - Illinois Natural History Survey) became available,<tei:lb/>running on the Rutherford Laboratory's IBM Multiprocessor. This program was used with<tei:lb/>multiple parsimony and global branch-swapping options.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>SEMEOLONCHA Gozmany, 1968<tei:lb/>penicillata Gozmany , 1968</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Meessiinae) comb. n.<tei:lb/>Scardia saccharata Meyrick, 1914: 205. Transferred to Narycia Stephens s.l. (Psychidae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>comb. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Classification and characters - but phylogeny?</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Objectives</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The object of this section is to derive a phylogenetic classification of the Scardiinae. Alternatives<tei:lb/>to the now widely-used 'Hennigian' phylogenetic classifications are those derived by phenetic<tei:lb/>methods. Arguments for and against different procedures of classification are rife and the reader<tei:lb/>is referred to the plethora of recent textbooks and papers on the subject for further enlighten-<tei:lb/>ment.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It was obvious by inspection that considerable homoplasy occurred within the Scardiinae and<tei:lb/>within the data matrix compiled for this exercise (Table 1). No 'hand-made' phylogeny could be<tei:lb/>derived. Techniques for measuring the degree of homoplasy and assessing character 'robust-<tei:lb/>ness' were therefore used to pinpoint 'reliable' characters and to clean up the data matrix by<tei:lb/>removing characters that exhibited high levels of homoplasy. Both phenetic and cladistic<tei:lb/>methods were employed, to gain familiarity with and to evaluate the techniques, and to contrast<tei:lb/>the results and assess the degree of consensus between them.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Methods</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Character compatibility and homoplasy</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The more characters in a matrix of character-scores that are mutually compatible, the more<tei:lb/>easily may a minimum-length rooted or unrooted tree be resolved. By current convention the<tei:lb/>minimum-length rooted tree is adopted as the hypothesis of phylogeny of a group. The most<tei:lb/>parsimonious tree (that with fewest steps) will be shorter and have a greater probability of being<tei:lb/>unique the greater the degree of character compatibility within the matrix.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Le Quesne (1969; 1972; 1979) has shown the incompatibility of a pair of binary-state<tei:lb/>characters to involve the presence of all four possible combinations of character-states. This test<tei:lb/>for incompatibility has become known colloquially as Le Quesne's test. Character incompatibil-</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>44 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 1 Character matrix for Scardiinae: 26 OTUs and 54 characters.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DATA MATRIX<tei:lb/>TAXON 1<tei:lb/>TAXON 2<tei:lb/>TAXON 3<tei:lb/>TAXON<tei:lb/>TAXON<tei:lb/>TAXON<tei:lb/>TAXON<tei:lb/>TAXON<tei:lb/>TAXON<tei:lb/>TAXON 10<tei:lb/>TAXON 11<tei:lb/>TAXON 12<tei:lb/>TAXON 13<tei:lb/>TAXON 14<tei:lb/>TAXON 15<tei:lb/>TAXON U<tei:lb/>TAXON 17<tei:lb/>TAXON IS<tei:lb/>TAXON 19<tei:lb/>TAXON 20<tei:lb/>TAXON 21<tei:lb/>TAXON 22<tei:lb/>TAXON 23<tei:lb/>TAXON 24<tei:lb/>TAXON 25<tei:lb/>TAXON 26</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 1 1 10000010000000001 10000010000000000001 101 1 1 100000000 APOMORPHIES: 14</tei:p>

         <tei:p>1111 00000 1 000000000 1101 000 1 1 000000 110101 00 11001 1000000 APQMORPH I ES : 1 8</tei:p>
         <tei:p>111100000100001000111010000000000000000000000000000000 APOMORPHIES: 10</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 1 110000 1 1 000 1 0000 1110 10000 1 1 000000000 10011011 1001000 APOMORPHIES: 20</tei:p>
