      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 67</tei:p>
         <tei:p>brown scales close to eyes. Labial palpus cream, dark brown on outer surface of first and second segment.<tei:lb/>Maxillary palpus mixed cream and dark brown, 5-segmented, reaching a little more than one-half length of<tei:lb/>second segment of labial palpus. Antennal scape, pedicel and basal flagellar segments dark brown above;<tei:lb/>cilia 1-0 x (cf)orO-4 x ($) flagellar diameter. Thorax cream flecked with light brown ;tegula dark brown,<tei:lb/>cream at apex only. Forewing cream, scattered orange-brown scales along veins, strongly marked with<tei:lb/>dark brown to form a coarse, cryptic pattern resembling tree-bark. Hindwing light greyiwh cream with<tei:lb/>slightly darker greyish flecks. Legs cream; fore- and mid-legs strongly marked above with dark brown but<tei:lb/>pale at articulations; outer surface of mid-tibia with distinctive transverse pale streaks; outer mid-tibial and<tei:lb/>outer proximal hind tibial spurs 0-7 length of inner spurs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Petersen 1960: fig. 1; Zagulajev, 1968: fig. 4; Zagulajev, 1973: figs 15D, 94). Saccus almost<tei:lb/>an equilateral triangle; uncus lobes large, divergent, elongately triangular, hooked at the apices.<tei:lb/>Subscaphium not developed. Juxta, if present, fused with valvae and not recognizable as such; transtilla<tei:lb/>not developed. Valva triangular, with large conical dorsocaudally-directed medial process; smaller blunt<tei:lb/>process from internal surface of valva close to base of ventral margin. Aedeagus about 10 x as long as<tei:lb/>broad in middle, with blunt subapical carina; vesica without cornuti (but large microtrichia possibly<tei:lb/>present).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Zagulajev, 1968: fig. 5; Zagulajev, 1973: figs 95, 96). Eighth tergite as long as eighth sternite,<tei:lb/>with three or four pairs of strong apical setae; eighth sternite forming pair of stout, setose, caudally-<tei:lb/>directed lobes lateral and dorsal to ostium; ventral margin of ostium slightly concave, protruded deeply<tei:lb/>ventrad. Antrum thick-walled, longitudinally constricted dorsoventrally, lined with microtrichia, twice<tei:lb/>length of eighth sternite. Ductus bursae thin- walled, finely microtrichiate, extending well beyond apices of<tei:lb/>apophyses anteriores. Corpus bursae ovate, with pair of small signa, each a flattened cone invaginated into<tei:lb/>wall of corpus bursae; bursa copulatrix overall more than twice length of apophyses anteriores.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Iran; U.S.S.R. (Caucasus).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY Zagulajev (1973) has bred this species from a variety of polypores (Fames, Ganoderma,<tei:lb/>Polyporus, Coriolus) on Quercus, Zelcova and Parrotia in the Caucasus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 108 ex., 10 pupae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>U.S.S.R.: 1 cf, Adzharia, 15.vi.1969 (Zagulajev); 1 $, Georgia, 19.viii.1972 (Zagulajev) (BMNH).<tei:lb/>'Central Europe': 1 cf (BMNH). Also a further 105 ex., 10 pupae (ZI) (see Zagulajev, 1973).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The specimen from 'Central Europe' bears the registration number [18J76-75: this refers to an<tei:lb/>identified synoptic collection of 2500 European Microlepidoptera purchased from Staudinger. This<tei:lb/>specimen, with the reference number 687, was bought as an example of 'Scardia boleti' (i.e., Morophaga<tei:lb/>choragelld) (BMNH Accession Register). It must be assumed that its locality label is as incorrect as its<tei:lb/>identification.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The three Old World Morophagoides species are allopatric and iranensis is the only Morophagoides to<tei:lb/>occur in the western Palearctic region. It differs from ussuriensis and moriutii in lacking any dark scaling on<tei:lb/>the third segment of the labial palpus but apart from this difference the three species are externally quite<tei:lb/>similar. The male genitalia of iranensis are distinguished by the divergent uncus lobes with hooked apices,<tei:lb/>and by the process from the valva being broadly conical: in the other two species the uncus lobes each bear a<tei:lb/>ventrally-directed nodular process, and the process from the valva is slender. The female genitalia of<tei:lb/>iranensis lack the conspicuous ventral triangular pocket that forms the ventral margin of the ostium in<tei:lb/>ussuriensis and moriutii; instead, the form of the antrum is conventional.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A tentative phylogeny for Morophagoides cannot be resolved because of the lack of material of most<tei:lb/>species. However, the Old World and New World species may form separate monophyletic groups (the<tei:lb/>New World species have a conspicuously modified juxta; the juxta is either lost or entirely fused with the<tei:lb/>valva in species from the Old World; species from the Old World have short antennal cilia; the cilia are long<tei:lb/>in species from the New World). Within these groups three sister-group pairings are apparent: moriutii +<tei:lb/>ussuriensis (synapomorphies: uncus lobes with nodular processes, ventral margin of ostium infolded to<tei:lb/>form a triangular pocket), burkerella + berkeleyella (see 'Remarks' for burkerella) and pythium +<tei:lb/>nimbiferum (see 'Remarks' for pythium).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morophagoides ussuriensis (Caradja)<tei:lb/>(Figs 10, 80)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scardia ussuriensis Caradja, 1920: 167. Lectotype cf , U.S.S.R. (MINGA), designated by Petersen (1957:<tei:lb/>593) [not examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>68 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Zagulajev, 1973: fig. 89; Fig. 10). cf , 15-19 mm; &lt;J&gt;, 17-23 mm. Coloration and external structure<tei:lb/>similar to iranensis but maxillary palpus light greyish cream, outer surface of third segment of labial palpus<tei:lb/>with a few brown scales.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Petersen, 1957: fig. 246; Zagulajev, 1973: figs 14b, 15G, 90; Fig. 80). Saccus triangular;<tei:lb/>uncus lobes broad, appressed to tegumen for only medial third of their width; lateral margin produced<tei:lb/>ventrad to form a strongly sclerotized knuckle-shaped process. Subscaphium indicated only by slight<tei:lb/>thickening of diaphragma close to base of valval apodemes. Juxta, if present, fused with valvae and not<tei:lb/>recognizable as such; transtilla not developed. Valva triangular, apex consisting of two overlapping lobes,<tei:lb/>inner lobe extended mesad to form an elongately triangular process with a sinuate apex, outer lobe forming<tei:lb/>a blunt process close to ventral margin of valva. Aedeagus about 14 x as long as broad in middle, with<tei:lb/>digitiform subapical carina; vesica with patch of large spicular microtrichia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Petersen, 1957: fig. 247; Zagulajev, 1973: figs 17G, 18b, 91, 92). Eighth tergite slightly<tei:lb/>longer than eighth sternite , with three or four pairs of strong subapical setae ; eighth sternite forming pair of<tei:lb/>slender, setose, caudally-directed lobes dorsal to ostium; ventral margin of ostium transverse, protruding<tei:lb/>strongly ventrad. Antrum with conspicuous and strongly sclerotized triangular pocket in ventral wall,<tei:lb/>antrum itself behind the pocket, elongate, longitudinally constricted dorsoventrally, lined with microt-<tei:lb/>richia, about 2-5 x length of eighth sternite. Ductus bursae thin-walled, microtrichia at posterior end<tei:lb/>around inception of ductus seminalis at junction with antrum. Corpus bursae ovate, with pair of small<tei:lb/>pouch-shaped signa invaginated into wall of corpus bursae (Zagulajev figures (1973: fig. 92b) a pair of<tei:lb/>additional minute conical signa situated further posteriorly - 1 believe this to be an individual variation);<tei:lb/>bursa copulatrix overall more than twice length of apophyses anteriores.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. U.S.S.R. (Amur, Chabarovsk, Maritime Territories).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. Zagulajev (1973) associates this species with several genera of trees but no identifications of the<tei:lb/>host fungus have been made. Moriuti's detailed description (1976) of the life history of 'ussuriensis' from<tei:lb/>Japan refers to moriutli (see below).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 26 ex. , 2 pupae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>U.S.S.R.: 1 cf, Vladivostok, 21. vii. 1876 or 19. vii. 1877 (C/iristop/i) (genitalia slide no. 12356; BMNH); 1<tei:lb/>ex. (head, thorax and fore wings only), same data; 1 cf , Amur, Raddefka, 3.viii.l876 (Chris toph) (genitalia<tei:lb/>slide no. 12357; BMNH); 1 $, Ussuri Railway, Chabarovsk, 14.vii.1910 (Borsow) (BMNH). Also a<tei:lb/>further 22 ex., 2 pupae (ZI) (see Zagulajev, 1973).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Externally similar to iranensis and moriutii, ussuriensis has a restricted distribution on the<tei:lb/>easternmost mainland of the U.S.S.R. It is characterized by the conspicuous knuckle-shaped processes of<tei:lb/>the uncus lobes in the male genitalia. With moriutii it shares a conspicuous and diagnostic feature in the<tei:lb/>female genitalia - a conical ventral pouch, triangular in dorso-ventral view, which runs anteriorly from the<tei:lb/>ventral (posterior) margin of the ostium: the antrum proper has its posterior inception in the dorsal wall of<tei:lb/>this pouch although the pouch should be considered a part of the antrum too. Females of moriutii have a<tei:lb/>much more deeply concave ventral ostial margin than those of ussuriensis, and the medial region of the<tei:lb/>antrum is broader. However, the latter difference is subject to considerable intraspecific variation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morophagoides moriutii sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 11, 81, 82, 141)<tei:lb/>[Morophagoides ussuriensis (Caradja); Moriuti, 1976: 86; Moriuti, 1982: 164. Misidentifications.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Moriuti, 1976: figs 1, 2; Moriuti, 1982: pi. 2, fig. 17, pi. 236, fig. 3; Fig. 11). cf, 16-17 mm; $, 19-24<tei:lb/>mm (Taiwanese specimens - cf, 24 mm; $, 24, 29 mm). Coloration and external structure similar to<tei:lb/>iranensis but, like ussuriensis, maxillary palpus light greyish cream, outer surface of third segment of labial<tei:lb/>palpus strongly marked with brown in basal half.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Moriuti, 1976: fig. 3; Moriuti, 1982: pi. 248, fig. 9; Figs 81, 82). Saccus triangular, slightly<tei:lb/>tapered; uncus lobes divergent, somewhat square, outer corners with ventrally-directed blunt process.<tei:lb/>Subscaphium poorly developed, represented by slight thickening of diaphragma. Juxta, if present, fused<tei:lb/>with valva and not recognizable as such; transtilla not developed. Valva with lobed deep apex and with<tei:lb/>elongate mesally-directed triangular process on internal surface. Aedeagus 15 x as long as broad in middle<tei:lb/>(stouter, only 10 x in Taiwanese examples), with digitiform subapical carina; vesica with patch of large<tei:lb/>spicular microtrichia.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 69</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Moriuti, 1976: figs 4, 5; Fig. 141). Eighth tergite as long as eighth sternite, with three pairs of<tei:lb/>stout apical setae and about 8 pairs of scattered smaller setae; eighth sternite forming pair of small setose<tei:lb/>caudally-directed lobes dorsal to ostium; ventral margin of ostium concave, protruded strongly ventrad.<tei:lb/>Antrum with triangular and strongly sclerotized pocket in ventral wall, antrum itself behind the pocket,<tei:lb/>elongate, very thick-walled, longitudinally constricted dorso-ventrally, lined with strongly sclerotized and<tei:lb/>conspicuous nodular microtrichia, about 2-5 x length of eighth sternite. Ductus bursae lined with spicular<tei:lb/>microtrichia for almost entire length from inception of ductus seminalis anteriorly. Corpus bursae<tei:lb/>elongately ovate , with pair of pouch-shaped signa invaginated into wall ; bursa copulatrix overall more than<tei:lb/>twice length of apophyses posteriores.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Japan; Taiwan.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. Moriuti (1976) has described the biology of this species (as ussuriensis) in some detail and figured<tei:lb/>the larva and pupa. Specimens were reared from the fungus Lentinus edodes and its host timber. Lentinus,<tei:lb/>the shiitake fungus, is a valuable commercial crop used in gourmet cookery.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 9 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Japan: Honsyu, Okayama, Syootyo, ex cultured wood of Lentinus edodes, em. 15. vi. 1968<tei:lb/>(Inoue) (coll. S. Moriuti, Osaka).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Japan: 2 cf, data as holotype (BMNH; coll. S. Moriuti); 1 cf, 1 $, Honsyu, Nara,<tei:lb/>Katuragisan, ex polyporaceous fungus, em. 31. v. 1961 (Saito) (BMNH; coll. S. Moriuti); 1 $, Honsyu,<tei:lb/>Nara, Koozindake, 1200 m, 2-3. viii. 1971 (Moriuti) (coll. S. Moriuti).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Excluded from paratype series. Taiwan (Formosa): 1 Cf, 2 9, Arizan, 7000', 14, 17, 17. ix. 1906<tei:lb/>(Wileman) (genitalia slide nos. 12360, 12361; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Superficially similar to iranensis and ussuriensis, moriutii has a NW. Pacific distribution. The<tei:lb/>genitalia of both sexes are structurally close to those of ussuriensis but in the male the process from each<tei:lb/>uncus lobe is apical and irregular, not subapical and knuckle-shaped as in ussuriensis. In the female the<tei:lb/>ventral lip of the ostium is more strongly concave than in ussuriensis and the internal surface of the antrum<tei:lb/>is more markedly rugose.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The marked difference between the illustration of the uncus lobes of the male by Moriuti (1976: fig. 3)<tei:lb/>and that given here for a Japanese specimen (Fig. 81) is entirely due to the degree of compression of the<tei:lb/>preparation: in Fig. 81 the cover-slip is not in contact with the genital armature. Compression of the<tei:lb/>preparation of a specimen from Taiwan (Fig. 82) splays out the ventral processes of the uncus in similar<tei:lb/>fashion to that shown in Moriuti's illustration.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Specimens from Taiwan are substantially larger than those from Japan; the aedeagus is slightly thicker<tei:lb/>and the processes from the uncus are slightly narrower. However, at present I consider the two groups of<tei:lb/>specimens to be conspecific although I exclude Taiwanese material from paratype status.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morophagoides berkeleyella (Powell)<tei:lb/>(Figs 12, 83)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>'Scardia' berkeleyella Powell, [1968]: 303. Holotype cf , U.S.A. (CAS) [not examined].<tei:lb/>Morophagoides berkeleyella (Powell) Davis, 1983: 5.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 12). cf, 14, 16mm. Vertex and frons whitish, brown close to eyes. Labial palpus purple-brown<tei:lb/>but pale buff at apex and articulations and on inner surface. Maxillary palpus pale buff, 5-segmented,<tei:lb/>extending to about one-half length of second segment of labial palpus, basal three segments flecked above<tei:lb/>with purple-brown. Antennal scape, pedicel and flagellum dark brown, paler beneath; cilia 1-5 x (cf)<tei:lb/>flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula dark brown flecked with paler scales. Forewing pale buff, strongly<tei:lb/>flecked with dark brown to form a speckled cryptic pattern (similar to that of Morophaga morellus in one<tei:lb/>example; in the other much more variegated and similar to that of iulina but more strongly speckled);<tei:lb/>fringe with pale apical spot, otherwise yellow-grey with grey basal band. Hindwing greyish cream with<tei:lb/>slightly darker irregular apical spots. Legs greyish ochreous; fore- and mid-legs dark grey above and on<tei:lb/>sides, articulations conspicuously white; outer mid-tibial spur and outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-7 length<tei:lb/>of inner spurs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Powell, [1968]: fig. 6; Fig. 83). Saccus narrowly triangular, concave laterally, as long as valva<tei:lb/>+ juxta; uncus lobes moderately sclerotized, sparsely setose, fused dorsally and curved ventrad at sides,<tei:lb/>thus semicylindrical; corners produced slightly to form pair of shallow triangular processes. Subscaphium<tei:lb/>narrow, hardly sclerotized, spatulate anteriorly. Juxta partially fused with valvae, bipartite, forming pair of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>70 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>large, blade-shaped caudally-directed processes extending well beyond apices of valvae. Valva short,<tei:lb/>globose, with digitate apical process. Aedeagus slender, 20 x as long as broad, with strong subapical<tei:lb/>corniform carina one-seventh length of aedeagus; vesica with fine spicular cornuti (microtrichia).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA 9 (Powell, [1968]: fig. 7). (From Powell's description and illustration.) Eighth tergite slightly<tei:lb/>longer than eighth sternite; eighth sternite forming pair of stout setose lobes caudal to ostium; ventral<tei:lb/>margin of ostium irregular. Antrum short, elongately funnel-shaped, one-half length of apophyses<tei:lb/>anteriores. Ductus and corpus bursae pyriform, thin-walled, corpus bursae with pair of small pouch-<tei:lb/>shaped signa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. U.S.A. (California).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. Powell ([1968]) reared the type-series of this species from Polyporus gilvus on fallen Quercus<tei:lb/>agrifolia, from dead stems of Lupinus, and from a log of Lithocarpus: these data are reiterated by<tei:lb/>Lawrence &amp; Powell (1969).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 2 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>U.S.A.: 1 cf (paratype), California, 2 m. SE. of Canyon, Contra Costa County, ex Polyporus gilvus on<tei:lb/>fallen Quercus agrifolia, coll. 5.H., emerged 9.iv.l967 (genitalia slide no. 2240 [Powell]; BMNH); 1 cf ,<tei:lb/>California, Burney Mt, 14.viii.1930 (genitalia slide no. 13107; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Most closely related to M. burkerella, berkeleyella is, however, a much smaller species. Powell<tei:lb/>([1968]) suggests that it is less distinctly marked than burkerella but the male from Burney Mt is strongly<tei:lb/>variegated. The male genitalia of the two species differ substantially only in the form of the uncus lobes<tei:lb/>(compare illustrations) which are broader and flatter in burkerella than in berkeleyella. The female<tei:lb/>genitalia differ in that the signa are substantially larger in burkerella than in berkeleyella, the antrum is not<tei:lb/>as tapered and the ventral margin of the ostium is evenly convex. Whereas the caudal lobes of the eighth<tei:lb/>sternite are elongate and terminal in berkeleyella, they are very short and subterminal in burkerella.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morophagoides burkerella (Busck)<tei:lb/>(Figs 13, 84, 140)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scardia burkerella Busck, 1904: 777. Holotype $, U.S.A. (NMNH) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scardia gracilis Walsingham, 1907: 225. Holotype cf , U.S.A. (NMNH) [examined]. [Synonymized by</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Davis (1983: 5).]<tei:lb/>Scardia caryophylella Busck, 1908: 92. Holotype $ , U.S.A. (NMNH) [examined]. [Synonymized by Davis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(1983: 5).]<tei:lb/>Scardia errandella Busck, 1908: 94. Holotype cf , U.S.A. (NMNH) [examined]. [Synonymized by Davis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(1983: 5).]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 13). cf$, 19-28 mm. Vertex and frons cream, brown close to eyes. Labial palpus brown,<tei:lb/>cream at apex and articulations and on inner surface. Maxillary palpus 5-segmented, extending to apex of<tei:lb/>second segment of labial palpus, buff, strongly flecked above with brown. Antennal scape, pedicel and<tei:lb/>basal segments of flagellum dark brown above, flagellum lighter distally; cilia 1-5 x (cf) or 0-3 x ($)<tei:lb/>flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula cream, dark brown in anterior half but mixed with cream on thorax.<tei:lb/>Forewing light yellowish buff, strongly speckled and blotched with dark brown to form a dense, cryptic<tei:lb/>pattern resembling tree-bark, usually with a strongly defined medial band; fringe barred, with well-defined<tei:lb/>grey basal line. Hindwing cream tinted with grey, with irregular terminal grey line; with apical grey spots<tei:lb/>extended into fringe; fringe with grey basal line. Legs pale yellowish buff; foreleg, mid-leg and hind tarsus<tei:lb/>strongly marked above and on sides with dark brown but pale at articulations; outer mid-tibial spur 0-8<tei:lb/>length of inner; outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-7 length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Fig. 84). Similar to those of berkeleyella (q.v.) but uncus lobes broader, flatter, the sides not<tei:lb/>deeply folded ventrad.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Fig. 140). Eighth tergite slightly shorter than eighth sternite, with three pairs of elongate<tei:lb/>setae at caudal margin and a medial pair of sensilla basiconica; eighth sternite almost square but flared<tei:lb/>anteriorly, with narrow medial emargination posteriorly and pair of shallow subterminal setose lobes;<tei:lb/>ostium protuberant, ventral margin slightly convex; lip of antrum with three pairs of strong setae on<tei:lb/>internal surface. Antrum elongate, more than one-half length of apophyses anteriores, very thick-walled,<tei:lb/>with coarsely rugose internal surface. Ductus bursae short, thin-walled, lined with microtrichia, extending<tei:lb/>to apices of apophyses anteriores. Corpus bursae ovoid, thin-walled, with pair of large and strongly<tei:lb/>sclerotized shark's fin-shaped signa.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 71</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. U.S.A.: California (Powell, [1968] - asgracilis) but possibly restricted to the Coast Range<tei:lb/>(Lawrence &amp; Powell, 1969); Utah; Washington State; Pennsylvania (Forbes, 1923). Canada: British<tei:lb/>Columbia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. Recorded by Lawrence &amp; Powell (1969) from a wide range of host Polyporaceae in California<tei:lb/>and recorded by Powell ([1968]) as possibly having two generations per year. Lawrence &amp; "Powell found<tei:lb/>this to be the commonest scardiine that they encountered in breeding from fungi and found it to be 'limited<tei:lb/>primarily to Polyporaceae with relatively large and persistent sporophores, or large colonies with extensive<tei:lb/>sterile tissue in species with small sporophores'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 37 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $ (of burkerella), U.S.A.: Washington, Hoquiam, bred from Tsuga heterophylla (Burke)<tei:lb/>(genitalia slide no. 18654; NMNH). Holotype cf (of gracilis), U.S.A.: California (Beutenmueller)<tei:lb/>(genitalia missing) (NMNH). Holotype $ (of caryophylella), U.S.A.: California, Fieldbrook, 28.V.1903<tei:lb/>(Barber) (abdomen missing) (NMNH). Holotype cf (of errandella), U.S.A.: [Washington State], (Beuten-<tei:lb/>mueller) (abdomen missing) (NMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>U.S.A.: 30 ex., California, various hosts, dates and localities (genitalia slide no. 12400; BMNH; UC,<tei:lb/>Berkeley); 1 cf , 1 $, Utah, Dividend, vii.1926 (BMNH). Canada: 1 cf , British Columbia, Fraser Mills,<tei:lb/>12.vii.1921 (E.H.B.) (genitalia slide no. 12399; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This is the larger and commoner of the two North American Morophagoides species: for<tei:lb/>differentiation from berkeleyella see 'Remarks' for that species. M. burkerella and berkeleyella are<tei:lb/>probably sister-groups, exhibiting close similarity in the male genitalia, notably in the modification of the<tei:lb/>juxta of both species to form a pair of elongate, almost rectangular processes, and in the reduction of the<tei:lb/>valva to a globose shape with a terminal digitate process.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morophagoides montium (Walsingham) comb. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 14, 144)<tei:lb/>Phycis montium Walsingham, 1914: 359. Holotype $, PANAMA (BMNH) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 14). $, 17 mm. Vertex and frons cream, mixed strongly with brown close to eyes. Labial<tei:lb/>palpus brown but cream at apex and articulations and on inner surface except for brown-dusted medial area<tei:lb/>on second segment. Maxillary palpus buff, brown above on basal segments, 5-segmented, extending<tei:lb/>probably no more than two-thirds length of second segment of labial palpus. Antennal scape, pedicel and<tei:lb/>basal flagellar segments dark brown, distal segments paler; cilia 0-3 x flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula<tei:lb/>brown, slightly paler posteriorly. Forewing cream speckled with orange-brown and marked more strongly<tei:lb/>with dark brown to form a complicated cryptic pattern; dorsum generally lacking dark markings and thus<tei:lb/>conspicuously pale; fringe strongly chequered. Hindwing light brownish grey. Legs damaged but foreleg<tei:lb/>and mid-leg dull buff strongly marked above with grey-brown, pale at articulations.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf . Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Fig. 144). Eighth tergite almost circular, as long as eighth sternite, with three pairs- of<tei:lb/>elongate setae and one or two shorter setae at caudal margin, with numerous pits (?sensilla coeloconica)<tei:lb/>scattered close to caudal margin; eighth sternite forming a strongly sclerotized plate ventral to ostium,<tei:lb/>terminating caudally in a pair of lobes; each lobe with a single elongate seta and numerous smaller<tei:lb/>spine-like setae at the tip; eighth sternite hardly sclerotized anteriorly; antrum triangular, short, strongly<tei:lb/>sclerotized; inception of ductus seminalis at apex of antrum. Ductus bursae thin-walled, lined with spicular<tei:lb/>microtrichia (broken and a section missing so length uncertain). Corpus bursae thin-walled, pyriform, with<tei:lb/>a pair of shallow pocket-shaped signa that are rectangular in lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Panama.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Panama: Volcan de Chiriqui, 2000-3000', 1881 (Champion} (genitalia slide no. 15279;<tei:lb/>BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is small, of comparable size to M. nimbiferum, but considerably smaller than<tei:lb/>pythium or iulina. Its wing pattern is not as variegated as that of iulina but not as uniform in the anterior half<tei:lb/>of the wing as in pythium or nimbiferum. The hindwing is darker than that of iulina or pythium. The female<tei:lb/>genitalia are distinctive, characterized by the short antrum and by the lobes ventral to the ostium being</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>72 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>broad, situated far posteriorly, and with only a shallow emargination between them. In pythium the antrum<tei:lb/>is elongate, the ostium set in a deep emargination between the narrow processes of the eighth sternite; in<tei:lb/>nimbiferum the ostium is anterior, the processes arising caudally, and the eighth sternite strongly and<tei:lb/>complexly modified dorsal to the processes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Walsingham's original description oi montium was based on five specimens. One of these was expressly<tei:lb/>cited as 'Type' and two others (in NMNH) cited as paratypes. The remaining two specimens are implicitly<tei:lb/>excluded from type-status. They are, in fact, not conspecific with the holotype and are described below as<tei:lb/>new species -pythium and nimbiferum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morophagoides pythiumsp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 15, 143)<tei:lb/>[Phycis montium Walsingham; Walsingham, 1914: 360. Partim - 1 $ only. Misidentification.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 15). 9 , 24 mm. Vertex and frons cream, brown close to eyes. Labial palpus brown, cream at<tei:lb/>articulations; cream flecked with light brown on inner surface. Maxillary palpus pale buff flecked with<tei:lb/>brown; basal two segments strongly marked above with dark brown; 5-segmented, extending to about<tei:lb/>three-quarters length of second segment of labial palpus. Antennal scape, pedicel and basal flagellar<tei:lb/>segments dark brown above, distal segments lighter; cilia 0-5 x flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula<tei:lb/>brown anteriorly, cream posteriorly. Forewing cream, lightly flecked with orange-brown, strongly marked<tei:lb/>with dark brown to form a cryptic 'moss-pattern' but termen, costa and dorsum less strongly marked and<tei:lb/>thus conspicuously paler; conspicuous small white subtornal spot. Hindwing pale greyish cream. Legs all<tei:lb/>wanting except foreleg - buff beneath, grey-brown above and on sides but pale at articulations.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf . Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA 9 (Fig. 143). Eighth tergite markedly longer than eighth sternite, with three pairs of strong<tei:lb/>subapical setae; eighth sternite short, folded laterally to accommodate bases of apophyses, with pair of<tei:lb/>narrow setose processes either side of ostium, folded anteriorly to ostium to form a shallow pouch. Antrum<tei:lb/>elongate, thick-walled, about one-half length of apophyses anteriores. Ductus bursae lined with micro-<tei:lb/>trichia close to antrum, as long as antrum, thin-walled. Corpus bursae thin-walled, with pair of thin shark's<tei:lb/>fin-shaped signa set in sclerotized base-plates, each base-plate with and surrounded by scattered micro-<tei:lb/>trichia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Costa Rica.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 2 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype 9, Costa Rica: Volcan de Irazu, 6000-7000', 18 (Rogers) (genitalia slide no. 12383;<tei:lb/>BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratype. Costa Rica: 1 9 , Puntarenas Prov. , 6 km S. of San Vito, 2 or 5. v. 1967 (Veiro) (UC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. With nimbiferum and montium, pythium forms a group of dark-patterened Neotropical species<tei:lb/>from which iulina is excluded by dint of its strongly variegated pattern. M. pythium is larger and has paler<tei:lb/>hindwings than montium and nimbiferum. The genitalia are distinctive in that the paired processes of the<tei:lb/>eighth sternite do not overly the ostium as in montium, are not entirely caudal to it as in nimbiferum, but<tei:lb/>form the lateral margins of the ostium and extend caudally. Like nimbiferum, the eighth tergite is<tei:lb/>considerably longer than the eighth sternite but the antrum is distinctly thicker and more elongate. Apart<tei:lb/>from nimbiferum, this is the only Morophagoides species to have microtrichia associated with the signa. M.<tei:lb/>pythium and nimbiferum may be sister-groups (synapomorphies: microtrichia in corpus bursae; eighth<tei:lb/>sternite 'shouldered' to accommodate bases of apophyses anteriores; ostium close to anterior margin of<tei:lb/>eighth sternite).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morophagoides nimbiferum sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 16, 142)<tei:lb/>[Phycis montium Walsingham; Walsingham, 1914: 360. Partim -19 only. Misidentification.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 16). 9&gt; 16 mm. Vertex and frons brownish cream, brown close to eyes. Labial palpus brown<tei:lb/>on outer surface but pale at apex and articulations; inner surface cream, small patch of brownish scales in<tei:lb/>middle of second and middle of third segment. Maxillary palpus light buff, strongly flecked above with</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 73</tei:p>
         <tei:p>brown, 5-segmented, reaching three-quarters length of second segment of labial palpus. Antennal scape<tei:lb/>and pedicel dark brown above, flagellum damaged and mostly lost. Thorax and tegula brown anteriorly,<tei:lb/>light buff posteriorly. Forewing cream, sparsely flecked with orange-brown, strongly marked with dark<tei:lb/>brown; however, termen, dorsum and costal spots conspicuously pale. Hindwing light grey. Legs dull buff,<tei:lb/>fore- and mid-legs dark grey-brown above and on sides but pale at articulations and across mid-tibia; outer<tei:lb/>mid-tibial spur 0-7 length of inner; outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-6 length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA 9 (Fig. 142). Eighth tergite considerably longer than eighth sternite, with three pairs of large<tei:lb/>and two pairs of small marginal setae and about 10 scattered sensilla (basiconica and (?) coeloconica);<tei:lb/>eighth sternite short, strongly folded transversely, with strongly sclerotized 'shoulders' at bases of<tei:lb/>apophyses; medially with three convergent sclerites forming a flexible blunt process overlain by a lobate<tei:lb/>membranous outgrowth of the ovipositor; paired setose processes arising caudally to ostium, strongly<tei:lb/>divergent, each bearing a pair of large setae and numerous smaller setae at apex; ostium close to anterior<tei:lb/>margin of sternite. Antrum short, thick-walled, but hardly sclerotized, less than one-quarter length of<tei:lb/>apophyses anteriores. Ductus bursae half length of apophyses, lined with microtrichia in posterior half.<tei:lb/>Corpus bursae ovoid, with pair of thorn-shaped signa set in sclerotized base-plates, each base-plate with<tei:lb/>and surrounded by scattered microtrichia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Guatemala.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Guatemala: Volcan de Atitlan, 2500-3500', [xii.1880], (Champion) (genitalia slide no.<tei:lb/>12385; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is similar in size and external appearance to montium but the forewing pattern is less<tei:lb/>variegated. The genitalia are distinctive, however; the eighth sternite is strongly folded with elongate<tei:lb/>processes that arise posteriorly, and the ostium is close to the anterior margin, a configuration quite unlike<tei:lb/>that of any other species. Additionally, the signa differ from those of all other Morophagoides in being<tei:lb/>slender and thorn-like rather than laterally compressed and pocket-shaped. Withpythium, nimbiferum is<tei:lb/>the only Morophagoides species to have microtrichia associated with the signa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morophagoides iulina (Walsingham) comb. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 17, 85)<tei:lb/>Phycis iulina Walsingham, 1914: 359. Holotype cf , GUATEMALA (BMNH) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Walsingham, 1914: pi. 10, fig. 17 (colour); Fig. 17). cf , 26 mm. Vertex and frons whitish, light<tei:lb/>brown close to eyes. Labial palpus pale buff speckled strongly with dark brown on first segment and on<tei:lb/>basal two-thirds of second segment. Maxillary palpus whitish, 5-segmented, elongate, extending beyond<tei:lb/>apex of second segment of labial palpus, basal three segments flecked above with dark brown. Antennal<tei:lb/>scape and pedicel buff flecked with dark brown; flagellum pale buff; cilia 2-5 x flagellar diameter. Thorax<tei:lb/>and tegula dark purple-brown with only a few whitish scales posteriorly. Forewing cream mottled with pale<tei:lb/>orange-brown; strong W-shaped dark brown mark occupying most of wing; strong dark brown costal spots;<tei:lb/>terminal spots small but extending through fringe and giving a conspicuously chequered appearance to the<tei:lb/>fringe. Hindwing slightly greyish silk-white. Mid-legs missing; fore-leg strongly marked above with dark<tei:lb/>purple-brown; hind-leg pale buff, tibial spurs damaged.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Fig. 85). Saccus broadly triangular, apex rounded; uncus lobes almost semicircular, strongly<tei:lb/>folded, with conspicuously serrate inner edge. Subscaphium a broad but almost imperceptible thickening<tei:lb/>of the diaphragma. Juxta, if present, represented by a pair of shallow and inconspicuous ventral lobes at<tei:lb/>bases of valvae; transtilla represented by a pair of shallow membranous lobes dorsal to anellus. Valva<tei:lb/>simple, with subapical tuft of inwardly-directed strong spicular setae. Aedeagus about 8 x as long as broad<tei:lb/>at base, lacking carinae; vesica with minute spicular cornuti (microtrichia).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $. Unknown.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. Guatemala.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>74 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf, Guatemala: Totonicapam, 8500-10,500', [viii.1880], (Champion) (genitalia slide no.<tei:lb/>12398; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Among the American Morophagoides species, iulina is distinguished by its pale forewing<tei:lb/>ground-colour with strong W-shaped mark; it is large, of similar size to burkerella, and the female could<tei:lb/>well be the largest of the genus. The male genitalia are distinguished by the serrate uncus lobes and by the<tei:lb/>characteristic modified setae on the valvae. It is the only species of Morophagoides that does not have a<tei:lb/>blunt subapical carina on the aedeagus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The affinities of iulina are obscure . The structure of its genitalia set it well apart from the other American<tei:lb/>species of which the males are known (berkeleyella and burkerella). However, the ventral lobes at the bases<tei:lb/>of the valvae may well be homologous with the enormously developed pair of lobes (assumed to be the<tei:lb/>juxta) in these species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MONTESCARDIA Amsel</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Montescardia Amsel, 1952: 139. Type-species: Euplocamus tessulatellus Zeller, 1846: 178, by original<tei:lb/>designation and monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Antenna (male) with dorsal cilia, ventral surface scaled; cilia shorter than 1-5 x flagellar<tei:lb/>diameter. Scape with more than 15 pecten bristles. Interocular index (male) 1-0 or less. Maxillary palpus<tei:lb/>5-segmented; pilifers present; second segment of labial palpus shorter than width of head. Outer mid and<tei:lb/>proximal hind tibial spurs &gt;0-4 length of inner spurs. Forewing with 7? 3 and R 4 separate; M 2 , M 3 and CuA\<tei:lb/>separate; mottled coloration forming cryptic, coarse 'moss' pattern. Male with coremata in eighth<tei:lb/>abdominal segment; coremata not associated with apodemes. Male genitalia with complex uncus separated<tei:lb/>from tegumen by narrow band of membrane; tegumen broken dorsally by at least a membranous suture<tei:lb/>line; valva lacking basal setose lobe on inner surface; apex of valva not forming ventral hook or hooks,<tei:lb/>without spines; valvae fused ventrally into a single movable complex, valvae without longitudinal cleft;<tei:lb/>saccus wider than long; juxta complex, entire, not divided medially; vesica lacking spicular cornuti;<tei:lb/>aedeagus with spicular or spinose carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. Juxta complex, enveloping aedeagus to form an elaborate, double-layered<tei:lb/>and partially fused intromittent complex; subscaphium broad, triangular; female with eighth tergite<tei:lb/>explanate, forming pair of broad lateral flanges (but not in fuscofasciella).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Holarctic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. See Montescardia tessulatellus (Zeller).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species of Montescardia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Males (male genitalia of fuscofasciella are unknown)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Maxillary palpus elongate, reaching apex of second segment of labial palpus .... fuscofasciella (p. 76)<tei:lb/>Maxillary palpus short, only just reaching base of second segment of labial palpus 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Caudal apex of juxta + aedeagus-complex fused, boat-shaped tessulatellus (p. 74)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caudal apex of juxta + aedeagus-complex bilobed, lobes separated by their own width</tei:p>
         <tei:p>kurenzovi (p. 75)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Females</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Maxillary palpus elongate , reaching apex of second segment of labial palpus ; posterior margin of</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ostium a protuberant ridge; ostium teardrop-shaped (Fig. 146) fuscofasciella (p. 76)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Maxillary palpus short, only just reaching base of second segment of labial palpus; posterior</tei:p>
         <tei:p>margin of ostium not defined, eighth sternite merging into membrane of ovipositor 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Eighth tergite 1 -3 x or more wider than long tessulatellus (p. 74)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eighth tergite roughly as wide as long kurenzovi (p. 75)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Montescardia tessulatellus (Zeller)<tei:lb/>(Fig. 18)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euplocamus tessulatellus Zeller, 1846: 178. LECTOTYPE cf, AUSTRIA (BMNH), here designated<tei:lb/>[examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 75</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 18). C?$, 22-29 mm. Vertex and frons straw-coloured, tufts above eyes darker. Labial palpus<tei:lb/>straw-coloured, strongly flecked with brown on outer surface of second and third segments but pale at<tei:lb/>articulations. Maxillary palpus whitish, very short, only just reaching second segment of labial palpus,<tei:lb/>5-segmented. Antennal scape and pedicel straw-coloured, dark brown above; flagellum grey-brown<tei:lb/>above; cilia 1-0 x (cf) or 0-7 x ($) flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula cream, strongly flecked with<tei:lb/>brown. Forewing cream, marked with orange-brown along veins and strongly flecked with dark brown to<tei:lb/>form ill-defined jagged medial and postmedial bands; medial costal spot strongly defined; strong dark spot<tei:lb/>at end of cell. Hindwing pale grey, mottled at margin and fringe. Legs straw-coloured, fore-, mid- and<tei:lb/>hindlegs strongly marked above and on outer surfaces with dark brown, but pale at articulations; outer<tei:lb/>mid-tibial spur 0-6 length of inner; outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-7 length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Petersen, 1957: fig. 242, pi. 12, figs 1, 2; Zagulajev, 1973: figs 16A, 80, 81). Saccus short,<tei:lb/>triangular; uncus lobes strongly sclerotized, separated from tegumen by relatively broad membranous<tei:lb/>area, setose only apically and laterally, with irregularly serrate caudal margin. Subscaphium triangular.<tei:lb/>Juxta enveloping and partly fused with aedeagus to form an elaborate intromittent complex; transtilla not<tei:lb/>developed. Valvae fused ventrally to form a united complex with a narrowly V-shaped medioventral<tei:lb/>emargination; apices of valvae simple, rounded. Aedeagus fused with juxta to form intromittent complex;<tei:lb/>vesica without cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Petersen, 1957: fig. 243; Zagulajev, 1973: figs 82, 83). Eighth tergite longer than eighth<tei:lb/>sternite, caudal one-quarter membranous, with four pairs of strong and elongate subapical setae posterior<tei:lb/>to irregular margin of sclerotization and with about six scattered pairs of sensilla basiconica; tergite<tei:lb/>explanate anteriorly to form conspicuous pair of quadrate lateral flaps; eighth sternite U-shaped, bases of<tei:lb/>arms of 'U' strongly folded, between arms a broad and deep depression leading to ostium which is overlain<tei:lb/>by a strong semicircular sclerite. Antrum short, longitudinally folded and with very fine transverse<tei:lb/>striations; inception of ductus seminalis at anterior end of antrum. Ductus bursae thick-walled, slightly<tei:lb/>longer than antrum. Corpus bursae large, ovate, extending well beyond apices of apophyses anteriores;<tei:lb/>signa absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Sweden; Norway; Finland (Krogerus et al., 1971); Italy (Petersen &amp; Gaedike, 1979);<tei:lb/>Sardinia (Amsel, 1952); central Europe including East and West Germany; Yugoslavia; Austria; Ruma-<tei:lb/>nia; Hungary; Czechoslovakia; Poland; U.S.S.R. (European Region, Crimea, E. Siberia, Primorsk<tei:lb/>region); Mongolia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. Petersen (1969) has recorded this species from pore-fungi and from dead wood of Picea and<tei:lb/>Fagus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 82 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lectotype C", [Austria]: Semm[e]ring [approx. 80 km. SW. of Vienna], vi (Mann) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Poland: 1 $ (paralectotype), [approx. 15 km W. of Klodzkol] 'Sfd' ['between Reinerz and the<tei:lb/>Seefelder'], 29.vii (Zeller} (BMNH). 80 ex., various localities (see 'Distribution') (BMNH; ZI). (For<tei:lb/>details of ZI holdings see Zagulajev (1973).)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is characteristically patterned and, with its geographical context, should be<tei:lb/>identifiable without recourse to dissection. Unlike all other Palaearctic scardiines with this wing-pattern,<tei:lb/>all veins in the forewing are free and the forewing appears correspondingly broader than in, say,<tei:lb/>Morophaga (but beware of Morophagoides iranensis, worn specimens of which might be mistaken for<tei:lb/>Montescardia). Unlike most other scardiines, the hind tarsus in Montescardia is dark brown above, the<tei:lb/>pattern broken by pale scaling at the articulations. In the female, the eighth tergite is deeply recessed into<tei:lb/>the intersegmental membrane, forming a well-defined dorsal pouch with a strongly microtrichiate dorsal<tei:lb/>internal surface. This species and M. kurenzovi may be separated from the North American fuscofasciella<tei:lb/>by their having very short maxillary palpi: in fuscofasciella the palpi would, if unfolded, reach the apex of<tei:lb/>the second segment of the labial palpus. Separation of tessulatellus and kurenzovi is more problematical:<tei:lb/>the latter taxon is probably no more than a slight geographical variant of tessulatellus from the edge of its<tei:lb/>range. However, further material of kurenzovi is required to clarify its status. It may be tentatively<tei:lb/>separated from tessulatellus using the characters described in the key and below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Montescardia kurenzovi (Zagulajev) comb. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scardia kurenzovi Zagulajev, 1966: 637. Holotype cf, U.S.S.R. (ZI) [examined].<tei:lb/>ADULT. C"$, 21-5-23-5 mm. Coloration and external structure similar to tessulatellus.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>76 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Zagulajev, 1966: fig. 2A; Zagulajev, 1973: figs 15A, 15b, 16B, 84). Similar to those of<tei:lb/>tessulatellus but apex of juxta-aedeagus complex with pair of separated lobes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Zagulajev, 1966: figs 2b, 2B; Zagulajev, 1973: figs 17A, 17b, 19A, 85, 86). Similar to those of<tei:lb/>tessulatellus but eighth tergite not as broadly explanate, outer corners of tergite acute.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. U.S.S.R. (Maritime Territory); Kurile Is (Kunashir) (Zagulajev, 1973).<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 5 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , U.S.S.R.: Maritime Territory, Khasan district, Verkhnyaya Sidimi, 8.vi.l950 (Zagulajev}<tei:lb/>(ZI).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>U.S.S.R.: 1 9 (paratype), data as holotype but nr Vladivostok, 8. i\.l956(Omelko); 1 $ (paratype),data<tei:lb/>as holotype but Suchan, source of the Sitsa River, 28.viii.1928 (Kurentsov} (ZI); 1 $, data as first paratype<tei:lb/>but 24.vii. 1950 (Zagulajev} (ZI); 2 $, Kurile Is., Kunashir, 5-7. vii. 1962 &amp; 6.vii.l964 (Krlvolutskaya} (21-<tei:lb/>only one specimen present when examined by author).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. It is unlikely that this taxon represents a good species (see 'Remarks' for tessulatellus}; the<tei:lb/>differences between it and tessulatellus are subtle in the extreme. The BMNH collection contains a male<tei:lb/>Montescardla from Khabarovsk ('Chabarovsk') on the Amur River. This locality is at the edge of the<tei:lb/>geographical range of kurenzovi as recorded by Zagulajev (1973) and well beyond the eastern limit of<tei:lb/>tessulatellus recorded by the same author. However, this specimen is an entirely typical example of<tei:lb/>tessulatellus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Montescardia fuscofasciella (Chambers) comb. n.<tei:lb/>(Figs 19, 146)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euplocamus (?) fuscofasciella Chambers, 1875: 257. LECTOTYPE $, U.S.A. (MCZ), here designated</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[examined].<tei:lb/>Scardiapravatella Busck, 1908: 94. Holotype cf , U.S.A. (NMNH), here designated [examined]. [Synony-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>mizedbyDavis(1983:5).]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 19). , 27 mm. Vertex and frons pale buff. Labial palpus off-white, strongly flecked with<tei:lb/>brown on outer surface. Maxillary palpus cream, flecked with brown above on basal segments, elongate,<tei:lb/>5-segmented, reaching apex of second segment of labial palpus. Antennal scape, pedicel and basal flagellar<tei:lb/>segments dark brown above; flagellum medium brown; cilia 0-6 x () flagellar diameter. Thorax and<tei:lb/>tegula speckled brown and cream. Forewing brownish cream, ill-definedly orange-brown along veins,<tei:lb/>strongly speckled with dark brown to form strong solid blotches and a well-defined medial transverse<tei:lb/>fascia. Hindwing light grey-brown, ill-defined paler mottling at apex. Legs greyish buff, fore- and mid-legs<tei:lb/>strongly marked above with dark brown but pale at articulations; hind tarsus also dark brown above but<tei:lb/>articulations pale; outer mid-tibial spur 0-4 length of inner; outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-5 length of<tei:lb/>inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf . Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Fig. 146). Eighth tergite markedly longer than eighth sternite, with three or four pairs of<tei:lb/>strong subapical setae; eighth sternite moulded round large pyriform ostium, apex emarginate, laterocaud-<tei:lb/>al lobes each with pair of strong setae . Antrum very short , dorsal wall rugose ; inception of ductus seminalis<tei:lb/>almost at level of ventral margin of ostium. Ductus bursae broad, with lepidote (?microtrichiate) inner<tei:lb/>surface, merging with elongately ovate corpus bursae. Corpus bursae thin- walled, extending slightly<tei:lb/>anteriorly beyond apophyses anteriores; signa absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. U.S.A. (Kentucky (?), Pennsylvania, North Carolina, Texas (?)).<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 3 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lectotype $ (of fuscofasciella}, U.S.A.: 'Kentucky' [but more probably Texas - see 'Remarks']<tei:lb/>(Chambers} (genitalia slide no. 2563 [Davis]; MCZ). Holotype cf (of pravatella} (abdomen missing),<tei:lb/>U.S.A.: Pennsylvania, New Brighton, 23.viii.1902 (Merrick) (NMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>U.S.A.: 1 ex. (abdomen missing), North Carolina, 1884 (Morrison) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Distinguished from its congeners by its elongate maxillary palpus, fuscofasciella is a distinctly<tei:lb/>dark, speckly species somewhat reminiscent of Morophaga morellus. Apart from Morophagoides bur-</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 77</tei:p>
         <tei:p>kerella it is the only North American scardiine of this size and wing-pattern. In burkerella the thorax and<tei:lb/>the apices of the tegulae are cream , not with mixed brown and cream scales , and the hindwing is pale cream<tei:lb/>with a slight greyish tint, considerably paler than the light grey-brown hindwing oi fuscofasciella.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The female genitalia are very different from those oftessulatellus; the eighth tergite is not explanate, the<tei:lb/>inner surface of the ductus bursae is lepidote, and the shape of the eighth sternite is markedly different. The<tei:lb/>structure of the male genitalia, presently unknown, may prove fuscofasciella not to be a Montescardia. Its<tei:lb/>present placement should be considered provisional.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Chambers (1875: 258) refers to 'the foregoing descriptions of "Teneina [sic] from Texas" . . . the<tei:lb/>conclusion of a series' . The block of descriptions of Texan material appears to begin on p . 250 with Gelechia<tei:lb/>saphirinella and to include fuscofasciella. Although the lectotype is labelled 'Kentucky', the label is not by<tei:lb/>Chambers and may be erroneous. The type-locality must remain in question as the distribution of this<tei:lb/>species is hardly known.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B YTHOCRA TES Meyrick</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bythocrates Meyrick, 1919: 268. Type-species: Bythocrates drosocycla Meyrick, 1919: 268, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Antenna (male) with dorsal cilia, ventral surface scaled; cilia shorter than 1-5 x flagellar<tei:lb/>diameter. Scape with fewer than 15 pecten bristles. Interocular index (male) 1-0 or less. Maxillary palpus<tei:lb/>with fewer than 5 segments; pilifers present; second segment of labial palpus shorter than width of head.<tei:lb/>Outer mid and proximal hind tibial spurs &gt;0-4 length of inner spurs. Forewing with R 3 and R 4 separate ; M 3<tei:lb/>and CuAi stalked or very closely approximated at base; mottled coloration forming cryptic, coarse 'moss'<tei:lb/>pattern. Male lacking coremata in eighth abdominal segment. Male genitalia with simple uncus- a pair of<tei:lb/>setose lobes - separated from tegumen by narrow band of membrane; tegumen unbroken, completely<tei:lb/>sclerotized dorsally; valva lacking basal setose lobe on inner surface; apex of valva not forming ventral<tei:lb/>hook or hooks, without spines; valvae fused ventrally into a single movable complex, valvae without<tei:lb/>longitudinal cleft; saccus wider than long; juxta simple, entire, not divided medially; vesica with spicular<tei:lb/>cornuti; aedeagus smooth-surfaced, without spicular carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. Valvae entirely fused ventrally, with no trace of a suture line (line effusion<tei:lb/>also difficult to discern in some species of Daviscardia); corpus bursae of female with four strongly<tei:lb/>sclerotized, pocket-shaped (or wedge-shaped) signa; ductus bursae with oblique regular constrictions;<tei:lb/>female eighth tergite entirely divided medially.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Neotropical region - Guyana, Trinidad.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Has been bred from Poly poms in Trinidad (label data).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bythocrates drosocycla Meyrick</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 20, 145)<tei:lb/>Bythocrates drosocycla Meyrick, 1919: 268. Holotype cf , GUYANA (BMNH) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Clarke, 1970: pi. 16, figs 1, Ib; Fig. 20). cf , 11 mm; $, 14 mm. Vertex and frons dull buff. Labial<tei:lb/>palpus dark brown but pale buff on inner surface of second segment. Maxillary palpus buff-cream, a few<tei:lb/>dark brown scales above close to base, short, 4-segmented, extending only to basal one-fifth of second<tei:lb/>segment of labial palpus. Antennal scape and pedicel dull buff, flagellum dark brown; cilia 1-0 x (cf) or<tei:lb/>0-7 x ($) flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula dark brown. Forewing purple-brown with very slightly<tei:lb/>darker mottling forming an indistinct 'moss' pattern; costa with six or seven inconspicuous paler yellowish<tei:lb/>spots; termen with interrupted line of yellowish spots. Hindwing purple-brown. Legs dull buff; outer<tei:lb/>mid-tibial spur 0-5 length of inner; outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-6 length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Clarke, 1970: pi. 16, figs Ic-le). Saccus shallow, triangular; uncus lobes slender, elongate,<tei:lb/>digitiform, widely separated. Subscaphium strongly sclerotized, shuttle-shaped. Juxta not identified;<tei:lb/>transtilla forming V-shaped arch between costae of valvae. Valvae fused; valval complex elongate,<tei:lb/>strongly sclerotized and setose at apex, with transverse ridge at three-quarters and pair of oblique<tei:lb/>sclerotized bars at one-half, these fused with transtilla. Aedeagus short, broad and stumpy, only 4 x as long<tei:lb/>as broad, smooth-surfaced; vesica with minute spicular cornuti (microtrichia).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Fig. 145). Eighth tergite divided medially, slightly longer than eighth sternite, with three<tei:lb/>pairs of stout terminal bristles; eighth sternite deeply folded transversely to form a triangular sterigma with</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>78 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>strongly sclerotized truncated apex overlying ostium and bearing pair of elongate setae plus single<tei:lb/>(?supernumerary) seta and a few scattered sensillae (?basiconica). Antrum not developed. Ductus bursae<tei:lb/>as long as apophyses anteriores, thin-walled, lined anteriorly with granular microtrichia from inception of<tei:lb/>ductus seminalis (at twice length of eighth sternite from ostium), oblique constrictions forming a<tei:lb/>characteristic pattern. Corpus bursae ovate, posterior half with regular transverse constrictions, thin-<tei:lb/>walled, with four stout, wedge-shaped and finely spinose signa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Guyana, Trinidad.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. Specimens have been reared from Polyporus in Trinidad.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 3 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype d", Guyana: Bartica, ii.1913 (Parish) (genitalia slide no. JFGC 6639; BMNH).<tei:lb/>Trinidad: 1 cf , 1 $, reared from Polyporus, 1922 (Urich) (genitalia slide nos 1664, 13110; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This small, dark species may be recognized simply by its external appearance: it bears a slight<tei:lb/>resemblance to Diataga but is smaller, darker and broader-winged. Forewing veins RT, and R 4 are separate,<tei:lb/>unlike Diataga. Both male and female genitalia are distinctive, the male in that the valvae are strongly<tei:lb/>fused and the elongate uncus lobes are widely separated, and the female in that it is the only scardiine with<tei:lb/>more than two signa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DAVISCARDIA gen. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type-species: Scardia color adella Dietz, 1905: 25.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Antenna (male) lacking dorsal cilia, ventral surface without scales; cilia longer or shorter than<tei:lb/>1-5 x flagellar diameter. Scape with more than 15 pecten bristles. Interocular index (male) greater than<tei:lb/>1-0. Maxillary palpus with fewer than 5 segments; pilifers present; second segment of labial palpus shorter<tei:lb/>than width of head. Outer mid and proximal hind tibial spurs &gt;0-4 length of inner spurs. Forewing with R 3<tei:lb/>and /? 4 separate; M 2 , A/ 3 and CuA\ separate; pattern consisting of pale termen and dorsum on darker<tei:lb/>ground-colour. Male lacking coremata in eighth abdominal segment. Male genitalia with complex uncus<tei:lb/>fused with tegumen ; tegumen unbroken , completely sclerotized dorsally ; valva lacking basal setose lobe on<tei:lb/>inner surface; apex of valva forming ventral hook or hooks, or with spines; valvae fused ventrally into a<tei:lb/>single movable complex, valvae without longitudinal cleft; saccus wider than long; juxta, if present, fused<tei:lb/>with valvae and not recognizable as such; vesica with spicular cornuti; aedeagus smooth-surfaced, without<tei:lb/>carinae, but minute spicular carinae present in two species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. None; however, this is the only group of species with a pale apex and<tei:lb/>dorsum in the forewing which lacks coremata; the deep, almost box-like fused valvae are also characteris-<tei:lb/>tic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Neotropical region; Nearctic region -U.S.A. (southern states).<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. See Daviscardia coloradella (Dietz).</tei:p>
