         <tei:p>Daviscardia coloradella (Dietz) comb. n.<tei:lb/>(Figs 21, 86-88, 147)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scardia coloradella Dietz, 1905: 25. LECTOTYPE cf , U.S.A. (MCZ), here designated [examined on</tei:p>
         <tei:p>author 's behalf by D. R. Davis].<tei:lb/>Fernaldia coloradella (Dietz) Davis, 1983: 5.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 21). cf $ , 26-33 mm. Vertex whitish, frons brownish yellow. Labial palpus grey-brown, paler<tei:lb/>on inner surface, whitish at base and apex of terminal segment. Maxillary palpus light grey-brown, short,<tei:lb/>3-segmented. Antennal scape, pedicel and flagellum dark brown; cilia 2-3 x (cf) or 0-5 x ($) flagellar<tei:lb/>diameter. Thorax whitish flecked with brown; tegula whitish, brown anteriorly. Forewing purple-brown,<tei:lb/>paler spots along costa, with continuous whitish posterior and terminal fascia strongly flecked with<tei:lb/>purple-brown and tinged with orange-brown posteriorly ; pair of conspicuous dark spots at apices of R 3 and<tei:lb/>R 4 ; brown flecks coalescing at tornus and fringe ; posterior margin of dark fascia strongly sinuate. Hindwing<tei:lb/>very light brownish grey. Legs greyish buff, hindlegs paler, foreleg and mid-leg grey brown above but pale<tei:lb/>at articulations; outer mid-tibial spur 0-5 length of inner; outer hind proximal tibial spur 0-6 length of inner<tei:lb/>spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Figs 86-88). Saccus shallow, almost square; uncus lobes very short, widely separated, but<tei:lb/>fused basally, each with setose ventral lobe bearing short triangular process with three or four stiff bristles;<tei:lb/>uncus lobes setose but strongly sclerotized, each with pair of spinose setae close to apex. Tegumen<tei:lb/>produced laterocaudally to form pair of rounded 'shoulders'. Subscaphium not developed. Juxta, if<tei:lb/>developed, fused with valvae and not recognizable but possibly forming caudally-directed hand-shaped<tei:lb/>process. Valva sinuate, fused with medial pair of hand-shaped processes, apex with dorsal ridge and<tei:lb/>chisel-shaped ventral tip. Aedeagus stout, 8 x as long as broad at middle, without carinae; vesica with<tei:lb/>numerous strong, spicular cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA 9 (Fig. 147). Eighth tergite longer than eighth sternite, with five pairs of stout subapical setae<tei:lb/>and two or three very small marginal setae, with scattered pits anterior to large setae; eighth sternite deeply<tei:lb/>folded to accommodate broad ostium, ventral margin of ostium with pair of large lobes, each bearing a pair<tei:lb/>of stout subapical setae and numerous smaller apical and subapical setae. Antrum broadly funnel-shaped,<tei:lb/>inception of ductus seminalis at apex of 'funnel' just beyond anterior margin of eighth sternite. Ductus<tei:lb/>bursae and corpus bursae contiguous, posteriorly with sclerotized region on left and irregularly-margined<tei:lb/>and more strongly sclerotized patch on right, wall between these patches with microtrichia; medial region<tei:lb/>thick-walled, anterior region ovoid, signa absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>80 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. U.S.A. (Colorado, Arizona, Utah, New Mexico, Maine; Texas- Dietz, 1905); Mexico<tei:lb/>(Durango - Powell, [1968]; Lawrence &amp; Powell, 1969).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. Reared from fungus on Pseudotsuga, from Poly poms on Pinus and from Ganoderma on Populus<tei:lb/>in the U.S.A., and from Ganoderma on Quercus in Mexico (Lawrence &amp; Powell, 1969).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 7 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lectotype cf , U.S.A.: Colorado, Durango, 9.xii.l899 (Dietz) (MCZ).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>U.S.A.: 1 cf (paralectotype) , New Mexico, Beulah, end of viii. (genitalia slide no. 12387; BMNH); lex.,<tei:lb/>Maine, Lincoln Co., 3 m. SE. Demariscotta, 14.vii.1969 (Powers} (UC); 1 $, Arizona, Cochise Co., upper<tei:lb/>Miller Canyon, Huachuca Mts, 6-7000', 9.viii.l974 (D. &amp; J. Powell) (BMNH); 1 $, Arizona, Redington<tei:lb/>(BMNH); 2 $ , Arizona, Huachuca Mts, 27.ix.1903 (Oslar) (genitalia slide no. 12388; BMNH); 1 $ , Utah,<tei:lb/>Wasatch Co., 7 m. E. of Springville, 6000', 28.vii. 1968 (Doyen) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This is the only Daviscardia species known to occur north of Mexico. It is larger than all other<tei:lb/>known species, the pale forewing fascia is more strongly speckled with brown, and the antennal cilia of the<tei:lb/>male are the longest of the genus, approached only by those of an unnamed species from Mexico (see<tei:lb/>below). The male genitalia are distinctive in that the tegumen does not bear the laterocaudal processes that<tei:lb/>are present in all other species except radulella; the valvae are produced ventrally to form a pair of<tei:lb/>hand-shaped lobes. These lobes may be homologous with the irregular, quadrate mediocaudal process<tei:lb/>between the valvae of radulella and with the hemicylindrical structure in the same position in bicolorella.<tei:lb/>By analogy with other genera, it seems likely that the juxta is implicated in these structures but that it is<tei:lb/>closely fused with the ventrobasal region of each valva and is not recognizable. However, in several species<tei:lb/>(for example, mackiei) there is no trace of any specialization at the ventral margin of the valva, and the<tei:lb/>juxta is either entirely subsumed into the valval complex or else has been lost. For the purpose of scoring<tei:lb/>character-states for numerical analysis, the juxta in Daviscardia is interpreted as primitively present and<tei:lb/>modified into a complex structure.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The female genitalia of coloradella are distinctive in their size, the presence of two sclerotized patches at<tei:lb/>the posterior end of the ductus bursae, and the deep U-shaped medial emargination of the ventral lip of the<tei:lb/>ostium.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I am unable to formulate a hypothesis of phylogeny for Daviscardia. However, two groups of species are<tei:lb/>recognizable - coloradella + radulella (with specialized ventral process(es) at the base(s) of the valvae,<tei:lb/>possibly derived from the juxta, and with the tegumen lacking laterocaudal processes) and all remaining<tei:lb/>species (with laterocaudal processes from the tegumen). Of the latter group, bicolorella has a ventral<tei:lb/>process between the valvae possibly homologous with that of radulella.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The identity of Mexican specimens, left in some doubt by Powell ([1968]), has not been confirmed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Daviscardia radulella sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 22, 91)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 22). cf , 16 mm. Coloration and external structure similar to bimendella (see below) but vertex<tei:lb/>and frons pale yellow-ochre; antennal flagellum light greyish brown above; cilia 1-0 x flagellar diameter;<tei:lb/>thorax and tegula brown, thorax flecked with brownish cream. Forewing with narrow posterior cream<tei:lb/>fascia continuous with terminal fascia but almost broken at tornus; distal margin of anterior brown fascia<tei:lb/>strongly concave; costa with about eight cream flecks, two basal pairs of these coalesced and extended<tei:lb/>posteriorly to form conspicuous spots; terminal fascia with large brown spots between R 3 and R 5 and<tei:lb/>between MI and M 2 . (All legs badly damaged or missing.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Fig. 91). Saccus rounded, with slightly angled apex; uncus lobes very shallow, simple, widely<tei:lb/>separated, fused basally, ventral lobe little more than a ridge. Tegumen not extended laterocaudally.<tei:lb/>Subscaphium represented by thickening of diaphragma, with spatulate anterior end. Juxta, if developed,<tei:lb/>fused with valvae and not recognizable but possibly forming irregularly quadrate ventral process between<tei:lb/>arms of valvae; transtilla not developed. Valva simple, with small and thorn-like apical and subapical<tei:lb/>processes. Aedeagus stout, about 10 x as long as broad in middle, lacking carinae; vesica with numerous<tei:lb/>stout spicular cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $. Unknown.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. Costa Rica.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 81</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Costa Rica: Palo Verde, 5250', 1920 (genitalia slide no. 12386; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. A small, speckly species, radulella may be recognized by the uniform head vestiture, short<tei:lb/>antennal cilia and marked extension of the dark forewing fascia towards the tornus. The male genitalia are<tei:lb/>distinctive in that there are no processes from the tegumen (as in color adella - q.v.) and there is an<tei:lb/>irregularly quadrate ventral process between the bases of the valvae.<tei:lb/>The holotype was originally identified by Meyrick in his collection as 'Cranaodes iulina Wals.'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Daviscardia bimendella (Zeller) comb. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 23, 90)<tei:lb/>Tinea bimendella Zeller, 1863: 143. LECTOTYPE cf , VENEZUELA (BMNH), here designated [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Zeller, 1863: pi. 2, fig. 5; Fig. 23). cf , 22 mm. Vertex white, frons brown. Labial palpus brown,<tei:lb/>whitish at articulations, apex, and on inner surface of first and second segments. Maxillary palpus<tei:lb/>brownish, very short, 3-segmented. Antennal scape and pedicel brown; flagellum ochreous; cilia 1-7 x<tei:lb/>flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula whitish, anterior half of tegula brown. Forewing purple-brown with<tei:lb/>extensive continuous terminal and posterior whitish fascia flecked with brown; some orange-brown scales<tei:lb/>close to posterior margin at one-half; costa with large basal and smaller medial white spot. Hindwing<tei:lb/>off-white, diffusely flecked with grey at apex. Legs pale buff; foreleg strongly marked with dark brown<tei:lb/>above; mid-legs missing; outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-6 length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Fig. 90). Saccus short, rounded; uncus lobes very short, widely separated and apparently not<tei:lb/>fused basally, each with pendulous ventrally-directed lobe bearing subapical triangular process. Tegumen<tei:lb/>produced caudally to form pair of lateral digitate processes. Subscaphium defined but only recognizable at<tei:lb/>spatulate anterior end. Juxta either not developed or entirely fused with valvae and unrecognizable. Valva<tei:lb/>simple, with shallow spine on terminal margin and with spined apex. Aedeagus stout, 10 x as long as broad<tei:lb/>in middle, lacking carinae; vesica with numerous strong, spicular cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA 9- Unknown.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. Venezuela.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 ex.<tei:lb/>Lectotype cf , Venezuela (genitalia slide no. 13124; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. D. bimendella, with beckeri, luctuosa, mackiei, species A and radulella, forms a group of<tei:lb/>externally very similar species. With the much larger coloradella, beckeri, and the unnamed species from<tei:lb/>Mexico, it is conspicuous in having the male antennal cilia longer than 1-5 x the diameter of the flagellar<tei:lb/>segments; however, the male antenna of luctuosa is unknown. As in coloradella, beckeri, luctuosa and<tei:lb/>mackiei, the scales of the frons and vertex are of contrasting shades, the vertex whitish and the frons<tei:lb/>brownish. It may be separated from beckeri, luctuosa and mackiei by the broader pale terminal fascia in the<tei:lb/>forewing and by the large pale basicostal spot. This spot, although present in mackiei, is suffused with<tei:lb/>purple-brown in that species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The male genitalia are very similar to those of luctuosa but each valva has a pair of terminal thorn-like<tei:lb/>projections and the uncus lobes each bear a triangular medioventral process; these are absent in luctuosa.<tei:lb/>The aedeagus is smooth-surfaced but in luctuosa it bears numerous minute spicular carinae. The male<tei:lb/>genitalia resemble even more those of beckeri but differ in that the armature is larger, the tegumen<tei:lb/>processes are broader and not as strongly pointed, and the free arms of the valvae are more elongate. The<tei:lb/>triangular medioventral process on each uncus lobe is hardly developed in beckeri.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Meyrick misidentified a male of mackiei and the holotype female of hypocritella as 'Cranaodes<tei:lb/>bimendella' in his collection.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Daviscardia beckeri sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 24, 25, 92, 148)<tei:lb/>[Phycis luctuosa Walsingham, 1914: 358. Partim-2 9 only. Misidentification.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Figs 24, 25). cf 9, 14-21 mm. Coloration and external structure similar to bimendella but frons<tei:lb/>light brown, inner surface of third segment of labial palpus greyish (white in one female from Mexico),</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>82 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>antennal flagellum grey-brown, cilia 2-0 x (cf) or 0-4 x (9) flagellar diameter; forewing costa with a few<tei:lb/>ill-defined paler flecks; hindwing light grey in females; outer mid-tibial spur 0-35 length of inner; outer<tei:lb/>proximal hind tibial spur 0-6 length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Fig. 92). Similar to those of bimendella but genital armature smaller, only about 1-05 mm<tei:lb/>long (about 1-30 mm in bimendella); uncus lobes not as elongate, subapical triangular process on each lobe<tei:lb/>very small and insignificant. Subscaphium well defined only at slightly spatulate anterior end, ribbon-like.<tei:lb/>Ventral emargination between valvae infilled to two-thirds by membranous 'bridge' (only to one-half in<tei:lb/>bimendella); setae of valvae stout and spine-like.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Fig. 148) . Eighth tergite as long as eighth sternite , with three or four pairs of strong subapical<tei:lb/>setae and numerous terminal and subterminal pits; eighth sternite with lamellate surface and only slightly<tei:lb/>sclerotized dorsal to ostium , ventral lip of ostium m-shaped , lobes each bearing one pair of large setae and<tei:lb/>numerous small setae. Antrum with nodular/microtrichiate internal surface, terminating in strongly<tei:lb/>sclerotized colliculum well beyond margin of eighth sternite. Ductus bursae short, thin- walled, inception of<tei:lb/>ductus seminalis at junction with corpus bursae. Corpus bursae pyriform (but exaggeratedly so), posterior<tei:lb/>end sclerotized, sclerotization terminating anteriorly in equatorial band of spicular signa; corpus swollen<tei:lb/>anterior to signa, membrane thick-walled and finely reticulate, becoming thin-walled and smooth-surfaced<tei:lb/>in globular anterior region.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Mexico; Costa Rica.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 6 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Costa Rica: Turrialba, 600 m, iii.1973 (Becker) (genitalia slide no. 9492; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. 1 cf, 1 $, data as holotype, x.1971 and iii.1973 (coll. V. O. Becker, Brasilia); 1 $, data as<tei:lb/>holotype, x.1971 (genitalia slide no. 9493; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Excluded from paratype series. Mexico: 2 $ , Vera Cruz, Jalapa, 4500' , 1887 (Schaus; Trujillo) (genitalia<tei:lb/>slide no. 13126; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species, similar to bimendella, luctuosa and mackiei, is difficult to recognize by external<tei:lb/>characteristics. It may be distinguished from mackiei by its considerably longer antennal cilia in the male,<tei:lb/>and from bimendella by the darker costal region of the forewing and the greater extension in the tornal<tei:lb/>region of the dark forewing fascia. The outer mid-tibial spur is shorter in beckeri than in luctuosa or mackiei<tei:lb/>(0-35 as opposed to 0-50 the length of the inner spur). The male genitalia are distinguished from those of<tei:lb/>bimendella as described above.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The female genitalia are very similar to those of mackiei but the spicular signa are in an equatorial band,<tei:lb/>not in a pair of opposed T-shaped clusters, and mackiei has no posterior sclerotized patch on the corpus<tei:lb/>bursae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is questionable whether the two females from Mexico are conspecific with the type-series. The<tei:lb/>genitalia of one specimen have been dissected (the other has the abdomen missing) and are illustrated (Fig.<tei:lb/>148). In comparison with the dissected female from Costa Rica, there are only five strong setae on the<tei:lb/>eighth tergite (i.e. two pairs plus one supernumerary) whereas there are three pairs plus one in the Costa<tei:lb/>Rican specimen. The antrum is only very weakly sclerotized, the posterior region of the corpus bursae has<tei:lb/>only an irregular sclerotized patch, the shape of the corpus bursae is substantially different, and there is no<tei:lb/>reticulation of the membrane anterior to the signa. However, the Mexican specimen has mated whereas<tei:lb/>the Costa Rican example is virgin; this may account for the differences in the structure and thickness of the<tei:lb/>membrane of the corpus bursae and for the difference in its shape.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Daviscardia luctuosa (Walsingham) comb. n.<tei:lb/>(Figs 26, 89)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phycis luctuosa Walsingham, 1914: 358. LECTOTYPE cf, COSTA RICA (BMNH), here designated<tei:lb/>[examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 26). cf, 20 mm. Coloration and external structure similar to bimendella but frons light brown,<tei:lb/>inner surface of labial palpus pale greyish; (antennae broken). Forewing pattern similar to bimendella, but<tei:lb/>tornal region of pale fascia narrower as distal margin of dark fascia is expanded towards tornus; pale costal<tei:lb/>spots (particularly basal spot) smaller than in bimendella and suffused with purple-brown; outer mid-tibial<tei:lb/>spur 0-5 length of inner; outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-6 length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 83</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Fig. 89). Similar to those of bimendella but uncus lobes more widely separated, ventral lobe<tei:lb/>shorter and without triangular process ; lateral processes of tegumen broader basally ; valva with free caudal<tei:lb/>region more elongate, outer surface swollen and slightly ridged, spine on terminal margin represented only<tei:lb/>by slight irregular swelling; aedeagus similar to that of bimendella but ventral surface with numerous<tei:lb/>minute spicular carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Costa Rica.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 ex.<tei:lb/>Lectotype cf , Costa Rica: Volcan de Irazu, 6-7000', 18 (Rogers) (genitalia slide no. 13129; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is similar to bimendella (see 'Remarks', above) but the terminal pale forewing fascia<tei:lb/>is narrower and the pale costal spots much smaller. The male genitalia differ as described for bimendella.<tei:lb/>The external similarity of luctuosa and its allies is such that Walsingham's syntype series of this species<tei:lb/>included the male and (provisional) female ofmackiei as well as the (holotype) female of lupulella and two<tei:lb/>females of beckeri, and the holotype oiMoscardia varna.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Daviscardia mackieisp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 27-29, 93, 150)<tei:lb/>[Phycis luctuosa Walsingham, 1914: 358. Partim - 1 cf , 1 $ only. Misidentification.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Figs 27-29). cf , 18, 19 mm; $ , 16 mm. Coloration and external structure similar to bimendella and<tei:lb/>luctuosa but antennal cilia 1-3 x (cf) flagellar diameter (antennae of $ broken). Forewing pattern similar<tei:lb/>to luctuosa but pale costal spots larger, resembling more those of bimendella, but suffused with purple-<tei:lb/>brown as in luctuosa; female with purple-brown fascia extended towards tornus, reaching posterior margin<tei:lb/>and extending into fringe.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Fig. 93). Saccus shallowly triangular; uncus lobes very short, widely separated, but fused<tei:lb/>basally to form a kidney-shaped complex, each with pendulous setose ventral lobe bearing shallow<tei:lb/>subapical triangular process; uncus lobes setose but strongly sclerotized. Tegumen produced caudally to<tei:lb/>form pair of lateral triangular blunt-tipped processes. Subscaphium not developed. Juxta, if present, fused<tei:lb/>with valvae and not recognizable; transtilla possibly represented by thickened band across diaphragma<tei:lb/>between bases of valvae. Valva simple, lobate, apex with strong internal ridge terminating in shallow<tei:lb/>pyramidal process. Aedeagus stout, 8 x as long as broad at middle, without carinae; vesica with numerous<tei:lb/>strong spicular cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Fig. 150). Eighth tergite longer than eighth sternite, with three pairs of strong subapical<tei:lb/>setae and a few scattered pits in posterior half; eighth sternite with lamellate surface and only slightly<tei:lb/>sclerotized dorsal to ostium, ventral lip of ostium m-shaped, lobes each bearing one pair of large setae and<tei:lb/>numerous small setae. Antrum with nodular/microtrichiate internal surface, terminating in colliculum well<tei:lb/>beyond margin of eighth sternite. Ductus bursae short, thin-walled, inception of ductus seminalis at<tei:lb/>junction with corpus bursae. Corpus bursae elongately pyriform, sparsely microtrichiate just anterior to<tei:lb/>inception of ductus seminalis, with strongly sclerotized subequatorial band bearing numerous dense and<tei:lb/>strong spicular signa arranged in two opposed inverted T-shaped clusters; membrane adjacent to these<tei:lb/>clusters with regular honeycomb-like reticulation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. (?)Guatemala; Colombia; Bolivia.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 3 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Bolivia: Yungas de la Paz, 1908 (Seebold) (genitalia slide no. 12393; BMNH) (paralecto-<tei:lb/>typeof luctuosa).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratype. Colombia: 1 cf , La Crumbre, 6600', v.1914 (P.) (genitalia slide no. 12391; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Excluded from paratype series. Guatemala: 1 $, Alta Vera Paz, Sinanja, x.1879 (Champion) (genitalia<tei:lb/>slide no. 13128; BMNH) (paralectotype of luctuosa).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Externally very similar to bimendella, beckeri and luctuosa, mackiei has shorter antennal cilia in<tei:lb/>the male than bimendella or beckeri although it has a large basicostal spot on the forewing similar to that in</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>84 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>bimendella. This spot is, however, suffused with brown whereas it is pure white in bimendella. The male<tei:lb/>genitalia are distinctive in having a pointed saccus, stout valvae with pyramidal apical processes, and the<tei:lb/>tegumen with triangular laterocaudal processes with rounded apices. The female, provisionally placed<tei:lb/>here , is distinguished by the elegant arrangement of spicular signa in a pair of opposed T-shaped clusters at<tei:lb/>the mid-length of the corpus bursae.<tei:lb/>Meyrick originally identified the paratype of this species in his collection as 'Cranaodes bimendella Z.'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Daviscardia bicolorella sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 30, 94)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 30). d", 17, 18 mm. Coloration and external structure similar to bimendella but frons whitish<tei:lb/>with a few brown lateral scales; entire inner surface of labial palpus whitish; antennal flagellum pale buff;<tei:lb/>cilia only 1-0 x flagellar diameter. Forewing purple-brown with very broad posterior and terminal cream<tei:lb/>fascia, tinged with orange-brown on dorsum and with some scattered brown scales in terminal fascia.<tei:lb/>Hindwing slightly greyish cream, some darker grey flecks at apex; mid-leg light grey-brown above and on<tei:lb/>outer surface of tibia, pale at articulations, tibia with oblique pale band on outer surface at one-half; outer<tei:lb/>mid-tibial spur 0-4 length of inner; outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-6 length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Fig. 94). Saccus triangular but rounded apically, with vinculum and tegumen forming a<tei:lb/>distinctly elongate genital armature; uncus lobes small, widely separated, strongly sclerotized, forming<tei:lb/>ventrally-directed lobe with strongly setose inner surface. Tegumen extended laterocaudally to form pair<tei:lb/>of sharp, spine-like processes. Subscaphium present, narrow, only slightly sclerotized. Juxta, if developed,<tei:lb/>fused with valvae and not recognizable, but possibly forming hemicylindrical process between valvae;<tei:lb/>transtilla hardly sclerotized but represented by thickened diaphragma forming a rigid cowl-shaped<tei:lb/>structure dorsal to valvae. Valva simple, apex ridged and sinuate. Aedeagus slender, about 20 x as long as<tei:lb/>broad at middle, without carinae; vesica with four or five short sagittate cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $. Unknown.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. Bolivia.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 2 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Bolivia: Cochabamba (Yunga del Espiritu Santo), 1888-9 (Germain) (genitalia slide no.<tei:lb/>13121; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratype. 1 $ , data as holotype (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species, while superficially similar to bimendella, beckeri, luctuosa and mackiei, is<tei:lb/>distinguished by its short antennal cilia, glossy and markedly contrasting forewing fasciae with very little<tei:lb/>brown speckling in the pale fascia, lack of pale costal spots, and its uniformly pale-coloured frons and<tei:lb/>vertex. The male genitalia are distinguished by the elongate genital armature, sharp-tipped and horn-like<tei:lb/>laterocaudal tegumen processes (somewhat similar to those of beckeri), and by the hemicylindrical ventral<tei:lb/>structure (?juxta) between the bases of the valvae. This is the only species of Daviscardia that has a long<tei:lb/>and narrow aedeagus with only a few cornuti. All other species have an aedeagus about 10 times as long as<tei:lb/>broad and with numerous spicular cornuti. D. bicolorella has an aedeagus about 20 times as long as broad<tei:lb/>with only four or five small cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Daviscardia species A<tei:lb/>(Fig. 95)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT, d", 18 mm. Vertex and frons light ochre. Labial palpus dark brown, apex ochreous. Antennal cilia<tei:lb/>2-0 x flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula dark brown anteriorly, whitish posteriorly. Forewing pattern<tei:lb/>similar to that of bimendella but without pale costal spots; distal half and terminal area of continuous pale<tei:lb/>fascia strongly flecked with purple-brown, strong spot at apex of R 4 . Hind wing light grey. Outer mid-tibial<tei:lb/>spur 0-4 length of inner; outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-75 length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Fig. 95). Saccus shallow, rounded; uncus lobes widely separated, but fused basally, each<tei:lb/>forming shallow caudal and slightly longer ventral setose lobe. Tegumen extended laterocaudally to form<tei:lb/>two pairs of digitate processes. Subscaphium ribbon-like, ill-defined. Juxta, if developed, fused with valvae<tei:lb/>and not recognizable; transtilla possibly developed as a broadly triangular region of thickened membrane.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 85</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Valva ridged on internal surface, spatulate, with truncated apex. Aedeagus stout, about 10 x as long as<tei:lb/>broad at middle, with subapical group of numerous spicular carinae; vesica with numerous strong spicular<tei:lb/>cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $. Unknown.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. Mexico.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 ex.<tei:lb/>Mexico: 1 cf , Oaxaca, km 140 on highway 175, 4000', 22. v. 1969 (Howden) (UC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species may be distinguished from all other Daviscardia by its having two processes from<tei:lb/>each corner of the tegumen rather than one. Superficially, it resembles bimendella and its allies but, like<tei:lb/>bicolorella, radulella and lupulella (and, possibly, hypocritella), the head vestiture is coloured uniformly.<tei:lb/>D. bicolorella has whitish head vestiture but the present species, radulella, lupulella and hypocritella have<tei:lb/>the frons and vertex a light shade of ochre. This species may be separated from radulella (the only one of<tei:lb/>these species of which the male is known) by its longer antennal cilia (twice the flagellar diameter in this<tei:lb/>species but only as long as the flagellar diameter in radulella).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Daviscardia lupulella sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 31, 149)<tei:lb/>[Phycis luctuosa Walsingham, 1914: 358. Partim- 1 $ only. Misidentification.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 31). $, 23 mm. Vertex and frons light orange-brown (but very worn). Labial palpus brown,<tei:lb/>paler on inner surface. Maxillary palpus brownish grey, 3-segmented, but longer than in preceding species,<tei:lb/>almost reaching apex of second segment of labial palpus. Antennal scape, pedicel and flagellum dark<tei:lb/>brown but scape and distal region of flagellum ochreous above; cilia 0-7 x flagellar diameter. Thorax and<tei:lb/>tegula dark brown in anterior half, light orange-brown posteriorly. Forewing purple-brown with ill-defined<tei:lb/>and slightly paler costal spots at one-third and two-thirds; with brownish cream terminal and posterior<tei:lb/>fascia strongly tinted posteriorly and basally with orange-brown; strong dark spot at apex of R 4 ; further<tei:lb/>smaller spots on apices of M 1? M 2 and M 3 ; pale fascia sparsely flecked with purple-brown scales; posterior<tei:lb/>margin of purple-brown fascia with shallowly V-shaped medial emargination. Hind wing grey. Foreleg and<tei:lb/>mid-leg grey-brown, darker above, pale at articulations (hind legs missing); outer mid-tibial spur 0-5 length<tei:lb/>of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Fig. 149). Eighth tergite longer than eighth sternite, with three or four pairs of strong<tei:lb/>subapical setae and numerous terminal and subterminal pits; eighth sternite smooth dorsal to ostium,<tei:lb/>ventral lip of ostium m-shaped, lobes each bearing one pair of large setae and numerous small setae.<tei:lb/>Antrum with nodular/microtrichiate internal surface, strongly sclerotized but not forming a colliculum<tei:lb/>anteriorly, terminating well beyond anterior margin of eighth sternite. Inception of ductus seminalis at<tei:lb/>apex of antrum. Corpus bursae elongately pyriform, posterior region thin-walled, appearing finely<tei:lb/>reticulate under phase-contrast; strongly wrinkled in a coarse reticular pattern and thick-walled medially;<tei:lb/>anteriorly very thin-walled; signa absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Panama.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Panama: Volcan de Chiriqui, 2000-3000', 1881 (Champion) (genitalia slide no. 12392;<tei:lb/>BMNH) (paralectotype of luctuosa).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This and the following species, hypocritella, are distinctive in that they are large and plain-<tei:lb/>patterned (and probably glossy-looking when fresh). The coloration of the head vestiture is uniform. The<tei:lb/>maxillary palpus is more elongate in this than in other Daviscardia species and the pale forewing fascia is<tei:lb/>more strongly tinted with orange-brown. The genitalia are distinctive in that there is an elongate, strongly<tei:lb/>sclerotized antrum and, as in hypocritella, no sclerotization of the ductus bursae. The m-shaped ventral lip<tei:lb/>of the ostium is similar to that seen in luctuosa and mackie; but quite unlike that of hypocritella which is<tei:lb/>almost transverse and with a deep and narrow medial emargination.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>86 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Daviscardia hypocritella sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 32, 151)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 32). $ , 24 mm. Coloration and external structure similar to preceding species, but coloration<tei:lb/>of head , thorax and legs uncertain , owing to covering of fungal hyphae . Forewing with whitish fascia paler ;<tei:lb/>distal margin of purple-brown fascia slightly concave, turned at right-angles close to tornus, posterior<tei:lb/>margin only slightly concave medially, otherwise nearly straight; posterior fascia only slightly tinted with<tei:lb/>orange-brown on dorsum; pale fascia sparsely flecked with purple-brown scales; purple-brown spot at apex<tei:lb/>of R 4 only.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf . Unknown. ,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Fig. 151). Eighth tergite longer than eighth sternite, with four pairs of strong subapical setae,<tei:lb/>a few terminal pits and a pair of small setae; eighth sternite with terminal ostium, almost square-ended,<tei:lb/>ventral lip of ostium with deep and narrow medial emargination; posterior margin with two pairs of<tei:lb/>elongate strong setae and numerous smaller setae. Antrum short, hardly sclerotized, internal surface<tei:lb/>nodular/microtrichiate, apex forming a strongly sclerotized colliculum, its apex level with anterior margin<tei:lb/>of eighth sternite. Ductus bursae elongate, lined with sparse microtrichia, finely reticulate close to corpus<tei:lb/>bursae if observed under phase-contrast (x250); inception of ductus seminalis at one-fifth posteriorly.<tei:lb/>Corpus bursae spherical, posterior half thick- walled with strong transverse wrinkles; signa absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Panama.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 ex.<tei:lb/>Holotype $, Panama: Chiriqui, 1899 (/?.) (genitalia slide no. 13125; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The pale forewing fascia of this species is not as strongly spotted with dark brown nor as strongly<tei:lb/>suffused posteriorly with orange-brown as in lupulella. The genitalia are distinctive and markedly different<tei:lb/>from those of the four other species of Daviscardia of which the female is known. The elongate ductus<tei:lb/>bursae and spherical corpus bursae are peculiar to hypocritella, and it is the only Daviscardia species in<tei:lb/>which the ventral lip of the ostium is not even approximately m-shaped.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The holotype of this species was originally identified by Meyrick in his collection as 'Cranaodes<tei:lb/>bimendella Z.' along with the present paratype of mackiei.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SCARDIA Treitschke</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scardia Treitschke, 1830: 291. Type-species: Phycis boleti Fabricius, 1798: 463, by subsequent designation</tei:p>
         <tei:p>byBusck,1914:65.<tei:lb/>Agarica Sodoffsky, 1837(6): 20 (93). Type-species: Phycis boleti Fabricius, 1798: 463. [Unnecessary</tei:p>
         <tei:p>objective replacement name for Scardia Treitschke.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fernaldia Grote, 1881: 274. Type-species: Fernaldia anatomella Grote, 1881: 274, by monotypy. Syn. n.<tei:lb/>Duomitella Koshantschikov, 1923: 22. Type-species: Duomitella relicta Koshantschikov, 1923: 23, by</tei:p>
         <tei:p>monotypy. [Synonymized by Zagulajev, 1973: 83.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Antenna (male) lacking dorsal cilia, ventral surface without scales; cilia shorter than 1-5 x<tei:lb/>flagellar diameter. Scape with more than 15 pecten bristles. Interocular index (male) 1-0 or less. Maxillary<tei:lb/>palpus 5-segmented; pilifers present; second segment of labial palpus shorter than width of head. Outer<tei:lb/>mid and proximal hind tibial spurs &gt;0-4 length of inner spurs. Forewing with R 3 and R 4 separate; M 2 , M 3<tei:lb/>and CuAi separate; pattern consisting of pale termen and dorsum on darker ground-colour. Male with<tei:lb/>coremata in eighth abdominal segment; coremata not associated with apodemes. Male genitalia with<tei:lb/>complex uncus fused with tegumen; tegumen unbroken, completely sclerotized dorsally; valva lacking<tei:lb/>basal setose lobe on inner surface; apex of valva forming ventral hook or hooks, or with spines; valvae +<tei:lb/>juxta fused ventrally into a single movable complex, valvae without longitudinal cleft; saccus wider than<tei:lb/>long; juxta complex, conspicuous, entire, not divided medially; vesica with spicular cornuti; aedeagus<tei:lb/>smooth-surfaced, without spicular carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. Uncus fused with bases of valvae, with pair of elongate horn-like internal<tei:lb/>processes; female with frenulum of about 15 strong bristles.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Western and eastern Palaearctic region; Oriental region - NE. India, Borneo; Nearctic<tei:lb/>region; Neotropical region - Venezuela.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 87</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Scardia anatomella (Grote) comb. rev.<tei:lb/>(Figs 33, 34, 96, 153)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fernddia anatomella Grote, 1881: 274; Davis, 1983: 5. LECTOTYPE $, U.S.A. (BMNH), here</tei:p>
         <tei:p>designated [examined].<tei:lb/>Scardia fiskeella Busck, 1908: 93. Holotype &lt;j&gt;, U.S.A. (NMNH) [examined]. [Synonymized by Davis,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1983: 5.]<tei:lb/>Scardia anatomella (Grote) Walsingham, 1882: 171; Dyar, [1903]: 568; Dietz, 1905: 24; McDunnough,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1939: 104.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Figs 33, 34). cf $, 20-34 mm. Coloration and external structure similar to boletella but antennal<tei:lb/>cilia onlyO-4 x ($)flagellar diameter and distal segments of antenna light brown. Forewing with little or no<tei:lb/>orange-brown scaling on veins; in specimen from Venezuela (Fig. 34) cream markings not as strongly<tei:lb/>speckled with brown as in boletella; cream markings at posterior margin reduced in several examples.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Fig. 96). Saccus broad, shallow; uncus lobes very short and reduced, highly modified, with<tei:lb/>elongate and spine-like dorsal processes and shallow, dentate dorsal ridge, setae few, restricted to<tei:lb/>mediodorsal region. Caudal margin of juxta-tegumen complex strongly emarginate, with four pairs of<tei:lb/>strong spines arising from fused base at dorsocaudal margin of each uncus lobe. Subscaphium not</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>88 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>developed. Juxta U-shaped, with further inverted U-shaped sclerotization within the 'U', fused laterally<tei:lb/>with valvae, extended distally into pair of claw-shaped processes; transtilla not developed. Valva with<tei:lb/>ventral margin strongly angled outward, apical margin strongly emarginate and with shallow subapical flap<tei:lb/>running obliquely across ventrocaudal region, with weak medial longitudinal ridge and with shallow<tei:lb/>triangular process close to costa at one-half. Aedeagus tapered, simple, 4 x as long as broad at base, apex<tei:lb/>obliquely truncated; vesica with a few scattered minute spicular cornuti (microtrichia) close to inception of<tei:lb/>ductus ejaculatorius (i.e., at apex of vesica when everted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Fig. 153). Eighth tergite slightly longer than eighth sternite, inverted shield-shaped anterior<tei:lb/>region strongly sclerotized, posterior quarter almost membranous but with five pairs of strong submarginal<tei:lb/>setae and numerous smaller setae, these scattered almost to mid-length of tergite; eighth sternite folded to<tei:lb/>form strongly sclerotized posterior lobe overlying deep pocket (a 'false antrum'), then folded again<tei:lb/>ventrally and slightly anteriorly to form pair of shallowly triangular lobes only slightly sclerotized mesally<tei:lb/>and forming lateral margins of ostium; lobes each with three strong setae and four or five smaller setae.<tei:lb/>Anterior margin of ostium membranous and ill-defined; sternite deepened dorso-ventrally at anterior end<tei:lb/>to accommodate antrum. Antrum ill-defined, slightly tapered anteriorly, extending slightly beyond<tei:lb/>anterior margin of eighth sternite; inception of ductus seminalis close to anterior end of antrum. Ductus<tei:lb/>bursae slightly less than one-half length of apophyses anteriores, thin-walled. Corpus bursae elongately<tei:lb/>ovoid, thin-walled except for posterior third which is apparently thicker and more heavily-staining,<tei:lb/>reaching 1-3 length of apophyses anteriores; signa absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. U.S.A. (New York - Grote, 1881; North Carolina - Busck, 1908; Louisiana; Arkansas;<tei:lb/>Oregon- Walsingham, 1882; California -Powell, [1968]; Florida -Kimball, 1965; Pennsylvania -Forbes,<tei:lb/>1923; Illinois, Texas, Utah - Dietz, 1905); Canada (Ontario - Forbes, 1923); Venezuela.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. Described by Walsingham (1882) who bred several specimens from larvae collected in Oregon in<tei:lb/>March. The larvae were boring round holes in a fallen dead pine tree.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 14 ex., 5 pupae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lectotype $ (of anatomella) (abdomen missing), U.S.A.: New York (Grote) (BMNH). Holotype 9 (of<tei:lb/>ftskeella), U.S.A.: North Carolina, Tryon, 8.vii.l904 (Fiske) (genitalia slide no. 18664; NMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>U.S.A.: 9 ex., Oregon, Grant Co., Camp Watson, in dead wood (pine), coll. iii, em. vi.1872<tei:lb/>(Walsingham) (genitalia slide nos. 19195, 12389, 12390; BMNH); 1 cf, Louisiana, 1884 (Morrison)<tei:lb/>(BMNH); 1 $, Arkansas, Hope, vi.1926 (BMNH). Venezuela: 1 cf (ex Felder coll.) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The only New World species of Scardia, anatomella is characterized by the genitalia of both<tei:lb/>sexes: in the male the uncus lobes are short and modified into spine-like processes; the female genitalia<tei:lb/>differ from other Scardia in that the triangular membranous lobe dorsal to the ostium is lacking, as in<tei:lb/>amurensis, and the eighth sternite has a conspicuous and strongly sclerotized posterior margin that is dorsal<tei:lb/>to the ostium. This strongly developed posterior region also occurs in amurensis but in that species it is<tei:lb/>deeply cleft and overlaid (in ventral view) by a pair of lateral processes directed caudally and extending<tei:lb/>beyond this posterior and dorsal region of the sternite.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The specimen from Venezuela is from the Felder collection. It may be labelled incorrectly. It is lighter<tei:lb/>and with a more strongly marbled appearance to the forewings than specimens from the U.S.A. : this is due<tei:lb/>to the lack of brown speckling within the cream forewing markings, and the comparatively larger pale<tei:lb/>costal spots.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I am unable to resolve convincingly the phylogeny of the six Scardia species. 5. boletella and caucasica<tei:lb/>are clearly sister-species, their sister-group being alleni (synapomorphy: membranous triangular lobe<tei:lb/>overlying ostium dorsally). The sister-group of boletella + caucasica + alleni is probably amurensis<tei:lb/>(synapomorphy: elongate and tapered uncus lobes). The precise relationship of this grouping to ana-<tei:lb/>tomella and assamensis, which retain the short, squat uncus complex also observed in Daviscardia, the<tei:lb/>probable sister-group of Scardia, is uncertain. However, the uncus lobes in anatomella are almost<tei:lb/>completely separated from the tegumen by membrane whereas in all other Scardia species they are almost<tei:lb/>completely fused; the degree of separation observed in anatomella is similar to that observed in<tei:lb/>Daviscardia and is considered to be the ground-plan state of the character. On the basis of this decidedly<tei:lb/>weak feature, anatomella is the sister-group of all other Scardia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scardia assamensis sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 35, 97, 101)<tei:lb/>ADULT (Fig. 35). cf , 24 mm. Coloration and external structure similar to boletella but frons and vertex dark</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 89</tei:p>
         <tei:p>reddish brown, thorax and tegula deep purple-brown. Forewing (worn) lacking extensive pale posterior<tei:lb/>fascia, with only scattered whitish scales close to posterior margin; pale markings of terminal fascia<tei:lb/>silver-grey, not as extensive as in boletella. Hindwing fringe not chequered.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Figs 97, 101). Saccus broad, shallow; uncus lobes short, apices short and digitate and widely<tei:lb/>separated, strongly sclerotized and with setae restricted to laterodorsal region. Fused uncus-tegumen<tei:lb/>complex strongly emarginate medially, membrane of emargination bearing conspicuous group of about 40<tei:lb/>strong spines. Subscaphium not developed. Juxta trapezoidal , fused laterally with valvae , extended distally<tei:lb/>to form pair of hand-shaped processes; transtilla not developed. Valva simple, with small shallow<tei:lb/>hook-like process at apex. Aedeagus stout, about 5 x as long as broad at base, strongly sclerotized, apex<tei:lb/>laterally emarginate; vesica with scattered minute spicular cornuti (microtrichia) for half its length closest<tei:lb/>to inception of ductus ejaculatorius (i.e., in apical half of vesica if it were everted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $. Unknown.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. India- Assam.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , India: Assam, Khasi Hills, Cherrapunji, v.1895 (native collector] (genitalia slide no. 1514;<tei:lb/>BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This is the only Old World Scardia species in which the lobes of the uncus are short. S.<tei:lb/>assamensis is small; it lacks the extensive pale fascia at the posterior margin of the forewing that<tei:lb/>characterizes other Scardia with the exception ofalleni. It is the only species in which the head, thorax and<tei:lb/>tegulae are entirely dark brown and the only one in which the horn-like lateral processes from the juxta are<tei:lb/>modified and hand-shaped, bearing small digitate subterminal processes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scardia amurensis Zagulajev<tei:lb/>(Figs 36, 98, 154)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scardia amurensis Zagulajev, 1965: 411; 1973: 96; Moriuti, 1982: 163. Holotype cf, U.S.S.R. (ZI)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[examined]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[(?) Scardia boletella (F.); Caradja, 1939: 111. Misidentification.]<tei:lb/>[Scardia boletella (F.); Issiki, 1957: 16. Misidentification.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Issiki, 1957: pi. 2, fig. 46 (colour); Moriuti, 1982: pi. 2, fig. 12 ($), pi. 227, fig. 1 (cf) (colour); Fig.<tei:lb/>36). cf $ , 39-42 mm. Coloration and external structure similar to boletella.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Zagulajev, 1965: fig. 1; Zagulajev, 1973: figs 15B, 16b, 75; Moriuti, 1982: pi. 248, figs 10,<tei:lb/>lOa; Fig. 98). Saccus broad, shallow; uncus lobes flattened laterally, strongly sclerotized, setose, tapered to<tei:lb/>a point; tegumen extended dorsocaudally to form overlying triangular process, spined membranous dorsal<tei:lb/>recess thus absent. Subscaphium not developed but membrane of diaphragma in this region forming<tei:lb/>shallow lateral pockets with transverse wrinkling. Juxta quadrate, fused laterally with valvae, extended<tei:lb/>distally into pair of claw-like processes, with doubly bulbed shallow ventral process; transtilla not<tei:lb/>developed. Valva almost square, simple, costa extended caudally in a simple, rounded extension that is<tei:lb/>bulbous subapically; slight basal ridge on internal surface of valva close to patch of about 10 short, strong<tei:lb/>setae. Aedeagus 5 x as long as broad at base, explanate apically, planarian-shaped; vesica with minute<tei:lb/>spicular cornuti (microtrichia) close to inception of ductus ejaculatorius (i.e., at apex if vesica were<tei:lb/>everted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Zagulajev, 1973: figs 76, 77; Fig. 154). Eighth tergite slightly longer than eighth sternite,<tei:lb/>inverted shield-shaped anterior region strongly sclerotized, posterior quarter almost membranous but with<tei:lb/>five pairs of strong submarginal setae and numerous smaller setae; eighth sternite strongly folded to form<tei:lb/>pair of lateral setose digitate processes, each overlying a cushion-shaped lobe; ostium a deep fold behind<tei:lb/>these cushion-like lobes, ventral margin a narrow bridge between them. Course of antrum complex,<tei:lb/>oriented dorso-ventrally through base of cushion-like lobes then turned anteriorly and forming a<tei:lb/>colliculum-like apex just anterior to margin of eighth sternite; inception of ductus seminalis apparently<tei:lb/>close to inner bases of cushion-like lobes (i.e., remarkably posterior). Ductus bursae very thin-walled,<tei:lb/>one-half length of apophyses anteriores, with fine and numerous irregular transverse constrictions. Corpus<tei:lb/>bursae ovoid, very thin-walled, reaching 1-3 length of apophyses anteriores; signa absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>90 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. U.S.S.R. - Amur and Primorsk regions; (?) China (Caradja, 1939); Japan.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. Specimens have been collected on the trunk of a rotting tree and bred from larvae living in fungus<tei:lb/>(Zagulajev, 1973); the Japanese specimen examined (see below) was bred from Fames fomentarius .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 10 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , U.S.S.R.: Primorsk Terr., Spassk-Dalniy, at light, 5.viii.l950 (Zagulajev) (ZI).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>U.S.S.R.: 1 O" (paratype), Amur Prov., Svobodnyi Dist., Simonovo vill., at light, l.viii.1959 (Falko-<tei:lb/>vitsh) (ZI); 1 cf (paratype), Primorsk Terr., Suchan, on trunk of rotting tree, 16. viii. 1950 (Zagulajev) (ZI);<tei:lb/>1 $, Ussuri, Kaimanovka vill., 28-31. vii. 1964 (Tsvetayev) (ZI); 1 cf, 1 $, Suputinskiy Reserve, bred from<tei:lb/>larva in fungus, 14. v. 1967 (Mamaev) (BMNH; ZI); 2 $, Ussuri Railway, Chabarovsk, 14. vii. 1910 &amp;<tei:lb/>23. vii. 1911 (Borsow) (BMNH); 1 ex., data not recorded (ZI). Japan: 1 cf , Ehime Pref., Mt Sara, bred<tei:lb/>from Fames fomentarius , em. 8. v. 1954 (Hisamatsu) (genitalia slide; coll. S. Moriuti, Osaka).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The wing-pattern of this species and the morphology of the male genitalia are very similar to<tei:lb/>those of boletella (see 'Remarks' for that species) and caucasica. The female genitalia, however, are<tei:lb/>markedly different, lacking the triangular membranous lobe dorsal to the ostium and having the eighth<tei:lb/>sternite conspicuously modified as described above.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caradja's record of 'boletella' from China, probably referable to this species, has not been confirmed by<tei:lb/>examination of the original specimen.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scardia allenisp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 37, 152)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 37). $, 31 mm. Coloration and external structure similar to boletella but frons and vertex<tei:lb/>brownish yellow, maxillary palpus dark purple-brown, thorax cream, tegula dark purple-brown. Forewing<tei:lb/>with pale markings almost obliterated by dark purple-brown, a few silvery white scales close to posterior<tei:lb/>margin at one-half; terminal fascia composed of discrete silvery white spots not speckled with brown as in<tei:lb/>boletella. Hindwing charcoal grey, a few slightly paler flecks towards apex, fringe not chequered.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf . Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Fig. 152). Eighth tergite slightly longer than eighth sternite, with four pairs of elongate,<tei:lb/>strong setae close to posterior margin, and with a few scattered minute thorn-like setae; eighth sternite<tei:lb/>separated by membranous sutures into roughly triangular mediocaudal and lateral sclerites; mediocaudal<tei:lb/>region rugose, posterior margin strongly concave, with five pairs of strong setae and numerous smaller<tei:lb/>setae; ostium overlain dorsally by triangular membranous lobe, wall of ovipositor dorsal and slightly<tei:lb/>posterior to apex of lobe ballooned ventrad to form pair of shallow lobes. Antrum very short, conical,<tei:lb/>sclerotized strongly at anterior end and forming a colliculum-like constriction. Ductus bursae thick-walled,<tei:lb/>with strong and regular transverse constrictions on inner surface (this apparent restriction to the inner<tei:lb/>surface may be an artefact caused by separation of the outer layer of the membrane of the ductus). Corpus<tei:lb/>bursae contiguous with ductus, elongately ovoid, reaching 1-5 length of apophyses anteriores; signa<tei:lb/>absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Borneo -Brunei.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 ex.<tei:lb/>Holotype $, Brunei: Labi, lowland forest, 60 m, 12. i. 1980 (Allen) (genitalia slide no. 1517; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Of the six Scardia species, alleni is the darkest, the pale terminal and posterior fasciae of the<tei:lb/>forewing being markedly reduced in comparison with the other species. The hindwing is distinctively<tei:lb/>darker than in the other species. The genitalia resemble those of boletella and caucasica in that there is a<tei:lb/>triangular membranous lobe dorsal to the ostium, but the ventral margin of the ostium lacks the deep U- or<tei:lb/>V-shaped invagination of these species and the membranous lobe lacks a terminal sclerite.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The locality in which the holotype was collected is on the Rampayoh River in an area of low hills forested<tei:lb/>with typical lowland dipterocarp forest (Allen, pers. comm.).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scardia boletella (Fabricius) nom. rev.<tei:lb/>(Figs 38, 99, 155)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[Phalaena (Tinea) gigantella [Denis &amp; Schiffermuller]; Hiibner, 1790: 38, pi. 2(2), fig. F. Misidentifica-<tei:lb/>tion.l</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 91</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tinea boletella Fabricius, 1794: 287. LECTOTYPE (?) $, [AUSTRIA or SWEDEN], (ZM), here designated</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phycis \boleti Fabricius, 1798: 463. Unjustified emendation of boletella.<tei:lb/>Noctua polypori Esper, [1804]: pi. 196, fig. 1; [1805]: 64. Unnecessary objective replacement name for</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phycis boleti F., 1798 (cited as Tinea Boleti') which is an unjustified emendation of Tinea boletella F.,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1794.<tei:lb/>Duomitella relicta Koshantschikov, 1923: 23. Syntypes, 1 cf, 1 $, U.S.S.R. (ZI) [examined]. [Synony-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>mized by Zagulajev, 1973: 89.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Hubner, 1796: pi. 3, fig. 18; Esper, [1804]: pi. 196, fig. 1; Zagulajev, 1973: figs 31, 32, 66, pi. 2, fig.<tei:lb/>1; Fig. 38). Cf $ , 37-60 mm. Vertex and frons brownish cream, brown close to eyes. Labial palpus cream,<tei:lb/>brown on outer surface of first and second segment and in middle of third segment. Maxillary palpus cream<tei:lb/>flecked with brown. Antennal scape, pedicel and flagellum dark brown; cilia 1-2 x (cf) or 0-7 x (9)<tei:lb/>flagellar diameter. Thorax cream flecked with brown; tegula brown, cream posteriorly. Forewing cream,<tei:lb/>strongly patterned with dark purple-brown, with orange-brown on veins; cream coloration almost<tei:lb/>obliterated by brown and restricted to termen and posterior margin, with a few pale flecks towards costa;<tei:lb/>fringe conspicuously chequered. Hind wing light grey-brown, pale flecks towards apex; fringe chequered.<tei:lb/>Legs cream, strongly flecked with brown but pale at articulations; outer mid-tibial spur 0-6 length of inner;<tei:lb/>outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-7 length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Petersen, 1957: fig. 238; Zagulajev, 1973: figs 14B, 67; Fig. 99). Saccus broad, shallow;<tei:lb/>uncus lobes flattened laterally, strongly sclerotized, setose and tapered to a point; tegumen with dorsal<tei:lb/>emargination bearing five or six pairs of strong spines; dorsal region of fusion of uncus lobes and tegumen<tei:lb/>broad, with shallow lateral invaginations. Subscaphium not developed, but membrane in this region with<tei:lb/>lateral patches of lamellate microtrichia. Juxta broadly V-shaped, fused laterally with valvae, extended<tei:lb/>distally into pair of horn-shaped processes; transtilla not developed. Valva simple but with shallow and<tei:lb/>rugose costal flap and with mediobasal fold; apical margin with broadly U-shaped emargination. Aedeagus<tei:lb/>10 x as long as broad, strongly sclerotized but simple; vesica with minute spicular cornuti (microtrichia)<tei:lb/>close to inception of ductus ejaculatorius (i.e. at apex if vesica were everted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Petersen, 1957: fig. 239; Zagulajev, 1973: figs 68, 69; Fig. 155). Eighth tergite slightly longer<tei:lb/>than eighth sternite, with slightly concave caudal margin, with four pairs of strong marginal setae at<tei:lb/>posterior corners and seven or eight pairs of smaller submarginal setae; eighth sternite oval, strongly<tei:lb/>keeled, ventral margin of ostium V-shaped, with small medial emargination; lobes either side of ostium<tei:lb/>each bearing six stout setae and a few smaller setae; ostium surmounted by membranous posteriorly-<tei:lb/>extended lobe bearing elongate heart-shaped sclerite with shallow lateral invaginations; posterior to lobe<tei:lb/>and sclerite a deep anteriorly-directed pocket forming a 'false antrum'. Antrum hardly sclerotized, tapered<tei:lb/>anteriorly, reaching anterior margin of eighth sternite; inception of ductus seminalis just anterior to<tei:lb/>colliculum-like apex of antrum. Ductus bursae one-half length of apophyses anteriores, with irregular<tei:lb/>transverse constrictions, very thin-walled. Corpus bursae ovoid, very thin-walled, reaching 1-3 length of<tei:lb/>apophyses anteriores.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Norway (Aarvik &amp; Midtgaard, 1982); Sweden (Petersen, 1957); Finland (Jalava, 1977);<tei:lb/>U.S.S.R. - Baltic and European regions, Crimea, Siberia (Zagulajev, 1973); West Germany (Petersen,<tei:lb/>1968); Czechoslovakia (Petersen, 1965); Hungary (Petersen, 1957); Rumania; Austria (Petersen, 1957);<tei:lb/>Switzerland (Rebel, 1901); Italy (Petersen &amp; Gaedike, 1979); Yugoslavia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. See Zagulajev (1973: 93) - bred from Fomes, Ganoderma and Polyporus. Zagulajev (1973: figs<tei:lb/>20, 22, 26, 27) illustrates the larva. The biology is also described briefly by Mitterberger (1910: 171) and<tei:lb/>Koshantschikov (1923). The latter author found three live pupae enclosed in webbed frass on fungi on a<tei:lb/>dead birch, and he also found three large larvae (which he preserved) in the fungus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 54 ex., 4 pupae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lectotype (?)$&gt; (of boletella) (abdomen missing), [Austria or Sweden]: labelled 'boleti' in Fabricius'<tei:lb/>hand (Sehested &amp; Tender Lund collection, ZM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Syntypes (of relicta), U.S.S.R.: Siberia, Irkutsk, Minussinsk dist., Sajan Mts, Tiberkul Lake: 1 cf,<tei:lb/>21.vii., 1 $, 17.vii.1920 (Koshantschikov) (ZI).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>37 ex., 4 pupae (ZI) and 15 ex. (BMNH), various localities (see 'Distribution' and Zagulajev (1973)).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Esper expressly proposed the name polypori as a replacement name for 'Tinea Boleti' which he<tei:lb/>considered preoccupied by Noctua boleti F. , 1777.<tei:lb/>This species is one of the largest Tineidae and has a wide but sporadic boreo-alpine/cold temperate</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>92</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>distribution in the western Palaearctic region, occurring in montane localities as far south as Italy and<tei:lb/>Yugoslavia. It may be separated from all other Scardia by the genitalia, characteristic in both sexes but very<tei:lb/>similar indeed to those of caucasica; the latter species represents an isolated geographical race of boletella<tei:lb/>only arguably deserving of specific status. With caucasica, boletella may be separated from all other Scardia<tei:lb/>by the elongate and pointed lobes of the uncus in the male and by the triangular membranous lobe that<tei:lb/>overlies the ostium of the female and terminates in a laterally invaginated sclerite. The only other Scardia<tei:lb/>with pointed uncus lobes is amurensis (although they may also occur in alleni when the male of that species<tei:lb/>is discovered) in which the tegumen forms a shallow triangular hood above the uncus lobes (the tegumen is<tei:lb/>emarginate in boletella and caucasica) and in which the apex of the aedeagus is conspicuously explanate. S.<tei:lb/>alleni has a similar membranous lobe overyling the ostium in the female but the lobe is not sclerotized at its<tei:lb/>apex. The pronounced allopatry of the Scardia species is helpful in identification although further<tei:lb/>collecting may show the presently disjunct distributions to be artefactual.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scardia caucasica Zagulajev</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 39, 100, 156)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scardia caucasica Zagulajev, 1965: 412, figs 2, 3. Holotype C? , U.S.S.R. (ZI) [examined].<tei:lb/>ADULT (Zagulajev, 1973: fig. 70; Fig. 39). $ , 44 mm. Coloration and external structure similar to boletella.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Zagulajev, 1965: figs 3, 19; 1968: fig. 16; 1973: fig. 72; Fig. 100). Similar to boletella but<tei:lb/>dorsal margins of uncus lobes not extended as far caudally (in lateral view); dorsal region of tegumen<tei:lb/>narrow, with deep lateral indentations; valva with costal flap hardly developed, apical margin only<tei:lb/>shallowly concave.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Zagulajev, 1965: fig. 2; 1968: fig. 17; 1973: fig. 73; Fig. 156). Similar to boletella but eighth<tei:lb/>tergite with only three pairs of large setae and two or three pairs of small setae; ventral margin of ostium<tei:lb/>deeper, V-shaped; lobes either side of ostium more elongate, each with four strong setae arranged in a<tei:lb/>diagonal line at one-half, smaller setae concentrated at apex. Lobe dorsal to ostium broader and shorter,<tei:lb/>with dome-shaped terminal sclerite with small, deep lateral invaginations.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. U.S.S.R. - Caucasus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. Zagulajev (1973) collected a male of this species on a fungus-infested ash trunk.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 10 ex., 4 pupae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , U.S.S.R.: Caucasus, Georgia, Lagodekhi, 8.viii.l961 (Zagulajev) (ZI).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>U.S.S.R.: Caucasus: 1 cf, Tbilisi dist., Manglis, 13.ix.1882 (Christoph) (ZI); 1 &lt;j&gt;, 4.viii.l891 (Hede-<tei:lb/>mann) (ZI); 1 $, Lagodekhi, 1888 (Mlokosevitch) (ZI); 2 cf , 3 $, Lagodekhi, wet forest in lower zone of<tei:lb/>reserve, 27-30. vii and 8.viii.l961 (Zagulajev) (ZI; 1 $ in BMNH) (all paratypes); 1 cf, Armenia,<tei:lb/>Idzfrevanskiy dist., 30 km from Sevkar, Kerants Monastery, on fungus-infested ash trunk at dusk,<tei:lb/>31.vii.1960 (Zagulajev) (ZI).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. For differentiation of this species from boletella, see above; see also 'Remarks' for boletella.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PERILICMETIS Meyrick</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Perilicmetis Meyrick, 1932ft: 323. Type-species: Perilicmetis diplaca Meyrick, 1932ft: 324, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Antenna (male) lacking dorsal cilia, ventral surface scaled; cilia shorter than 1-5 x flagellar<tei:lb/>diameter. Scape with fewer than 15 pecten bristles. Interocular index (male) greater than 1-0. Maxillary<tei:lb/>palpus with fewer than 5 segments; pilifers present; second segment of labial palpus shorter than width of<tei:lb/>head. Outer mid and proximal hind tibial spurs &gt;0-4 length of inner spurs. Forewing with R 3 and R 4<tei:lb/>separate; M 3 and CuA\ stalked or very closely approximated at base; light grey speckled with dark brown,<tei:lb/>with broad, dark brown, oblique subterminal fascia. Male with coremata in eighth abdominal segment;<tei:lb/>coremata without associated apodemes. Male genitalia with complex uncus fused with tegumen; tegumen<tei:lb/>unbroken, completely sclerotized dorsally; valva lacking basal setose lobe on inner surface; apex of valva<tei:lb/>not forming ventral hook or hooks, without spines; valvae separate, not fused together ventrally, without<tei:lb/>longitudinal cleft; saccus longer than wide; juxta simple, entire, not divided medially; vesica lacking<tei:lb/>spicular cornuti; aedeagus with spicular or spinose carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. Forewing with oblique dark brown subterminal fascia constricted in<tei:lb/>middle to form a pair of large, narrowly connected spots; remainder of forewing light grey, finely speckled<tei:lb/>with dark brown.</tei:p>

      </tei:div>
