         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 93</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Neotropical region - Brazil.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Perilicmetis diplaca Meyrick</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 40, 102, 180)<tei:lb/>Perilicmetis diplaca Meyrick, 1932ft: 324. LECTOTYPE cf , BRAZIL (NM), here designated [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Figs 40, 180). cf, 17-22 mm. Vertex and frons chocolate brown. Labial palpus chocolate brown,<tei:lb/>outer surface of third segment darker. Maxillary palpus buff, dark brown above, 4-segmented, short,<tei:lb/>reaching only basal one-sixth of second segment of labial palpus. Antennal scape buff, large dark brown<tei:lb/>spot above; pedicel dark brown; flagellum pale buff; cilia 0-8 x flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula<tei:lb/>greyish white flecked with dark brown anteriorly. Forewing greyish white, strongly flecked with dark<tei:lb/>brown; conspicuous oblique subterminal fascia formed from pair of large dark brown spots. Hindwing very<tei:lb/>pale greyish brown, whitish towards base. Legs pale buff; foreleg and mid-leg strongly marked with dark<tei:lb/>brown above and on sides but pale at articulations; hind tarsus banded with brown; outer mid-tibial spur<tei:lb/>0-45 length of inner; outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-5 length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Fig. 102). Saccus triangular; uncus lobes separated, strongly fused with tegumen, tapered<tei:lb/>and divergent apically, well-sclerotized, setose. Subscaphium not developed. Juxta represented by only<tei:lb/>slight ventral thickening of anellus; transtilla not developed. Valva elongate, broad, simple, apex forming<tei:lb/>slight dorsal hook. Aedeagus 8 x as long as broad, somewhat flattened dorsoventrally, with dense spinose<tei:lb/>carinae on ventral surface; vesica without cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $. Unknown.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. Brazil.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 7 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lectotype cf , Brazil: Santa Catharina, Neu Bremen, 23. ii. 1931 (Hoffmann) (NM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Brazil: 2 cf , (paralectotypes) Santa Catharina, Jaragua, 24.viii.1929, 16.ix.1930 (Hoffmann) (BMNH;<tei:lb/>NM); 1 cf, Sao Paulo (Jones) (BMNH); 1 cf, Parana, Castro, x.1895 (Jones) (BMNH); 1 cf, Santa<tei:lb/>Catharina, Neu Bremen, 2.ix.l936 (Hoffmann) (genitalia slide no. 6966; BMNH); 1 cf , Santa Catharina,<tei:lb/>18.iii.1936 (Hoffmann) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The external appearance of this species is very distinctive, the wing-pattern being unlike that of<tei:lb/>any other tineid known to me. Although the specimens examined are old and probably faded, the forewing<tei:lb/>ground-colour is distinctly greyish. The only other scardiines that could be thought of as greyish are the<tei:lb/>Amorophaga species. The genitalia of Perilicmetis resemble superficially those of Amorophaga but the<tei:lb/>valva is much more simple and the tegumen is complete dorsally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MOSCARDIA gen. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type-species: Myrmecozela renitens Meyrick, 1922ft: 591.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Antenna (male) lacking dorsal cilia, ventral surface scaled; cilia shorter than 1-5 x flagellar<tei:lb/>diameter. Scape with fewer than 15 pecten bristles. Interocular index (male) greater than 1-0. Maxillary<tei:lb/>palpus 5-segmented in renitens but probably with fewer (four or three) segments in varna; pilifers present;<tei:lb/>second segment of labial palpus shorter than width of head. Outer mid and proximal hind tibial spurs &gt;0-4<tei:lb/>length of inner spurs. Forewing with /? 3 and R 4 separate; M 2 , M 3 and CuA\ separate; pattern consisting of<tei:lb/>pale termen and dorsum on darker ground-colour. Male with coremata in eighth abdominal segment;<tei:lb/>coremata associated with short, lobe-like apodemes at anterior corners of eighth sternite. Male genitalia<tei:lb/>with complex uncus fused with tegumen; tegumen unbroken, completely sclerotized dorsally (but broken<tei:lb/>dorsally by a membranous suture line in renitens) ; valva lacking basal setose lobe on inner surface; apex of<tei:lb/>valva forming ventral hook or hooks, or with spines; valvae separate, not fused together ventrally, without<tei:lb/>longitudinal cleft; saccus longer than wide; juxta simple, entire, not divided medially; vesica lacking<tei:lb/>spicular cornuti; aedeagus with spicular or spinose carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. None; however, males ofMoscardia species may be recognized externally<tei:lb/>by their brown forewing with pale apex and dorsum and completely scaled antenna with short cilia;</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>94 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>exclusive microscopic characters are the short apodemes of the eighth sternite in combination with minute<tei:lb/>microtrichia on the second sternite.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Neotropical region -Brazil, Bolivia.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species of Moscardia (only males are known)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Tegumen broken by dorsal line of membrane, without processes; uncus lobes strongly sclero-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>tized and with serrate subapical ridge renitens (p. 94)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tegumen complete dorsally, strongly sclerotized, with pair of small lanceolate caudal processes;<tei:lb/>uncus lobes almost membranous, apices rounded (Fig. 104) varna (p. 95)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Moscardia renitens (Meyrick) comb. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 41)<tei:lb/>Myrmecozela renitens Meyrick, 19226: 591. Holotype cf , BRAZIL (BMNH) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Clarke, 1970: pi. 32, fig. 3; Fig. 41). d", 22 mm. Vertex and frons pale whitish ochre, frons strongly<tei:lb/>tinted reddish brown. Labial palpus very dark brown on outer surface but cream at articulation between<tei:lb/>second and third segments and at tip; inner surface light brown on second segment, cream on third.<tei:lb/>Maxillary palpus short, not as long as second segment of labial palpus, but probably 5-segmented, dark<tei:lb/>brown. Antennal scape and pedicel cream, flecked with light brown; flagellum brownish cream, darker<tei:lb/>brown on basal few segments; cilia 0-8 x (cf ) flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula medium brown, whitish<tei:lb/>posteriorly. Forewing badly rubbed; traces of pattern present only at margins, brownish cream flecked with<tei:lb/>light brown, strongly spotted with dark brown at costa and with strong dark brown spot on posterior margin<tei:lb/>at two-thirds. Hindwing light greyish brown with slight purple iridescence. Legs cream flecked with brown;<tei:lb/>foreleg and mid-leg strongly marked with dark brown above and on sides but pale at articulations, outer<tei:lb/>surface of mid-tibia with broad oblique whitish band; outer mid-tibial spur 0-5 length of inner spur [hind<tei:lb/>legs missing].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Clarke, 1970: pi. 32, figs. 3a, 3b). Saccus elongate, triangular, almost as long as valva; uncus<tei:lb/>lobes triangular, strongly sclerotized, fused with tegumen but with incomplete membranous suture<tei:lb/>forming line of flexion, with serrate subapical ridge. Subscaphium apparently not developed (but<tei:lb/>preparation poor). Juxta apparently large and shield-shaped (but preparation damaged in this area and<tei:lb/>difficult to interpret); transtilla apparently not developed. Valva simple, with small setose lobe on costa at<tei:lb/>three-quarters and with three small peg-like apical processes; membranous subapical suture on outer<tei:lb/>surface. Aedeagus stout, 5 x as long as broad, asymmetrical, with three strong, subapical horn-shaped<tei:lb/>carinae directed caudally, and with three similar but smaller anteriorly-directed carinae closer to apex;<tei:lb/>vesica without cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $. Unknown.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. Brazil.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 ex.<tei:lb/>Holotype cf , Brazil: Teffe, i.1920 (Parish) (genitalia slide no. JFGC 6653; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The condition of the holotype of this species, and of the slide of its genitalia, is such that<tei:lb/>description of the forewing pattern and of the juxta/transtilla/subscaphium region is not possible. Despite<tei:lb/>this, the genitalia are characterized simply by the structure of the uncus lobes and the valva. M. renitens<tei:lb/>differs from varna in that the maxillary palpus of the latter, while as long as that of renitens, has apparently<tei:lb/>only three segments. In varna the tegumen is strongly sclerotized and unbroken dorsally and the uncus<tei:lb/>lobes are almost membranous; the tegumen is produced caudally to form a pair of small, rhomboidal<tei:lb/>processes. In renitens the tegumen is broken dorsally by a zone of membrane, the uncus lobes are strongly<tei:lb/>sclerotized, and there are no processes from the tegumen.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There is no trace of a pattern of pale apex and dorsum on the forewings of the holotype of renitens.<tei:lb/>Although the specimen is very rubbed, I would have expected to find traces of such a pattern, had one<tei:lb/>been present. It is possible, therefore, that this species and varna have quite different forewing patterns.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 95</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Moscardia varna sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 42, 104)<tei:lb/>[Phycis luctuosa Walsingham, 1914: 358, partim- 1 cf only. Misidentification.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 42). cf , 17 mm. Vertex and frons brownish cream. Labial palpus dark brown on outer surface,<tei:lb/>paler on inner surface and at apex. Maxillary palpus short, not as long as second segment of labial palpus,<tei:lb/>probably 4- or 3-segmented, dark brown. Antennal scape and pedicel dark brown above; flagellum light<tei:lb/>grey-brown; cilia 1-0 x (cf) flagellar diameter; (thorax obscured by glue). Tegula medium brown.<tei:lb/>Forewing deep purple-brown, with continuous golden brown posterior and terminal fascia occupying more<tei:lb/>than half of total wing area; scales close to junction with deep brown anterior fascia pale gold, increasing<tei:lb/>the contrast between the two. Hindwing dark grey. Legs greyish-ochreous (worn and damaged).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Fig. 104). Saccus elongate, triangular; uncus lobes small, inturned ventrad, almost<tei:lb/>membranous, setose, surmounted by strongly sclerotized tegumen with pair of small rhomboidal<tei:lb/>mediocaudal processes. Subscaphium not developed. Juxta represented only by slight thickening of<tei:lb/>anellus; transtilla not developed. Valva elongate, twice length of saccus, extending well beyond apices of<tei:lb/>tegumen lobes; simple, with small and shallow triangular lobe bearing 6 small setae at two-thirds of costa;<tei:lb/>apex of valva rounded, with spinose setae. Aedeagus stout, 6 x as long as broad, with, either side,<tei:lb/>subapical group of two triangular basally-directed carinae; vesica without cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $. Unknown.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. Bolivia.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Bolivia: Yungas de la Paz, 1908 (Seebold) (genitalia slide no. 13122; BMNH) (paralecto-<tei:lb/>type of Phycis luctuosa Walsingham).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. See 'Remarks' for renitens for differentiation from that species. The external appearance of<tei:lb/>varna, with strongly developed, continuous and extensive distal and posterior fasciae on the forewing, is<tei:lb/>characteristic: the posterior pale fascia extends further anteriorly than in any other species dealt with here.<tei:lb/>The aedeagus is only lightly sclerotized and has suffered slight damage during preparation. The anellus has<tei:lb/>been torn and has peeled back the wall of the aedeagus from close to the carinae . Interpretation is therefore<tei:lb/>difficult but there appear to be a pair of elongate, sinuate processes that originally commenced as ridges at<tei:lb/>the base of the aedeagus and reached the apices of the (backward-directed) carinae. These are now folded<tei:lb/>backward from close to the base of the aedeagus and lie within a fold of the anellus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENTINGIA gen. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type-species: Gentingia hollowayi sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Antenna (male) lacking dorsal cilia, ventral surface scaled; cilia longer than 1-5 x flagellar<tei:lb/>diameter. Scape with fewer than 15 pecten bristles. Interocular index (male) greater than 1-0. Maxillary<tei:lb/>palpus with fewer than 5 segments; pilifers present; second segment of labial palpus shorter than width of<tei:lb/>head. Outer mid and proximal hind tibial spurs &gt;0-4 length of inner spurs. Forewing with R 3 and R 4 stalked<tei:lb/>or very closely approximated at base; M 2 , A/ 3 and CuA^ separate; ground-colour very pale bronze, with<tei:lb/>pattern of small purple-brown marginal spots and larger costal blotch. Male with coremata in eighth<tei:lb/>abdominal segment; coremata without associated apodemes. Male genitalia with complex uncus fused with<tei:lb/>tegumen; tegumen unbroken, completely sclerotized dorsally; valva lacking basal setose lobe on inner<tei:lb/>surface; apex of valva not forming ventral hook or hooks, without spines; valvae fused ventrally, without<tei:lb/>longitudinal cleft; saccus longer than wide; juxta, if present, fused with valvae and not recognizable as<tei:lb/>such; vesica with spicular cornuti; aedeagus with spicular or spinose carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. Male with tegumen produced laterocaudally into pair of hooked processes;<tei:lb/>female with scobinate signum surrounding inception of ductus bursae in corpus bursae; interior surface of<tei:lb/>ductus bursae denticulate anteriorly, posteriorly with overlapping scale-like plaques.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Oriental region- Malay Peninsula, Borneo.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>96 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gentingia hollowayisp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 43, 103, 157, 184)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Figs 43, 184). O"$, 16-19 mm. Vertex and frons pale yellow-brown. Labial palpus ochreous,<tei:lb/>strongly suffused with brown on outer surface but pale at apex and articulations. Maxillary palpus whitish,<tei:lb/>flecked with dark brown above, short, apparently 3-segmented. Antennal scape and pedicel ochreous,<tei:lb/>flecked above with dark brown ; flagellum light greyish ochreous , with darker scales basidorsally ; cilia 1 5 x<tei:lb/>(O") orO-5 x (5) flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula cream, strongly flecked anteriorly with dark brown.<tei:lb/>Forewing pale golden, strongly spotted with dark purple-brown along costa and termen; strong wedge-<tei:lb/>shaped dark blotch from costa across end of cell to CuP; conspicuous (but frequently abraded) dark spot on<tei:lb/>middle of dorsum. Hindwing off-white. Legs ochreous cream, foreleg and mid-leg dark brown above;<tei:lb/>outer mid-tibial spur and outer hind proximal tibial spur 0-6 length of inner spurs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Fig. 103). Saccus triangular, strongly tapered anteriorly; uncus lobes short, small, strongly<tei:lb/>sclerotized, curved ventrad, burin-shaped, setose, entirely fused with tegumen; tegumen with pair of<tei:lb/>lateral hook-shaped processes. Subscaphium not developed. Juxta, if present, entirely fused with valvae<tei:lb/>and not recognizable ; transtilla not developed . Valvae strongly fused ventrally to form single movable unit ;<tei:lb/>medioventrally with an m-shaped projecting caudal margin, overlying this a medial thimble-shaped<tei:lb/>process; apices of valvae rounded, dorsal to the medial structures and extending caudally beyond them;<tei:lb/>inner margins of valvae emarginate at level of m-shaped process; ventral surface of valva smooth, apically<tei:lb/>and dorsally with numerous setae, dorsal margin (costa) hardly sclerotized but with line of about six strong<tei:lb/>setae. Aedeagus tapered, 12 x as long as broad in middle, with lateral bands of thorn-like carinae from<tei:lb/>one-half to apex; vesica with minute blunt lepidote cornuti (?microtrichia).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Fig. 157). Eighth tergite considerably longer than eighth sternite, with two subapical pairs of<tei:lb/>elongate strong setae, three or four pairs of smaller setae at posterior corners, and with scattered pits in<tei:lb/>caudal half; eighth sternite triangular, deeply pocketed laterally, apex with V-shaped emargination<tei:lb/>interrupted by keel-like mediocaudal process with bilobed tip, each lobe bearing pair of elongate strong<tei:lb/>setae and a few small setae. Antrum broad, funnel-shaped posteriorly then tubular and slightly asymmet-<tei:lb/>rical, meeting ductus seminalis at two-thirds anteriorly, reaching 0-75 length of apophyses anteriores,<tei:lb/>anterior end strongly microtrichiate, microtrichia extending into ductus bursae. Ductus bursae very<tei:lb/>thick-walled, internal surface strongly lepidote, the scale-like surface projections arranged in a regular<tei:lb/>transverse pattern giving the appearance of very fine regular constrictions under low-powered magnifica-<tei:lb/>tion; lepidote projections highly developed anteriorly, resembling sharks' teeth, and continuous with<tei:lb/>denticles of signum. Corpus bursae thin-walled, with U-shaped denticular signum surrounding inception of<tei:lb/>ductus bursae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Malay Peninsula; Borneo (Fig. 200).<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 3 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , West Malaysia: W. Pahang, Genting Highlands, ca 4400', 23. xi. 1981 (Tuck) (genitalia<tei:lb/>slide no. 9479; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Sarawak: 1 cf , MtDulit, R. Koyan, 2500', primary forest, river-bank vegetation, 18. xi. 1932<tei:lb/>(Hobby &amp; Moore) (BMNH); 1 $ , Gunung Mulu National Park, G. Mulu site 14 - camp 2.5, G.R. 413461,<tei:lb/>1000 m, lower montane forest, at m.v. light in canopy or understorey, ii.1978 (Holloway et al.) (genitalia<tei:lb/>slide no. 9482; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This taxon is distinctively patterned and structurally atypical. The wing-pattern strongly<tei:lb/>resembles that of Semeoloncha from West Africa and there are genital similarities in the male, notably in<tei:lb/>the structure of the tegumen and uncus lobes. The valvae of the two genera are very different, however,<tei:lb/>Semeoloncha having a pair of separated soft, lobate, strongly setose valvae with an extraordinary process<tei:lb/>from the modified apodeme. Both genera have an atypically-shaped saccus and both have a tapered<tei:lb/>aedeagus; however, the aedeagus is smooth-surfaced in Semeoloncha but with numerous thorn-like<tei:lb/>carinae in Gentingia. The female genitalia of Semeoloncha are unknown; however, the genitalia of<tei:lb/>Gentingia differ from those of all other Scardiinae in the peculiar shape of the eighth sternite and in the<tei:lb/>presence of a single U-shaped denticulate signum at the point of inception of the ductus bursae on the<tei:lb/>corpus bursae.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 97</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SEMEOLONCHA Gozmany</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Semeoloncha Gozmany, 1968: 332. Type-species: Semeoloncha penicillata Gozmany, 1968: 324, by<tei:lb/>original designation and monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Antenna (male) with dorsal cilia, ventral surface scaled; cilia shorter than 1-5 x flagellar<tei:lb/>diameter. Scape with fewer than 15 pecten bristles. Interocular index (male) greater than 1-0. Maxillary<tei:lb/>palpus 5-segmented; pilifers present; second segment of labial palpus shorter than width of head. Outer<tei:lb/>mid and proximal hind tibial spurs &gt;0-4 length of inner spurs. Forewing with /? 3 and R 4 separate; A/ 3 and<tei:lb/>CuA\ stalked or very closely approximated at base; ground-colour very pale bronze, with pattern of small,<tei:lb/>purple-brown marginal spots and larger costal blotch. Male with coremata in eighth abdominal segment;<tei:lb/>coremata associated with short, lobe-like apodemes at anterior corners of eighth sternite. Male genitalia<tei:lb/>with complex uncus fused with tegumen; tegumen unbroken, completely sclerotized dorsally; valva lacking<tei:lb/>basal setose lobe on inner surface; apex of valva not forming ventral hook or hooks, without spines; valvae<tei:lb/>separate, not fused together ventrally, without longitudinal cleft; saccus longer than wide; juxta simple,<tei:lb/>entire, not divided medially; vesica with spicular cornuti; aedeagus smooth-surfaced, without spicular<tei:lb/>carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. Male with eighth tergite reduced, narrow and rod-like, broadening<tei:lb/>anteriorly, thus T-shaped. Coremata very large, recessed as far as anterior margin of seventh segment;<tei:lb/>apodeme of valva with strong, arcuate dorsal process arising at one-third from apodeme base and directed<tei:lb/>caudally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Afrotropical region - Sierra Leone.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Semeoloncha penicillata Gozmany</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 44)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Semeoloncha penicillata Gozmany, 1968: 334. Holotype cf , SIERRA LEONE (BMNH) [examined].<tei:lb/>Semeoloncha penicillata Gozmany; Gozmany &amp; Vari, 1973: 152, fig. 460.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 44). cf , 20 mm. Vertex and frons whitish. Labial palpus whitish, strongly flecked with brown<tei:lb/>on outer and upper surfaces of first and base of second segment. Maxillary palpus cream, flecked above<tei:lb/>with brown, short, 5-segmented, not reaching one-half length of second segment of labial palpus. Antenna<tei:lb/>cream; cilia 0-25 x (cf ) flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula cream, slightly darker anteriorly. Forewing<tei:lb/>very pale golden or straw-coloured (probably very faded) with small light brown marginal spots, these<tei:lb/>merged to form a terminal line between /? 4 and M 3 ; larger conspicuous spots just beyond one-half on costa<tei:lb/>and subtornally. Hindwing pale greyish cream with inconspicuous brown blotches on apical margin. Legs<tei:lb/>cream; fore-tibia and fore-tarsus marked above with brown but conspicuously pale at articulations; outer<tei:lb/>mid-tibial spur and outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-7 length of inner spurs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Gozmany, 1968: figs 46-48; Gozmany &amp; Vari, 1973: fig. 460). (For description of the caudal<tei:lb/>region of the abdomen, see 'Remarks'.) Saccus diamond-shaped, almost as long as tegumen + uncus;<tei:lb/>uncus lobes entirely fused with and subsumed into tegumen, possibly forming the setose caudal margin;<tei:lb/>tegumen + uncus cowl-shaped, with strongly melanized horn-like lateral processes. Subscaphium not<tei:lb/>developed. Juxta not developed but anellus swollen to form irregular and microtrichiate lobe at base of<tei:lb/>each valva; transtilla not developed. Valvae closely appressed (but not fused) basally, lobate, setose;<tei:lb/>apodemes extraordinarily elongate, each with long and arcuate caudally-directed spike arising from dorsal<tei:lb/>surface two-thirds from apex. Aedeagus tapered, stout, 7 x as long as broad in middle; apex extended as a<tei:lb/>narrow tapering band of sclerotization; vesica with minute spicular cornuti (?microtrichia).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ . Unknown.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. Sierra Leone.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 2 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Sierra Leone: vii.1895 (Clements) (genitalia slide no. 14997; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sierra Leone: 1 cf (paratype), data as holotype but v.1895 (genitalia slide no. 15008; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. When examined originally, both genitalia preparations of this species (only two specimens are<tei:lb/>known) were very poor. The basal three abdominal segments of the holotype remained attached to the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>98 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>specimen but the remainder of the abdomen had been thrown away, leaving only the badly compressed<tei:lb/>genitalia and aedeagus on the slide. In the case of the paratype, the terminal two abdominal segments only<tei:lb/>had been retained; these were damaged and contorted, making the structure impossible to interpret. The<tei:lb/>genital armature was so badly crushed that it had split longitudinally down the tegumen. Like the holotype,<tei:lb/>it was grossly overstained. It was thus impossible to determine the structure of the subscaphium, juxta or<tei:lb/>transtilla, or to code enough information for inclusion of Semeoloncha in the numerical analyses.<tei:lb/>Remounting of both preparations after rehydration, cleaning and differentiating clarified the structure of<tei:lb/>the diaphragma and details of the seventh and eighth segment. The eighth sternite is broad and the<tei:lb/>coremata are set in the sternite rather than in the pleural membrane: the dorsal margin of the corematal<tei:lb/>invagination is strengthened, forming the lateral margin of a dorsal triangular complex consisting of<tei:lb/>sternite (lateral and outer anterior margins), tergite (medial rod-shaped structure with expanded anterior<tei:lb/>end) and pleural membrane (region with small spiracle either side of rod-like tergite). This extraordinary<tei:lb/>structure and the extreme modification of the valval apodeme serve to distinguish Semeoloncha from all<tei:lb/>other scardiine taxa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CRANAODES Meyrick<tei:lb/>Cranaodes Meyrick, 1919: 238. Type-species: Cranaodes stereopa Meyrick, 1919: 239, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Antenna (male) lacking dorsal cilia, ventral surface scaled; cilia longer than 1-5 x flagellar<tei:lb/>diameter. Scape with fewer than 15 pecten bristles. Interocular index (male) 1-0 or less. Maxillary palpus<tei:lb/>5-segmented; pilifers present; second segment of labial palpus shorter than width of head. Outer mid and<tei:lb/>proximal hind tibial spurs &gt;O4 length of inner spurs. Forewing with /? 3 and /? 4 separate; M 2 , A/ 3 and CuA\<tei:lb/>separate; ground-colour pale bronze, with pattern formed of large purple-brown blotches (but ground-<tei:lb/>colour paler and blotches more extensive in oroya). Male with coremata in eighth abdominal segment;<tei:lb/>coremata associated with short, lobe-like apodemes at anterior corners of eighth sternite. Male genitalia<tei:lb/>with complex uncus fused with tegumen; tegumen broken dorsally by at least a membranous suture line;<tei:lb/>valva lacking basal setose lobe on inner surface; apex of valva not forming ventral hook or hooks, without<tei:lb/>spines; valvae separate, not fused together ventrally, without longitudinal cleft; saccus longer than wide;<tei:lb/>juxta simple, entire, not divided medially; vesica lacking spicular cornuti; aedeagus smooth-surfaced,<tei:lb/>without spicular carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. Forewing pattern consisting of bold purple-brown patches on a pale bronze<tei:lb/>ground-colour (except in oroya).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Neotropical region - Colombia, Panama, Peru; Oriental region - Borneo.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species of Cranaodes</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Females (females of oroya are unknown)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>stereopa (p. 98)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cranaodes stereopa Meyrick</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 45, 158)<tei:lb/>Cranaodes stereopa Meyrick, 1919: 239. Holotype d", COLOMBIA (BMNH) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Clarke, 1970: pi. 17, figs 2, 2a, 2b; Fig. 45). C?, 27 mm; $, 40 mm. Vertex and frons brownish<tei:lb/>yellow. Labial palpus cream, brownish on outer surface, slender, not strongly tufted on second segment.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 99</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Maxillary palpus cream, flecked with brown above, relatively short, reaching only about one-half length of<tei:lb/>second segment of labial palpus. Antennal scape and pedicel light grey-brown; cilia 1-7 x (c?) or 0-5 x (9)<tei:lb/>flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula light yellow-brown, strongly flecked with dark brown anteriorly.<tei:lb/>Forewing pale bronze marked with strong purple-brown blotches forming a broken irregular postmedial<tei:lb/>band; quadrate basal blotch continuous with strong basicostal blotch; numerous smaller costal spots.<tei:lb/>Hindwing light brownish grey. Legs buff, foreleg and mid-leg dark brown above but paler at articulations<tei:lb/>and across middle of mid-tibia; outer mid-tibial spur 0-6 length of inner; outer hind proximal tibial spur 0-7<tei:lb/>length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA c? (Clarke, 1970: pi. 17, figs 2c, 2d). Saccus triangular; uncus lobes entirely fused with outer<tei:lb/>corners of tegumen, each forming a setose and strongly sclerotized knob-like protuberance with a pair of<tei:lb/>small apical spines. Subscaphium not developed. Juxta quadrate, strongly sclerotized, transtilla not<tei:lb/>developed. Valva plain, with strong and setose medial digitate process, apodeme with shallow dorsally-<tei:lb/>directed flap. Aedeagus stout, 10 x as long as broad in middle, sclerotization of apex a thin tapered process<tei:lb/>only, ventrally with distinctive subbasal longitudinal 'keel'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA 9 (Fig. 158). Eighth tergite longer than eighth sternite, with three pairs of strong epimarginal<tei:lb/>setae and numerous scattered (?)microsetae; eighth sternite with broad terminal ostium with strong<tei:lb/>V-shaped emargination of ventral lip; margin of eighth sternite either side of ostium with compact group of<tei:lb/>four elongate setae and numerous smaller setae. Antrum short, broadly funnel-shaped, inception of ductus<tei:lb/>seminalis posterior to anterior margin of eighth sternite. Ductus bursae thick- walled, inner surface rugose,<tei:lb/>rugosity with distinct transverse pattern that becomes transverse wrinkling further anteriorly. Corpus<tei:lb/>bursae thin-walled, elongately ovoid; signa absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Panama; Colombia.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 2 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype O", Colombia: San Antonio, 5800', xi.1907 (genitalia slide no. JFGC 6645; BMNH).<tei:lb/>Panama: 1 $, Chiriqui (genitalia slide no. 13109; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This is one of the largest and most striking Tineidae, its characteristic wing-pattern serving to<tei:lb/>distinguish it from all other Neotropical species. Similarities to sequestrata may be entirely the result of<tei:lb/>convergence; however, in the absence of further material of sequestrata (particularly males) any discussion<tei:lb/>as to whether or not the two species are really congeneric would be conjectural. They differ in the length of<tei:lb/>the (female) antennal cilia, in the shape and size of the forewing markings and in the genitalia, stereopa<tei:lb/>having a strong U-shaped emargination of the ventral lip of the ostium (= posterior margin of eighth<tei:lb/>sternite) and sequestrata having a slightly convex margin with considerably more strong and elongate setae<tei:lb/>than stereopa. In both species the ductus bursae has fine transverse wrinkling (= regular constrictions) but<tei:lb/>in stereopa this is represented posteriorly by rugosity with a distinctive transverse pattern. This latter<tei:lb/>feature may represent the unexpanded state of the ductus prior to copulation and the ductus may assume a<tei:lb/>regularly constricted form after being expanded. There is a marked difference between the two species in<tei:lb/>the form of the wall of the ovipositor dorsal to the ostium: in sequestrata this wall is ballooned ventrally to<tei:lb/>form a lobe large enough to close off the ostium, whereas in stereopa the ovipositor wall is quite smooth.<tei:lb/>Similar swellings of the ovipositor wall occur in most Scardiinae but they are not always conspicuous nor, in<tei:lb/>theory, capable of closing over the ostium (there is no evidence that this is the function of these lobes).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The function and homology of the flap from the valval apodeme of the male of stereopa is uncertain.<tei:lb/>Similar but much more elongate processes are found in Semeoloncha. Apodemal processes also occur in<tei:lb/>the poorly-known genus Leptozanda (Robinson, 1976); this is probably also a scardiine taxon but the<tei:lb/>material available is in such condition as to make precise placement impossible. The apodemal processes of<tei:lb/>these groups are analogous to some of the modifications of the labides that occur in Tinissa (Robinson,<tei:lb/>1976) although probably not homologous.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cranaodes oroya sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 46, 106)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 46). cf , 26 mm. Coloration and external structure of head similar to stereopa. Thorax<tei:lb/>brownish cream, a few darker scales anteriorly; tegula grey-brown, a few pale scales at margins. Forewing<tei:lb/>pale bronze (but badly faded) strongly marked with dark brown to form a possibly continuous anterior<tei:lb/>fascia similar to that of Daviscardia species (but specimen very worn); paler spots along costa; conspicuous<tei:lb/>pale round spots at end of cell and at end of fold. Hindwing light grey-brown. Legs buff, foreleg and mid-leg</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>100 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>darker above (very worn); outer mid-tibial spur 0-7 length of inner; outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-75<tei:lb/>length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Fig. 106). Saccus elongately triangular; uncus lobes similar to those oistereopa but forming<tei:lb/>only a very small pair of hook-shaped processes on the outer corners of the tegumen. Subscaphium not<tei:lb/>developed. Juxta represented only by ill-defined thickening of anellus; transtilla not developed. Valva with<tei:lb/>strongly folded costa and ventral margin, otherwise plain, apodeme without flap (but flap otstereopa may<tei:lb/>represent initial development or reduction of costal fold of this species). Aedeagus almost cylindrical, 10 x<tei:lb/>as long as broad in middle, with triangular membranous zone from base to almost one-third and with<tei:lb/>similar but shorter zone from apex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $. Unknown.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. Peru.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Peru: R. Inambari, La Oroya, 3100', dry season, ix.1904 (Ockenderi) (genitalia slide no.<tei:lb/>12394; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Smaller and with much more extensive dark forewing markings than stereopa, oroya may also be<tei:lb/>distinguished by the male genitalia in which the costa and ventral margin of the valva are strongly folded<tei:lb/>inward. The flap from the valval apodeme ofstereopa is absent in oroya but may form a part of the costal<tei:lb/>fold. The middle of the valva bears a conspicuous setose digitate process mstereopa but is smooth in oroya.<tei:lb/>Although the wing pattern of the two species is strongly divergent, the similarities of the male genitalia<tei:lb/>(notably in the complex of the uncus lobes plus tegumen) suggest that they are congeneric.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cranaodes sequestrata Meyrick<tei:lb/>(Figs 47, 159,200)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Craneodes [sic] sequestrata Meyrick, 1926: 164. Holotype cf, SARAWAK (SM, Kuching) [not found -<tei:lb/>probably destroyed].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Robinson, 1984: pi. 6, fig. 4; Fig. 47). $, 32 mm. Vertex and frons yellow-brown. Labial palpus<tei:lb/>pale buff, strongly speckled with dark brown on outer surface, apex pale. Maxillary palpus grey-brown,<tei:lb/>reaching only about one-half length of second segment of labial palpus. Antennal scape and pedicel pale<tei:lb/>buff, flecked with dark brown; flagellum pale buff; cilia 1-0 x flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula<tei:lb/>off-white, strongly flecked with grey-brown anteriorly, thorax almost entirely dark. Forewing light<tei:lb/>greenish bronze flecked with pale brown; large quadrate dark brown spot from costa to posterior margin of<tei:lb/>cell at one-half; basal half of costa flecked with dark brown; dorsum strongly flecked with dark brown (but<tei:lb/>worn); a few small dark spots at apex and termen. Hindwing pale greyish buff. Legs pale buff; foreleg and<tei:lb/>mid-leg darker above, mid-tibia with pair of large diffuse blackish spots above; outer mid-tibial spur 0-5<tei:lb/>length of inner; outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-6 length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA 9 (Fig. 159). Eighth tergite longer than eighth sternite, with four pairs of strong terminal setae<tei:lb/>and numerous scattered smaller lateral setae; eighth sternite forming a protruding ledge that accommo-<tei:lb/>dates ostium behind its posterior margin; sternite with 10 pairs of elongate setae and a few smaller setae<tei:lb/>close to caudal margin. Antrum narrow and cylindrical, ostium closed by bulbous protrusion of ovipositor<tei:lb/>wall; inception of ductus seminalis just posterior to anterior margin of eighth sternite. Ductus bursae<tei:lb/>elongate, thin-walled, but with fine and close-set transverse wrinkles, extending beyond apices of<tei:lb/>apophyses anteriores. Corpus bursae thin- walled, elongately ovoid; signa absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Borneo (Fig. 200).<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Brunei: 1 $, Bukit Pagon, LP 308, 5520', upper montane forest, 15-20. ii. 1982 (Robinson) (genitalia<tei:lb/>slide no. 6981; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The female specimen described here agrees well with Meyrick's original description of the male:<tei:lb/>discrepancies are in the colour of the head ('greyish ochreous'), the ground-colour of the forewing</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 101</tei:p>
         <tei:p>('prismatic white') and the absence of any mention of dark markings on the dorsum. It is unlikely that<tei:lb/>Meyrick's holotype of this species, deposited originally in the Sarawak Museum, Kuching, still exists.<tei:lb/>Exhaustive searches at my request by the present curators (and by workers in the 1950s - Diakonoff , pers.<tei:lb/>comm.) have failed to turn up any of the material described in Meyrick's 1926 paper. I am reasonably<tei:lb/>confident that the female described here is of Meyrick's species. On the basis of the characters available<tei:lb/>from this female there is no reason to exclude sequestrata from Cranaodes. However, the genitalia do differ<tei:lb/>substantially from those otstereopa (q.v.) and the similarities may be entirely due to convergence.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PECTINISCARDIA gen. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type-species: Cranaodes prosty lias Meyrick, 1927: 327.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Antenna (male) with dorsal cilia, ventral surface scaled; cilia longer than 1-5 x flagellar<tei:lb/>diameter. Scape with fewer than 15 pecten bristles. Interocular index (male) 1-0 or less. Maxillary palpus<tei:lb/>5-segmented; pilifers present; second segment of labial palpus shorter than width of head. Outer mid and<tei:lb/>proximal hind tibial spurs &gt;0-4 length of inner spurs. Forewing with R^ and R 4 separate; A/ 2 , M 3 and CuA\<tei:lb/>separate; mottled coloration forming cryptic, coarse 'moss' pattern. Male lacking coremata in eighth<tei:lb/>abdominal segment. Male genitalia with simple uncus - a pair of setose lobes - fused with tegumen;<tei:lb/>tegumen broken dorsally by at least a membranous suture line; valva lacking basal setose lobe on inner<tei:lb/>surface; apex of valva forming ventral hook or hooks, or with spines; valvae separate, not fused together<tei:lb/>ventrally, without longitudinal cleft; saccus longer than wide; juxta simple, entire, not divided medially;<tei:lb/>vesica with spicular cornuti; aedeagus damaged - presence of carinae uncertain.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. Ventrocaudal margin of valva with strong pectinifer of about 12 spines<tei:lb/>(this character is paralleled in Morophaga formosana and iriomotensis) .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Neotropical region - Colombia.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pectiniscardia prostylias (Meyrick) comb. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 48)<tei:lb/>Cranaodes prostylias Meyrick, 1927: 327. Holotype cf , COLOMBIA (BMNH) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Clarke, 1970: pi. 17, figs 2b, 3; Fig. 48). cf , 27 mm. Vertex and frons cream. Labial palpus cream,<tei:lb/>flecked on outer surface with brown (but very worn). Maxillary palpus cream flecked with brown,<tei:lb/>5-segmented, short, reaching only one-fifth length of second segment of labial palpus. Antennal scape and<tei:lb/>pedicel pale buff, scape flecked strongly above with brown but distal third cream; pedicel and basal flagellar<tei:lb/>segments dark brown above; cilia 3-0 x flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula worn and damaged.<tei:lb/>Forewing very worn, golden cream patterned with purple-brown; costa and fringe with conspicuous<tei:lb/>chequering. Hindwing pale cream (worn) with a few scattered darker scales at apex and termen. Legs<tei:lb/>(worn) pale buff; foreleg and mid-leg marked strongly above and on sides with brown but pale at<tei:lb/>articulations; mid-tibia with pale oblique medial bar on outer surface; outer mid-tibial spur 0-6 length- of<tei:lb/>inner spur; hind tibial spurs broken.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Clarke, 1970: pi. 17, figs3a, 3b). Saccus elongate, triangular, longer than tegumen + uncus;<tei:lb/>uncus lobes broad, square-ended. Subscaphium not developed. Juxta shield-shaped, hardly sclerotized;<tei:lb/>transtilla not developed. Valva an obliquely truncated rectangle, simple except for well-developed<tei:lb/>pectinifer of about 12 stout spines. Aedeagus 9 x as long as broad; apex damaged but with strong<tei:lb/>sickle-shaped subapical carina and at least a pair of smaller corniform carinae; vesica with minute spicular<tei:lb/>cornuti (microtrichia).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ . Unknown.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. Colombia.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 ex.<tei:lb/>Holotype cf , Colombia: Central Cordilleras, 11,800', xi. 1920 (genitalia slide no. JFGC 6646; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The holotype of this species is so worn that it is impossible to provide good external<tei:lb/>characteristics for its recognition. However, the alternated dark and light spots down the costa give it a<tei:lb/>chequered appearance and this feature is distinctive: it is not nearly so strongly developed in any other New</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>102 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>World scardiine. The forewing pattern is otherwise hard to discern. The apical fascia is certainly pale: the<tei:lb/>dorsum has lost almost all scales but was probably also pale and the remainder of the wing appears to have<tei:lb/>been mottled with dark brown. Fresh specimens might resemble Morophagoides species such as iulina. The<tei:lb/>male genitalia of Pectiniscardia are quite distinctive. A pectinifer is developed otherwise in the Scardiinae<tei:lb/>only in Morophagaformosana and iriomotensis and I believe this to be a clear case of convergence.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HORMANTRIS Meyrick</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hormantris Meyrick, 1927: 327. Type-species: Hormantris astragalopa Meyrick, 1927: 327, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Antenna (male) lacking dorsal cilia, ventral surface scaled; cilia longer than 1-5 x flagellar<tei:lb/>diameter. Scape with fewer than 15 pecten bristles. Interocular index (male) 1-0 or less. Maxillary palpus<tei:lb/>5-segmented; pilifers absent; second segment of labial palpus longer than width of head. Legs damaged -<tei:lb/>relative lengths of tibial spurs unknown. Forewing with /? 3 and R 4 separate; M 2 , M 3 and CuA\ separate;<tei:lb/>mottled coloration forming cryptic, coarse 'moss' pattern. Male lacking coremata in eighth abdominal<tei:lb/>segment. Male genitalia with simple uncus - a pair of setose lobes - separated from tegumen by narrow<tei:lb/>band of membrane; tegumen unbroken, completely sclerotized dorsally; valva lacking basal setose lobe on<tei:lb/>inner surface; apex of valva not forming ventral hook or hooks, without spines; valvae separate, not fused<tei:lb/>together ventrally, without longitudinal cleft; saccus longer than wide; juxta simple, entire, not divided<tei:lb/>medially; vesica with spicular cornuti; aedeagus with spicular or spinose carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. Ventral half of inner surface of valva with dense field of thorn-like setae.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. Neotropical region - Colombia.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hormantris astragalopa Meyrick</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 49)<tei:lb/>Hormantris astragalopa Meyrick, 1927: 327. Holotype cf , COLOMBIA (BMNH) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Clarke, 1970: pi. 29, figs 1, la, Ib; Fig. 49). 0", 34 mm. Head and thorax almost entirely denuded<tei:lb/>but some white and brown scales on labial palpus. Maxillary palpus whitish, elongate, 5-segmented.<tei:lb/>Antennal scape and pedicel whitish with some brown scales; flagellum pale buff-cream; cilia about 8 x<tei:lb/>flagellar diameter. Forewing almost entirely denuded, pale buff-cream with scattered small brown<tei:lb/>speckles; slightly larger brown spots on costa; large subapical dark brown spot. Hindwing off-white<tei:lb/>mottled with pale grey. Foreleg buff strongly flecked with dark brown; other legs lost.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA d" (Clarke, 1970: pi. 29, figs Ic, Id). Saccus broad, elongate and strongly sclerotized; uncus<tei:lb/>lobes small, digitiform, poorly sclerotized, sparsely setose. Subscaphium not developed. Juxta, if present,<tei:lb/>represented by only slight swelling of anellus; transtilla not developed. Valva almost circular, dorsal half<tei:lb/>strongly spined on internal surface; ventral margin with rounded triangular flap at one-half and with short,<tei:lb/>stout basal setose lobe. Aedeagus dumb-bell-shaped with dense spinose carinae on dorsal surface of apical<tei:lb/>half; vesica with group of eight spine-like cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $. Unknown.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. Colombia.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 ex.<tei:lb/>Holotype cf , Colombia: Mt Tolima, 12,500', x.1920 (genitalia slide no. JFGC 6644; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Hormantris differs from Cnismorectis (q.v.) in having a more elongate maxillary palpus; the<tei:lb/>antennal cilia are considerably longer, the longest of any scardiine known. Unlike Cnismorectis, the ventral<tei:lb/>surface of the antenna is scaled and the pecten is sparse with, apparently, fewer than 15 bristles (but the<tei:lb/>specimen is worn and the bristle-sockets have not been checked in a microscopic preparation). The<tei:lb/>holotype of astragalopa is so worn as to make impossible any comparison of wing pattern except the<tei:lb/>observation that the subapical dark brown spot does not occur in Cnismorectis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CNISMORECTIS Meyrick<tei:lb/>Cnismorectis Meyrick, 1936: 109. Type-species: Cnismorectis choritica Meyrick, 1936: 109, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 103</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Antenna (male) lacking dorsal cilia, ventral surface without scales; cilia longer than 1-5 x<tei:lb/>flagellar diameter. Scape with more than 15 pecten bristles. Interocular index (male) greater than 1-0.<tei:lb/>Maxillary palpus with fewer than 5 segments; pilifers absent; second segment of labial palpus longer than<tei:lb/>width of head. Outer mid and proximal hind tibial spurs &gt;0-4 length of inner spurs. Forewing with R^ and<tei:lb/>R 4 separate; M 2 , M 3 and CuA\ separate; mottled coloration forming cryptic, coarse 'moss' pattern. Male<tei:lb/>lacking coremata in eighth abdominal segment. Male genitalia with simple uncus - a pair of setose lobes -<tei:lb/>separated from tegumen by narrow band of membrane; tegumen unbroken, completely sclerotized<tei:lb/>dorsally; valva lacking basal setose lobe on inner surface; apex of valva not forming ventral hook or hooks,<tei:lb/>without spines; valvae separate, not fused together ventrally, without longitudinal cleft; saccus longer than<tei:lb/>wide; juxta complex, entire, not divided medially; vesica with spicular cornuti; aedeagus smooth-surfaced,<tei:lb/>without spicular carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. Ventral margins of valvae invaginated, contiguous with juxta which is<tei:lb/>infolded anteriorly, the whole complex forming a deep, broad pocket; vesica with elongate oval of small,<tei:lb/>thorn-like cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Neotropical region- Peru, Bolivia.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cnismorectis choritica Meyrick<tei:lb/>(Figs 50, 105,160, 182)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cnismorectis choritica Meyrick, 1936: 109. LECTOTYPE $, BOLIVIA (BMNH), here designated [ex-<tei:lb/>amined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Figs 50, 182). cf $, 26-36 mm. Vertex and frons very pale buff with a few dark scales. Labial<tei:lb/>palpus very pale buff flecked with brown. Maxillary palpus whitish, 4-segmented, very short, not reaching<tei:lb/>base of second segment of labial palpus. Antennal scape and pedicel ochreous cream flecked with brown,<tei:lb/>flagellum ochreous cream; cilia 3.0 x (cf ) or 0.3 x ($) flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula very pale buff<tei:lb/>flecked with brown. Forewing cream flecked and finely strigulated with orange-brown (particularly along<tei:lb/>veins) and dark brown, dark markings concentrated to leave ill-defined paler ante- and postmedial fasciae.<tei:lb/>Hindwing dirty cream strigulated with pale grey. Legs pale buff strongly flecked with brown, particularly<tei:lb/>above on fore-leg and mid-leg; mid-tibia conspicuously rough-scaled; tarsi ringed with brown; outer<tei:lb/>mid-tibial spur 0.8 length of inner; outer proximal hind tibial spur 0.6 length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Fig. 105). Saccus slender, elongate; uncus lobes slender, small, only slightly sclerotized,<tei:lb/>setose. Subscaphium not developed. Juxta apparently forming ventral wall of pocket that extends<tei:lb/>anteriorly behind saccus and extends laterally into ventral margins of valvae; transtilla not developed.<tei:lb/>Valva almost rectangular with dorsal corner produced into a spatulate lobe; ventral margin invaginated to<tei:lb/>form conspicuous pocket; internal surface with coarse microtrichia and two or three small peg-like<tei:lb/>processes (?sensillae) at four-fifths. Aedeagus slender, elongate, 20 x as long as broad in middle, without<tei:lb/>carinae; base of vesica with elongate oval of small, thorn-like cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Fig. 160). Seventh sternite with corethrogyne of fine, elongate hairs. Eighth tergite slightly<tei:lb/>longer than eighth sternite, deeply emarginate medially, with two pairs of elongate terminal setae and five<tei:lb/>pairs of smaller terminal setae. Eighth sternite with deep U-shaped medial emargination accommodating<tei:lb/>ostium, with dense, stiff, elongate bristles. Antrum narrow, cylindrical, one-third length of apophyses<tei:lb/>anteriores. Ductus bursae thin-walled, as long as antrum; inception of ductus seminalis close to junction<tei:lb/>with antrum. Corpus bursae thin-walled, pyriform, twice length of antrum; signa absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Bolivia, Peru.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 5 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lectotype $ , Bolivia: Santa Cruz, Samaipata, 1500 m, iii (Steinbach) (genitalia slide no. 6970; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bolivia: 1 &lt;j&gt; (paralectotype), 1934 (Staudinger) (BMNH); 1 cf , 1 $, Rio Tanampaya, 1894 (Garlepp)<tei:lb/>(genitalia slide no. 6969; BMNH). Peru: 1 $, Huanuco, Cushi, 1900 m (Hoffmann) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Cnismorectis is the sister-group of Hormantris. The two are conspicuous in that they have a<tei:lb/>distinctive mottled pattern on the hindwings and exceptionally elongate labial palpi: both have lost the<tei:lb/>pilifers. In the male genitalia of both, the uncus lobes are very small and digitiform and the vesica has<tei:lb/>thorn-like cornuti. The microtrichia on the valva of Cnismorectis are, however, replaced functionally by a</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>104 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>field of very small thorn-like spines covering the dorsal half of the valva in Hormantris.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The relationship of these genera to Dorata Busck, a genus of five greyish cream species with plain<tei:lb/>hindwings from northern Mexico and south-western U.S.A., requires further investigation. Superficially,<tei:lb/>Dorata does not look like a scardiine but, like Cnismorectis and Hormantris, has elongate labial palpi and<tei:lb/>lacks pilifers. The uncus lobes are similar to those of Cnismorectis but bear strong, thorn-like spines.<tei:lb/>Similar spines occur on the dorsal lobe of the strongly bifurcated valva which also carries a setose digitate<tei:lb/>process from the ventral margin in the one species examined (Dorata atomophora Meyrick). The ventral<tei:lb/>lobe of the valva of Dorata may represent the juxta: a pouch superficially similar to that of Cnismorectis<tei:lb/>runs anteriorly from the ventral base of the valva. Davis (in prep.) is including Dorata in a revision of the<tei:lb/>North American Tineidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MINISCARDIA gen. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type-species: Scardia minimella Busck, 1914: 65.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Antenna (male) lacking dorsal cilia, ventral surface scaled; cilia longer than 1-5 x flagellar<tei:lb/>diameter. Scape with fewer than 15 pecten bristles. Interocular index (male) greater than 1-0. Maxillary<tei:lb/>palpus with fewer than 5 segments; pilifers present; second segment of labial palpus shorter than width of<tei:lb/>head. Outer mid and proximal hind tibial spurs &gt;0-4 length of inner spurs. Forewing with R^ and R 4<tei:lb/>separate: M 3 and CuAi stalked or very closely approximated at base; mottled coloration forming cryptic,<tei:lb/>coarse 'moss' pattern. Male with coremata in eighth abdominal segment; coremata not associated with<tei:lb/>apodemes. Male genitalia with simple uncus - a pair of setose lobes - fused with tegumen; tegumen<tei:lb/>unbroken, completely sclerotized dorsally; valva lacking basal setose lobe on inner surface; apex of valva<tei:lb/>not forming ventral hook or hooks, without spines; valvae separate, not fused together ventrally, without<tei:lb/>longitudinal cleft; saccus longer than wide; juxta, if present, simple, entire, not divided medially; vesica<tei:lb/>with spicular cornuti; aedeagus with spicular or spinose carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. None; however, may be recognized by the exclusive combination of<tei:lb/>moss-like forewing pattern with veins M 3 and CuA\ stalked or connate - see 'remarks' for minimella.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Neotropical region - Panama, Costa Rica, Guatemala, Brazil; Nearctic region - U.S.A.<tei:lb/>(Arizona).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Miniscardia minimella (Busck) comb. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 55, 56, 111,165)<tei:lb/>Scardia minimella Busck, 1914: 65. Holotype cf , PANAMA (NMNH) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Figs 55, 56). cf , 15-19 mm. $ , 20-25 mm. Vertex and frons orange-brown, with dark brown tufts<tei:lb/>close to eyes. Labial palpus orange-brown, strongly marked with deep purple-brown on outer surface.<tei:lb/>Maxillary palpus dull buff, deep purple-brown on upper and outer surfaces, probably 3-segmented,<tei:lb/>reaching only one-half length of second segment of labial palpus. Antennal scape and pedicel orange-<tei:lb/>brown, dark purple-brown above; flagellum scales light grey-brown but darker at base of flagellum; cilia<tei:lb/>1-5 x (cf ) or 0-2 x ($) flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula deep purple-brown, thorax with buff-cream<tei:lb/>transverse band, tegula tipped with buff-cream. Forewing buff-cream, strongly speckled with deep<tei:lb/>purple-brown, speckling concentrated into basal, medial and subterminal fasciae. All deep purple-brown<tei:lb/>markings (especially on underside) with pronounced blue-green iridescence when observed at an acute<tei:lb/>angle. Hindwing light brownish grey. Legs buff, foreleg and mid-leg heavily marked above and at sides<tei:lb/>with deep purple-brown, but pale at articulations; mid-tibia with pair of conspicuous oblique dark bars on<tei:lb/>outer surface; hindleg greyish above; outer mid-tibial spur 0-5 length of inner; outer hind proximal tibial<tei:lb/>spur 0-75 length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Fig. 111). Saccus elongate, triangular, more than half length of genital armature; uncus<tei:lb/>lobes triangular, fused with each other and with tegumen, sclerotized, setose, apices level with apices of<tei:lb/>valvae. Subscaphium not developed. Juxta not developed or represented only by ill-defined thickening of<tei:lb/>base of anellus; transtilla not developed. Valva slender, triangular, simple. Aedeagus 7 x as long as broad,<tei:lb/>with subapical dorsal transverse band of small, thorn-like carinae; vesica with minute spicular cornuti<tei:lb/>(?microtrichia).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Fig. 165). (Description based on examples from French Guiana and Brazil.) Eighth tergite</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 105</tei:p>
         <tei:p>slightly longer than eighth sternite, with about 8 strong setae close to caudal margin and pair of large medial<tei:lb/>patches of microtrichia; eighth sternite with shallowly m-shaped caudal margin, strongly folded medially to<tei:lb/>accommodate broad, transverse ostium with convex or slightly concave ventral lip; apex of eighth sternite<tei:lb/>with two or three pairs of strong setae and numerous short, small setae. Antrum with broad posterior<tei:lb/>chamber, dorsal surface of chamber with dome-shaped thickening surrounding inception of ductus<tei:lb/>seminalis; anterior region of antrum a short, smooth-walled, narrow tube reaching less than 0-25 length of<tei:lb/>apophyses anteriores. Ductus bursae thick-walled posteriorly, with about 15 irregular transverse constric-<tei:lb/>tions, becoming very thin-walled anteriorly. Corpus bursae globular, very thin-walled, extending to 1-25<tei:lb/>length of apophyses anteriores; signa absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Guatemala; Costa Rica; Panama; French Guiana; Brazil.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 7 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Panama: Porto Bello, v.1912 (Busck) (genitalia slide no. 20156; NMNH, Washington).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Guatemala: 1 cf, Poptum, Peten, 15-16. ix. 1973 (Becker) (coll. Becker, Brasilia). Costa Rica: 1 cf , San<tei:lb/>Jose, 1922 (genitalia slide no. 12689; BMNH); 1 $, 1935 (H. S.) (genitalia slide no. 12680; BMNH). French<tei:lb/>Guiana: 1 $ , Nouvelle Chantier, x. (Le Moult) (genitalia slide no. 12684; BMNH); 1 $ , St Jean du Maroni<tei:lb/>(Le Moult) (BMNH). Brazil: 1 , Rio Brilhante, Mato Grosso, 23-27. x. 1970 (Becker) (coll. Becker,<tei:lb/>Brasilia).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is one of the few Neotropical taxa of Scardiinae that has an olivaceous 'moss' pattern<tei:lb/>resembling that of the Morophaga choragella-group. Other Neotropical taxa with this pattern are Diataga<tei:lb/>(with M 2 and M 3 stalked in the forewing and with very short outer tibial spurs) and Morophagoides (all<tei:lb/>veins free , pattern generally more variegated) . In the forewing A/ 3 and CuA } are always stalked or connate ;<tei:lb/>this characteristic is also found in the smaller and darker Bythocrates and in Perilicmetis with its<tei:lb/>characteristic dark brown subterminal fascia. The male genitalia are remarkable for their simplicity of<tei:lb/>structure, the female genitalia for the internal thickened and sclerotized ridge that is the posterior<tei:lb/>continuation of the apophyses anteriores extending and remaining conspicuous as far posteriorly as the<tei:lb/>setose apical region of the eighth sternite.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The females listed here may not be conspecific with each other or with the males. A single female from<tei:lb/>Arizona (see below) appears to be a congener but not conspecific. The female from Brazil has similar<tei:lb/>genitalia to those of the female from French Guiana but the ventral lip of the ostium is concave in the<tei:lb/>former and convex in the latter. The broad posterior region of the antrum is much less strongly sclerotized<tei:lb/>in the Brazilian specimen and the transverse constrictions of the ductus bursae are more numerous, about<tei:lb/>double the number present in the French Guiana specimen. The female from Costa Rica, with a 5 mm<tei:lb/>longer wingspan than the other specimens examined, has only 5 pairs of apical setae on the eighth sternite<tei:lb/>and a broader, shorter antrum lacking the narrow anterior region of the other two examples; the ductus<tei:lb/>bursae lacks transverse constrictions and the bursa copulatrix, although collapsed in preparation, does not<tei:lb/>extend beyond the apophyses anteriores.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Miniscardia species A</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 166)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT. $ , 17 mm. Coloration and external structure similar to minimella.<tei:lb/>GENITALIA cf . Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Fig. 166). Similar to those of minimella but ventral lip of ostium not extended as far<tei:lb/>posteriorly, and with distinct marginal bulbosity; antrum short, not extending anteriorly beyond inception<tei:lb/>of ductus seminalis; posterior region of ductus bursae distinctly scobinate on external surface; apex of<tei:lb/>eighth s'ternite with three pairs of strong setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. U.S.A. (Arizona).<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>U.S.A.: 1 9, Arizona, CochiseCo., HuachucaMts, Miller Canyon, 7. viii. 1974 (Powell) (genitalia slide;<tei:lb/>UC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This specimen probably represents a species different from minimella but, with only a single<tei:lb/>female example in poor condition available for examination, its status remains uncertain. The matter is</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>106 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>complicated by the apparent variability of females of minimella. The example of minimella from Costa<tei:lb/>Rica has genitalia very similar to those of this specimen from Arizona; both lack sclerotization of the ductus<tei:lb/>bursae to form an antrum anterior to the inception of the ductus seminalis, and in both the ventral lip of the<tei:lb/>ostium is almost straight, rather than being convex as in examples from Brazil and French Guiana.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NECROSCARDIA gen. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type-species: Tirtea funeratella Zeller, 1863: 144.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Antenna (male) lacking dorsal cilia, ventral surface scaled; cilia longer than 1-5 x flagellar<tei:lb/>diameter. Scape with fewer than 15 pecten bristles. Interocular index (male) greater than 1-0. Maxillary<tei:lb/>palpus with fewer than 5 segments; pilifers present; second segment of labial palpus shorter than width of<tei:lb/>head. Outer mid and proximal hind tibial spurs &gt;0-4 length of inner spurs. Forewing with R 3 and R 4<tei:lb/>separate; M 2 , M 3 and CuA\ separate; pattern consisting of pale termen and dorsum on darker ground-<tei:lb/>colour. Male with coremata in eighth abdominal segment; coremata associated with elongate, rod-like<tei:lb/>apodemes at anterior corners of eighth sternite. Male genitalia with complex uncus separated from<tei:lb/>tegumen by narrow band of membrane; tegumen broken dorsally by at least a membranous suture line;<tei:lb/>valva lacking basal setose lobe on inner surface; apex of valva not forming ventral hook or hooks, without<tei:lb/>spines; valvae separate, not fused together ventrally, without longitudinal cleft; saccus wider than long;<tei:lb/>juxta complex, divided medially; vesica with spicular cornuti; aedeagus with spicular or spinose carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. Apex of tegumen forming a single prong-like or bifid process dorsal to the<tei:lb/>uncus lobes; juxta enormously enlarged, bipartite, closely appressed to and forming a functional part of the<tei:lb/>valvae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Neotropical region- Venezuela, Colombia, Bolivia.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species of Necroscardia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Pair of cream triangular marks on posterior margin of forewing equal in size (Fig. 54); male<tei:lb/>without large phylliform setae on eighth sternite; male with dorsal process from tegumen<tei:lb/>bifid, extending caudally well beyond lobes of uncus (Fig. 109); female seventh sternite with<tei:lb/>posterior margin strongly emarginated medially, with scattered field of strong, needle-like</tei:p>
         <tei:p>setae (Fig. 163) morticina(p. 107)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Proximal cream triangular mark on posterior margin of forewing considerably larger than distal<tei:lb/>mark which is reduced to a minute spot (Fig. 53); male with two pairs of enormous phylliform<tei:lb/>setae on posterior corners of eighth sternite (Fig. 110); male with dorsal process from tegumen<tei:lb/>a single spine, not extending beyond lobes of uncus (Fig. 108); female seventh sternite with<tei:lb/>posterior margin transverse, lacking needle-like setae funeratella(p. 106)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Necroscardia funeratella (Zeller) comb. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 53, 108, 110, 164)<tei:lb/>Tinea funeratella Zeller, 1863: 144. LECTOTYPE cf , VENEZUELA, here designated [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Zeller, 1863: pi. 2, fig. 6; Fig. 53). cf , 20 mm; $ , 23 mm. Vertex and frons brownish cream, reddish<tei:lb/>brown near eyes. Labial palpus cream flecked with brown, purple-brown on outer surface but pale at apex,<tei:lb/>sparsely scaled. Maxillary palpus greyish brown above, paler beneath, short, not as long as second segment<tei:lb/>of labial palpus, probably 3-segmented. Antennal scape and pedicel greyish brown; flagellum greyish<tei:lb/>brown cilia 1-7 x (cf) or 0-7 x ($) flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula cream, anterior third brown.<tei:lb/>Forewing purple-brown with cream terminal fascia containing brown speckling and small brown apical and<tei:lb/>medioterminal spots; costa with a few pale flecks; posterior margin with broad cream spot, large triangular<tei:lb/>cream spot almost at mid-point, and small cream spot at three-quarters. Hindwing light brownish grey.<tei:lb/>Legs cream, finely flecked with grey-brown; foreleg and mid-leg grey-brown above and on outer surfaces,<tei:lb/>tibiae traversed by cream band; articulations pale; outer mid-tibial spur 0-7 length of inner; outer proximal<tei:lb/>hind tibial spur 0-8 length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Figs 10B , 1 10) . Eighth sternite with elongate apodemes reaching anterior margin of seventh<tei:lb/>sternite, at each posterior corner with one large and one small strong phylliform seta. Saccus broadly<tei:lb/>triangular, shorter than valvae; uncus lobes minute, setose, but sclerotized and lacking setae at apices,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 107</tei:p>
         <tei:p>surmounted by spike-shaped caudal process from vinculum almost as long as uncus lobes. Subscaphium not<tei:lb/>developed. Juxta strongly developed, bipartite, forming pair of tuberculate setose lobes surmounting and<tei:lb/>appressed basally to valvae; transtilla not developed. Valva short, plain, pyramidal, bearing lobe of juxta<tei:lb/>on inner surface. Aedeagus small, strongly tapered apically, and with scattered minute thorn-like carinae;<tei:lb/>vesica with very few minute spicular cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Fig. 164). Seventh sternite unmodified. Eighth tergite longer than eighth sternite, with line<tei:lb/>of minute setae at posterior margin, five or six pairs of very strong submarginal setae and four or five pairs<tei:lb/>of conspicuous but minute pits scattered in posterior one-quarter. Eighth sternite and genital tract<tei:lb/>pathologically deformed in specimen examined: illustrated but not described further here.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Venezuela; Colombia.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 2 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lectotype cf , Venezuela: (genitalia slide no. 12379; BMNH).<tei:lb/>Colombia: 1 $, Sierra del Libano, 6000', v. 1899 (Smith) (genitalia slide no. 12396; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. For differentiation ot funeratella and morticina, see the key above. The female described above<tei:lb/>resembles the lectotype remarkably closely and I am confident that they are conspecific. Walsingham<tei:lb/>identified the female as funeratella - the specimen bears his determination label.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Necroscardia morticina sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 54, 109, 162, 163)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 54). cf , 21 mm. $ , 17 mm. Coloration and external structure similar to funeratella but apices<tei:lb/>of second and third segments of labial palpus cream, third segment of cf entirely cream; cilia ($) 3 x<tei:lb/>flagellar diameter; posterior margin of forewing with pale spots coalesced to form continuous band from<tei:lb/>base to tornus, spots triangular, of equal size; posterior and terminal cream fascia strongly speckled with<tei:lb/>purple-brown; outer mid-tibial spur 0-6 length of inner; outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-7 length of inner<tei:lb/>spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Fig. 109). Eighth sternite with short, rod-like apodemes reaching posterior margin of<tei:lb/>seventh sternite. Saccus broadly triangular, shorter than valvae; uncus lobes small, outer corners produced<tei:lb/>into shallow, setose process, inner posterior margin sclerotized and lacking setae, surmounted by<tei:lb/>V-shaped process from tegumen that extends well beyond tips of uncus lobes. Subscaphium not developed.<tei:lb/>Juxta strongly developed, bipartite, forming pair of strong, triangular setose lobes with shallowly serrate<tei:lb/>dorsocaudal margin appressed to and set in apices of valvae; transtilla not developed. Valva short, plain,<tei:lb/>half barrel-shaped, with juxta lobe set in top of 'barrel'. Aedeagus slender, apex sclerotized only on one<tei:lb/>side and duck's bill-shaped, with fine thorn-like carinae at apex; vesica with minute spicular cornuti near<tei:lb/>inception of ductus ejaculatorius.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Figs 162, 163). Seventh sternite rounded caudally, with shallow medial U-shaped emargina-<tei:lb/>tion, strongly sclerotized, with scattered strong setae. Eighth tergite slightly longer than eighth sternite,<tei:lb/>with narrowly V-shaped mediocaudal emargination; posterior margin with numerous small setae, five pairs<tei:lb/>of strong submarginal setae; four or five pairs of scattered pits at four-fifths posteriorly; a few small,<tei:lb/>scattered setae at one-half. Eighth sternite wrinkled laterally, short, forming strong keel-shaped sterigma<tei:lb/>with trilobed apex (= ventral lip of ostium); apical one-third of sterigma with 10-12 pairs of strong,<tei:lb/>elongate setae. Antrum elongate, broad but tapering anteriorly, one-half length of apophyses anteriores,<tei:lb/>lined with elongate microtrichia; inception of ductus seminalis at posterior extremity of antrum (!). Ductus<tei:lb/>bursae as long as antrum, with fine transverse constrictions. Corpus bursae thin- walled, ovoid; signa<tei:lb/>absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Bolivia.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 2 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Bolivia: Cochabamba, Yungas del Espiritu Santo, 1888-9 (Germain) (genitalia slide no.<tei:lb/>12395; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratype. 1 $ , data as holotype (genitalia slide no. 12406; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. For differentiation of morticina and funeratella, see the key above. The female paratype of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>108 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>morticina is the only specimen of Necroscardia that could be considered to be in even fair conditions. Like<tei:lb/>the other three specimens, however, the second segment of the labial palpus is not densely scaled as in<tei:lb/>other scardiine genera with a similar wing-pattern (Moscardia, Scardia, Daviscardid).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TINISSA Walker</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tinissa Walker, 1864: 780; Robinson, 1976 (revision); 1981 (reclassification and additional species).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type-species: Tinissa torvella Walker, 1864: 780, by monotypy.<tei:lb/>Polymnestra Meyrick, 1927: 331. Type-species: Polymnestra perilithias Meyrick, 1927: 331, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[Synonymized by Gozmany &amp; Vari, 1973: 85.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Antenna (male) lacking dorsal cilia, ventral surface scaled; cilia longer or shorter than flagellar<tei:lb/>diameter. Scape with more than 15 pecten bristles. Interocular index (male) greater than 1-0. Maxillary<tei:lb/>palpus short, 3-segmented (but a few species with 5 segments) (Fig. 181); pilifers absent; second segment of<tei:lb/>labial palpus shorter than width of head. Outer mid and proximal hind tibial spurs &gt;0-4 length of inner<tei:lb/>spurs. Forewing with Rj, and R 4 separate; M 2 , M 3 and CuA\ separate; pattern consisting of pale spots or<tei:lb/>speckles on darker ground-colour. Male with or without coremata in eighth abdominal segment; coremata<tei:lb/>without associated apodemes. Male genitalia with simple or complex uncus separated from tegumen by<tei:lb/>narrow band of membrane; valva lacking basal setose lobe on inner surface; apex of valva not forming<tei:lb/>ventral hook or hooks, without spines; tegumen broken dorsally by at least a membranous suture line;<tei:lb/>valvae separate, not fused together ventrally, without longitudinal cleft; saccus wider or narrower than<tei:lb/>long; juxta complex, entire in most species but narrowed ventrally almost to the point of division; vesica<tei:lb/>lacking spicular cornuti; aedeagus with or without spinose carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. Hind tibia with apical and subapical tufts of elongate, dark-tipped scales;<tei:lb/>juxta of male complex, strongly modified and incorporated with valvae to form a functional valvae-juxta<tei:lb/>complex (as in Necroscardia); females of most species with segments VII markedly reduced in length but<tei:lb/>with extended intersegmental membrane between segments VII and VIII bearing a strong corethrogyne of<tei:lb/>fine, elongate scales.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Afrotropical region; Oriental region; Australian region as far east as the Solomon Is and as<tei:lb/>far south as Queensland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. One species has been reared from fungus on bamboo (see Robinson, 1976: 257). Typical habitats<tei:lb/>are shown in Figs 199 and 200.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Further treatment of Tinissa is not provided here: descriptions and illustrations of the 34<tei:lb/>included species have been provided by Robinson (1976; 1981).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SCARDIELLA gen. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type-species: Scardia approximated Dietz, 1905: 27.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Antenna (male) with dorsal cilia, ventral surface scaled; cilia longer than 1-5 x flagellar<tei:lb/>diameter. Scape with fewer than 15 pecten bristles. Interocular index (male) 1-0 or less. Maxillary palpus<tei:lb/>5-segmented; pilifers present; second segment of labial palpus shorter than width of head. Outer mid and<tei:lb/>proximal hind tibial spurs &gt;0-4 length of inner spurs. Forewing with 7? 3 and R 4 separate; M 2 , M 3 and CuAi<tei:lb/>separate; mottled coloration forming cryptic, coarse 'moss' pattern. Male lacking coremata in eighth<tei:lb/>abdominal segment. Male genitalia with complex uncus separated from tegumen by narrow band of<tei:lb/>membrane; tegumen broken dorsally by at least a membranous suture line; valva lacking basal setose lobe<tei:lb/>on inner surface; apex of valva not forming ventral hook or hooks, without spines; valvae separate, not<tei:lb/>fused together ventrally, without longitudinal cleft; saccus longer than wide; juxta simple, entire, not<tei:lb/>divided medially; vesica with spicular cornuti; aedeagus with spicular or spinose carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. Bulbus ejaculatorius of male very large, almost 3 x length of aedeagus;<tei:lb/>ductus bursae of female with spicular inner surface from two-thirds to nine-tenths posteriorly (this also<tei:lb/>occurs, probably by convergence, in Montescardiafuscofascielld).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Nearctic region.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 109</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scardiella approximately (Dietz) comb. n.<tei:lb/>(Figs 52, 107, 161)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scardia approximated Dietz, 1905: 27. LECTOTYPE cf , U.S.A. (NMNH), here designated [examined<tei:lb/>on author's behalf by D. R. Davis].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Dietz, 1905: pi. 1, fig. 8; Fig. 52). O"$, 13-16 mm. Vertex and frons cream, tinted with brown<tei:lb/>around eyes. Labial palpus whitish, strongly flecked with brown on outer surface of second segment and<tei:lb/>middle of outer surface of third segment. Maxillary palpus whitish, flecked with light brown, 5-segmented,<tei:lb/>extending to three-quarters length of second segment of labial palpus. Antennal scape, pedicel and<tei:lb/>flagellum greyish buff, dark brown above, flagellum dark brown above only on basal five or six segments;<tei:lb/>cilia 2-0-2-5 x (cf) or 0-4 x () flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula cream, tegula strongly flecked<tei:lb/>anteriorly with brown, thorax flecked laterally and far anteriorly with brown.
