Forewing whitish, strongly<tei:lb/>flecked with light orange-brown, particularly along veins, and patterned with dark brown to form strong<tei:lb/>medial and basal fasciae and dense spotting over remainder of wing; fringe with medial grey-brown line and<tei:lb/>irregular chequering. Hindwing pale greyish cream, fringe lighter. Legs pale buff-cream, foreleg and<tei:lb/>mid-leg strongly marked with dark brown above and on sides (including tarsi) but pale at articulations and<tei:lb/>with strong whitish bar across mid-tibia; hind tarsus strongly marked above with brown; outer mid-tibial<tei:lb/>spur 0-6 length of inner; outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-7 length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Fig. 107). Saccus elongate, triangular; uncus lobes a pair of digitiform processes, widely<tei:lb/>separated, strongly sclerotized. Subscaphium broad but represented only by slight thickening of dia-<tei:lb/>phragma. Juxta represented only by almost imperceptible thickening of anellus; transtilla not developed.<tei:lb/>Valva short, rounded, with strong basicostal digitate process. Aedeagus stout, 7 x as long as broad, with<tei:lb/>shallowly triangular subapical carinae and numerous minute scattered thorn-like carinae; vesica with<tei:lb/>minute spicular cornuti (microtrichia); bulbus ejaculatorius very long, almost 3 x length of aedeagus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Fig. 161). Eighth tergite longer than eighth sternite, with three pairs of strong subapical<tei:lb/>setae; eighth sternite with strongly developed sterigma accommodating short, cylindrical antrum; eighth<tei:lb/>sternite quadrangular caudal to sterigma, hardly sclerotized, with two pairs of strong setae and 12-15 pairs<tei:lb/>of scattered smaller setae; ventral lip of ostium strongly concave. Antrum not extending beyond anterior<tei:lb/>margin of eighth sternite. Ductus bursae elongate, 1-5 x length of apophyses anteriores, lined with stout<tei:lb/>microtrichia anterior to inception of ductus seminalis at level of one-half length of apophyses anteriores<tei:lb/>(i.e., short length of ductus bursae posterior to ductus seminalis is without microtrichia). Corpus bursae<tei:lb/>pyriform, continuous with ductus, thin-walled; signa absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. U.S.A.: Pennsylvania, New Jersey, District of Columbia, Maryland, Ohio (Dietz, 1905);<tei:lb/>New York; Massachusetts, Georgia (Forbes, 1923). Canada: Toronto.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. The larva has been found in a rotten sycamore log (Forbes, 1923).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 5 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lectotype cf , U.S.A.: Maryland, Plummer's Island, vii.1901 (Busck) (NMNH) [examined on author's<tei:lb/>behalf by D.R.Davis].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>U.S.A.: 1 $ (paralectotype), Pennsylvania, Hazleton, 15.vii.1896 (Dietz) (BMNH); 1 $, New York,<tei:lb/>Fishers, 21.vii.1933 (Klots) (genitalia slide no. 12403; BMNH). Canada: 3 cf, Toronto, vi.1922 (Parish)<tei:lb/>(genitalia slide no. 12402; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This small species is very distinctive. Its pattern is lighter than that of all other North American<tei:lb/>scardiines and resembles more that of a nemapogonine. The antennal cilia of the male are extraordinarily<tei:lb/>long: few other Scardiinae have cilia more than twice as long as the diameter of the flagellar segments. The<tei:lb/>strongly patterned hind tarsi are also characteristic: they are pale in most other scardiines. Scardiella<tei:lb/>appears to be a 'primitive' taxon. It has only six apomorphies (Table 1) and its affinities are obscure. Its<tei:lb/>apomorphic features are its elongate antennal cilia, absence of coremata, complex uncus, dorsally<tei:lb/>discontinuous tegumen, sparse setal patch on the second abdominal sternite, and its basicostal process on<tei:lb/>the valva. This last has been scored as a 'basal setose lobe' in Table 1, homologous with that ofMorophaga,<tei:lb/>Amorophaga and Diataga. However, I believe it is an independent development and it is not included in<tei:lb/>the generic diagnosis. Afroscardia also has a setose lobe and this has been scored similarly; the lobe is<tei:lb/>subcostal and situated far distad on the valva . It seems unlikely that it is homologous with that of Scardiella .<tei:lb/>The affinity of the two taxa suggested by numerical analysis is, in all probability, due to convergence.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>110 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>AFROSCARDIA gen. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type-species: Polymnestra capnochalca Meyrick, 1932ft: 207.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Antenna (male) with dorsal cilia, ventral surface scaled; cilia longer than 1-5 x flagellar<tei:lb/>diameter. Scape with more than 15 pecten bristles. Interocular index (male) 1-0 or less. Maxillary palpus<tei:lb/>with fewer than 5 segments; pilifers present; second segment of labial palpus shorter than width of head.<tei:lb/>Outer mid and proximal hind tibial spurs &gt;0-4 length of inner spurs. Forewing with /? 3 and R 4 separate ; M 2 ,<tei:lb/>A/3 and CuAi separate; mottled coloration forming cryptic, coarse 'moss' pattern. Male lacking coremata<tei:lb/>in eighth abdominal segment. Male genitalia with simple uncus - a pair of setose lobes - fused with<tei:lb/>tegumen; tegumen broken dorsally by broad, membranous region; valva lacking basal setose lobe on inner<tei:lb/>surface; apex of valva forming ventral hook or hooks, or with spines; valvae separate, not fused together<tei:lb/>ventrally, without longitudinal cleft; saccus longer than wide; juxta simple, entire, not divided medially;<tei:lb/>vesica lacking spicular cornuti; aedeagus with spicular or spinose carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. Sclerotization of tegumen interrupted dorsally by broad membranous<tei:lb/>region between lateral arms of tegumen; lobes of uncus fused with tegumen so that genital armature<tei:lb/>terminates dorsocaudally in a pair of widely separated lobes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Afrotropical region - Uganda.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Afroscardia capnochalca (Meyrick) comb. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 51)<tei:lb/>Polymnestra capnochalca Meyrick, 1932ft: 207. Holotype cf , UGANDA (BMNH) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 51). Cf $, 18-20 mm. Vertex and frons purple-brown. Labial palpus purple-brown, second<tei:lb/>segment white on inner surface and on apex of ventral tuft. Maxillary palpus whitish, very short,<tei:lb/>3-segmented. Antennal scape, pedicel and flagellum dark brown, paler beneath and on pecten; cilia 2-0 x<tei:lb/>(cf) or 0-8 x (9) flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula purple-brown. Forewing uniformly purple-brown<tei:lb/>with violet iridescence, apex slightly paler; fringe yellow. Hindwing greyish brown, fringe yellowish. Legs<tei:lb/>ochreous buff, dark brown above and on sides; outer mid-tibial spur 0-6 length of inner; outer proximal<tei:lb/>hind tibial spur 0-75 length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Gozmany &amp; Vari, 1973: fig. 451). Saccus elongate, tapered, longer than tegumen + uncus;<tei:lb/>uncus lobes flap-like, small, widely separated, only weakly sclerotized; transtilla not developed. Valva<tei:lb/>elongately triangular with slightly hooked apex, with small subcostal setose lobe at two-thirds. Aedeagus<tei:lb/>slender, elongate , more than 15 x as long as broad, with very fine spicular subapical carinae ; vesica without<tei:lb/>cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $. Unknown.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. Uganda (Ruwenzori Mts).<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 5 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Uganda: [Ruwenzori Mts], Bujubis, 12,000', 16.viii.1931 (Hancock) (genitalia slide no.<tei:lb/>10264; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Uganda: 1 9 (paratype) (abdomen missing), Ruwenzori Mts, 10,000', viii.1931 (Hancock) (BMNH); 1<tei:lb/>Cf , Ruwenzori Range, Bigo, 11,400', 29. vii. 1952 (Fletcher) (BMNH); 2 cf , Ruwenzori Range, heath zone<tei:lb/>above Nyamgasani Valley, 12-13,000', xii.1934-i.1935 (Buxton) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This is the only scardiine that has an entirely plain-coloured forewing. It resembles superficially<tei:lb/>Bythocrates from the New World, but in that genus the fringes are concolorous with the forewing and there<tei:lb/>is a row of pale spots along the costa. Afroscardia is distinctive also in that, despite its having a complete<tei:lb/>venation (although R 4 and R 5 are connate), it is very narrow-winged, the forewing more than four times as<tei:lb/>long as broad. The only other scardiine genus with the wings so slender is Diataga. The male genitalia of<tei:lb/>Afroscardia are distinctive in that the tegumen is broken dorsally by a membranous zone and the uncus<tei:lb/>lobes are widely separated: the terminal arms of the tegumen are strongly sclerotized and rod-like.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 111</tei:p>
         <tei:p>AMOROPHAGA Zagulajev</tei:p>
         <tei:p>^Amorophaga Zagulajev, 1966: 634. [Nomen nudum.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amorophaga Zagulajev, 1968: 329. Type-species: Amorophaga hyrcanica Zagulajev, 1968: 331, figs 1, 2,<tei:lb/>by original designation and monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Antenna (male) lacking dorsal cilia, ventral surface without scales; cilia longer than 1-5 x<tei:lb/>flagellar diameter (but shorter in hyrcanica). Scape with more than 15 pecten bristles. Interocular index<tei:lb/>(male) 1-0 or less. Maxillary palpus 5-segmented; pilifers present; second segment of labial palpus shorter<tei:lb/>than width of head. Outer mid and proximal hind tibial spurs &gt;0-4 length of inner spurs. Forewing with /? 3<tei:lb/>and /? 4 stalked or very closely approximated at base; M 2 , M 3 and CuA\ separate; pattern elements<tei:lb/>consisting of greyish or olivaceous longitudinal streaks on a paler background. Male with coremata in<tei:lb/>eighth abdominal segment; coremata without associated apodemes. Male genitalia with complex uncus<tei:lb/>separated from tegumen by narrow band of membrane ; tegumen broken dorsally by at least a membranous<tei:lb/>suture line; valva with setose basal lobe on inner surface; apex of valva forming ventral hook or hooks, or<tei:lb/>with spines; valvae separate, not fused together ventrally, with deep emargination forming longitudinal<tei:lb/>cleft; saccus wider than long; juxta complex, divided medially; however, juxta simple and undivided in<tei:lb/>cryptophori, vesica lacking spicular cornuti; aedeagus with spinose carinae (but not in cryptophori).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. Wing pattern composed of longitudinal streaks.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Holarctic-U.S.S.R. (Azerbaidjan), Nepal, Japan, U.S.A. (Idaho, California).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. See Amorophaga cryptophori (Clarke).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species of Amorophaga</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Males (males of rosemariae are unknown)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Antennal cilia shorter than 1-5 x flagellar diameter; uncus broad, short, with pair of small lateral</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ventrally-directed hooks hyrcanica(p. 113)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Antennal cilia longer than 1-5 x flagellar diameter; uncus narrow, elongate, without lateral</tei:p>
         <tei:p>hooks 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Uncus with pair of strong, curved processes directed ventrally and caudally and resembling a</tei:p>
         <tei:p>gnathos. (western U.S.A.) cryptophori (p. 112)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Uncus lacking any ventrally-directed processes (Fig. 112). (Japan) japonica(p. 114)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Females (females of hyrcanica and japonica are unknown)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Forewing ground-colour cream (with olivaceous tint when fresh), strongly marked with orange-<tei:lb/>buff and dark brown, overall appearance olivaceous (Fig. 57) ; outer mid tibial spur only about<tei:lb/>0-3 length of inner spur; frenulum with two bristles; seventh sternite with posterior margin<tei:lb/>strongly sclerotized and serrated (Fig. 168) . (Nepal) rosemar/ae(p. Ill)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Forewing ground-colour very pale grey, lightly marked with brownish grey, overall appearance</tei:p>
         <tei:p>greyish (Figs 58, 59); outer mid tibial spur one-half length of inner spur; frenulum with about<tei:lb/>six bristles; seventh sternite with smooth and only lightly sclerotized posterior margin,<tei:lb/>(western U.S. A.) cryptophori (p. 112)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amorophaga rosemariae sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 57, 167,168, 198)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 57). $, 23, 29 mm. Vertex and frons whitish, scales greyish brown basally. Labial palpus<tei:lb/>whitish, most scales of second segment tipped with blackish brown; third segment with elongate brown spot<tei:lb/>on outer surface. Maxillary palpus whitish, second and third segment with dark brown scales above.<tei:lb/>Antennal scape and pedicel pale buff, scape with a few dark dorsal scales; flagellum pale buff; cilia 1-0 x<tei:lb/>flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula whitish, strongly flecked with brown. Forewing cream marked with<tei:lb/>orange-buff (particularly along veins) and dark brown; overall appearance olivaceous in fresh specimen<tei:lb/>but rapidly becoming brownish; pattern similar to that of Morophaga choragella but disrupted by<tei:lb/>longitudinal streaking; conspicuous dark spots at two-thirds of costa and in middle of posterior margin.<tei:lb/>Legs dull buff speckled with brown; foreleg and mid-leg strongly speckled with brown above, but all legs<tei:lb/>paler at articulations; outer mid-tibial spur 0-3 length of inner; outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-6 length of<tei:lb/>inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf . Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>112</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Figs 167, 168). Seventh sternite with strongly serrated and sclerotized posterior margin and<tei:lb/>with small V-shaped medial emargination. Eighth tergite narrow, shallowly bilobed posteriorly, with<tei:lb/>about 10 strong marginal setae and numerous smaller scattered marginal and submarginal setae; eighth<tei:lb/>sternite almost square in ventral view but extended laterally dorsad to almost meet the narrow tergite;<tei:lb/>ostium transverse, sternite transversely ridged to either side and extended caudally and inwardly to form<tei:lb/>pair of terminal lobes posterior to ostium, each bearing three strong setae and numerous smaller setae.<tei:lb/>Antrum smooth-walled to one-half length of sternite then strongly folded longitudinally anterior to<tei:lb/>inception of ductus seminalis, reaching two-thirds length of apophyses anteriores. Ductus bursae as long as<tei:lb/>antrum, very thin-walled, contiguous with corpus bursae which is elongately ovoid and thin-walled; signa<tei:lb/>absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Nepal.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. Unknown. The holotype was collected at mercury-vapour light at about 2100 hrs in primary<tei:lb/>montane Himalayan oak forest (Fig. 198). The paratype was collected some 800 m lower down the same<tei:lb/>ridge, in the Schima-Castanopsis zone.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 2 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Nepal: Kathmandu district, Phulchoki, 2700 m (8800'), 28.V.1983 (Robinson et al.)<tei:lb/>(genitalia slide no. 6994; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratype. Nepal: 1 $ , data as holotype but 1950 m, mixed Schima-Castanopsis forest, 19. vi. 1984 (Allen)<tei:lb/>(BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The generic placement of this species must be considered somewhat doubtful. A. rosemariae<tei:lb/>exhibits similarities to species of the Morophaga choragella-group (wing pattern; eighth sternite extended<tei:lb/>dorsally; antrum elongate and strongly folded) but differs sufficiently (in disruption of pattern and in<tei:lb/>laterocaudal extension of the eighth sternite) to make doubtful its attribution to that group. In placing it in<tei:lb/>Amorophaga, considerable weight is given to the wing-pattern. Such streaking of a recognizable pattern<tei:lb/>does not occur elsewhere in the Scardiinae and may represent a stage in the transformation of the<tei:lb/>Morophaga-type pattern to the markedly derived streaked pattern of the other three Amorophaga species.<tei:lb/>This is the only species of scardiine in which the caudal margin of the seventh sternite in the female is<tei:lb/>serrated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The remaining three species of Amorophaga (hyrcanica, cryptophori andjaponica) have a similar pale,<tei:lb/>streaked wing-pattern but that of hyrcanica is the palest and the most noticeably brown-tinted. The pattern<tei:lb/>of cryptophori is distinctly grey, that ofjaponica greyish brown (although both specimens ofjaponica are<tei:lb/>faded). The four species of Amorophaga are allopatric. A tentative phylogeny for the genus would have<tei:lb/>hyrcanica andjaponica as sister-groups (synapomorphies: pale wing-pattern, ventrocaudal hook on valva,<tei:lb/>short, stout aedeagus), cryptophori the sister-group of hyrcanica + japonica (synapomorphy: wing-<tei:lb/>pattern) and rosemariae the sister-group of these three.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amorophaga cryptophori (Clarke) comb. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 58)<tei:lb/>Morophaga cryptophori Clarke, 1940: 114. Holotype cf , U.S.A. (NMNH) [not examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Clarke, 1940: figs 2 [head], 3-3b [venation]; Fig. 58). cf$, 23-29 mm. Vertex and frons light<tei:lb/>greyish brown, all scales tipped with white. Labial and maxillary palpus coloured similarly. Antennal scape<tei:lb/>and pedicel light greyish brown, all scales tipped with white; pecten bristles darker brown, tipped with<tei:lb/>white; flagellum greyish brown, scales tipped with white; cilia 3 x (cf) or 1-0 x ($) flagellar diameter.<tei:lb/>Thorax and tegula as head. Forewing very pale grey; strong speckles of brownish grey forming irregular<tei:lb/>longitudinal streaks, some darker marks at end of cell, and conspicuously barred termen and fringe.<tei:lb/>Hindwing pale grey. Legs brownish grey (but hind femur and tibia paler), paler beneath and at<tei:lb/>articulations above; fore- and mid-tibiae banded above with white at base and middle; outer mid-tibial spur<tei:lb/>0-5 length of inner; outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-7 length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Clarke, 1940: figs 1-lb, 5). Saccus very broad, 1-3 x as wide as long, and shorter than valvae<tei:lb/>or uncus; uncus lobes slender, digitiform, setose, anteriorly infolded ventrad to form pair of caudally-<tei:lb/>directed hooks resembling the two halves of a gnathos. Subscaphium slender, well-sclerotized, rod-like.<tei:lb/>Juxta elongately ovate, transversely wrinkled, rugose, moulded round anellus; transtilla not developed.<tei:lb/>Valva divided by longitudinal cleft into spatulate dorsal lobe and shorter, broader ventral lobe with<tei:lb/>irregularly dentate ventral margin and similarly dentate mediolongitudinal ridge converging with ventral<tei:lb/>margin close to base; base of valva with broad, setose ventral lobe. Aedeagus stout, 8 x as long as broad at</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 113</tei:p>
         <tei:p>one-half, tapered and only sclerotized on dorsal surface from one-half, lacking carinae; vesica without<tei:lb/>cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Clarke, 1940: figs 4, 4a). Eighth tergite with strongly trilobed posterior margin, with about<tei:lb/>12 strong marginal setae and similar number of smaller setae; eighth sternite strongly sclerotized, ostium at<tei:lb/>a little beyond one-half, flanked by pair of short lobes, each with four or five strong setae and similar<tei:lb/>number of smaller setae ; sternite produced into large , conspicuous caudal flap to side of each lobe . Antrum<tei:lb/>1-5 x length of eighth sternite, transversely ridged close to ostium just anterior to inception of ductus<tei:lb/>seminalis at four-figths posteriorly; sides of antrum weakly folded ventrad in anterior third. Ductus bursae<tei:lb/>as long as antrum, very thin-walled. Corpus bursae almost spherical, very thin-walled; signa absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. U.S.A. (Idaho, California).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. The type-series was reared from Cryptophorus (= Polyporus) volvatus (Clarke, 1940). Lawrence<tei:lb/>&amp; Powell (1969: 43) recorded cryptophori from the same fungus associated with Abies and Pinus in several<tei:lb/>scattered localities in California. They considered this to be the only Californian scardiine that is<tei:lb/>host-specific.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 4 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>U.S.A.: 1 cf , 3 $, California, El Dorado Co., Blodgett Forest, 13 m. E. of Georgetown, reared from<tei:lb/>Polyporus volvatus coll. 9.vii.l967, em. 23-26. vii. 1967 (Turner} (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The wing-pattern of this species is similar only to those of the Old World species hyrcanica and<tei:lb/>japonica. The male genitalia differ conspicuously in the structure of the uncus lobes which are extended<tei:lb/>ventrally and caudally to form a striking imitation of a gnathos (a structure absent in the Scardiinae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amorophaga hyrcanica Zagulajev<tei:lb/>Amorophaga hyrcanica Zagulajev, 1968: 331, figs 1, 2. Holotype cf , U.S.S.R. (ZI) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Zagulajev, 1973: fig. 98). $, 21, 23 mm. (For full description, see Zagulajev (1968: 331, or 1973:<tei:lb/>118).) Antenna! cilia 1-0 x (cf) flagellar diameter. Forewing with R 3 and R 4 only approximated at base,<tei:lb/>cream patterned with diffuse longitudinal streaks of light purplish brown, conspicuous dark brown costal<tei:lb/>and terminal spots, strong basal streak and more diffuse subtornal blotch at three-quarters of posterior<tei:lb/>margin. Hindwing cream, darker marginal spots at ends of veins. Outer mid-tibial and outer proximal hind<tei:lb/>tibial spurs 0-5 length of inner spurs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Zagulajev, 1968: fig. 2; 1973: fig. 99). Saccus broad, as wide as or wider than long, as long as<tei:lb/>tegumen + uncus; uncus lobes almost fused in dorsal mid-line, inturned ventrad and strongly sclerotized<tei:lb/>laterally to form pair of blunt, ventrally-directed hooks. Valva with elongate, digitiform costal process<tei:lb/>extending well beyond uncus or ventral region of valva; ventral region bilobed, ventral lobe inturned,<tei:lb/>blunt, hook-like; base of valva with broad, setose membranous lobe; small, digitate process from middle of<tei:lb/>valva. Aedeagus about 6 x as long as broad at mid-length, as long as genital armature (excluding costal<tei:lb/>process of valva).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ . Unknown.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. U.S.S.R. (Azerbaidjan).<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 2 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , U.S.S.R.: Azerbaidjan, Talysh, Astara dist., R. Lyakar, district of Mamagon Village (22<tei:lb/>km W. of Pensar), 2000 m, 10.viii.1962 (Zagulajev) (ZI).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 cf (paratype), data as holotype but Alashya Village, ix.1962 (ZI).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The antennal cilia of male hyrcanica are shorter than those of cryptophori or japonica (males of<tei:lb/>rosemariae are unknown) and the genitalia are distinctive; the other two species have the costal lobe of the<tei:lb/>valva flattened and smaller, and the uncus lobes are of different form (produced ventrally and caudally to<tei:lb/>form a passable copy of a gnathos - cryptophori - or tapered with subapical 'thorns' - japonica). See<tei:lb/>'Remarks' for A. rosemariae for further comments.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>114 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amorophagajaponicasp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 59, 112)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 59). d", 22 mm - holotype, 23 mm - paratype. (Both specimens faded.) Vertex and frons very<tei:lb/>light brown, scales strongly tipped with white. Labial palpus and maxillary palpus coloured similarly.<tei:lb/>Antennal scape and pedicel with scales light brown basally, otherwise whitish; flagellum whitish; cilia 2-5 x<tei:lb/>flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula light brown, scales tipped with white. Forewing white, strongly<tei:lb/>speckled with light brown to form irregular longitudinal streaks and conspicuously barred termen and<tei:lb/>fringe. Hindwing light brownish grey. Legs light brown; foreleg and mid-leg darker above; all legs whitish<tei:lb/>at articulations; mid-tibia entirely whitish except for oblique brown streak on outer surface; outer<tei:lb/>mid-tibial spur and outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-7 length of inner spurs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA C? (Fig. 112). Saccus short, 1-5 x as broad as long; uncus lobes triangular, strongly sclerotized,<tei:lb/>setose, each with pair of small, subapical thorn-like projections. Subscaphium broad, tapered caudally.<tei:lb/>Juxta ill-defined, weakly sclerotized, ovate, moulded round anellus; transtilla not developed. Valva with<tei:lb/>short, setose costal lobe (probably homologous with dorsal lobe of cryptophori and costal process of<tei:lb/>hyrcanicd) not reaching apex of valva; ventral (conspicuous) lobe of valva tapered and slightly hooked<tei:lb/>apically , with three small subapical thorn-like processes; ventral margin with strong dorsally-directed spine<tei:lb/>at two-thirds; base of valva with broad, setose, membranous lobe. Aedeagus stout, 7 x as long as broad,<tei:lb/>with elongate membranous channel extending dorsally from apex almost to base; apical quarter with fine,<tei:lb/>spicular carinae; vesica without cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA 9- Unknown.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. Japan.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 2 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Japan: 1886 (Pryer) (genitalia slide no. 13354; BMNH).<tei:lb/>Paratype. Japan: 1 d", Tottori, Daisen, 9-11. vii. 1964 (Takahama) (coll. S. Moriuti, Osaka).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is superficially similar to hyrcanica and cryptophori. It has a finer and more greyish<tei:lb/>wing-pattern then hyrcanica but, from the limited material available, is not separable by external<tei:lb/>characteristics from cryptophori. The male genitalia differ in the extremely short costal process (dorsal<tei:lb/>lobe) of the valva being shorter than the ventral lobe of the valva: it is longer in the other two species. The<tei:lb/>uncus lobes are characteristic in all three species - modified to form a gnathos-like pair of processes in<tei:lb/>cryptophori, square-tipped and inturned to form a pair of small hooks in hyrcanica and elongately<tei:lb/>triangular with subapical 'thorns' injaponica.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIATAGA Walsingham</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Diataga Walsingham, 1914: 374. Type-species: Diataga leptosceles Walsingham, 1914: 375, pi. 10, fig. 26,<tei:lb/>by original designation and monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Antenna (male) lacking dorsal cilia, ventral surface without scales; cilia longer than 1-5 x<tei:lb/>flagellar diameter. Scape with more than 15 pecten bristles. Interocular index (male) 1-0 or less. Maxillary<tei:lb/>palpus 5-segmented; pilifers present; second segment of labial palpus shorter than width of head. Outer<tei:lb/>mid and proximal hind tibial spurs &lt;0-4 length of inner spurs. Forewing with Rj and R 4 stalked or very<tei:lb/>closely approximated at base; M 2 and A/ 3 stalked or very closely approximated at base; mottled coloration<tei:lb/>forming cryptic, coarse 'moss' pattern. Male with coremata in eighth abdominal segment; coremata<tei:lb/>associated with elongate, rod-like apodemes at anterior corners of eighth sternite. Male genitalia with<tei:lb/>simple uncus - a pair of setose lobes - separated from tegumen by narrow band of membrane; tegumen<tei:lb/>unbroken, completely sclerotized dorsally; valva with setose basal lobe on inner surface; apex of valva<tei:lb/>forming ventral hook or hooks, or with spines; valvae separate, not fused together ventrally, without<tei:lb/>longitudinal cleft; saccus longer than wide; juxta complex, divided medially; vesica with spicular cornuti;<tei:lb/>aedeagus smooth-surfaced, without spicular carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. Two pairs of veins fused, stalked or connate in forewing; M 2 and M 3<tei:lb/>stalked or very closely approximated at base in forewing; aedeagus bifurcated from close to base, dorsal<tei:lb/>arm with apex swollen; juxta bifid, forming pair of strongly defined lobes either side of anellus, and closely<tei:lb/>associated with basal setose lobes of valvae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Neotropical region; Nearctic region - Arizona only.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 115</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. See Diataga leptosceles Walsingham.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species of Diataga</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Females (females of compsacma, brasiliensis , frustraminis and levidensis are unknown).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>shallowly concave 2</tei:p>

         <tei:p>(Fig. 171) direpta(p. 120)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Diataga leptosceles Walsingham<tei:lb/>(Figs 60, 113, 114, 121, 169, 183, 185-188, 193-197)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Diataga leptosceles Walsingham, 1914: 375. LECTOTYPE cf, MEXICO (BMNH), here designated<tei:lb/>[examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Walsingham, 1914: pi. 10, fig. 26 (colour); Figs 60, 183). cf$ , 17-34 mm. Vertex and frons cream,<tei:lb/>streaked with brown close to eyes. Labial palpus cream flecked with light brown, whitish on inner surface,<tei:lb/>densely flecked with brown on upper surface of second segment. Maxillary palpus cream, densely flecked<tei:lb/>with brown above on second segment. Antennal scape and pedicel cream, densely flecked above with light<tei:lb/>brown; flagellum light buff; cilia 2-5 x (cf) flagellar diameter (females examined all have the antennae<tei:lb/>missing). Thorax whitish flecked with brown; tegula brown with a few white scales. Forewing densely<tei:lb/>mottled medium and dark brown, with a few scattered pale scales; termen with black spots edged with<tei:lb/>cream between veins; costa with rectangular cream spot at one-half, and one at three-quarters, smaller and<tei:lb/>inconspicuous white spots closer to apex. Hindwing dark grey. Legs cream, strongly flecked with brown<tei:lb/>above and at sides, more lightly below, but hind tarsus pale; outer mid-tibial and outer proximal hind tibial<tei:lb/>spur 0-25 length of inner spurs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA d* (Figs 113, 114, 121). Saccus slender, elongate, twice as long as broad; uncus lobes slender,<tei:lb/>elongate, 0-40 length of genital armature, moderately sclerotized, setose. Subscaphium elongate, ribbon-<tei:lb/>like. Juxta with collar-shaped base, forming pair of lateral shark's fin-shaped lobes with slightly ballooned<tei:lb/>membranous internal surface; transtilla collar-shaped, closely associated with setose and spinose lobes at<tei:lb/>bases of valvae. Valva with triangular process close to ventral margin, a further rounded or triangular<tei:lb/>process just dorsal to this, and a rounded or triangular process nearer to apex. Aedeagus with conspicuous<tei:lb/>mushroom-shaped dorsal arm extending well beyond ventral arm (aedeagus proper).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA (Fig. 169). Eighth tergite narrow, elongate, with pair of subapical groups of setae, each<tei:lb/>consisting of 4-5 large and similar number of small setae; eighth sternite forming strongly developed<tei:lb/>sterigma, ostium apical and flanked either side by pair of large setae plus 4-5 small setae; membrane of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>116 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ovipositor dorsal to sterigma with strong transverse wrinkles. Antrum twice length of eighth sternite,<tei:lb/>inception of ductus seminalis at two-thirds posteriorly. Ductus bursae broadening gradually into pear-<tei:lb/>shaped corpus bursae that extends to 1-25 length of apophyses anteriores; signa absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. (?)U.S.A. (Arizona - Lawrence &amp; Powell, 1969); Mexico; Costa Rica; Ecuador; Trinidad;<tei:lb/>French Guiana; Brazil; Peru.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. Lawrence &amp; Powell (1969: 44) record this species from Daedalea microsticta in Mexico and<tei:lb/>(identified tentatively) from Polyporus vulpinus on Populus fremontii in Arizona. Becker (pers. comrn.)<tei:lb/>has bred this species from a 'polyporus' in Costa Rica; larvae and pupae from this rearing are figured here<tei:lb/>(Figs 185-188, 193-197). For notes on larvae and pupae of this species, see 'Biology' for the Scardiinae,<tei:lb/>above.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 14 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lectotype cf , Mexico: Vera Cruz, Jalapa, 1895 (Schaus) (genitalia slide no. 12409; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mexico: 1 $?, data as lectotype but 1897. Ecuador: 1 cf, (Joannis). Trinidad: 1 cf (abdomen missing),<tei:lb/>vi.1905 (Busck). No data: 1 cf . (All BMNH; all paralectotypes.) Costa Rica: 1 cf , 1 $, Turrialba, 600 m,<tei:lb/>6.iv.l975, 5.viii.l971 (Becker} (coll. V. O. Becker, Brasilia); 2 cf , 3 pupae, 3 larvae, Turrialba, 25.V.1972<tei:lb/>[bred from a fungus] (Becker) (coll. V. O. Becker, Brasilia). French Guiana: 1 cf , Nouvelle Chantier, iv.<tei:lb/>(Le Moult) (BMNH). Brazil: 1 cf , Amazonas, Prainha, at light, 17.xii.1873 (Trail) (BMNH); 1 cf , Teffe,<tei:lb/>xii.1919 (Parish) (BMNH); 1 cf , Sta Catarina, Brusque, 6.ix.l970 (Becker) (coll. V. O. Becker, Brasilia).<tei:lb/>Peru: 1 cf , Pacaya, vi.1912 (M.) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. One male paralectotype of leptosceles is not of this species but is referable to frustraminis (q.v.),<tei:lb/>the only other Diataga known that is dark-winged and almost patternless. D. leptosceles may be separated<tei:lb/>from frustraminis by its pale costal markings on the forewing (absent in frustraminis) and brown tegulae<tei:lb/>(whitish in frustraminis). The remaining species of Diataga are pale (brasiliensis, compsacma, levidensis,<tei:lb/>mercennarid) or have a strongly developed pattern (direpta) reminiscent of that of Morophaga choragella.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The male genitalia of specimens from French Guiana and Brazil differ slightly from those of the<tei:lb/>lectotype from Mexico in that the costa of the valva is emarginate close to the apex and the two dorsal<tei:lb/>processes of the valva are pointed rather than rounded. The significance, if any, of this regional variation<tei:lb/>may become clearer when further material is available. At present I consider the two genital types to<tei:lb/>represent a single species. The dorsal process of the aedeagus, and the form of the valva, differ from that<tei:lb/>exhibited by other Diataga species (compare illustrations). The male genitalia of leptosceles differ from<tei:lb/>frustraminis in lacking a ventrally hooked valva (compare illustrations) and in the form of the aedeagus;<tei:lb/>this has the dorsal process mushroom-shaped in leptosceles but spatulate and hooked in frustraminis . The<tei:lb/>apex of the aedeagus proper (the ventral arm of the aedeagus) is obliquely truncated in leptosceles and<tei:lb/>arum flower-shaped in frustraminis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The female genitalia differ from those of the other two species of which the female is known<tei:lb/>(mercennaria and direpta) in that the dorsal margin of the ostium is shallowly concave (V-shaped in<tei:lb/>mercennaria', straight in direpta), the sides of the sterigma are not explanate as in mercennaria, the ostium is<tei:lb/>broader than in direpta and the eighth tergite extends caudally beyond the eighth sternite (it does not reach<tei:lb/>the tip of the sterigma in direpta).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Diataga frustraminis sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 61, 115, 122)<tei:lb/>[Diataga leptosceles Walsingham, 1914: 375, partim- 1 cf only. Misidentification.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 61). cf , 21 mm. Coloration and external structure similar to leptosceles but head and palpi not<tei:lb/>so heavily marked with brown, ground-colour chalky white rather than cream; thorax and tegula chalky<tei:lb/>white, only very slightly flecked with pale brown; legs paler and not as heavily marked with brown as in<tei:lb/>leptosceles; forewing costa with scattered pale scales but lacking pair of elongately rectangular cream spots<tei:lb/>present in leptosceles.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Figs 115, 122). Saccus elongate and broad, 1-3 x as long as broad; uncus lobes elongate but<tei:lb/>only 0-25 length of genital armature, moderately sclerotized, setose. Subscaphium ribbon-like, broadened<tei:lb/>anteriorly. Juxta similar to that of leptosceles, apex of lobes distinctly membranous and ballooned;<tei:lb/>transtilla only weakly sclerotized, collar-shaped, inconspicuous, closely associated with spinose lobes at<tei:lb/>bases of valvae. Valva with strongly hooked ventral margin, separated from dorsal region bearing three<tei:lb/>triangular processes by deep emargination . Aedeagus with dorsal arm spatulate , strongly curved ventrad at</tei:p>

         <tei:p>apex; ventral arm (the aedeagus proper) characteristically arum flower-shaped; base of vesica with small,<tei:lb/>sclerotized plate.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Diataga brasiliensis (Zagulajev) comb. n.</tei:p>

Forewing cream marked with orange-brown along veins and speckled with dark<tei:lb/>brown; however, speckling almost absent anterior to R 3 , thus forming a paler costal fascia occupying<tei:lb/>anterior third of wing; dark quadrate costal spot at nearly two-thirds, smaller deep brown spots at apex of<tei:lb/>/?! and at apex of wing between R 2 and R 3 , and between R 4 , R 5 and M l . Hindwing brownish cream with<tei:lb/>distinct golden tint, darker towards margin, with grey apical and subapical (costal) spots.          <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Zagulajev, 1966: fig. 5; Figs 116, 123). Saccus elongate, twice as long as broad; uncus lobes<tei:lb/>short but infolded ventrad and extended anteriorly, 0-25 length of genital armature, quite strongly<tei:lb/>sclerotized, setose only posteriorly, anteriorly wrinkled and more strongly sclerotized. Subscaphium short,<tei:lb/>broad, inverted T-shaped. Juxta with collar-shaped base, forming pair of triangular lateral lobes; transtilla<tei:lb/>collar-shaped, closely associated with triangular setose lobes at bases of valvae. Valva almost triangular,<tei:lb/>ventral margin inturned and with shallow medial and subterminal triangular processes; middle of valva<tei:lb/>with strong fold extending to apex where it terminates in a triangular process; swelling of apical process<tei:lb/>extended as a shallow ridge to process at middle of ventral margin. Aedeagus dorsal arm 0-65 length of<tei:lb/>ventral arm (aedeagus proper), tapered from two-thirds to apex; apex of aedeagus with shallow thorn-like<tei:lb/>carinae; base of aedeagus with strong caudally-directed lobe.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ . Unknown.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. Brazil.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 ex.<tei:lb/>Holotype cf , Brazil: Rio Grande do Sul (genitalia slide [GSR]; MING A).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. In the original description of this species, Zagulajev (1966) gives a date of capture ('5.vii.') for<tei:lb/>the holotype. There is no date given on the data labels and the source of his information is unknown. The<tei:lb/>genitalia of the holotype were dissected and stored in glycerine in a vial by Zagulajev; I have mounted the<tei:lb/>genitalia in Euparal on a slide.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The external appearance of brasiliensis is distinctive; the hindwing is paler than that of leptosceles,<tei:lb/>frustraminis or direpta, more yellowish than that of mercennaria, and resembles that of compsacma or<tei:lb/>levidensis but is distinctively gold-tinted. The forewing pattern is paler than that of leptosceles or<tei:lb/>frustraminis and posteriorly as dark as direpta or mercennaria; however, the anterior third of the wing is<tei:lb/>pale. This division of the forewing into contrasting anterior and posterior fasciae is unknown in any other</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>118 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>scardiine. The genitalia of brasiliensis differ from those of all other Diataga in the form of the aedeagus,<tei:lb/>with its short dorsal arm, and the characteristic pattern of ridging and processes on the valva.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Diataga compsacma Meyrick<tei:lb/>(Figs 63, 117,124)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Diataga compsacma Meyrick, 1919: 270. Lectotype cf , GUYANA (BMNH), designated by Clarke, 1970: 47<tei:lb/>[examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Clarke, 1970: pi. 23, fig. 1 ; Fig. 63). cf , 15, 16 mm. Vertex and frons cream. Labial palpus cream,<tei:lb/>flecked with dark brown on outer and upper surfaces. Maxillary palpus cream flecked with brown above on<tei:lb/>second segment. Antennal scape and pedicel cream with a few brown scales; flagellum very pale buff; cilia 4<tei:lb/>x flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula cream flecked with brown. Forewing cream marked with<tei:lb/>orange-brown along veins and speckled with dark brown; dark speckling concentrated in ill-defined<tei:lb/>wedge-shaped costal spot at one-half, otherwise sparse; pair of apical dark brown spots between R 4 and R 5<tei:lb/>and R 5 and M l edged inwardly by pair of cream transverse lines. Hindwing off-white, flecked apically with<tei:lb/>brown. Legs cream flecked with brown, foreleg and mid-leg more densely flecked, particularly above;<tei:lb/>outer mid-tibial spur 0-3 length of inner; outer proximal hind tibial spur about 0-35 length of inner spur<tei:lb/>(damaged).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Clarke, 1970: pi. 23, figs la, Ib; Figs 117, 124). Saccus elongate, about twice as long as broad<tei:lb/>(but angled in preparation); uncus lobes elongate, broadened apically, 0-25 length of genital armature,<tei:lb/>moderately sclerotized, setose. Subscaphium strongly sclerotized, broadened into inverted Y-shape<tei:lb/>anteriorly. Juxta details not visible in preparation; transtilla, if present, very weakly sclerotized and<tei:lb/>occluded in preparation by slightly sclerotized and strongly setose lobes at bases of valvae. Valva with<tei:lb/>ventral margin turned inward and extended into a triangular spine at one-half; beyond this, a nodular,<tei:lb/>setose excrescence bearing a smaller dorsal spine; 'with wedge-shaped subapical process. Aedeagus with<tei:lb/>dorsal arm swollen distally, curved ventrad and bifurcate at apex, as long as ventral arm (aedeagus proper).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $. Unknown.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. Guyana.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 2 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lectotype cf , Guyana: Bartica, xii.1912 (Parish) (genitalia slide no. JFGC 6651; BMNH).<tei:lb/>Guyana: 1 cf (paralectotype), data as lectotype but i.1913.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is of similar coloration to levidensis and mercennaria although the latter has a more<tei:lb/>strongly developed forewing pattern with elements similar to those of direpta weakly expressed. D.<tei:lb/>compsacma is smaller than mercennaria although this difference may not be significant when further<tei:lb/>material is discovered (see, for example, the size-range of leptosceles) . The wing-pattern of compsacma is<tei:lb/>more brownish than that of levidensis and the brown markings on legs and mouthparts are heavier. The<tei:lb/>male genital armature of compsacma is, like that of levidensis, very small, only about 1-2 mm long. By<tei:lb/>contrast, the genital armature is more than 1 -8 mm long in mercennaria and longer in the other species. The<tei:lb/>male genitalia of mercennaria are quite distinctive - see 'Remarks' for that species. The genital differences<tei:lb/>between compsacma and levidensis are in the valvae and aedeagus. In compsacma the valva bears a medial<tei:lb/>triangular process arising close to the ventral margin with, beyond it, a nodular setose excrescence; in<tei:lb/>levidensis the medial triangular process is very shallow and beyond it arises an elongate process with a<tei:lb/>chisel-shaped end. The dorsal arm (process) of the aedeagus is bifid in compsacma but only channelled<tei:lb/>longitudinally at the apex in levidensis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Diataga levidensis sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 64, 118, 125)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 64). cf , 16 mm. Coloration similar to compsacma, but brown speckling of labial palpus and<tei:lb/>legs very light; second segment of maxillary palpus dark brown above; flagellum white; cilia 3 x flagellar<tei:lb/>diameter. Forewing flecked with whitish scales, these concentrated at costa to form broken pale costal<tei:lb/>streak from one-third. Hindwing off-white, flecked with brown apically and with dark brown apical spot.<tei:lb/>Outer mid-tibial spur 0-35 length of inner; outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-25 length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Figs 118, 125). Saccus triangular, almost twice as long as broad; uncus lobes elongate,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 119</tei:p>
         <tei:p>broadened apically, 0-35 length of genital armature, moderately sclerotized, setose. Subscaphium strongly<tei:lb/>sclerotized, elongate, inverted T-shaped. Juxta with only weakly sclerotized collar-shaped base, forming<tei:lb/>pair of ovate lateral lobes; transtilla collar-shaped, closely associated with setose/spinose lobes at bases of<tei:lb/>valvae. Valva with shallowly inturned ventral margin forming shallow triangular process at one-third; from<tei:lb/>near middle of valva an elongate digitate process with chisel-shaped apex bearing four or five stiff bristles<tei:lb/>on internal bevel of 'chisel'. Aedeagus dorsal arm almost as long as ventral arm (aedeagus proper),<tei:lb/>explanate at apex, surface nearest ventral arm finely scobinate; base of aedeagus with small, round<tei:lb/>membranous areas appearing as perforations.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $. Unknown.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. Peru.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype G", Peru: Iquitos, hi. 1920 (Parish} (genitalia slide no. 12416; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This small, pale species resembles superficially compsacma and is of similar size. The wing-<tei:lb/>pattern resembles also that of mercennaria (which is more variegated) but mercennaria is a larger species<tei:lb/>(about 20 mm wingspan as opposed to 16 mm in levidensis}; however, this difference may not be significant<tei:lb/>when longer series of both species are available. The forewings of compsacma are more brownish and the<tei:lb/>mouthparts and legs more heavily flecked with brown than in levidensis. The male genitalia of levidensis are<tei:lb/>characterized by the valva bearing a single, elongate process with chisel-shaped apex and by the short<tei:lb/>dorsal arm of the aedeagus: only brasiliensis and levidensis have the dorsal arm shorter than the ventral arm<tei:lb/>(aedeagus proper). In levidensis the ventral swelling at the base of the aedeagus is particularly pronounced.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Diataga mercennaria sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 65, 119, 120, 126, 170)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 65). cf $, 19-21 mm. Coloration of head and appendages, thorax and tegulae similar to<tei:lb/>compsacma but flagellum scales off-white tipped with brown in holotype (off-white in paratypes); cilia 3 x<tei:lb/>(C?) or 0-4 x ($)flagellar diameter. Forewing cream, finely speckled with brown; speckles concentrated to<tei:lb/>form inwardly oblique dark fascia from two-thirds of costa; dark brown pair of apical spots between ^ 4 and<tei:lb/>R 5 and R 5 and M t edged inwardly with pair of fine white transverse lines. Hindwing light grey-brown with<tei:lb/>paler speckles towards apex; dark apical spot; some diffuse, smaller, dark terminal spots between veins.<tei:lb/>Legs cream speckled with dark brown, speckles concentrated at bases of tarsi, on upper surface of foreleg<tei:lb/>(solid brown on tibia) and to form pair of ill-defined diagonal streaks on outer surface of mid-tibia; outer<tei:lb/>mid-tibial spur 0-4 length of inner; outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-35 length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Figs 119, 120, 126). Posterior margin of eighth sternite with short digitate process either side<tei:lb/>of mid-line. Saccus square, anterior margin concave, 1-5 x as long as broad; uncus lobes short, 0-25 length<tei:lb/>of genital armature, fairly strongly sclerotized, setose, with strong laterobasal spine. Subscaphium not<tei:lb/>developed. Juxta narrow and ill-defined medially, forming pair of contorted, strongly sclerotized lobes;<tei:lb/>transtilla strongly sclerotized, forming pair of flattened rods overlying and closely associated with<tei:lb/>setose/spinose lobes at bases of valvae. Valva with strongly folded ventral margin forming sclerotized lobe;<tei:lb/>small triangular process from folded surface at one-half. Aedeagus with dorsal arm slightly longer than<tei:lb/>ventral arm, apex slightly swollen and rounded; ventral arm (aedeagus proper) with membranous dorsal<tei:lb/>surface, apex with pair of shallow, sclerotized, dorsally-directed processes each bearing an internal wart;<tei:lb/>base of vesica (? or end of ductus ejaculatorius) with pair of sclerotized plates.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Fig. 170). Eighth tergite elongate, with pair of subapical groups each comprising 3 large and<tei:lb/>3 or 4 small setae; eighth sternite forming strongly developed sterigma with explanate sides; ostium apical,<tei:lb/>flanked either side by 6 or 7 strong setae and a few smaller setae, dorsal margin with V-shaped medial<tei:lb/>emargination. Antrum twice length of eighth sternite, dorsal wall folded into pair of shallow lobes at<tei:lb/>one-half at inception of ductus seminalis. Ductus bursae broadening gradually into corpus bursae that<tei:lb/>extends to 1-25 length of apophyses anteriores; ductus and corpus bursae strongly wrinkled (?unexpanded<tei:lb/>-virgin specimen); signa absent.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>120 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 3 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , French Guiana: St Jean du Maroni, vii (Le Moult) (genitalia slide no. 12407; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. French Guiana: 1 cf, Godebert-Maroni, v (Le Moult) (BMNH). Trinidad: 1 $, Caparo<tei:lb/>(Birch) (genitalia slide no. 12410; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This is a large, pale species with some of the wing-pattern elements of the much darker direpta.<tei:lb/>While mercennaria is larger than known specimens of compsacma or levidensis, this size difference may not<tei:lb/>be significant when longer series are available for comparison. The male genitalia of mercennaria are quite<tei:lb/>distinct from those of other Diataga: the eighth sternite bears caudal processes, the saccus is truncated<tei:lb/>anteriorly with a slightly concave anterior margin, the uncus has a pair of laterobasal spines, the transtilla<tei:lb/>forms a pair of rods, the juxta lobes are contorted and the subscaphium is not developed. The female<tei:lb/>genitalia are distinctive in that the sterigma is laterally explanate, strongly setose to either side of the<tei:lb/>ostium, and the dorsal margin of the ostium is strongly emarginate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Diataga direpta sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 66, 171)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 66). $, 20, 23 mm. Coloration of head and appendages, thorax and tegulae similar to<tei:lb/>compsacma but head tufts with some brown scales admixed; flagellum scales off-white, some tipped with<tei:lb/>brown; cilia 0-3 x flagellar diameter. Forewing predominantly light brown, speckled with darker brown to<tei:lb/>form ill-defined oblique basal and postmedial fasciae; some whitish scales forming medial and subterminal<tei:lb/>blotches on costa, subterminal blotch broadly U-shaped. Hindwing light grey-brown with a few paler flecks<tei:lb/>at apex. Legs cream flecked with brown; foreleg more heavily flecked above, mid-tibia with pair of<tei:lb/>ill-defined oblique brown streaks on outer surface ; outer mid-tibial spur 0-3 length of inner; outer proximal<tei:lb/>hind tibial spur 0-35 length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf . Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Fig. 171). Eighth tergite shorter than eighth sternite, with about 20 pairs of strong setae<tei:lb/>scattered along full length of tergite close to lateral margins; eighth sternite forming strongly developed<tei:lb/>sterigma bearing scattered setae of moderate size over posterior half; ostium apical, narrow, dorsal margin<tei:lb/>transverse, straight. Antrum twice length of eighth sternite, with slight longitudinal fold (?artefact),<tei:lb/>inception of ductus seminalis at two-thirds posteriorly. Ductus bursae broadening gradually into ovoid,<tei:lb/>thin-walled corpus bursae; signa absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Argentina.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 2 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Argentina: Alta Gracia, ii.1934 (C.B.) (genitalia slide no. 12408; BMNH).<tei:lb/>Paratype. 1 $ , same data as holotype (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species resembles superficially Morophaga choragella (q.v.), so much so that Meyrick had<tei:lb/>identified the two specimens above as 'Scardia boleti' in his collection. While the wing-pattern of direpta is<tei:lb/>far more variegated than that of either leptosceles or frustraminis , it is nevertheless a large , dark species and<tei:lb/>more likely to be confused with one of these than with one of the smaller, paler species (brasiliensis ,<tei:lb/>compsacma, levidensis, mercennaria). The female genitalia differ from those of mercennaria and leptos-<tei:lb/>celes in that the sterigma is strongly setose in the posterior half, is not laterally explanate, and the ostial<tei:lb/>diameter is only about 0-06 mm (about 0- 1 mm in leptosceles, 0-15 mm in mercennaria).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MOROPHAGA Herrich-Schaffer</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morophaga Herrich-Schaffer, 1853: (7), (22). Type-species: Euplocamus morellus Duponchel, 1838: 79,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>pi. 288, fig. 5, by subsequent monotypy (Herrich-Schaffer, 1854: 78).<tei:lb/>Atabyria Snellen, 1884: 164. Type-species: Atabyria bucephala Snellen, 1884: 166, pi. 9, fig. 1, by</tei:p>
         <tei:p>monotypy. [Synonymized by Petersen (1959: 577).]<tei:lb/>Osphretica Meyrick, 1910: 475. Type-species: Osphretica chomatias Meyrick, 1910: 475, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[Synonymized by Gozmany (1966: 499).]<tei:lb/>Microscardia Amsel, 1952: 139. Type-species: Noctua boleti F., 1777: 282, by original designation and</tei:p>
         <tei:p>monotypy. [Synonymized by Petersen (1959: 577).]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Antenna (male) lacking dorsal cilia, ventral surface without scales; cilia longer than 1-5 x</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 121</tei:p>
         <tei:p>flagellar diameter. Scape with more than 15 pecten bristles. Interocular index (male) 1-0 or less. Maxillary<tei:lb/>palpus 5-segmented; pilifers present; second segment of labial palpus shorter than width of head. Outer<tei:lb/>mid and proximal hind tibial spurs &gt;0-4 length of inner spurs, but less in borneensis. Forewing with R 3 and<tei:lb/>R 4 stalked or approximated at base; M 2 , M 3 and CuA\ separate; coloration usually mottled, forming<tei:lb/>cryptic, coarse 'moss' pattern, but conspicuously different - bold purple-brown markings on white - in<tei:lb/>bucephala-group. Male with or without coremata in eighth abdominal segment; coremata associated with<tei:lb/>elongate, rod-like apodemes at anterior corners of eighth sternite in choragella-group (but not in<tei:lb/>fasciculata) . Male genitalia with simple uncus - a pair of setose lobes - separated from tegumen by narrow<tei:lb/>band of membrane ; tegumen completely sclerotized dorsally or broken by a membranous suture line ; valva<tei:lb/>with setose basal lobe on inner surface; apex of valva forming ventral hook or hooks, or with spines; valvae<tei:lb/>separate, not fused together ventrally, with deep emargination forming longitudinal cleft; cleft not present,<tei:lb/>however, in bucephala-group; saccus longer than wide; juxta simple (but complex in donodes), entire, not<tei:lb/>divided medially; vesica with or without spicular cornuti; aedeagus with or without carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. None; may be recognized, however, by combination of 'moss'-patterned<tei:lb/>forewing with R 3 and R 4 stalked (but note aberrant pattern of bucephala-group) and deeply cleft valva (not<tei:lb/>in bucephala-group).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Western and eastern Palaearctic region; Afrotropical region; Oriental region; Australian<tei:lb/>region. Absent from the New World.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. See under entries for individual species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Preliminary work on the Scardiinae in 1975 suggested that the type-species of Scardia was Tinea<tei:lb/>mediella Hubner, 1796, a result of the designation by Walsingham (November, 1914) of 'Noctua boleti F. '<tei:lb/>as type-species. Noctua boleti F., 1777, is not eligible for designation as type-species of Scardia Treitschke<tei:lb/>as it is not an included species. However, Walsingham included Tinea mediella Hubner, 1796, in his<tei:lb/>synonymy of boleti and, as mediella is one of the species included by Treitschke, its designation as<tei:lb/>type-species by Walsingham would have been valid (Int. Code zool. Norn. , Article 69(a) (v)) had it been<tei:lb/>the earliest designation. Tinea mediella Hubner, 1796, is currently considered to be a junior subjective<tei:lb/>synonym of Tinea choragella [Denis &amp; Schiffermiiller], 1775: 137 (Charpentier, 1821: 127).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This finding, which would have made Scardia the valid generic name for the species placed here in<tei:lb/>Morophaga, and Fernaldia the valid name for those in Scardia, was communicated to several workers in<tei:lb/>litteris. Generic combinations and synonymy based on the Walsingham designation were published by<tei:lb/>Davis (1983). My colleagues I. W. B. NyeandD. S. Fletcher have recently found an earlier designation of a<tei:lb/>type-species for Scardia by Busck (April, 1914). This designation (see below) maintains the usage of<tei:lb/>Morophaga and Scardia by authors with the exception of Davis (1983).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morophaga could well be paraphyletic with respect to Diataga and Amorophaga - see the discussion<tei:lb/>following numerical analysis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The bucephala-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Outer and mid and proximal hind tibial spurs &gt;0-4 length of inner spurs. Forewing pattern"<tei:lb/>conspicuous, bold purple-brown markings on a white ground-colour. Male with coremata in eighth<tei:lb/>abdominal segment; coremata without associated apodemes. Tegumen unbroken, completely sclerotized<tei:lb/>dorsally; valva without longitudinal cleft; juxta simple, entire, not divided medially; vesica lacking spicular<tei:lb/>cornuti; aedeagus with spicular or spinose carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. Wing pattern of bold purple-brown blotches on a white or off-white<tei:lb/>background; valva with ventral margin extended caudally so that valva is rudder-shaped.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Eastern Palaearctic region; Oriental region as far east as New Guinea; Afrotropical region.<tei:lb/>Absent from the western Palaearctic region and Australia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species of the 6ucep/ia/a-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Distal margin of large spot on posterior margin of forewing angled towards apex of wing (Fig.<tei:lb/>67) ; angle between extended ventral margin and dorsal region of valva with triangular process<tei:lb/>(Fig. 127) ; antrum less than one-half length of apophyses anteriores (Fig. 173) cremnarcha (p. 122)<tei:lb/>Distal margin of large spot on posterior margin of forewing angled towards middle of costa;<tei:lb/>angle between extended ventral margin and dorsal region of valva without triangular process;<tei:lb/>antrum at least four-fifths length of apophyses anteriores 2</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>122 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Inner surface of labial palpus cream; maxillary palpus cream with a few darker scales on second</tei:p>
         <tei:p>and third segments; upper surface of hindleg ochreous, like under-surface; dorsal region of<tei:lb/>valva rounded apically (Fig. 128); antrum + ductus bursae as long as apophyses anteriores,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>corpus bursae only slightly offset to the left (Fig. 174) bucephala(p. 123)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Inner surface of labial palpus brown; maxillary palpus brown; upper surface of hindleg grey,<tei:lb/>paler at articuatlions; dorsal region of valva truncated apically; antrum + ductus bursae<tei:lb/>considerably longer than apophyses anteriores, ductus strongly looped to the left (Figs 175,<tei:lb/>176) 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Distal margin of large spot on posterior margin of forewing slightly concave or sinuate (Fig . 69) ;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>caudal extension of ventral region of valva rounded in cross-section, with subapical process</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 129) ; microtrichia in antrum larger anteriorly than posteriorly soror(p. 124)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Distal margin of purple-brown spot on posterior margin of forewing strongly 'stepped' (Fig. 70);<tei:lb/>caudal extension of ventral region of valva flattened, truncated at apex, without subapical<tei:lb/>process (Fig. 130); microtrichia in antrum of uniform size vadonella(p. 124)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morophaga cremnarcha (Meyrick) comb. n.<tei:lb/>(Figs 67, 127, 173)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scardia cremnarcha Meyrick, 1932ft: 323. LECTOTYPE cf , KASHMIR (BMNH), here designated [ex-<tei:lb/>amined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morophaga nigrocapitella Petersen, 1959: 571, pi. 32, fig. 1; fig. 19. Holotype cf , AFGHANISTAN [SW.]:<tei:lb/>Arghandab R. (LN) [not examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Petersen, 1959: pi. 32, fig. 1; Fig. 67). cf, 12-25 mm. $, 18-26 mm. Coloration and external<tei:lb/>structure similar to bucephala but cf antennal cilia 4 x flagellar diameter. Distal margin of large spot on<tei:lb/>posterior margin of forewing angled towards apex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Petersen, 1959: fig. 19; Zagulajev, 1973: fig. 62; Fig. 127). Similar to bucephala but valva<tei:lb/>with triangular process present in angle between caudal extension of ventral region of valva and dorsal<tei:lb/>region; bilobate process close to costa with distal lobe enlarged and tapered; aedeagus not as slender as in<tei:lb/>bucephala, only 15 x as long as broad, apical one-sixth with about six minute thorn-like carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Fig. 173). Similar to bucephala, but medial emargination of eighth sternite broader,<tei:lb/>V-shaped. Antrum short, half length of apophyses anteriores, not as thick-walled as in bucephala, inner<tei:lb/>surface evenly lined with fine microtrichia anteriorly from inception of ductus seminalis. Ductus bursae<tei:lb/>with four or five regular transverse constrictions, only slightly offset to the left. Corpus bursae with<tei:lb/>posterior diagonal ribbing.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Afghanistan; Kashmir; India (Uttar Pradesh, Himachal Pradesh, Bihar, Madras); Nepal.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. Three of Meyrick's syntypes were found on 'old tree-stumps on which Polyporus was growing,<tei:lb/>but I could find no trace of larvae, pupae or cocoons in the fungus' (Fletcher - quoted by Meyrick, 1932ft:<tei:lb/>323). The specimen from the Shevaroy Hills referred to as 'Atabyria bucephala' by Fletcher ([1921]: 189)<tei:lb/>was bred 'from cocoons about a fungus growth on a tree'. Fletcher (1933: 73), referring to this species as<tei:lb/>'Scardia bucephala', records adults (presumably the syntypes of cremnarcha) resting on rotten tree-stumps<tei:lb/>at Gulmarg, Kashmir.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 12 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lectotype Cf , Kashmir: Gulmarg, 8800', vii. 1931 (Fletcher} (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Kashmir: 1 cf , 2 $ (paralectotypes) , data as lectotype (BMNH) . India: 1 9 , Uttar Pradesh, Mukteswar,<tei:lb/>19.vii.1927; 1 $ , Himachal Pradesh, Dharmsala, 1879 (Hocking); 1 cf , Himachal Pradesh, Kangra Valley,<tei:lb/>4500', ix. 1899 (Dudgeon); 2 cf, Bihar, Pusa, 12.viii. 1909 &amp; 30. vi. 1919 (H. L. D ., Fletcher); 1 $ with pupa,<tei:lb/>Madras, Shevaroy Hills, Yercaud, from cocoons about a fungus growth on a tree, 21. iv. 4. v. 1913 (Y. R.).<tei:lb/>Nepal: 1 $, Kathmandu District, Godaveri, 1700m, vii. 1982 (Allen). (All in BMNH.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The four species of the bucephala-group (bucephala, soror, vadonella and cremnarcha) are<tei:lb/>allopatric but restricted to the Old World; however, there may well be overlap of the ranges of cremnarcha<tei:lb/>and bucephala in NE. India and possibly Nepal. The wing patterns of three species are almost identical but<tei:lb/>that of cremnarcha is different, the large purple-brown spot on the posterior margin of the forewing being<tei:lb/>extended towards the wing-apex. The valva of cremnarcha bears a characteristic triangular flap between<tei:lb/>the dorsal lobe and the caudal extension, and the aedeagus is somewhat stouter (length = 15 x width, as<tei:lb/>opposed to 20-25 x in the other species); in the female the antrum is only half the length of the apophyses</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 123</tei:p>
         <tei:p>anteriores as opposed to roughly the same length in the other species. The wing-patterns of bucephala,<tei:lb/>soror and vadonella are similar, but the distal margin of the large spot on the posterior margin of the<tei:lb/>forewing is 'stepped' in vadonella (more so in the two females examined than in the rather worn male<tei:lb/>holotype) and in examples of bucephala from New Guinea; bucephala from elsewhere, and soror, have the<tei:lb/>margin slightly concave or sinuate. Both vadonella and soror differ from bucephala in having the whole of<tei:lb/>the labial palpus and the maxillary palpus brown - in bucephala the inner surface of the labial palpus is<tei:lb/>cream, as is the maxillary palpus except for some darker scaling on the second and third segments. In<tei:lb/>bucephala the dorsal region of the valva is rounded distally but it is truncated in soror and vadonella:<tei:lb/>microtrichia are restricted to the anterior one-quarter of the antrum in bucephala but evenly scattered in<tei:lb/>the other two species. The major difference between soror and vadonella lies in the form of the valva: the<tei:lb/>caudal extension of the ventral margin is rounded in cross-section in soror and bears a short subapical<tei:lb/>process. This process is absent in vadonella and the caudal extension of the valva is flattened and truncated.<tei:lb/>Differences in the female genitalia are minimal - the eighth sternite of soror is marginally narrower than<tei:lb/>that of vadonella and the microtrichia in the antrum are larger anteriorly whereas in vadonella they are of<tei:lb/>uniform size. The bursa copulatrix is not as elongate in vadonella as in soror (but still longer than in<tei:lb/>bucephala).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A tentative phylogenetic sequence for the group would have soror and vadonella as sister-groups<tei:lb/>(synapomorphies: colour of palpi, truncation of dorsal region of valva, strongly looped and elongate ductus<tei:lb/>bursae), bucephala as their sister-group (synapomorphies: forewing pattern, very slender aedeagus), and<tei:lb/>cremnarcha as the sister-group of the other three.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morophaga bucephala (Snellen)<tei:lb/>(Figs 68, 128, 174)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Atabyria bucephala Snellen, 1884: 166, pi. 9, fig. 1. LECTOTYPE cf , U.S.S.R. (ZI), here designated</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[examined].<tei:lb/>Osphretica chomatias Meyrick, 1910: 475. Holotype cf , SARAWAK (BMNH) [examined]. [Synonymized by</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bradley, 1965: 116.]<tei:lb/>Depressaria rotundata Matsumura, 1931: 1091. Lectotype $, JAPAN (EIHU), designated by Ridout, 1981:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>36 [not examined]. [Synonymized by Bradley, 1965: 116.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Snellen, 1884: pi. 9, fig. la (colour); Issiki, 1957: fig. 49 (colour); Zagulajev, 1973: pi. 2, fig. 5<tei:lb/>(colour); Fig. 68). cf $, 11-23 mm. Vertex and frons purple-brown, paler towards mouth. Labial palpus<tei:lb/>brown on outer surface, cream on inner surface. Maxillary palpus cream, some darker scaling on second<tei:lb/>and third segments. Antennal scape and pedicel dark brown; flagellum ochreous, some darker scales<tei:lb/>dorsally; cilia 3 x (cf ) or 0-3 x () flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula purple-brown anteriorly, cream<tei:lb/>posteriorly. Forewing cream with a brownish tint, patterned with bold purple-brown spots; distal margin of<tei:lb/>large posterior spot weakly concave or sinuate (but strongly stepped in examples from New Guinea and in<tei:lb/>one of two specimens known from Assam). Hindwing grey. Legs ochreous cream; foreleg and mid-leg dark<tei:lb/>brown above but pale at articulations; outer mid-tibial spur 0-4 length of inner; outer proximal hind tibial<tei:lb/>spur 0-5 length of inner.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Petersen, 1959: fig. 20; Zagulajev, 1973: fig. 59; Fig. 128). Saccus elongate, as long as<tei:lb/>tegumen + uncus; uncus lobes short, infolded ventrad, hardly sclerotized, setose. Subscaphium elongate,<tei:lb/>ribbon-like. Juxta weakly developed, shield-shaped; transtilla inverted U-shaped, closely associated with<tei:lb/>setose lobes at bases of valvae. Valva with rounded ventral apex, with m-shaped bilobate process close to<tei:lb/>costa. Aedeagus slender, 25 x as long as wide, apical fifth with about 15 minute, thorn-like carinae; vesica<tei:lb/>without cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Petersen, 1959: fig. 21; Zagulajev, 1973: figs 60, 61; Fig. 174). Eighth tergite slightly longer<tei:lb/>than eighth sternite, with subapical row of about 8 strong setae and apical line of numerous smaller setae;<tei:lb/>eighth sternite only weakly sclerotized , m-shaped , posterior margin forming ventral lip of ostium . Antrum<tei:lb/>tapered anteriorly, then slightly swollen posterior to inception of ductus seminalis at level of anterior<tei:lb/>margin of eighth sternite; anterior to inception of ductus seminalis only weakly sclerotized, but thick-<tei:lb/>walled, almost reaching apices of apophyses anteriores; with fine microtrichia on inner surface of anterior<tei:lb/>one-quarter (and also medially in a specimen from New Guinea). Ductus bursae very short, weakly turned<tei:lb/>to the left. Corpus bursae thin-walled, ovoid; signa absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. U.S.S.R. (Amur, Chabarovsk,Primorsk- Zagulajev, 1973); China (Kwangtung- Meyrick,<tei:lb/>1934; Kiangsu - Meyrick, 1935; Yunnan - Meyrick, 1938); Japan; Korea; India (Assam); Burma; Malaya;<tei:lb/>Borneo; Sulawesi; New Guinea.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>

         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Gozmany, 1965: fig. 33; Gozmany &amp; Vari, 1973: fig. 449; Fig. 129).          <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Gozmany &amp; Vari, 1973: fig. 450; Fig, 176). Similar to bucephala but strong setae mixed with<tei:lb/>smaller setae at posterior margin of eighth tergite. Antrum with inner surface evenly lined with<tei:lb/>microtrichia anteriorly from inception of ductus seminalis (but posterior microtrichia only one-third length<tei:lb/>of those in anterior region of antrum). Ductus bursae elongate, with regular transverse constrictions, and<tei:lb/>strongly looped to the left.</tei:p>
