         <tei:p>The more//us-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Outer mid and proximal hind tibial spurs &gt;0-4 length of inner spurs. Forewing with mottled<tei:lb/>coloration forming cryptic, coarse 'moss' pattern. Male with coremata in eighth abdominal segment;<tei:lb/>coremata not associated with apodemes. Tegumen unbroken, completely sclerotized dorsally; valva with<tei:lb/>deep emargination forming longitudinal cleft; juxta simple, entire, not divided medially; vesica lacking<tei:lb/>spicular cornuti; aedeagus smooth-surfaced, without spicular carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. See species' description.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. Western Palaearctic region.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morophaga morellus (Duponchel)<tei:lb/>(Fig. 71)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euplocamus morellus Duponchel, 1838: 79, pi. 288, fig. 5. Syntypes, 1 cf , 1 ?, [FRANCE] (7MNHN) [not</tei:p>
         <tei:p>examined].<tei:lb/>Morophaga morella t.fungicolella Dumont, 1930: 286. Syntypes, 1 cf , 3 $ , TUNISIA (BMNH) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Duponchel, 1838: pi. 288, fig. 5 (colour); Zagulajev, 1973: pi. 1, fig. 1 (colour); Fig. 71). cf$,<tei:lb/>21-28 mm. Vertex and frons greyish brown, scales tipped with white, pair of paler lateral tufts arising close<tei:lb/>to tentorial pits. Labial palpus greyish brown, scales tipped with white, but inner surface buff; third<tei:lb/>segment diffusedly banded with black basally and subapically. Maxillary palpus cream, dark scales above<tei:lb/>on second and third segments. Antennal scape and pedicel ochre-brown, with darker brown ventral scales;<tei:lb/>flagellum medium brown; cilia 2-5 x (cf) or 0-4 x (2) flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula dark brown<tei:lb/>anteriorly, light grey-brown posteriorly. Forewing ground-colour light brown, strongly speckled and<tei:lb/>mottled with dark brown, dark spots concentrated medially and subterminally. Hind wing light grey-brown<tei:lb/>with some ill-defined darker speckles towards apex. Legs buff but foreleg and mid-leg dark brown above,<tei:lb/>banded with buff at articulations; hind tibia light greyish above; outer mid-tibial spur 0-4 length of inner;<tei:lb/>outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-5 length of inner.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Petersen, 1957: fig. 244; Zagulajev, 1968: fig. 7, 1973: fig. 48). Saccus broadly triangular but<tei:lb/>as long as tegumen + uncus; uncus lobes short, square-ended, infolded both mesad and ventrad,<tei:lb/>moderately sclerotized, setose. Subscaphium ill-defined, broadening posteriorly. Juxta large, shield-<tei:lb/>shaped and conspicuously wrinkled; transtilla not developed. Valva with emargination separating ventral<tei:lb/>lobe bearing three peg-like processes from smaller dorsal lobe bearing subapical ventral flap. Aedeagus<tei:lb/>stout, S-shaped, 5 x as long as wide, without carinae; vesica lacking cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Petersen, 1957: fig. 245; Zagulajev, 1968: fig. 8, 1973: figs 49, 50). Eighth tergite as long as<tei:lb/>eighth sternite, with subapical row of about eight strong setae; eighth sternite strongly sclerotized, medially<tei:lb/>emarginate anteriorly, extended posteriorly into pair of digitate processes each bearing three strong setae<tei:lb/>and overlying ostium. Antrum cylindrical, 0-25 length of apophyses anteriores. Ductus bursae short, 0-5<tei:lb/>length of antrum. Corpus bursae globular, only reaching two-thirds length of apophyses anteriores; signa<tei:lb/>absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. S. France; Morocco; Tunisia; Sardinia; Sicily; Malta. Also reliably recorded in the literature<tei:lb/>from Spain, Algeria (Dumont, 1930); Asia Minor (Petersen, 1957); Italy, Greece (Rhodes) (Petersen &amp;<tei:lb/>Gaedike, 1979); U.S.S.R. (Crimea, Caucasus) (Zagulajev, 1973).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. This species has been bred from an excrescence on Morus (Duponchel, 1838), bred from<tei:lb/>Xanthochisma plorans on Populus and from fungus in hollow Pistacia atlantica (Dumont, 1930), bred from<tei:lb/>a polypore on Quercus suber (Martelli &amp; Arru, [1959]) and bred from dead wood of Quercus (Staudinger,<tei:lb/>1880: 270). The biology of this species has been discussed by Dumont (1930) who described the egg, larva<tei:lb/>and pupa.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>126 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 25 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Syntypes (of Morophaga morella f. fungicolella Dumont), 1 cf, 3 9, Tunisia: Maknassy, bred from<tei:lb/>fungus in Pistacia, various dates 1929-30 (Dumont) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>21 ex., various localities (see 'Distribution') (BMNH, ZI).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The only scardiine with a circum-Mediterranean distribution, morellus may be recognized by its<tei:lb/>wing-pattern which is brownish, rather than olivaceous as in members of the choragella-group. The<tei:lb/>characteristic short, square-ended uncus lobes of the male serve to differentiate it from all other<tei:lb/>Morophaga species. Its habitat is probably rather different from that of most other Scardiinae; whereas<tei:lb/>most species inhabit moist forest and woodland, the distributional records of morellus suggest that it is an<tei:lb/>inhabitant of much drier environments with open sclerophyll forest.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The sistrata-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Outer mid and proximal hind tibial spurs &lt;0-4 length of inner spurs. Forewing with mottled<tei:lb/>coloration forming cryptic, coarse 'moss' pattern. Male lacking coremata in eighth abdominal segment.<tei:lb/>However, coremata present (not associated with apodemes) in borneensis. Tegumen broken dorsally by at<tei:lb/>least a membranous suture line; valva with deep emargination forming longitudinal cleft; juxta simple,<tei:lb/>entire, not divided medially; vesica with spicular cornuti; aedeagus smooth-surfaced, without spicular<tei:lb/>carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. Uncus lobes fused apically and forming a small hook; aedeagus and vesica<tei:lb/>elongate, vesica with line of strong cornuti (but not in borneensis).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Oriental region.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species of the Morophaga sistrata-group (females are known only ofsistrato)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Males</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Coremata present in eighth abdominal segment; aedeagus short, less than 1 -0 mm long, lacking</tei:p>
         <tei:p>cornuti (Fig. 135) borneensis(p. 126)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coremata absent from eighth abdominal segment; aedeagus elongate, more than 1-25 mm long,<tei:lb/>with many stout cornuti (Figs 136, 137) 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Saccus elongate, 2-0-2-2 x as long as wide; apex of dorsal half of valva in the shape of a horse's</tei:p>
         <tei:p>head; ventral margin of ventral half of valva smooth (Fig. 132) sistrata(p. 127)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Saccus exceptionally elongate, 2-5 x or more as long as wide; apex of dorsal half of valva evenly<tei:lb/>rounded ; ventral margin of ventral half of valva with strong pectinifer 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Pectinifer on ventral margin of valva regular; strong hook-shaped process between pectinifer</tei:p>
         <tei:p>and base of valva (Fig. 133) formosana(p. 128)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pectinifer on ventral margin of valva irregular; no process between pectinifer and base of valva<tei:lb/>(Fig. 134) iriomotensis(p. 128)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morophaga borneensis sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 72, 131,135)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 72). cf , 13 mm. Vertex and frons cream, darker scales near eyes. Labial palpus cream flecked<tei:lb/>with brown, pale on inner surface, at apex of second segment and on outer surface of third segment except<tei:lb/>for brownish basal and subapical spots. Maxillary palpus cream, dark brown above on second and third<tei:lb/>segments. Antennal scape cream; pedicel dark brown; flagellum ochreous, darker brown above on basal<tei:lb/>three segments; cilia 2-0-2-5 x (cf ) flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula brown, a little paler posteriorly.<tei:lb/>Forewing (very worn) cream, marked with orange-brown on veins and strongly mottled with dark brown.<tei:lb/>Hindwing light brownish grey. Legs ochreous cream; foreleg and mid-leg dark brown above but pale at<tei:lb/>articulations and in middle of tibiae. (Hindlegs missing.) Outer mid-tibial spur 0-3 length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Figs 131, 135). Small coremata present in eighth segment, without associated apodemes.<tei:lb/>Saccus only as long as tegumen -I- uncus; uncus lobes extending just beyond apices of valvae, fused caudally<tei:lb/>and slightly hooked at apex. Subscaphium strongly developed, broad, ribbon-like. Juxta shield-shaped,<tei:lb/>only weakly sclerotized; transtilla inverted U-shaped, closely associated with small, digitate setose lobes at<tei:lb/>bases of valvae. Valva cleft (emarginate) for half its length, dorsal lobe with inwardly-directed triangular<tei:lb/>flap at apex; ventral lobe with hooked apex, pair of small, triangular sclerotizations extending dorsad from<tei:lb/>ventral margin across membranous inner face. Aedeagus short and stout, 6 x as long as broad at<tei:lb/>mid-length, without carinae; vesica without cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 127</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $. Unknown.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. Borneo.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 cf.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Sabah: Ulu Dusun, 30 miles W. of Sandakan, lowland dipterocarp forest, 28-31.1.1976<tei:lb/>(Classey) (genitalia slide no. 13197; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is the smallest member of the sistrata-group. It may be separated from the three<tei:lb/>others also by the characteristic form of the valva, the presence of coremata, and the short, stubby<tei:lb/>aedeagus which lacks cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The strata-group is Oriental and the distributions of its four constituent species are allopatric. The<tei:lb/>female of only sistrata is known, so the diagnostic comments here are confined to males. Externally, all four<tei:lb/>species are remarkably similar although borneensis is very small (13 mm as opposed to 16-20 mm in the<tei:lb/>other species) and is matched in size only by a single dwarf (12 mm) example of sistrata. Rather smaller and<tei:lb/>darker than members of the choragella-group, members of the sistrata-group cannot be reliably separated<tei:lb/>externally. Males of two species possess pectinifers on the ventrodistal margin of the valva: the pectinifer is<tei:lb/>neat and regular informosana but proximally irregular in iriomotensis . Of the other two species, borneensis<tei:lb/>possesses a pair of small coremata in the eighth segment but sistrata does not. Other differences are<tei:lb/>highlighted below. A phylogenetic arrangement of the species would have formosana and iriomotensis as<tei:lb/>sister-groups (synapomorphy: valval pectinifer), sistrata as the sister-group of this pair (synapomorphy:<tei:lb/>loss of coremata) and borneensis as the sister-group of the other three.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morophaga sistrata (Meyrick) comb. n.<tei:lb/>(Figs 73, 132, 136, 179)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scardia sistrata Meyrick, 1916: 618. LECTOTYPE cf , SRI LANKA (Ceylon) (BMNH), here designated<tei:lb/>[examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 73). cf $, (12 mm dwarf), normally 16-20 mm. Vertex and frons light brown, scales tipped<tei:lb/>with cream. Labial palpus cream flecked with brown, third segment with basal and subapical brown rings.<tei:lb/>Maxillary palpus whitish, flecked with brown on upper surface. Antennal scape cream, marked with brown<tei:lb/>above, pecten bristles light brown tipped with cream; pedicel brown; flagellum creamy brown; cilia 3 x<tei:lb/>(cf) or 0-5 x () flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula cream, densely flecked with brown anteriorly.<tei:lb/>Forewing cream, marked with orange-brown along veins and densely mottled with dark brown. Hindwing<tei:lb/>light brownish grey, some darker and lighter speckling at apex. Legs ochreous cream flecked with brown;<tei:lb/>foreleg and mid-leg brown above but pale at articulations, mid-tibia with pale band at one-half, hind tarsus<tei:lb/>brown basally; outer mid-tibial and outer proximal hind tibial spurs 0-3 length of inner spurs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Figs 132, 136). Coremata absent. Saccus elongate, longer than tegumen + uncus; uncus<tei:lb/>lobes extending well beyond apices of valvae, fused caudally, forming slight apical hook, weakly<tei:lb/>sclerotized, setose. Subscaphium well-defined, ribbon-like. Juxta moderately sclerotized, U-shaped;<tei:lb/>transtilla inverted U-shaped, closely associated with small, digitate setose lobes at bases of valvae. Valva<tei:lb/>deeply cleft (emarginate) , dorsal lobe with horse's head-shaped apex; ventral lobe with hooked apex and<tei:lb/>triangular basal lobe. Aedeagus slender, elongate, 12 x as long as wide at mid-length, lacking carinae;<tei:lb/>vesica with broken line of about 80 small, strong cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Fig. 179). Eighth tergite longer than eighth sternite, with 7 or 8 strong marginal setae<tei:lb/>towards apex and similar number of smaller setae; eighth sternite almost triangular, irregularly margined,<tei:lb/>with medial ostium flanked by pair of stout digitate processes, each with 3 strong apical setae and numerous<tei:lb/>smaller setae. Antrum twice length of eighth sternite, not extending beyond inception of ductus seminalis.<tei:lb/>Ductus bursae relatively thick-walled, contiguous with corpus bursae, with ventral scobinate band (not<tei:lb/>microtrichia). Corpus bursae thin-walled, extending to almost twice length of apophyses anteriores; signa<tei:lb/>absent (but pathological sclerotization of wall of ductus bursae present in one example examined).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Sri Lanka; India; Thailand; Malaya; Sulawesi; Philippines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. Larvae have been found feeding in decayed Polyporus (Meyrick, 1916: 618) in Ceylon and have<tei:lb/>been reared at Dehra Dun, India, from a fungus (Fletcher, 1933). The biology of this species, found in<tei:lb/>Fomes sp. at Pusa, Bihar, India, is described in detail by Fletcher ([1921]: 186).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>128 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 51 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lectotype cf , Sri Lanka (Ceylon): Puttalam, x.1904 (Pole) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sri Lanka (Ceylon): 1 cf, 1 $, Puttalam, v., x.1904 (Pole); 3 $, Wellawaya, xi.1905 (Alston); 1 $,<tei:lb/>Peradeniya, vii.1905 (Green); 1 cf, 1 ?, 1904 (Pole) (paralectotypes; all BMNH); 18 ex., Colombo,<tei:lb/>Puttalam, Peradeniya, Nawalapitiya (BMNH). India: 2 cf, 1 $, Bihar, Pusa, 20.vii.1907, 2.ix.l908,<tei:lb/>6.xi.l908 (Fletcher) (paralectotypes; BMNH); 12 ex. , Lucknow ('ex 1. in fungus'), Pusa, Karwar, N. Arcot<tei:lb/>- Sangarambadi ('from a fungus') (BMNH). Thailand: 2 cf , without detailed locality (BMNH). Malaya: 1<tei:lb/>Cf , Prov. Philippines: 1 cf, 1 $, Palawan, Brookes Point,<tei:lb/>Uring Uring, 22.viii., 27. ix. 1961 (Noona Dan Exp.] (ZM); 1 cf, Mindanao, Sapamoro, Curuan dist.,<tei:lb/>16.xii.1961 (Noona Dan Exp.) (ZM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. There are minor racial differences between the male genitalia of sistrata from Sri Lanka and<tei:lb/>examples from the Philippines. The horse's head-shaped dorsal apex of the divided valva is broader and<tei:lb/>slightly more inturned in Philippine specimens. The triangular flap-like process on the ventral margin of the<tei:lb/>valva is basal in Sri Lankan examples but somewhat larger and situated further distad, almost at one-half<tei:lb/>the length of the ventral margin of the valva, in specimens from the Philippines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Joannis (1930: 742) has recorded this species from Vietnam (Hanoi): the record is unconfirmed but is not<tei:lb/>unlikely.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morophaga formosana sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 74, 133,137)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 74). cf , 18 mm; $ , 16 mm. Vertex and frons cream, tufts close to tentorial pits basally dark.<tei:lb/>Labial palpus cream flecked with brown, brown scales concentrated at base and middle of third segment.<tei:lb/>Maxillary palpus cream flecked with brown, dark brown scales above on second segment. Antennal scape<tei:lb/>cream (worn); pedicel dark brown; flagellum light ochre; cilia 3 x (cf) or 0-5 x ($) flagellar diameter.<tei:lb/>Thorax and tegula whitish, brown anteriorly. Forewing whitish (?faded) marked with orange-brown on<tei:lb/>veins and strongly mottled with dark brown. Hindwing light brownish grey. Legs cream flecked with<tei:lb/>brown. Foreleg and mid-leg strongly marked with blackish brown above but pale at articulations and in<tei:lb/>middle of tibia; outer mid-tibial and outer proximal hind tibial spurs 0-3 length of inner spurs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Figs 133, 137). Coremata absent. Saccus elongate, 1-2 x length of tegumen + uncus; uncus<tei:lb/>lobes slender, extending a little beyond apices of valvae, fused caudally, forming shallow and inconspi-<tei:lb/>cuous ventral hook, moderately sclerotized, setose. Subscaphium well-defined, ribbon-like. Juxta narrow-<tei:lb/>ly U-shaped, well-sclerotized; transtilla strongly developed, inverted U-shaped, closely associated with<tei:lb/>small, digitate setose lobes at bases of valvae. Valva cleft (emarginate) for one-third its length, costa with<tei:lb/>thorn-like process at three-quarters; ventral lobe with larger thorn-like process from ventral margin at<tei:lb/>one-half and with well-ordered apical pectinifer of about 14 spines. Aedeagus elongate, slender, 18 x as<tei:lb/>long as wide at mid-length, lacking carinae; vesica with broken line of about 80 small, strong cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA 9- Unknown.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. China; Taiwan.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 3 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Taiwan: Taihoku, vi.1935 (Issiki) (genitalia slide no. 13119; BMNH).<tei:lb/>Paratype. Taiwan: 1 $, Tainan, 10. iv. 1906 (Wileman) (abdomen missing) (BMNH).<tei:lb/>Excluded from paratype series. China: 1 cf , Fu-chou ('Foochow'), 1935-6 (Yang) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Males of this species differ from both sistrata and borneensls in possessing a conspicuous<tei:lb/>pectinifer at the apex of the ventral lobe of the valva; a pectinifer is also present in iriomotensis (see<tei:lb/>'Remarks' for that species). Like sistrata (but unlike borneensis) the aedeagus is elongate, the vesica bears<tei:lb/>a row of about 80 small, strong cornuti and the eighth segment lacks coremata.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morophaga iriomotensis sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 134)<tei:lb/>ADULT, cf , 19 mm. Similarly patterned to sistrata and formosana (see above).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 129</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Fig. 134). Coremata absent. Saccus narrow, 2-5 x as long as wide, elongate, 1-3 x length of<tei:lb/>tegumen + uncus; uncus lobes slender, extending a little beyond apices of valvae, fused caudally, forming<tei:lb/>shallow and inconspicuous ventral hook, moderately sclerotized, setose. Subscaphium weakly sclerotized,<tei:lb/>ribbon-like. Juxta weakly sclerotized, heart-shaped, contiguous with M-shaped posteriorly-directed<tei:lb/>extension of medioventral margin of vinculum ; transtilla inverted U-shaped , closely associated with small ,<tei:lb/>digitate setose lobes at bases of valvae. Valva short, deeply cleft (emarginate); costa with shallow, lobe-like<tei:lb/>subapical process and broad, thorn-shaped process at one-half; ventral lobe with strongly dentate ventral<tei:lb/>margin, dentations regular and digitate at apex, forming a pectinifer with about 10 spines, but irregular and<tei:lb/>shallow in basal two-thirds. Aedeagus elongate, about 20 x as long as broad at mid-length, lacking carinae;<tei:lb/>vesica with line of 70-80 small, strong cornuti from base to apex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $. Unknown.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. Ryukyu Is.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 cf .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Ryukyu Is.: Iriomote, Maire-gawa, 8.ix.l965 (Arita) (genitalia slide no. 1060 [Robinson];<tei:lb/>coll. S. Moriuti, Osaka).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Externally practically identical with sistrata and formosana, this species has, like formosana, a<tei:lb/>more slender saccus than sistrata (in which the saccus is only about twice as long as wide); unlike<tei:lb/>formosana, the medioventral margin of the vinculum has an M-shaped process protruding between the<tei:lb/>valvae and contiguous with the weak juxta. The valva of iriomotensis resembles that of formosana in having<tei:lb/>a pectinifer (unlike sistrata), but the more proximal processes of the ventral margin of the valva are less<tei:lb/>ordered and there is no strong spine from the mid-point of the margin as in formosana. The costa of the<tei:lb/>valva has a stronger thorn-like process situated further proximad than that of formosana.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The c/onodes-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Outer mid and proximal hind tibial spurs &gt;0-4 length of inner spurs. Forewing with mottled<tei:lb/>coloration forming cryptic, coarse 'moss' pattern. Male lacking coremata in eighth abdominal segment.<tei:lb/>Tegumen unbroken, completely sclerotized dorsally; valva with deep emargination forming longitudinal<tei:lb/>cleft; juxta complex, entire, not divided medially; vesica with spicular cornuti; aedeagus with spicular or<tei:lb/>spinose carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. See species' description.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. Australian region.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morophaga clonodes (Meyrick) comb. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 75, 138, 172)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scardia clonodes Meyrick, 1893: 523. Holotype cf , AUSTRALIA (BMNH) [examined].<tei:lb/>Scar dia porphyrea Lower, 1903: 74. Holotype $, AUSTRALIA (SAM) [examined]. Syn. n.<tei:lb/>Scardia maculosa Diakonoff, 1949: 317. Holotype $, BURU (RNH) [examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 75). cf $ , 18-26 mm (9 from Emirau I., 15 mm). Vertex and frons cream mixed with brown.<tei:lb/>Labial palpus cream flecked with brown, brown spot on outer surface of third segment. Maxillary palpus<tei:lb/>whitish, flecked with brown above on second and third segments. Antennal scape whitish, base brown<tei:lb/>dorsally, pecten bristles cream; pedicel ochreous, dark brown dorsally; flagellum dull buff, some darker<tei:lb/>dorsal scales towards base; cilia 1-5-2-0 x (cf)orO-4 x ($) flagellar diameter. Hindwing ochreous grey with violet iridescence, some paler apical<tei:lb/>mottling. Legs ochreous cream, strongly flecked with dark brown; foreleg and mid-leg dark brown above<tei:lb/>but pale at articulations and across middle of mid-tibia; scaling on upper surface of hind tibia not flecked,<tei:lb/>distinctively ochreous; outer mid-tibial spur 0-4 length of inner spur; outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-5<tei:lb/>length of inner spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Fig. 138). Coremata absent. Saccus very broad, 1-25 x as long as wide, elongate, 1-3 x<tei:lb/>length of tegumen + uncus; uncus lobes small, infolded ventrad, moderately sclerotized, setose. Sub-<tei:lb/>scaphium not developed.       <tei:div>
         <tei:p>130 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>pair of strongly sclerotized, blade-shaped ventral lobes, strong mediocostal spine and elongate, setose<tei:lb/>basicostal lobe extending almost twice length of remainder of valva; setose lobes at bases of valvae<tei:lb/>probably represented by extensive setose basidorsal area between basicostal lobe and anellus. Aedeagus<tei:lb/>slender, 15 x as long as broad at mid-length, with minute subapical thorn-like carinae; vesica with fine<tei:lb/>spicularcornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Fig. 172). Intersegmental membrane between seventh and eighth segments with pair of<tei:lb/>lateroventral pockets, each with conspicuously scobinate lining. Eighth tergite quadrate, shorter than<tei:lb/>eighth sternite, with row of about 8 strong subterminal setae and 4 smaller terminal setae; eighth sternite<tei:lb/>very short laterally, produced mediocaudally to form a sterigma terminating in a pair of lobes, each with<tei:lb/>three strong terminal setae and numerous smaller setae; ostium at one-half length of sterigma. Antrum<tei:lb/>almost one-half length of apophyses anteriores, strongly sclerotized and longitudinally ridged; inception of<tei:lb/>ductus seminalis just posterior to anterior margin of eighth sternite. Ductus bursae and corpus bursae<tei:lb/>contiguous, pear-shaped, extremely thin- walled, not reaching apices of apophyses anteriores; signa<tei:lb/>absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. (?)Moluccas (Buru); Australia; New Guinea (Emirau I., Dyaul I.); Norfolk I.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. Specimens in the BMNH collection have been bred from fungus on the roots of Acacia<tei:lb/>aulacocarpa and from dead wood of Prunus persica.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 72 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype O" (of Scardia clonodes), Australia: New South Wales, South Creek, 2.iii.l878 (Meyrick)<tei:lb/>(BMNH). Holotype $ (of Scardia porphyred) (more than 20 fragments in gelatine capsule), Australia:<tei:lb/>Queensland, Cooktown (SAM). Holotype $ (of Scardia maculosd) (head and thorax on pin; about 15<tei:lb/>fragments in two gelatine capsules), Moluccas: Buru, Station 1, 1922 (Toxopeus) (RNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 51 ex. , Queensland, Townsville, ex fungus on roots of Acacia aulacocarpa, various emergence<tei:lb/>dates, in, iv.1901 (Dodd) (BMNH); 16 ex., Queensland, Townsville, Toowong, Dawson R., Rockhamp-<tei:lb/>ton, Herberton, Peak Downs, Huberton Hills, Kuranda, various dates (Dodd, Barnard}, including 1 cf<tei:lb/>from Toowong, ex 'dead wood of Peach tree' (BMNH). New Guinea: 1 $, St Matthias Group, Emirau<tei:lb/>('Squally') I., viii.1923 (Eichhorn) (BMNH); 1 cf , Dyaul I., Sumuna, 7.iii.l962 (Noona Dan Exp.) (ZM).<tei:lb/>Norfolk I.: 1 $, in house J.E./Red Road, 170 m, 18.x. 1977 (Jowett &amp; Jowett) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. While the general appearance of clonodes is typical of that of other Morophaga (with the<tei:lb/>exception of members of the bucephala-group), well-preserved specimens are distinctive in that the<tei:lb/>hindwing has violet iridescence and the erect scales on the upper surface of the hind tibia are bright<tei:lb/>ochreous. The genitalia of both sexes are distinctive. In the female, the scobinate intersegmental pockets<tei:lb/>are a conspicuous autapomorphy; however, shallow and smooth-surfaced pouches (no more than<tei:lb/>accentuated infolding of the membrane) are found also in the choragella-group. The highly modified male<tei:lb/>genitalia are peculiar within the genus in that coremata are absent (as in three of the four species of the<tei:lb/>sistrata-group) and the subscaphium and transtilla are not developed. The form of the valva is also highly<tei:lb/>characteristic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scardia maculosa Diakonoff was described from a single specimen without abdomen. In the original<tei:lb/>description the specimen is said to be a male. Upon receipt of the holotype, it was found that the specimen,<tei:lb/>mounted on elder pith (and already, apparently, stuck together with glue), had broken loose in transit and<tei:lb/>was very badly damaged. The fragments revealed, however, the typical venation of a Morophaga with /? 3<tei:lb/>and R 4 stalked at one-half, wing-pattern (rubbed) typical of the sistrata-group or clonodes, the outer<tei:lb/>mid-tibial spur 0-4 the length of the inner spur and the outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-5 the length of the<tei:lb/>inner spur. The antennae are those of a female, with a cilia length of about 0-6 the flagellar diameter. The<tei:lb/>comparative length of the tibial spurs probably precludes this species from the sistrata-group. Diakonoff 's<tei:lb/>reference to the iridescence of the hindwing is suggestive of affinity to clonodes. Accordingly, maculosa is<tei:lb/>tentatively synonymized with clonodes although this requires a dramatic extension of the geographical<tei:lb/>range of the latter species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The choragella-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Outer mid and proximal hind tibial spurs &gt;0-4 length of inner spurs. Forewing with mottled<tei:lb/>coloration forming cryptic, coarse 'moss' pattern. Male with coremata in eighth abdominal segment;<tei:lb/>coremata associated with elongate, rod-like apodemes at anterior corners of eighth sternite but apodemes<tei:lb/>lacking in fasciculata. Tegumen broken dorsally by at least a membranous suture line; valva with deep<tei:lb/>emargination forming longitudinal cleft; juxta simple, entire, not divided medially; vesica with spicular<tei:lb/>cornuti; aedeagus with spicular or spinose carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 131</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONSPICUOUS AUTAPOMORPHIES. Only group within Morophaga with rod-like apodemes from anterior<tei:lb/>corners of eighth segment (but see Diataga and Necroscardia); however, apodemes absent in fasciculata;<tei:lb/>valva with large, hook-shaped articulated process (absent in fasciculata but the large apical depression in<tei:lb/>the valva suggests that the ancestor of this species may have had this process).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Western and eastern Palaearctic region.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Keys to species of the Morophaga choragella-group<tei:lb/>Males (males of kobella are unknown)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Charpentier, 1821: 127.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Curtis, 1836: pi. 591 (colour); Duponchel, 1838: pi. 288, fig. 3 (colour); Spuler, 1910: pi. 91, fig. 31<tei:lb/>(colour); Wood, 1839: pi. 49, no. 1565 (colour); Zagulajev, 1973: fig. 51; Fig. 76). C?$, 21-30 mm. Vertex<tei:lb/>and frons cream. Labial palpus cream mixed with brown, apical segment with ill-defined subapical and<tei:lb/>basal brown rings. Maxillary palpus cream mixed with light brown, dark brown scales above on third<tei:lb/>segment. Antennal scape cream, basally mixed with brown on dorsal surface; pedicel dark brown above;<tei:lb/>flagellum ochreous, scales tipped with grey; cilia 3 x (a") or 0-7 x ($) flagellar diameter. Thorax and<tei:lb/>tegula cream, dark brown anteriorly. Forewing cream marked with orange-brown (particularly along<tei:lb/>veins), medium brown and dark brown (overall appearance distinctly olivaceous, particularly in fresh<tei:lb/>specimens). Hindwing grey, paler flecks at apex; bases of fringe scales paler. Legs cream; foreleg and<tei:lb/>mid-leg strongly marked with dark brown above in basal half of each segment; hindleg similarly marked<tei:lb/>with light grey; outer mid-tibial spur 0-5 length of inner; outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-7 length of inner.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Petersen, 1957: fig. 240; Zagulajev, 1968: fig. 9, 1973: fig. 52). Coremata present in eighth<tei:lb/>abdominal segment, associated with elongate, rod-like apodemes from eighth sternite. Saccus 0-6 length of<tei:lb/>tegumen + uncus; uncus lobes elongate, digitiform, moderately sclerotized, setose. Subscaphium ill-<tei:lb/>defined , ribbon-like . Juxta plate-shaped , contiguous with vinculum ; transtilla inverted elongate U-shaped ,<tei:lb/>closely associated with setose lobes at bases of valvae. Valva divided by deep emargination into dorsal and<tei:lb/>ventral lobes; ventral lobe rounded, ventral margin with row of shallowly dentate processes; dorsal lobe</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>132 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>with deep recess accommodating mobile and strongly sclerotized hook-shaped process. Aedeagus curved,<tei:lb/>9 x as long as broad, apex tapered gently, with fine spicular carinae; vesica with fine spicular cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Petersen, 1957: fig. 241; Zagulajev, 1968: fig. 10, 1973: fig. 53). Eighth tergite displaced<tei:lb/>caudally, shield-shaped, with slight posteromedial emargination; caudal margin with about 10 strong setae.<tei:lb/>Eighth sternite broad, lateral margins extended dorsally to almost meet anterior to the displaced tergite;<tei:lb/>ventrally a broad plate, extended caudally into pair of broad lobes with narrow emargination between<tei:lb/>them, overlying ostium. Antrum funnel-shaped and smooth-walled to inception of ductus seminalis at 0-6<tei:lb/>ventral length of eighth sternite anteriorly, then cylindrical with longitudinal ribbing, extending 0-4 length<tei:lb/>of apophyses anteriores. Ductus bursae short, 0-4 length of antrum. Corpus bursae very thin-walled,<tei:lb/>ovoid, extending slightly beyond apices of apophyses anteriores; signa absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Probably all European countries north of the Mediterranean, including Scandinavia and<tei:lb/>Finland; Bulgaria and Rumania; U.S.S.R. east to Novosibirsk Province (Zagulajev, 1973); Asia Minor.<tei:lb/>The identity of the specimen recorded from China (Yunnan) by Meyrick (1938) has not been confirmed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. Described by a number of European authors - see Zagulajev (1973) for a bibliography. The larva<tei:lb/>has been described in detail by Hinton (1956: 258, figs 1-14). This is a widespread and common species that<tei:lb/>has been bred from many species of bracket-fungi and from dead wood permeated by fungal hyphae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 346 ex., larvae and pupae, from various localities (see 'Distribution') (BMNH, ZI).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Males of choragella and hyrcanella may be recognized by the conspicuous articulated hook set in<tei:lb/>the dorsal lobe of the valva; however, this hook is absent infasciculata although the depression in the valva<tei:lb/>that accommodates the hook in the other species is present. The male ofkobella is unknown. M. choragella<tei:lb/>is smaller than hyrcanella (which is restricted to the Caucasus) and the ventral lobe of the valva (formed<tei:lb/>into a hook in hyrcanella) has a marginal row of shallowly dentate processes. Females are characterized by<tei:lb/>the short antrum and dorsally extended eighth sternite of which the ventral caudally-directed lobes are the<tei:lb/>posteriormost part.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Records of this species from Japan (e.g. Inoue, 1954: 17) are erroneous and may refer instead to either<tei:lb/>kobella (of which I have seen only a single female, in BMNH) or fasciculata or, more improbably, to<tei:lb/>Scardla amurensis (Zagulajev) (q. v.).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morophaga hyrcanella Zagulajev<tei:lb/>(Fig. 77)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morophaga hyrcanella Zagulajev, 1966: 639, fig. 3. Holotype $, U.S.S.R. (ZI) [examined].<tei:lb/>Morophaga talyshensis Zagulajev, 1966: 641, fig. 4. Holotype cf, U.S.S.R. (ZI) [examined]. [Synony-<tei:lb/>mized by Zagulajev, 1973: 76.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Zagulajev, 1973: pi. 1, fig. 2 (colour); Fig. 77). cf, 28 mm; $, 32 mm. Similarly patterned to<tei:lb/>choragella but frons and vertex more brownish; antennal cilia 4-0 x (cf) or 1-0 x (9) flagellar diameter;<tei:lb/>thorax and tegula brown; forewing with dark brown scaling more extensive, forming a V-shaped medial<tei:lb/>fascia; hindwing grey-brown; legs with dark markings more intense and extensive.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Zagulajev, 1966: fig. 4; 1973: fig. 56). Similar to choragella but ventral lobe of valva with<tei:lb/>hook-shaped ventral extension; aedeagus not as strongly curved.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Zagulajev, 1966: fig. 3; 1968: fig. 12; 1973: figs 19b, 57). Similar to choragella but<tei:lb/>sclerotization of eighth sternite extended caudally beyond lobes that form lateral margins of ostium.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. U.S.S.R. (Transcaucasus).<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Described by Zagulajev (1966; 1973: 78).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 45 ex., pupae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $ (of Morophaga hyrcanella), U.S.S.R.: Transcaucasia, Talysh, Lenkoran dist., Sarakh,<tei:lb/>19.vii.1964 (Zagulajev) (ZI). Holotype cf (of Morophaga talyshensis), U.S.S.R.: Transcaucasia, Talysh,<tei:lb/>R. Lyakar, nr Mamagon (22 km W. of Pensar), Astara dist., 2100 m, 10.viii.1962 (Zagulajev) (ZI).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>U.S.S.R.: 1 Cf, 1 $, 1 pupa, Talysh, L. Girkanskiy, 20. ix. 1967 (Zagulajev) (BMNH). Also a further 41<tei:lb/>ex., 30 pupae, various Transcaucasian localities (see Zagulajev, 1973: 78) (ZI).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. More strongly marked than choragella, hyrcanella is also distinguished externally by its larger<tei:lb/>size and more elongate antennal cilia in both sexes. Differences in genitalia are outlined above.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS 133</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morophaga fasciculata sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 78, 139, 178)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 78). cf, 15-18 mm; $, 21 mm. Vertex and frons cream. Labial palpus with apical segment<tei:lb/>uniformly pale , outer surface of second segment evenly flecked with brown . Maxillary palpus cream , some<tei:lb/>darker scaling above on second segment. Antennal scape whitish; pedicel brown above; flagellum<tei:lb/>ochreous; cilia3 x (cf)orO-5 x ( ^) flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula cream marked with brown, dark<tei:lb/>brown anteriorly. Forewing cream, patterned with brown (specimens worn and slightly faded), pattern<tei:lb/>similar to kobella and to species of the s /strata-group. Hindwing grey. Legs ochreous cream; foreleg and<tei:lb/>mid-leg brownish above, paler at articulations, mid-tibia with cream medial band; outer mid-tibial spur 0-4<tei:lb/>length of inner; outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-5 length of inner.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf (Fig. 139). Eighth segment with small coremata but no associated apodemes; eighth sternite<tei:lb/>with broadly U-shaped posterior emargination. Saccus broad, U-shaped, as long as tegumen + uncus;<tei:lb/>uncus lobes shorter than saccus, simple, only moderately sclerotized, setose. Subscaphium well-<tei:lb/>sclerotized, rod-like. Juxta small, quadrate, weakly sclerotized; transtilla not developed. Valva with<tei:lb/>broad, deep emargination; with dense dorsoventral band of slender, flattened scales on outer surface;<tei:lb/>separate tuft of close-set similar scales on ventral margin; apices of ventral and dorsal lobes serrate, a<tei:lb/>shallowly dentate ridge running anteriorly down internal face of valva; line of 5 or 6 peg-like spines at apex<tei:lb/>of costa, smaller peg-like spines on internal face of dorsal lobe. Membranous lobe at base of valva elongate,<tei:lb/>densely hirsute. Aedeagus short, 7 x as long as broad, with three lobate anteriorly-directed carinae; vesica<tei:lb/>with minute, inconspicuous spicular cornuti.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Fig. 178). Eighth tergite slightly longer than eighth sternite; eighth sternite short, with<tei:lb/>lateral membranous pouches in intersegmental membrane, caudal margin produced into pair of short<tei:lb/>lateral processes either side of ostium, each process with about 6 strong apical setae. Antrum broad,<tei:lb/>thick-walled, almost twice length of eighth sternite, with ill-defined longitudinal ridging. Ductus bursae +<tei:lb/>corpus bursae thin-walled, contiguous, elongately pear-shaped.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Japan.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. The type-species was bred from the fungus Trametes kusanoana Imazeki, adults emerging in late<tei:lb/>June and early July.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 4 ex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf, Japan: Honshu, Nara, bred from Trametes kusanoana Imazeki, coll. 29. vi. 1965, em.<tei:lb/>4.vii.l965 (Arltd) (genitalia slide no. 1048 [Robinson]; coll. S. Moriuti, Osaka).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. 2 cf , 1 9,dataasholotypebutem. 2.vii. and 30. vi. 1965 (genitalia slide no. 1049 [Robinson];<tei:lb/>coll. S. Moriuti, Osaka; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Similarities between the male genitalia of fasciculata, choragella and hyrcanella are marked, but<tei:lb/>fasciculata is distinctive in lacking the strong, articulated hook-like process set in the valva of the last two<tei:lb/>species. The deep emargination of the valva that accommodates the hook in the other two species is also<tei:lb/>present in fasciculata. Neither choragella nor hyrcanella possess the distinctive bundle of close-set flattened<tei:lb/>scales on the ventral margin of the valva that is present in fasciculata. Females of fasciculata are very similar<tei:lb/>externally to kobella. Separation of the two species, while simple enough using genitalic characters (the<tei:lb/>antrum of kobella is longer than the apophyses anteriores, but considerably shorter in fasciculata), is unsafe<tei:lb/>using external characteristics only, to judge from the material presently available. Comparison of fresh<tei:lb/>material of the two species may, however, reveal perfectly good pattern differences.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morophaga kobella sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 79, 177)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT (Fig. 79). $ , 23 mm. (Specimen slightly faded and badly discoloured by fine, dark dust.) Vertex and<tei:lb/>frons cream. Labial palpus cream flecked with dark brown, but whitish on inner surface. Maxillary palpus<tei:lb/>cream flecked with brown; dark brown scales above on second segment. Antennal scape cream flecked<tei:lb/>with brown; pedicel similar; flagellum medium brown; cilia 0-5 x flagellar diameter. Thorax and tegula<tei:lb/>cream flecked with brown, dark brown anteriorly. Forewing cream marked with orange-brown, medium<tei:lb/>brown and dark brown, pattern similar to that of choragella but dark costal markings denser, better-<tei:lb/>defined, antemedial costal spot not as elongate. Hindwing charcoal grey. Legs cream flecked with brown;<tei:lb/>foreleg and mid-leg strongly marked with dark brown above but cream at articulations; mid-tibia with</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>134 GADEN S. ROBINSON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>cream medial band; hind spurs strongly marked with dark brown; outer mid-tibial spur 0-4 length of inner;<tei:lb/>outer proximal hind tibial spur 0-5 length of inner.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA cf . Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENITALIA $ (Fig. 177). Eighth tergite broad, shield-shaped, slightly longer than eighth sternite, with<tei:lb/>subapical row of 4 strong setae surrounded by numerous scattered smaller setae. Eighth sternite broad,<tei:lb/>strongly sclerotized, with rectangular medial emargination posteriorly; lobes either side of emargination<tei:lb/>each with 3 aprcal setae; anteriorly, surface of sternite strongly ridged and folded to form strong ventral<tei:lb/>keel. Antrum smooth-surfaced posteriorly, further anteriorly thick-walled with strong longitudinal ridges<tei:lb/>on inner surface, extending beyond apices of apophyses anteriores. Ductus bursae short, convoluted,<tei:lb/>offset to the left. Corpus bursae elongately ovoid; signa absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Japan.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 ex.<tei:lb/>Holotype $, Japan: [Honshu], Kobe, 6.vii.l927 (Lewis) (genitalia slide no. 13116; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The external apperance of kobella is similar to that of members of the choragella-group<tei:lb/>(choragella,fasciculata) and the sistrata-group (sistrata,formosana, iriomotensis) . The bursa copulatrix is<tei:lb/>as elongate as in members of the sistrata-group but the antrum is internally ridged, as in the choragella-<tei:lb/>group. The tibial spurs are of a length comparable with that of members of the choragella-group rather than<tei:lb/>the sistrata-group. However, the present placement of kobella should be considered provisional until the<tei:lb/>male is discovered. This species may be separated from all other Morophaga species by its enormously<tei:lb/>elongate antrum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxa incertae sedis<tei:lb/>LEPTOZANCLA Meyrick</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leptozancla Meyrick, 1920: 107. Type-species: Leptozancla talaroscia Meyrick, 1920: 108, by original<tei:lb/>designation and monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This genus was redescribed by Gozmany &amp; Vari (1973) and by Robinson (1976a). The single species here<tei:lb/>included, L. talaroscia Meyrick, was described by Meyrick (1920: 107) from two males from Mt Kenya,<tei:lb/>both in poor condition. No further specimens of Leptozancla have been identified since its original<tei:lb/>description. In the absence of further material, the taxonomic position of Leptozancla must remain in<tei:lb/>doubt. However, it is probably a scardiine. Gozmany &amp; Vari (1973) and Robinson (1976a) treated<tei:lb/>Philagrias (see below) as a synonym of Leptozancla. However, in the light of the morphological differences<tei:lb/>between other scardiine genera this synonymy is not appropriate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>L. talaroscia has densely ciliate antennae, the cilia as long as the flagellar diameter. The genitalia are<tei:lb/>characterized by the valvae having been apparently entirely supplanted by the juxta as no typical valval<tei:lb/>apodeme is evident: the juxta (if, indeed, the structure is the juxta) forms a ventral complex resembling a<tei:lb/>pair of entirely fused valvae. The transtilla (and, possibly, remnants of the valval apodemes) forms a<tei:lb/>strongly sclerotized complex with four elongate and posteriorly-directed spines (labides) (Robinson,<tei:lb/>1976a: fig. 65).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PHILAGRIAS Meyrick gen. rev.<tei:lb/>Philagrias Meyrick, 1932a: 119. Type-species: Philagrias zelotica Meyrick, 1932a: 119, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The single species included here, P. zelotica, has been redescribed by Gozmany &amp; Vari (1973) and by<tei:lb/>Robinson (1976a). It was described from a single male example in poor condition from the highlands of<tei:lb/>Ethiopia. No further specimens of Philagrias have been identified since its original description. In the<tei:lb/>absence of further material, its taxonomic position must remain in doubt. However, it is probably a<tei:lb/>scardiine.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Philagrias is distinguished by the antennae having very short cilia (0-5 x the flagellar diameter) which lie<tei:lb/>almost parallel to the axis of the flagellum. Previous authors have recorded that Philagrias lacks antennal<tei:lb/>cilia. The 'valva' bears extraordinarily large and complicated processes (?labides) arising from the<tei:lb/>modified valval apodemes (Robinson, 1976a: fig. 66). It is not certain whether the valva is present and<tei:lb/>forms part of a valve-juxta complex or whether it has been supplanted entirely by the juxta. In previous<tei:lb/>papers (1976a; 1981) I have assumed the structure to be the juxta on the grounds that no recognizably<tei:lb/>functional remnant of the valval apodeme remains.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>f FUNGUS MOTHS 135</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scardia tholerodes Meyrick<tei:lb/>Scardia tholerodes Meyrick, 1894: 27. Syntypes, 3 ex., BURMA (7BMNH) [not found, not examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Other specimens collected at Koni in the Shan States by Manders and described by Meyrick in the same<tei:lb/>paper as tholerodes are in the BMNH collection (ex Meyrick collection). No specimens of tholerodes have<tei:lb/>been found, however. From Meyrick's original description, this taxon may be a member of the Morophaga<tei:lb/>sistrata-group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scardia pharetrodes Meyrick<tei:lb/>Scardia pharetrodes Meyrick, 1934: 42. Holotype $, CHINA (7MNHU) [not found, not examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The whereabouts of the holotype of this species are in doubt: according to the original description it should<tei:lb/>be in MNHU, Berlin. However, it has not been mentioned by Petersen who has had access to the Berlin<tei:lb/>collections. Neither has it turned up in the Caradja collection of MINGA, Bucharest, despite a search on<tei:lb/>my behalf by Dr A. Popescu-Gorj. The possible affinities of this taxon are not evident from Meyrick's<tei:lb/>original description.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scardia isthmiella Busck<tei:lb/>Scardia isthmiella Busck, 1914: 65. Holotype $, PANAMA (NMNH) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The holotype of this species is in poor condition. It resembles superficially a Daviscardia species but the<tei:lb/>pale scaling of the terminal fascia does not extend along the dorsum. Davis (in prep.) will publish a<tei:lb/>description and illustration of it. The genitalia are nondescript, the eighth sternite hardly sclerotized, the<tei:lb/>ventral margin of the ostium lined with small setae and with a doubly crescentic outline (very shallowly<tei:lb/>m-shaped). The ductus bursae has irregular transverse constrictions in its posterior two-thirds and extends<tei:lb/>to two-thirds the length of the apophyses anteriores. The corpus bursae is small and ovate and lacks signa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. 1 ex.<tei:lb/>Holotype $, Panama: Porto Bello, v.1912 (Busck) (genitalia slide no. 20155; NMNH).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>FUNGUS MOTHS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>179</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 198-200 Habitats of Scardiinae. 198, montane Himalayan oak forest in Nepal at 2700 m is<tei:lb/>type-locality of Amorophaga rosemariae. 199, tall mixed dipterocarp forest at 330 m in Brunei is habitat<tei:lb/>of Tinissa species (foreground clearing is helicopter landing-point: figures at edge of clearing give scale<tei:lb/>for 25-metre forest canopy). 200, comparatively stunted upper montane forest on steep 1700 m ridges in<tei:lb/>Brunei is habitat of Cranaodes sequestrata and an undescribed Tinissa species; lower montane forest on<tei:lb/>Gunong Mulu (distant ridge beyond low-lying cloud) is habitat of Gentingia hollowayi.</tei:p>

      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Generic Names<tei:lb/>of Moths of the World</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The aim of this series is to provide a complete list of all the<tei:lb/>generic names, their type-species, designations, and appropriate<tei:lb/>references, for each of the families of moths treated. By ensuring<tei:lb/>that each generic name has its type-species fixed in accordance<tei:lb/>with the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature, this<tei:lb/>series should rectify present confusion and form a basis for a more<tei:lb/>stable nomenclature. All generic names have been checked for<tei:lb/>homonymy, and if necessary replaced.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The authors are all specialists on the staff of the Department of<tei:lb/>Entomology, British Museum (Natural History) and have the<tei:lb/>unrivalled collections and resources of the Museum on which to<tei:lb/>base their work.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volume 1; Noctuoidea (part): Noctuidae, Agaristidae and Nolidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>by I. W. B.Nye.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1975 Pp.viii + 568 frontispiece 38.00</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volume 2; Noctuoidea (part): Arctiidae, Ctenuchidae, Dioptidae,<tei:lb/>Lymantriidae, Notodontidae, Thaumetopoeidae and Thyretidae.<tei:lb/>by A. Watson, D. S. Fletcher and I. W. B. Nye.<tei:lb/>1980 Pp.xiv + 228 frontispiece 26.50</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volume 3; Geometroidea: Apoprogonidae, Axiidae, Callidulidae,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cyclidiidae, Drepanidae, Epicopeiidae, Epiplemidae, Geometridae,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pterothysanidae, Sematuridae, Thyatiridae and Uraniidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>by D.S.Fletcher.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1979 Pp.xx + 243 frontispiece 26.50</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volume 4; Bombycoidea, Castnioidea, Cossoidea, Zygaenoidea,<tei:lb/>Sesioidea. Additions and amendments to Vols 1-3.<tei:lb/>by D. S. Fletcher and I. W. B. Nye.<tei:lb/>1982 Pp.xiv + 192 frontispiece 26.50</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volume 5; Pyraloidea.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>by D. S. Fletcher &amp; I. W. B. Nye.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1984 Pp.xv + 185 25.00</tei:p>
         <tei:p>To be published:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volume VI. Microlepidoptera and additions and corrections to Volumes</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I-V. This volume will complete the series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The set of 5 volumes published so far 125.00</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>Titles to be published in Volume 52</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The sandflies of Egypt (Diptera: Phlebotominae)<tei:lb/>By R. P. Lane</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fungus moths: a review of the Scardiinae (Lepidoptera: Tineidae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By G.S.Robinson</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A revision of the European Agathidinae (Hymenoptera: Braconidae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By G. E. J. Nixon</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A key to the Afrotropical genera of Eucoilidae (Hymenoptera), with a revision of certain genera</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By J. Quinlan</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Photoset by Rowland Phototypesetting Ltd, Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk<tei:lb/>Printed in Great Britain by Henry Ling Ltd, Dorchester</tei:p>

      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>(NATURAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>25A'</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PRESENTED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENERAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bulletin of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A revision of the European Agathidinae<tei:lb/>(Hymenoptera: Braconidae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>G. E. J. Nixon</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Entomology series</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vol 52 No 3 24 April 1986</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>The Bulletin of the British Museum (Natural History), instituted in 1949, is issued in four<tei:lb/>scientific series, Botany, Entomology, Geology (incorporating Mineralogy) and Zoology,<tei:lb/>and an Historical series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Papers in the Bulletin are primarily the results of research carried out on the unique and<tei:lb/>ever-growing collections of the Museum, both by the scientific staff of the Museum and by<tei:lb/>specialists from elsewhere who make use of the Museum's resources. Many of the papers are<tei:lb/>works of reference that will remain indispensable for years to come.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parts are published at irregular intervals as they become ready, each is complete in itself,<tei:lb/>available separately, and individually priced. Volumes contain about 300 pages and several<tei:lb/>volumes may appear within a calendar year. Subscriptions may be placed for one or more of<tei:lb/>the series on either an Annual or Per Volume basis. Prices vary according to the contents of<tei:lb/>the individual parts. Orders and enquiries should be sent to:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Publications Sales,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History),<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>London SW75BD,<tei:lb/>England.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>World List abbreviation: Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Ent.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trustees of the British Museum (Natural History), 1986</tei:p>

         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A revision of the European Agathidinae<tei:lb/>(Hymenoptera: Braconidae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>G. E. J. Nixon</tei:p>
         <tei:p>c/o Department of Entomology, British Museum (Natural History), Cromwell Road, London<tei:lb/>SW7 5BD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I GENERAL LIB<tei:lb/>Contents</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis 183</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction 183</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Depositories 184</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxonomic characters 184</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Biology 185</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Host records 186</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathidinae 187</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to European genera 188</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synonymic list of species 188</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Disophrys Forster 190</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cremnops Forster 191</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis Latreille 192</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rhamphagathis Tobias 214</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus Nees von Esenbeck 215</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Earinus Wesmael 226</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Baeognatha Kokujev 229</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Species inquirendae 230</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Index 242</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Seven genera of the braconid subfamily Agathidinae are revised for the European zoogeographical region .<tei:lb/>Keys to the genera and species are provided. Fifty-four species are recognized as valid, 11 are newly<tei:lb/>synonymized, and 11, including an extralimital species from Jordan, are described as new. Lectotypes are<tei:lb/>designated for 13 nominal species. Authentic host records are included together with an account of the<tei:lb/>biology of the subfamily.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although the braconid subfamily Agathidinae has a world-wide distribution, it is poorly<tei:lb/>represented in the western Palaearctic region. The present revision deals with the fauna of<tei:lb/>Europe, including European U.S.S.R., and Turkey; one species from Jordan is included for<tei:lb/>comparative purposes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Earlier contributions to the taxonomy of European Agathidinae are those of Nees von<tei:lb/>Esenbeck (1834), Wesmael (1837), Reinhard (1867), Thomson (1895), Marshall (1885; 1888)<tei:lb/>and Fahringer (1937). The more recent, notable taxonomic revisions on Palaearctic Agathidinae<tei:lb/>are those of Telenga (1955) and Tobias (1976&lt;z), the former concentrating on the European<tei:lb/>species, the latter on the Central Asian species. Their combined research reveals an agathidine<tei:lb/>fauna that hardly differs numerically from that covered in the present work. Even Tobias's paper<tei:lb/>(19766) on the Far Eastern species of Microdus includes only four that are not represented in<tei:lb/>Europe.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Agathidinae is well represented in the tropics and Shenefelt's catalogue (1970) lists</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bull. Br. Mus. not. Hist. (Ent.) 52 (3): 183-242 Issued 24 April 1986</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>184 G. E. J. NIXON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>numerous species; however, most of these will require investigation before their status can be<tei:lb/>properly assessed. Some attempt to sort out the chaos of names in the Oriental species has been<tei:lb/>made by Bhat &amp; Gupta (1977), but other than this no major taxonomic research has been done<tei:lb/>on the tropical fauna. The classified, tropical material in the British Museum (Natural History)<tei:lb/>has been examined briefly; although quantitatively small and unreliably determined it provides<tei:lb/>some information on evolutionary trends within the Agathidinae. It seems that the subfamily<tei:lb/>divides into two main sections, the Agathis-Microdus group of genera which have lobed or<tei:lb/>simple claws and are restricted mainly to the Northern Hemisphere, and the Cremnops-<tei:lb/>Disophrys group of genera which are predominantly tropical in distribution. Shenefelt (1970)<tei:lb/>includes most of the described species in these two genus groups. Microdus is Holarctic but also<tei:lb/>occurs in the Southern Hemisphere. Two mainly tropical genera, Cremnops and Disophrys, are<tei:lb/>each represented by a single species in the western Palaearctic region.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Little can be said here about the North American Agathidinae, but Agathirsia Westwood<tei:lb/>exhibits a line of descent different from the two genera just mentioned. Its wing venation is<tei:lb/>typical of the subfamily but its body-form and especially the exaggerated length of the labium<tei:lb/>isolate it from the Old World genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The aim of the present review is to enable the reader to identify more easily the European<tei:lb/>species of Agathidinae; to postulate evolutionary trends within the subfamily is beyond its<tei:lb/>scope.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Depositories</tei:p>
         <tei:p>AA A. A. Allen collection, Reigate, Surrey.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>AS Zoological Institute, Leningrad.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>EH Erasmus Haeselbarth collection, Munich.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HNHM Termeszettudomanyi Muzeum, Budapest.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>LC Linnaean collection, Linnean Society, London.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MNHU Museum fur Naturkunde der Humboldt-Universitat, Berlin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MS Mark Shaw collection, Edinburgh.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NM Naturhistorisches Museum, Vienna.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>RNH Rijksmuseum van Natuurlijke Historic, Leiden.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>UM University Museum, Oxford.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>USNM National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ZH Zoological Museum, Helsinki.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ZI Zoologiska Institutionen, Lund.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ZM Zoologisk Museum, Copenhagen.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ZSBS Zoologische Sammlung des Bayerischen Staates, Munich.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxonomic characters</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The agathidine taxa studied in this revision are variable in colour, sculpture and ovipositor<tei:lb/>length, and Agathis and Microdus contain groups of what at first sight appear to be valid species<tei:lb/>but which subsequently prove to be inseparable because of intermediate forms. There are two<tei:lb/>alternatives: either the variants are regarded as different species, or a wide range of variation is<tei:lb/>accepted. The latter alternative has been chosen here since the concept of a species-aggregate,<tei:lb/>even if it offers no more than a provisional solution, at least avoids an increase in the number of<tei:lb/>dubious taxa. Nevertheless, species of Agathidinae have some characters that are reasonably<tei:lb/>constant and therefore useful for identification purposes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The elongation of the head in facial view, though slightly variable, is frequently used in<tei:lb/>separating species of Agathis. It is defined as the length of the malar space measured against the<tei:lb/>longer diameter of the eye. The surface of the frons is also important, especially in Agathis in<tei:lb/>which it is either smooth, or provided with a deepened cavity or trough margined by raised keels.<tei:lb/>The conformation of this structure is diagnostic in such species as breviseta and assimilis.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE EUROPEAN AGATHIDINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Indispensable for at least a partial breakdown of species of Agathis are the mouth-parts. These<tei:lb/>are modified to form a beak, certain parts of which, especially the prementum, are much<tei:lb/>lengthened. Since the whole structure is, to some degree, retractile (and thus hidden), only the<tei:lb/>galea is used; this is attached to the base of the maxillary palpus, is constant in length and is<tei:lb/>generally visible. The thorax is uniform in shape though in Agathis it is subject to slight<tei:lb/>elongation. The notaulices are usually deeply impressed; when weak as in Agathis nigra and<tei:lb/>Microdus lugubrator, they may sometimes be absent in some specimens. Propodeal sculpture is<tei:lb/>variable and of limited value; within a species, such as Agathis glabricula, it can be entirely<tei:lb/>rugose or, more frequently, it has smooth, polished lateral panels. The number of teeth on the<tei:lb/>outer side of the middle tibia of Agathis is fairly constant; sometimes there are sufficient teeth<tei:lb/>(8-10, as in fulmeki) to be of diagnostic importance. In Agathis it is essential to examine the<tei:lb/>claws for the presence or absence of a lobe or tooth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Venation is used very little to separate species. In Microdus the radius (Rs) is sometimes<tei:lb/>characteristically curved on the side towards the stigma, and in one species, cingulipes, the<tei:lb/>curvature is so pronounced as to be diagnostic. The shape of the second submarginal cell<tei:lb/>(referred to herein as the areolet) is virtually uniform in Microdus, but in Agathis it is variable,<tei:lb/>and can be intraspecifically either triangular or distinctly four-sided; rarely, as in Agathis<tei:lb/>anglica, the four-sided condition is so pronounced that it always retains its distinctiveness. Less<tei:lb/>variable and more reliable in separating species of Agathis is the ratio between the two abscissae<tei:lb/>of the postmarginalis (Fig. 67). This vein is the distal extension of the stigma along the edge of<tei:lb/>the wing known as Rl; sometimes it continues beyond the point where it is joined by the radius<tei:lb/>(Rs) and thus becomes composed of two abscissae. The distal abscissa is sometimes so long as to<tei:lb/>be diagnostic, as in Agathis minuta.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In Agathis, the gaster rarely provides characters of taxonomic value, being in greater part<tei:lb/>smooth and polished. In Microdus, however, it frequently has sculpture that is specific, though<tei:lb/>variable in degree of intensity and definition. Earinus gloriatorius demonstrates the unreliability<tei:lb/>of gastral sculpture in the Agathidinae; in this species tergites 2+3 are sometimes smooth and<tei:lb/>polished, sometimes conspicuously rugose, with every intermediate condition.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ovipositor length is fairly uniform and of little use in the identification of species. There is<tei:lb/>nearly always considerable distortion in the apical tergites of dried specimens so that the actual<tei:lb/>length of the ovipositor is difficult to determine; the length of the ovipositor sheaths is more<tei:lb/>easily assessed and it is this length compared with that of the whole body that is mentioned in the<tei:lb/>descriptions.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The morphological terms used in this revision are based on those of Richards (1977) and Eady<tei:lb/>(1974). The fused second and third tergites of the gaster are referred to as 'tergites 2+3' because,<tei:lb/>in the majority of braconids, these two tergites have the appearance of a single segment,<tei:lb/>morphologically bipartite only by the presence of two lateral spiracles.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Biology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As far as is known species of Agathidinae are internal parasites of lepidopterous larvae, but their<tei:lb/>biology has received little attention. There are a few exceptions, however. Simmonds (1947)<tei:lb/>described the life history of Agathis vulgaris (Cresson), a parasite of Loxostege sticticalis (L.),<tei:lb/>the sugar-beet web- worm in North America, and gave a detailed account of the morphology of<tei:lb/>the early stages of the parasite and an assessment of its value in biological control. Simmonds<tei:lb/>considered Agathis vulgaris to be an important parasite of its host and in fact found it to be the<tei:lb/>most frequently bred parasite in his experiments.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dondale (1954) described the biology of Microdus dimidiator Nees von Esenbeck under the<tei:lb/>name Agathis laticinctus Cresson (Krombein et al. , 1979: 193). It is one of the parasites attacking<tei:lb/>the eye-spotted bud moth, Spilonota ocellana (Denis &amp; Schiffermuller) , an orchard pest in<tei:lb/>temperate North America. According to Dondale, the eggs of the parasite are deposited within<tei:lb/>the host during August and by early September have given rise to polypod, first-stage larvae<tei:lb/>which then enter a winter diapause. The overwintering larvae can be found within the<tei:lb/>host-caterpillars until the following July. The host-caterpillar reaches maturity and spins its</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>186 G. E. J. NIXON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>cocoon in late June or early July; the larva of the parasite then bores its way out and feeds<tei:lb/>externally on the juices of the host during a period of three or four hours, finally destroying it.<tei:lb/>Dondale does not consider Microdus dimidiator to be a particularly successful parasite but his<tei:lb/>paper, with its excellent illustrations of larval structures, is a notable contribution to the biology<tei:lb/>of Microdus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thorpe (1933) gave a brief account of the biology of Microdus pumilus Ratzeburg, a parasite<tei:lb/>of Coleophora laricella (Hiibner), the larch case-bearer. He figured the first and second instar<tei:lb/>larvae of the parasite but had no material of the later stages. He found Microdus pumilus to be<tei:lb/>very rare in England and , in spite of breeding a wide range of parasites from the host , obtained it<tei:lb/>only from the Forest of Dean, Gloucestershire. Host-material from the south of France, on the<tei:lb/>other hand, produced pumilus in abundance, the parasite reaching a level of 12 per cent, the<tei:lb/>adults emerging in June. The first instar of the parasite diapauses through the winter within its<tei:lb/>host and in this respect resembles Microdus dimidiator. According to Tobias (1964), one of the<tei:lb/>most serious pests of agriculture in Armenia is the Mallow moth, Pexicopia (Pectinophora)<tei:lb/>malvella (Hiibner). Over a number of years parasites of this moth were bred by A. S. Avetyan,<tei:lb/>among them Agathis malvacearum Latreille. Tobias does not assess the significance of mal-<tei:lb/>vacearum in the control of Pexicopia malvella and used Avetyan's bred material mainly to study<tei:lb/>the parasite's seasonal variability in size and colour.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Agathidinae, apart from Agathis vulgaris (mentioned above), have not been used in<tei:lb/>biological control in the tropics, consequently the literature provides only casual information on<tei:lb/>life-cycles. Gupta (1964), however, bred specimens of an Agathis sp. from the larvae of<tei:lb/>Holcocera pulverea Meyrick, the Lac predator. These were sent to C. F. W. Muesebeck who<tei:lb/>identified them as Agathis f estiva Muesebeck, a parasite of the Oriental fruit moth, Grapholita<tei:lb/>molesta Busck, in China. Gupta states that nothing much is known about the biology of/estiva,<tei:lb/>and suggested that it is hardly more than an occasional parasite of pulverea but that it may also<tei:lb/>parasitise other lepidopterous larvae occupying similar habitats.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Most of the above names are based on Kloet &amp; Hincks (1972).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>AGATHIDINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Disco-cubital vein (Rs+M) mostly undeveloped; hence 1st discoidal cell and 1st submarginal<tei:lb/>cell confluent, except in Earinus Wesmael; 2nd submarginal cell usually very small, triangular or<tei:lb/>subtriangular, forming an areolet (Fig. 50); when large (not much!) then 4-sided and often with accessory<tei:lb/>vein arising from outer side of 2nd transverse cubitus (2rm) (Disophrys-Cremnops genus-group); 2nd<tei:lb/>transverse cubitus absent in Baeognatha Kokujev; hence no closed areolet in this genus; radial cell always<tei:lb/>short, mostly narrow, terminating far proximal to apex of fore-wing (Figs 50, 55, 60).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head in facial view elongate (Disophrys-Cremnops genus-group); less frequently transversely elliptical<tei:lb/>(Microdus) . Mouth-parts mostly lengthened and drawn out in form of beak ; maxillary palpus 5-segmented ;<tei:lb/>labial palpus 4-segmented; in Microdus segment 3 of labial palpus sometimes so small that palpus appears<tei:lb/>to be 3-segmented.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thorax of generalised form except in highly specialised western Palaearctic Rhamphagathis Tobias.<tei:lb/>Pronotum with deep pit on each side, separated internally by fenestra. Propodeum variable; strongly,<tei:lb/>almost symmetrically areolated by raised keels (Disophrys-Cremnops genus-group) and then spiracle<tei:lb/>elongate; smooth to rugose with at most two longitudinal keels and spiracle circular (Agathis-Microdus<tei:lb/>genus-group).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gaster usually highly polished, smooth but tergites 2+3 often sculptured in Microdus; in the Afrotropic-</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>188 G. E. J. NIXON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>al Braunsia Kriechbaumer, related to Microdus, the gaster shows a highly characteristic sculpture of strong<tei:lb/>striation. Spiracles of tergite 1 situated on dorsal plate. Ovipositor variable in length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Based on knowledge of a relatively small sample of the subfamily, the above description has necessarily a<tei:lb/>restricted value. A study of the virtually unknown fauna of Australia and South America would certainly<tei:lb/>call for modifications.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The position of the Agathidinae with regard to the other braconid subfamilies has been defined by van<tei:lb/>Achterberg (1976). So far there is no evidence to contest the assertion that the Agathidinae can be<tei:lb/>separated from all other subfamilies by the venation of the fore-wing: the short radial cell in combination<tei:lb/>with the small second submarginal cell provides a character not found elsewhere in the Braconidae. This<tei:lb/>character is in general supported by the elongation of the head.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Van Achterberg (1984) has given a more up-to-date review of the phylogeny of the Braconidae based<tei:lb/>upon a comprehensive cladistic analysis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to European genera</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Hind claw cleft; frons with sharp keel or rounded ridge between external side of antennal</tei:p>
         <tei:p>insertion and lateral ocellus; inner spur of hind tibia very long, reaching middle of basal<tei:lb/>segment of hind tarsus 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Hind claw not cleft; frons unarmed or much more often with basal lobe or tooth; inner spur of</tei:p>
         <tei:p>hind tibia shorter, not reaching middle of basal segment of hind tarsus 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Body entirely fulvous ; fore- wing having dappled appearance , with broad , hyaline fascia beneath</tei:p>
         <tei:p>half yellow stigma and paler at base and apex; maxillary palpus in female with long bristles<tei:lb/>that are longer than palpal segments; ovipositor about as long as body</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CREMVOPSF6rster(p. 191)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Body variable in colour but always partly blackened ; fore- wing without dappled appearance and</tei:p>
         <tei:p>at most with pale, hyaline streak beneath stigma; maxillary palpus of female with only very<tei:lb/>short hairs; ovipositor very short, projecting only slightly beyond apex of gaster</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISOPHRYSF6rster(p. 190)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 First submarginal cell separated from 1st discoidal cell by a fully sclerotised vein (Fig. 67);</tei:p>
         <tei:p>sternaulus absent EARINUS Wesmael(p. 226)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- First submarginal cell more or less fused with 1st discoidal cell; sternaulus present (rarely</tei:p>
         <tei:p>reduced to a fine groove or virtually absent and then head in facial view elongate) 4</tei:p>

         <tei:p>- Fore- wing always with a closed areolet (2nd submarginal cell) 5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 Middle lobe of mesoscutum deeply hollowed out to form a wide trough , each side of which shows</tei:p>
