         <tei:p>RHAMPHAGA THIS Tobias<tei:lb/>nasicornis Telenga</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISOPHR YS Forster</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Disophrys Forster, 1862: 246. Type-species: Ichneumon inculcator Linnaeus sensu Forster, 1862</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(= Agathis caesa Klug).<tei:lb/>Diophrys Kriechbaumer, 1898: 181. [Unjustified emendation.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I have examined the original specimen of Ichneumon inculcator Linnaeus which is in the LC, London. It is<tei:lb/>an ichneumonid and as such has been dealt with by Fitton (1978) and van Rossem (1969).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Forster makes no mention of what material he had but merely cites Ichneumon inculcator L. as the<tei:lb/>type-species of Disophrys, adding a reference to Nees von Esenbeck: 'Agathis inc. Hym.ichn.aff.Mon. 1:<tei:lb/>138'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In view of the above, Disophrys must either be considered a genus in the Ichneumonidae, or interpreted<tei:lb/>as actually described by Forster. The latter course has been followed here but ratification will be required<tei:lb/>by the International Commission for Zoological Nomenclature.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The oldest available name for the species misidentified by Forster is caesa Klug, 1835, described from a<tei:lb/>female taken by Waltl at Puerto Real in Andalucia, Spain. This specimen has been examined; it bears a<tei:lb/>label, presumably in Klug's handwriting: 'Andalusien, Waltl d.' and another, red, marked 'type'. I have<tei:lb/>labelled this specimen as 'Agathis caesa Klug. Holotype $, G. E. J. Nixon, 1984', this being the name<tei:lb/>under which it was originally described.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Head in facial view elongate. Galea of maxillary palpus fully 3 times longer than greatest width;<tei:lb/>labial palpus 4-segmented; two apical segments subequal. Ocelli in high triangle; posterior tangent to<tei:lb/>anterior ocellus not touching posterior pair. Antennal sockets on inner side each with raised, sublamelli-<tei:lb/>form tubercle; in frontal view of head, space between antennal sockets shows as bilobed projection. Frons<tei:lb/>on each side with raised ridge . Notaulices deeply impressed . Areolet of fore-wing 4-sided ; outer side of 2nd<tei:lb/>transverse cubitus (r-m) with stub of vein; radius leaving stigma in basal third; distal abscissa of<tei:lb/>postmarginalis about half as long as proximal abscissa. Propodeum with strongly raised ridges enclosing<tei:lb/>areas of uneven size; spiracle large, subellipitical. Inner spur of hind tibia reaching middle of basal segment<tei:lb/>of hind tarsus; outer side of middle tibia without teeth; claws cleft. Gaster smooth, polished. Ovipositor<tei:lb/>projecting only slightly beyond apex of gaster.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The above diagnosis is based on the type-species and cannot therefore encompass the range of structure<tei:lb/>that may later be found to be acceptable for a more realistic definition of the genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although numerous species of Disophrys have been described from the tropics (Shenefelt, 1970), only<tei:lb/>four are known from the Palaearctic region. As well as caesa, these are calcaratrix Telenga (1955), dissors<tei:lb/>Kokujev (1903) and manifesto Kokujev (1903), all from Central Asia and all represented by at least one<tei:lb/>example in the BMNH. Examination of these three species suggests that modifications of the generic<tei:lb/>concept of Disophrys will include variation in the surface sculpture of the hind tibia (manifesto), the<tei:lb/>thickness and vestiture of the longer hind tibial spur (calcaratrix) , and the strength and sharpness of the<tei:lb/>frontal keel (manifesto).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Disophrys caesa (Klug)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis caesa Klug, 1835: 89. Holotype &lt;j&gt;, SPAIN (MNHU) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[Ichneumon inculcator Linnaeus; Forster, 1862: 246. Misidentification.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Disophrys caesus (Klug) Marshall, 1890: 574.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Diophrys [sic] anthracina Kriechbaumer, 1898: 185. LECTOTYPE cf , SPAIN (ZSBS), here designated</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[examined]. Syn. n.<tei:lb/>Disophrys anthracina Kriechbaumer; Szepligeti, 1904: 124.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE EUROPEAN AGATHIDINAE 191</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf $ , 8-11 mm long (excluding ovipositor). Body varying in colour from almost entirely red (holotype of<tei:lb/>caesd) to entirely black (anthracind) . Hind tibia varying from black and red to entirely black. Basal half of<tei:lb/>fore-wing either entirely infumate or with median and submedian cells almost hyaline (lectotype of<tei:lb/>anthracind).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>J. Head from above strongly transverse; in facial view somewhat variable; in nominate form decidedly<tei:lb/>elongate but less so in central European examples. Face strongly raised along middle line, covered with<tei:lb/>much coarse punctuation or, towards antennal insertions, rugose-punctation; face also much deepened at<tei:lb/>site of toruli. Frontal ridge strongly raised, sharp. Galea about 0.75 times longer than malar space.<tei:lb/>Antenna with 40-48 segments; flagellum tapering apically; middle segments almost transverse. Meso-<tei:lb/>scutum in profile sloping very gradually towards pronotum in Spanish specimens; in examples from further<tei:lb/>eastwards, the slope becomes steeper; this is correlated with smaller size and increase of red colour.<tei:lb/>Prepectal keel strong , well defined . Sternaulus in form of a wide trough , crossed by very strong rugae . Hind<tei:lb/>coxa above very coarsely rugose-reticulate; rugose area often separated from the weak oblong trough<tei:lb/>alongside it by a raised ridge; hind femur densely covered with shallow pits; hind tibia much roughened<tei:lb/>through dense covering of tiny, oblong tubercles; inner spur of hind tibia unmodified, about 1.5 times<tei:lb/>longer than outer one and reaching only slightly beyond middle of basal segment of hind tarsus. Gaster<tei:lb/>smooth, polished. Ovipositor sheath about 3 times longer than basal segment of hind tarsus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>O". Like female except for sexual differences.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED (from the Iberian Peninsula)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Portugal: 1 Cf, near Coimbra, Beira littoral, 22.vii.1970 (Pronk) (RNH). Spain: 1 $, Albarracin<tei:lb/>(RNH); 1 $, Ost Peja, ll.vii.1894 (RNH); 1 $ (holotype of caesd), Andalucia, Puerto Real (Waltt)<tei:lb/>(MNHU); 5 cT, 3 $, Barcelona, Calella d. Costa, vi.1971 (Boucek) (BMNH); 1 $, Burgos, 26.vi.1961<tei:lb/>(RNH); 1 Cf , 1 $i Jaen, Las Correderas (RNH); 2 d" (lectotype and paralectotype of anthracind), Castille,<tei:lb/>Cuenca, 1896 (Korb) (ZSBS).<tei:lb/>Other material examined</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8 d", 34 $. Austria, Greece, Hungary, Turkey, Yugoslavia (all BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Two males of the original material collected by Korb in Castille, Cuenca, and sent by him to<tei:lb/>Kriechbaumer, are in ZSBS; they agree with the original description in all respects except sex (Kriech-<tei:lb/>baumer stated that he had three females but found difficulty in sexing specimens of Disophrys). A male<tei:lb/>labelled 'Castilien, Cuenca, Korb 1896' is here designated as lectotype; the second specimen is labelled<tei:lb/>paralectotype.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CflEMJVOPS Forster</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cremnops Forster, 1862: 246. Type-species: Ichneumon deserter Linnaeus, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Achterberg (1982: 136) has caused confusion concerning the correct identity of the type-species of<tei:lb/>Cremnops and questions whether the latter is valid or a synonym of Vipio Latreille (1804: 173). His<tei:lb/>argument hinges on whether Ichneumon desertor L. , 1758 and what he calls Ichneumon desertor F. (recte /.<tei:lb/>desertor L. sensu F. , 1775) refer to the same species. He considers that they represent a single species as is<tei:lb/>clear from his statement 'Ichneumon desertor Fabricius is not a separate species, since Fabricius cited in his<tei:lb/>first description only the original description of Ichneumon desertor Linnaeus, 1758, together with the<tei:lb/>reference to Linnaeus' description. Therefore there cannot be any doubt that there is no separate species<tei:lb/>named Ichneumon desertor Fabricius. This fact was overlooked by Bradley (1919: 59) when he stated that<tei:lb/>"the type of Vipio Latreille is Ichneumon desertor Fabricius, not of Linnaeus" '. Achterberg continues<tei:lb/>'Because nomenclatorily Ichneumon desertor Fabricius is actually /. desertor Linnaeus, 1758, the genus<tei:lb/>Vipio Latreille . . . becomes ... a senior synonym of Cremnops Forster, 1862'. Obviously the truth of this<tei:lb/>statement depends on the validity of his previous statement. It can be shown that Achterberg's reasoning is<tei:lb/>false and that he misinterpreted Bradley (1919) as well as several earlier workers. He weakens his<tei:lb/>argument by stating that 'At present in the Fabricius collection there are specimens under desertor which<tei:lb/>are not conspecific (or congeneric) with /. desertor Linnaeus and this indicated only that Fabricius had<tei:lb/>difficulties in interpreting /. desertor Linnaeus'. This remark does not only indicate that Fabricius had<tei:lb/>trouble in interpreting /. desertor Linnaeus but implies also that he misidentified the Linnaean species and<tei:lb/>that /. desertor L. sensu F. , 1775, could in fact represent a different taxon. Earlier workers such as Latreille<tei:lb/>(1804), Nees von Esenbeck (1834) and Forster (1862) also considered that Fabricius had misidentified<tei:lb/>desertor L. and that the species he had belonged to a different group of Braconidae. Latreille (1804) placed<tei:lb/>what he called desertor F. (recte desertor L. sensu F.) with two other species in his genus Vipio. The<tei:lb/>Fabrician interpretation of desertor L. has been associated with this generic name ever since, having been<tei:lb/>cited as the type-species of Vipio by Forster (1862). Ichneumon desertor L., on the other hand, has long</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>192 G. E. J. NIXON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>been recognised as an agathidine and is the type-species of Cremnops by monotypy. Since it is obvious that<tei:lb/>/. deserter L. and /. desertor L. sensu F. refer to radically different species, Achterberg's (1982) contention<tei:lb/>that Vipio and Cremnops are synonyms because they have the same type-species is incorrect.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The critical references in the taxonomic history of the name desertor are as follows.<tei:lb/>Linnaeus, 1758: 563. Original description of Ichneumon desertor.<tei:lb/>Fabricius, 1775: 334. Ichneumon desertor L. sensu F., 1775.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Latreille ? 1804: 173. Ichneumon desertorL. sensu F., 1775. Transferred to genus Vipio Latreille.<tei:lb/>Forster, 1862: 235. Ichneumon desertorL. sensu F. , 1775. Cited as type-species of Vipio Latreille.<tei:lb/>Spinola, 1808: 101. Bracon deflagrator, erected (unnecessarily) as replacement name for /.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>desertor L.<tei:lb/>Nees von Esenbeck, 1834: 125. Bracon deflagrator Spinola transferred to genus Agathis, with /.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>desertor L. wrongly placed as junior synonym.<tei:lb/>Forster, 1862: 246. Agathis deflagrator (wrongly attributed to Nees von Esenbeck) cited as</tei:p>
         <tei:p>type-species of Cremnops. Correct citation should have been 'Agathis deflagrator (Spinola)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>sensu Nees, 1834'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS, cf $ . Head in facial view elongate. Mouth parts lengthened; galea fully twice as long as wide. A<tei:lb/>blunt keel, an extension of the outer rim of antennal socket, extends obliquely across frons half way<tei:lb/>towards posterior ocellus. Frons bilobed between antennal insertions. Propodeum almost symmetrically<tei:lb/>areolated by sharply raised keels; propodeal spiracle narrowly oval. Outer side of middle tibia without<tei:lb/>trace of teeth (cf . Agathis and Microdus). First abscissa of mediella of hind wing much shorter than second;<tei:lb/>areolet of fore-wing 4-sided with stub of vein arising from outer side of 2nd transverse cubitus. Gaster<tei:lb/>polished, smooth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cremnops desertor (Linnaeus)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichneumon desertor Linnaeus, 1758: 563. Holotype $, EUROPE (LC) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bracon deflagrator Spinola, 1808: 101. [Unnecessary replacement name for /. desertor Linnaeus.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis deflagrator (Spinola) Forster, 1862: 246. [Attributed to Nees von Esenbeck, 1834: 139.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf $, 6-8 mm long (excluding ovipositor). Entirely bright fulvous. Wings with a broad hyaline fascia at<tei:lb/>middle and two large, almost confluent spots at apex of wing.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Bristles of palpi upstanding, fully as long as palpal segments. Ovipositor sheath fully 0-66 times as<tei:lb/>long as gaster.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Bristles of palpi of ordinary form, much shorter than palpal segments.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>9 cf , 20 $. All from southern Europe. Tobias (1976) gives the range as Palaearctic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. I have seen no bred material. Tobias (1976) gives Cydia (Grapholita) pomonella L. (Tortricidae),<tei:lb/>Eurrhypara hortulata (L.) (Pyralidae) and Conopia [Syanthedon] spheciformis (Denis &amp; Schiffermiiller)<tei:lb/>(Sesiidae) as hosts, which include such a wide range of lepidopterous families that I doubt if all can be<tei:lb/>correct.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. The single European species can be easily recognised by its colour and by the long palpal<tei:lb/>bristles of the female.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>AGATHIS Latreille</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis Latreille, 1804: 173 [no included species] ; 1805: 175. Type-species: Agathis malvacearum Latreille,<tei:lb/>by subsequent monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Mostly black species, rarely entirely or partly marked with red. Head in facial view almost<tei:lb/>always elongate; if not markedly so then still clearly triangular. Ocelli always in a high triangle, the<tei:lb/>posterior tangent to the anterior ocellus not touching or cutting posterior pair. Antenna in the species<tei:lb/>under review never with more than 40 segments. Mouth parts characteristically lengthened, forming a<tei:lb/>beak. Notaulices almost always present. Propodeum without areolation but with two more or less distinct<tei:lb/>medial longitudinal keels; surface on each side of these keels usually smooth, polished; rarely surface of<tei:lb/>propodeum rugose all over. Spurs of hind tibia short, always less than half as long as basal segment of hind<tei:lb/>tarsus; middle tibia with at least two teeth on its outer side in about apical third. Hind claw with or without a<tei:lb/>lobe or tooth but never cleft; each of the posterior metasternal foramena that receive the insertion of the<tei:lb/>hind coxae open on its inner side. First discoidal cell and first cubital cell confluent; 2nd cubital cell always</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE EUROPEAN AGATHIDINAE 193</tei:p>
         <tei:p>small, most triangular, rarely obviously 4-sided. First tergite varying from entirely smooth to rugose-<tei:lb/>striate; tergites 2+3 rarely striate all over (semiaciculata Ivanov); sometimes with variable amount of<tei:lb/>broken rugose-striation distal to, and to sides of, faint, tranverse, blister-like swelling. Ovipositor at least<tei:lb/>as long as gaster.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species (females)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Antennal sockets separated on inner side by distance equal to diameter of anterior ocellus.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>syngenesiae Nees von Esenbeck(p. 196)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>umbellatarum Nees von Esenbeck (p. 197)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Agathis glaucoptera Nees von Esenbeck</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 3)<tei:lb/>Agathis glaucoptera Nees von Esenbeck, 1834: 128. Holotype ?$ , ITALY (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$, 7-8 mm long (excluding ovipositor). Almost entirely reddish yellow; ocellar region and scrobes<tei:lb/>blackish; mesosternum, mesopleurum and propodeal area black. Hind coxa varying from black to bright<tei:lb/>reddish yellow, like gaster; hind femur entirely reddish yellow.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head in facial view markedly elongate; in this aspect differing from all other included species in that the<tei:lb/>face is only weakly narrowed towards the mouth (Fig. 3). Malar space about 1-25 times as long as longer<tei:lb/>diameter of eye. Inner rims of antennal sockets joined to form a keel that unites with a shallow, V-shaped<tei:lb/>impression in front of anterior ocellus. Anterior ocellus raised as though on a prominence. Antenna 31-33<tei:lb/>segmented. Galea hardly twice as long as wide. Thorax in profile of generalised form. Notaulices deep but</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>196 G. E. J. NIXON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>not costate. Sternaulus deep, wide, strongly costate. Propodeum without clearly defined, longitudinal keel<tei:lb/>but with several coarse rugae in their place. Areolet of fore-wing small, stalked; stigma relatively elongate;<tei:lb/>distal abscissa of postmarginalis at least 0-66 times longer than proximal abscissa; anellus of hind wing<tei:lb/>joining anal cell above middle . Hind claw with large , conspicuous lobe ; outer side of middle tibia with 1-2 ,<tei:lb/>or without , teeth ; inner spur of hind tibia powerful , reaching middle of basal segment of hind tarsus . Gaster<tei:lb/>rather short. Tergite 1 about 1-33 times longer than wide at apex, smooth, polished. Ovipositor sheath<tei:lb/>about as long as gaster.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>France: 1 $, Perpignan, 10.vi.1976 (G. D. Slob) (RNH). Turkey: 1 $, Konya, ll.vi.1971 (Kl. Warnke)<tei:lb/>(RHN). Yugoslavia: 1 $, Macedonia, R. Reshik, (/. Waterston) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Marshall (1890) redescribed glaucoptera from a single female in poor condition but beyond<tei:lb/>doubt recognised the species correctly. Both Telenga (1955) and Tobias (1954; 1963) were in agreement<tei:lb/>with Marshall and these three authors have been followed here. A. glaucoptera is distinguished from all<tei:lb/>other species from the region by the shape of the head in facial view, in combination with the stalked<tei:lb/>areolet and the short ovipositor sheath. The point of emission of the anal vein in the hind wing is<tei:lb/>noteworthy and suggests that glaucoptera occupies a somewhat isolated position among the European<tei:lb/>species ofAgathis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis syngenesiae Nees von Esenbeck</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 5, 20)<tei:lb/>Agathis syngenesiae Nees von Esenbeck, 1814: 192, 194. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf $ , 4-5-5-6 mm (excluding ovipositor).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$, Body much marked with red; head varying from almost black to almost entirely red. Prothorax,<tei:lb/>mesoscutum, propodeum and mesosternum entirely black. Gaster almost entirely red.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head in facial view markedly elongate (Fig. 5); seen from above, strongly transverse and only shallowly<tei:lb/>emarginate behind (Fig. 20). Malar space equal to, or slightly longer than, longer diameter of eye. Mouth<tei:lb/>parts short for genus; galea hardly 1-5 times longer than wide. Antennal sockets not united on inner side to<tei:lb/>form a single keel but separated by a distance fully equal to diameter of anterior ocellus. Antenna with<tei:lb/>25-27 segments. Thorax moderately elongate, in profile as 13 : 8. Notaulices generally rather shallow.<tei:lb/>Sternaulus usually distinct but sometimes almost wanting, not extending beyond middle of mesopleurum.<tei:lb/>Sculpture of propodeum varying from coarsely reticulate all over to vaguely punctate-reticulate; the two<tei:lb/>longitudinal keels ofAgathis (s.str.) virtually wanting. Areolet of fore-wing triangular, almost petiolate;<tei:lb/>stigma more elongate than that of other species of region ; radial cell very narrow ; radius sometimes slightly<tei:lb/>curved inwards towards stigma; distal abscissa of postmarginalis as long as proximal abscissa. Hind claw<tei:lb/>with somewhat short, dentiform lobe; outer side of middle tibia with 2-3 widely spaced teeth; inner spur of<tei:lb/>hind tibia falling far short of middle of basal segment of hind tarsus. Tergite 1 about 1-25 times longer than<tei:lb/>its apical width, polished, smooth. Ovipositor sheath 1-33-1-5 times longer than body. Hypopygium very<tei:lb/>shallowly, broadly emarginate at apex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf. Inner and outer orbits pale marked (2 ex., Turkey), otherwise generally black. Posterior half of<tei:lb/>gaster blackened. Antenna with 25-26 segments.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>France: 1 $, Carpentras (Teunissen) (RNH); 2 $, 1 cf, Landes, St Girons Plage, on Helychrysum<tei:lb/>stoechas L. (P. Pronk) (RNH). Germany: 3 $ , Ruthe Coll. (BMNH). Holland: 1 $ , Terschelling (RNH); 1<tei:lb/>$ , Texel De Koog, pine forest, 6.ix. 1969 (L. Oosterweghel) (RNH). Portugal: 1 $ , Algarve, Val do Lobo,<tei:lb/>vii. 1967 (P. M. F. Verhoeff) (RNH). Spain: 1 $ , Cadiz, Jerez de la Frontera, viii. 1967 (P. M. F. Verhoeff)<tei:lb/>(RNH). Turkey: 1 cf , Uludag, viii. 1962 (Guichard &amp; Harvey) (BMNH); 2 $ , 1 cf , Bursa, near Karacabey,<tei:lb/>viii.1962 (Guichard &amp; Harvey) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This species closely resembles umbellatarum in colour but the two species are very different.<tei:lb/>Whereas umbellatarum is a typical Agathis, syngenesiae is in some respects like species of Microdus. The<tei:lb/>form of the keel between the antennal insertions approaches the condition found in Microdus. So also does<tei:lb/>the strongly transverse head as seen from above. Nevertheless, the elongate head and the lengthened</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE EUROPEAN AGATHIDINAE 197</tei:p>
         <tei:p>mouth-parts relate syngenesiae more closely to Agathis. The form of the frons between the antennal<tei:lb/>insertions together with the short galea make the species easy to recognise.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis umbellatarum Nees von Esenbeck</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis umbellatarum Nees von Esenbeck, 1814: 195. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost).<tei:lb/>Agathis kolazyi Fischer, 1959: 2. Holotype cf , YUGOSLAVIA (ZM) [examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf 9 , 4-5-5-0 mm long (excluding ovipositor). In all material available the body is conspicuously marked<tei:lb/>with red. Head black. Mesoscutum, and at least side of pronotum, red. Gaster varying from entirely red to<tei:lb/>red with blackened apex. Wings strongly darkened.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9- Head in facial view moderately lengthened; from above, strongly transverse, not produced<tei:lb/>backwards behind eyes as in malvacearum (cf. Fig. 26). Ocelli in a low, rather wide triangle. A moderately<tei:lb/>well-defined keel between antennal insertions; in front of anterior ocellus a well-defined excavation that<tei:lb/>tends to jut forwards. Malar space a little shorter than longer diameter of the eye, 11:14. Galea<tei:lb/>considerably longer than malar space, 14 : 11. Antenna with 23-26 segments: 23 (1), 24(2), 25 (5), 26 (3);<tei:lb/>flagellum somewhat tapered towards apex. Thorax in profile decidedly elongate. Notaulices sharply<tei:lb/>defined. The two longitudinal keels of propodeum sharply defined; side panels polished, virtually smooth<tei:lb/>all over. Radial cell decidedly long; areolet varying from triangular to distinctly 4-sided; distal abscissa of<tei:lb/>postmarginalis hardly 0-66 times as long as proximal abscissa. Inner spur of hind tibia falling considerably<tei:lb/>short of middle of basal segment of hind tarsus; outer side of middle tibia with very variable number of<tei:lb/>teeth, 2-14; hind claw with well-defined lobe; cleft between lobe and claw proper fully half as long as claw<tei:lb/>itself. Tergite 1 a little longer than apically wide, smooth, highly polished. Ovipositor sheath very slightly<tei:lb/>longer than body.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Thorax sometimes entirely black; sometimes mesoscutum red. Antenna with 23-24 segments; two<tei:lb/>preapical segments about 1-33 times longer than wide.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bulgaria: 4 cf , 1 $, v.-vi. (Zaykov) (ZC). Cyprus: 21 cf , 5 $, iv.-vi. (G. Mavromoustakis) (BMNH).<tei:lb/>France: 2 $, Basses Alpes, Digne, vi. (Slob) (RNH). Greece: 1 $, Corfu, Acharavi, v. (Oogstrom)<tei:lb/>(RNH); 1 , Kerfissos, vi. (Mavromoustakis) (BMNH); 1 9, Drosla, vi. (Mavromoustakis} (BMNH); 1<tei:lb/>9, Ilia, vii. (Day &amp; Else) (BMNH); 1 9, 2 cf , Thessalia, Kalambaka, vii. (Day &amp; Else) (BMNH). Turkey:<tei:lb/>1 9, Ankara, Temelli, vii. (Guichard &amp; Harvey) (BMNH); 1 9, Nigde, Kocas, vi. (Guichard &amp; Harvey)<tei:lb/>(BMNH); 10 cf, Istanbul, Yakuplu, vi. (Oorshot &amp; Wiering) (RNH). Yugoslavia: 1 &lt;j&gt;, Macedonia,<tei:lb/>Gorica, x. (van Achterberg (RNH); 1 cf (holotype of kolazyi), Dalmatia, Ragusa (Kolazy) (ZM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This brightly coloured species has a Mediterranean distribution. It is very like the northern<tei:lb/>varipes Thomson and, beyond colour, there is very little to separate the two species. Both are characterised<tei:lb/>by the form of the ante-ocellar impression and the shape of the head in facial view. Thus seen, however, the<tei:lb/>face of varipes is slightly wider; varipes also has a shorter galea.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis breviseta Nees von Esenbeck</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 52)<tei:lb/>Agathis breviseta Nees von Esenbeck, 1814: 194. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The type of breviseta is presumably lost. My interpretation of the species is based on that of Wesmael, the<tei:lb/>first reviser; I have examined two females (IRSNB), both bearing Wesmael's identification label but with<tei:lb/>no indication of locality.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9, ca 3-5 mm long (excluding ovipositor). Black. Hind femur black; hind tibia blackish on apical<tei:lb/>three-fifths, with dark ring towards base.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head in facial view considerably elongate. Malar space shorter than longer diameter of eye, 5 : 7. Galea<tei:lb/>dull, coriaceous, twice as long as wide. Between antennal sockets a short, knife-edged keel that projects<tei:lb/>above as a right angle before joining lowest point of deep cavity in front of anterior ocellus; this cavity deep,<tei:lb/>narrow, V-shaped. Ocelli in high triangle, the posterior tangent of front ocellus passing far in front of<tei:lb/>posterior ocelli. Antenna distinctly tapering from middle to apex, weakly bristly and with the two preapical<tei:lb/>segments about 1-33 times longer than wide; 29-30 segmented. Thorax in profile short, high. Notaulices<tei:lb/>deeply impressed. Sternaulus strongly impressed, reaching both anterior and posterior corner of meso-<tei:lb/>pleurum. Lateral panels of propodeum polished. Fore- wing with areolet almost always distinctly 4-sided</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>198 G. E. J. NIXON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(17 ex.); rarely almost triangular (4 ex.); apical abscissa of postmarginalis slightly more than 0-5 times<tei:lb/>longer than proximal abscissa. Hind femur decidedly thick, 2-5 times longer than widest part; outer side of<tei:lb/>middle tibia with 6-7 teeth; inner spur of hind tibia just reaching middle of basal segment of hind tarsus;<tei:lb/>hind claw with well-developed, somewhat pointed lobe.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gaster rather short and broad; segment 1 markedly triangular, as long as wide apically , irregularly striate<tei:lb/>to striate-rugose all over. Ovipositor sheath short, not longer than gaster; bristle-like hairs of apical third of<tei:lb/>ovipositor sheath not, or hardly, different from those of middle third (Fig. 52).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Belgium: 2 $, Wesmael coll. (IRSNB). Bulgaria: 23 $, Sh. poljana, 6-22.V.1976 (Zaykov) (ZC). Great<tei:lb/>Britain: 2 $, England, Buckinghamshire, vi-vii. (Benson) (BMNH). Ireland: 1 $, Antrim, Loch Neagh,<tei:lb/>26.vi.1967 (Stelfox) (USNM); 1 cf , 1 $, Dublin, Glenasmole, 24.vi.1938 (Stelfox) (USNM).          <tei:p>HOST. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This species is fairly easy to recognise on the combination of short galea and unusually short<tei:lb/>ovipositor sheath. In his description Nees draws special attention to the latter feature.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis assimilis Kokujev</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 2, 19, 25)<tei:lb/>Agathis assimilis Kokujev, 1895: 387. Holotype $, U.S.S.R. (AS) [not examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tobias (1963: 878) examined the type of assimilis which, he says, is badly damaged, lacking wings, legs<tei:lb/>(except one hind leg) and antennal tips. Specimens determined by him as assimilis have been received on<tei:lb/>loan at BMNH; his interpretation of Kokujev's species is accordingly accepted.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$ . Closely related to breviseta on the structure of the frons (Fig. 19) and the shortness of the galea. It may<tei:lb/>be compared with that species as follows.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour similar. Head in facial view (Fig. 2); seen from above, slightly more transverse, less produced<tei:lb/>backwards behind eyes (Fig. 25); this is correlated with a slightly lower ocellar triangle. Antenna thinner,<tei:lb/>filiform; two apical segments relatively a little longer; 28-31-segmented; flagellum considerably more<tei:lb/>bristly. Sternaulus reaching posterior margin of mesopleurum but not anterior margin. Areolet of<tei:lb/>fore- wing variable to same degree; apical abscissa of postmarginalis slightly longer. Legs more slender;<tei:lb/>hind femur about 3 times longer than wide; segment 3 of hind tarsus relatively a little longer; outer side of<tei:lb/>middle tibia with 4-5 teeth, arranged more or less in row; inner spur of hind tibia slightly shorter, relative to<tei:lb/>length of basal segment of hind tarsus. Tergite 1 slightly narrower, more shiny because of reduction in<tei:lb/>strength of sculpture; this vaguely coriaceous, with some weak striation on basal half. Ovipositor sheath<tei:lb/>much longer, about equal to propodeum plus gaster; as in breviseta, the apical, bristle-like hairs of the<tei:lb/>sheath are not differentiated from the rest.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Bulgaria, Great Britain.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This species and breviseta evidently form a small species-group characterised by the curious<tei:lb/>formation of the inter-antennal keel, combined with the deep, narrow cavity in front of the anterior<tei:lb/>ocellus. The long, filiform antenna and the longer ovipositor readily distinguish assimilis from breviseta.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>One $ examined (Great Britain: Scotland, The Birks, Aberfeldy, 26.vii.1954 (Stelfox) (BMNH)) has<tei:lb/>the propodeum rugulose and dull almost all over.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis fulmeki Fischer</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 10, 35, 42, 51)<tei:lb/>Agathis fulmeki Fischer, 19576: 6. Holotype 9 AUSTRIA (NM) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$, ca 3-5 mm long (excluding ovipositor). Black. Apical four segments of maxillary palpus almost always<tei:lb/>yellowish and in contrast with black labial palpus. Hind femur black; hind tibia without, or virtually<tei:lb/>without, a dark basal ring.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head in facial view short, subtriangular (Fig. 10). Longer diameter of eye 2-5 times longer than malar<tei:lb/>space. Surface between antennal insertions raised and ridge-like where it joins depression in front of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE EUROPEAN AGATHIDINAE 199</tei:p>
         <tei:p>anterior ocellus; this depressed area V-shaped, not deep, slightly domed at middle. Galea smooth, shiny,<tei:lb/>2-5 times longer than wide; labial palpus unusually long (Fig. 51). Clypeus largely polished, bare. Antenna<tei:lb/>with 25-27 segments; two preapical segments of flagellum hardly longer than wide. Thorax in profile<tei:lb/>elongate (Fig. 42), about twice as long as wide. Mesoscutum strongly shining, not densely hairy and often<tei:lb/>with vague punctuation, mostly on middle lobe. Notaulices sharply defined but not deep, distinctly<tei:lb/>foveate. Sternaulus short, shallow, sometimes almost obliterated and not reaching either posterior or<tei:lb/>anterior margin of mesopleurum. Areolet of fore-wing triangular or almost so; distal abscissa of<tei:lb/>post-marginalis hardly shorter than proximal abscissa. Legs rather thick; outer side of middle tibia with 6-7<tei:lb/>teeth (Fig. 35) ; hind femur about 2-5 times longer than wide ; inner spur of hind tibia just reaching middle of<tei:lb/>basal segment of hind tarsus; hind claw with conspicuous lobe, large, strongly bent and with deep cleft<tei:lb/>between itself and claw proper. Tergite 1 slightly longer than wide at apex, shiny, with faint traces of<tei:lb/>rugosity and weak indication of striation laterally. Ovipositor sheath about as long as gaster plus<tei:lb/>propodeum; seen from above, hairs of distal, slightly widened part of sheath considerably shorter and less<tei:lb/>noticeable than those proximal to it.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Austria: 1 $ (holotype), Modling-Vorderbriihl (NM). Bulgaria: 48 $, Rhodopi, vi-vii. (Zaykov) (ZC;<tei:lb/>17$ in BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. A most distinctive species, recognisable on combination of narrow thorax, short head and<tei:lb/>teeth on outer side of middle tibia. It differs from breviseta and assimilis in that the galea is longer and the<tei:lb/>decoration of the frons, though basically similar, has no knife-like edge between the antennal insertions.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis rufipalpis Nees von Esenbeck</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 17, 36)<tei:lb/>Agathis rufipalpis Nees von Esenbeck, 1814: 192. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wesmael (1837: 24) was the first reviser of Nees von Esenbeck's species; I have based my interpretation of<tei:lb/>rufipalpis on specimens in Wesmael's collection bearing his handwritten identification label.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species is extremely likefulmeki, differing from it only in the following characters.<tei:lb/>$ . Four apical segments of maxillary palpus sometimes paler than labial palpus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head in facial view slightly more elongate (Fig. 17). Longer diameter of eye about 1-75 times longer than<tei:lb/>malar space. Clypeus hairy all over. Depression in front of anterior ocellus more narrowly V-shaped.<tei:lb/>Antenna with 24-28 segments. Thorax in profile slightly less elongate (Fig. 36). Sternaulus equally short<tei:lb/>and weak. Outer side of middle tibia with 7-9 similarly thick teeth; inner spur of hind tibia distinctly less<tei:lb/>than half as long as basal segment of hind tarsus. Tergite 1 more distinctly sculptured and with somewhat<tei:lb/>broken striation almost all over. Ovipositor sheath about as long as gaster plus thorax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Belgium: 5 $, Brussels (1 $ BMNH, rest IRSNB). Bulgaria: 10 $, Rhodopi, vi.-vii. (A. Zaykov) (ZC).<tei:lb/>Ireland: 1 cf, Wexford, Curracloe, vii. (BMNH). Sweden: 1 $, Solna, viii.1976 (T. Huddleston &amp;<tei:lb/>J. Quinlan) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This species is very much likefulmeki and the two should always be considered together. It<tei:lb/>differs from breviseta and assimilis by the same characters as those which separate these species from<tei:lb/>fulmeki.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis varipes Thomson</tei:p>

         <tei:p>than in related tibialis, 2-25-2-33 times longer than wide, not longer than malar space. Antenna with 23-26<tei:lb/>segments: 23(2), 24(5), 25(1), 26(1). There is some overlap in the<tei:lb/>number of antennal segments.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis anglica Marshall<tei:lb/>(Figs 18, 49)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis anglica Marshall, 1885: 265. Holotype $, GREAT BRITAIN (BMNH) [examined].<tei:lb/>Agathis albanica Fischer, I951b: 3. Holotype $, ALBANIA (NM) [examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf $ , 4-5-5-0 mm long (excluding ovipositor).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$ . Black. Hind femur entirely black; hind tibia yellowish on basal two-thirds, with dark basal band and<tei:lb/>blackened on apical two-fifths. Medius of fore-wing usually colourless throughout.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head in facial view markedly elongate and considerably narrowed below eyes (Fig. 18) ; seen from above<tei:lb/>with face just out of view strongly transverse. Hardly a trace of a keel between antennal sockets and with at<tei:lb/>most a weakly impressed dimple in front of anterior ocellus. Malar space almost equal to longer diameter of<tei:lb/>eye, 13 : 15. Galea about 3-5 times longer than wide and about 1-5 times longer than malar space. Antenna<tei:lb/>with 26-29 segments, slightly tapered towards apex and with segment 4 from apex about 1-25 times longer<tei:lb/>than wide. Thorax in profile somewhat short and high. Notaulices deeply impressed. Propodeum with the<tei:lb/>usual two longitudinal keels and with polished, lateral panels. Sternaulus well defined, reaching posterior<tei:lb/>corner of mesopleurum. Radial cell short, broad (Fig. 49); aerolet markedly, characteristically 4-sided;<tei:lb/>distal abscissa of postmarginalis very short, 1-25-1-33 times as long as proximal abscissa. Outer side of<tei:lb/>middle tibia with 3-5 teeth arranged in a row; hind claw with at most a weakly angled projection at base.<tei:lb/>Tergite. 1 rugose-striate all over. Tergites 2+3 with well-defined, transverse, basal, blister-like swelling;<tei:lb/>surface posterior to this swelling with a considerable amount of striation or rugose-striation. Ovipositor<tei:lb/>sheath nearly as long as body.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Like female except for sexual differences. In nine examples from Turkey there is considerable<tei:lb/>variation in the definition of the impression in front of the anterior ocellus; sometimes it is relatively<tei:lb/>distinct; sometimes virtually absent; in all these examples the areolet of the fore- wing is very obviously<tei:lb/>4-sided. Tergites 2+3 show much less rugosity than in the female and are sometimes virtually smooth.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Agathis f/Wa/JsNees von Esenbeck</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Agathis malvacearum Latreille</tei:p>

Like female in having tergites 2+3 brightly coloured; a single example from Corsica (BMNH) has the<tei:lb/>mesoscutum as brightly reddish as the base of the gaster but each of the three lobes is suffused with<tei:lb/>infuscation; a single male from Bulgaria, Rhodopi, (ZC) has the mesoscutum entirely reddish.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bulgaria: 1 9&gt; Rhodopi, Petelovo, vii (Zaykov) (ZC). France: 1 cf, Basses Alpes, Digne, vi. (Slob)<tei:lb/>(RNH); 2 cf , 2 $ , Bretagne, Pres'ile de Rhuys, Kerfontaine, 1976, on Malva sp. (Doesberg) (RNH); 1 cf ,<tei:lb/>Corsica, vii. (BMNH). Greece: 1 $, Drosia, 4.vi.l957 (Mavromoustakis) (BMNH); 1 $, Kerfissos,<tei:lb/>8.vi.l957 (Mavromoustakis) (BMNH); 1 $, Epidavros, vi. (Mound) (BMNH). Turkey: 1 $, Mersin,<tei:lb/>Servatul Gecidi (Guichard &amp; Harvey) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Pexicopia malvella (Hiibner) (Gelechiidae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Tobias (1964) emphasises the colour variability of this species on the basis of series bred from<tei:lb/>the Mallow moth in Armenia. He points out that autumnal specimens are darkest in colour while summer<tei:lb/>forms emerging in August and September are lighter with tergites 1-3 red and the hind femur also<tei:lb/>reddened. He also considers (1963: 876) that darker examples of malvacearum agree with the original<tei:lb/>description of tibialis Nees von Esenbeck as well as with the interpretation of this latter species accepted by<tei:lb/>earlier authors. He accordingly suggests that tibialis Nees von Esenbeck may be a synonym of malvacearum<tei:lb/>Latreille. But in the absence of formal synonymisation I prefer to use the name 'tibialis Nees von Esenbeck'<tei:lb/>for a species that agrees better with Nees von Esenbeck's original description than any variety of<tei:lb/>malvacearum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The bulging temples of malvacearum are its most characteristic feature and the head in consequence<tei:lb/>appears strongly produced backwards behind the eyes when seen from above.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis griseifrons Thomson<tei:lb/>(Fig. 44)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis griseifrons Thomson, 1895: 2227. LECTOTYPE $, SWEDEN: (ZI), here designated [examined].<tei:lb/>Agathis laticarpa Telenga, 1955: 255. Holotype $&gt;, U.S.S.R.: Ukraine, Chernogavskaya Oblast (AS) [not<tei:lb/>examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf $, 4-8-5-5 mm long (excluding ovipositor). Black. Legs predominantly reddish but colour variable;<tei:lb/>hind femur often entirely reddish but sometimes darkened on basal half, more rarely with infuscation<tei:lb/>extending along whole of upper surface; hind tibia often markedly yellowish, infuscate on about apical<tei:lb/>third, with a darkened basal ring.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9 Head in facial view obviously elongate. Malar space fully two-thirds as long as longer diameter of eye,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE EUROPEAN AGATHIDINAE 203</tei:p>
         <tei:p>11 : 15. Galea as long as malar space. Face densely clothed with greyish or pale brownish pubescence. No<tei:lb/>trace of a keel between antennal insertions and virtually no impression in front of anterior ocellus. Antenna<tei:lb/>with 31-33 segments: 31 (1), 32 (8), 33 (3); flagellum rather finely tapered towards apex. Thorax in profile<tei:lb/>short and of generalised appearance. Side of pronotum anterior to the oblique trough usually very coarsely<tei:lb/>rugose. Notaulices deeply impressed. Sternaulus strongly developed, reaching posterior corner of meso-<tei:lb/>pleurum. Areolet of fore-wing distinctly 4-sided; distal abscissa of postmarginalis about 0-33 as long as<tei:lb/>proximal abscissa. Hind claw with pale, dentiform lobe at base (Fig. 44); outer side of middle tibia with 1-3<tei:lb/>teeth arranged in a row. Gaster of ordinary form. Tergite 1 about as long as apically wide, striate-rugose all<tei:lb/>over. Frequently a certain amount of striation to side of, and apical to, transverse, blister-like, posterior<tei:lb/>swelling. Ovipositor sheath about as long as gaster plus thorax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Like female except for sexual differences. Antenna very long, tapered apically, 29-32-segmented;<tei:lb/>segment 8 from apex twice as long as wide. Usually more brightly coloured than female with apical four<tei:lb/>segments of maxillary palpus entirely yellowish. Tooth at base of hind claw often hardly developed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bulgaria: 1 $, Rhodopi, Gabrovo, viii. (Zaykov) (ZC). France: 1 cf, Beaune, ex Pyrausta aurata<tei:lb/>Scopoli on Mentha aquatica L. (BMNH); 1 $, Nantua, Marshall coll. (BMNH). (Lefebe)<tei:lb/>(RNH); 2 $ , Asperen, vi.-viii. (Zwakhals) (RNH). Ireland: 1 cf , 1 $ , Woodbrock, vi. (Stelfox) (USNM);</tei:p>

         <tei:p>HOST. Pyrausta aurata (Scopoli) (Pyralidae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. In one of the two females from Holland, Asperen, tergite 1 is almost smooth over most of the<tei:lb/>apical half, and the dark ring at the base of the hind tibia is joined to the infuscate area at the apex of the<tei:lb/>tibia by a broad band of infuscation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis griseifrons is largely characterised by the absence of a keel between the antennal insertions, the<tei:lb/>virtual absence of any impression in front of the anterior ocellus, the dense pubescence of the face and the<tei:lb/>usually predominantly red-marked hind femur. Having a rugose first tergite, it is at once different from<tei:lb/>the superficially similar tibialis and varipes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis nigra Nees von Esenbeck<tei:lb/>(Figs 11, 38, 45)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis nigra Nees von Esenbeck, 1814: 191. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis testaceipes Fischer, 19576: 8. Holotype $, AUSTRIA (NM) [examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wesmael (1837: 23) was the first reviser of Nees von Esenbeck's species; I have based my interpretation of<tei:lb/>nigra on specimens in Wesmael's collection bearing his handwritten identification label.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf $ , 4-5-4-8 mm (excluding ovipositor). Black, rarely tergites 2+3 reddish (1 9 , Yugoslavia). Hind femur<tei:lb/>reddish but flushed with infuscation on basal half; almost entirely reddish in 2 $ from Yugoslavia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Head in facial view not strongly elongate (Fig. 11). Malar space distinctly shorter than longer<tei:lb/>diameter of eye, 9: 13. A weak or vestigial keel between antennal insertions. A more or less distinct<tei:lb/>V-shaped impression in front of anterior ocellus. Mouth parts very long; when fully extruded distinctly<tei:lb/>longer than head; galea fully 4 times as long as wide, tapering to a fine point. Antenna 23-25-segmented: 23<tei:lb/>(4), 24(2), 25 (4); two preapical segments about 1-33 times longer than wide. Thorax in profile markedly<tei:lb/>elongate (Fig. 38). Mesoscutum having a black, shiny appearance owing to sparseness of pubescence.<tei:lb/>Notaulices varying much in definition but usually weakly defined, at least anteriorly; virtually absent in 1 $<tei:lb/>(Yugoslavia, Korab Mts); frequently obliterated in posterior half in other females. Sternaulus usually<tei:lb/>reaching posterior corner of mesopleurum, rarely fading out before this. Propodeum showing a slight<tei:lb/>peculiarity in that each lateral panel shows on its dorsal surface a broad, transverse band of very coarse<tei:lb/>rugosities. Areolet of fore-wing always very obviously triangular; in two females even with short stalk;<tei:lb/>distal abscissa of postmarginalis almost as long as proximal abscissa. Inner spur of hind tibia falling far short<tei:lb/>of middle of basal segment of hind tarsus ; outer side of middle tibia with 1-3 teeth arranged more or less in a<tei:lb/>row; in one female without teeth; hind claw with at most a small projection at base (Fig. 45). Gaster highly<tei:lb/>polished; tergite 1 virtually without trace of sculpture. Ovipositor sheath about as long as body.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>204 G. E. J. NIXON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf. Like female except for sexual differences. Antenna with 23-24 segments; flagellum very thin,<tei:lb/>thread-like, the two preapical segments almost twice as long as wide.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Austria: 1 $ (holotype oftestaceipes), Burgenland, Schiitzen, 10.vii.1941 (Fulmek) (NM). Belgium: 7 $,<tei:lb/>6 cf , viii. (Crevecoeur) (IRSNB); 1 cT, Brussels, Wesmael coll. (IRSNB). Germany: 1 $, Mecklenburg<tei:lb/>(Konow) (BMNH). Yugoslavia: 1 &lt;j&gt;, Korab Mts, Stirovica, viii. (Martina) (BMNH); 1 $, Nicpur, vii.<tei:lb/>(Martina] (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This is one of the more distinct species, largely characterised by the much lengthened galea,<tei:lb/>absence of lobe on hind claw and especially by the almost obliterated notaulices. The two other species with<tei:lb/>long galea included in this revision are taurica and zaykovi, but both can easily be separated from nigra.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A single female from Spain: Navarra, Peralta (Achterberg) (RNH) may possibly represent a further<tei:lb/>species. In all important respects it resembles nigra - short head and absence of lobe on hind claw - but the<tei:lb/>galea is longer, nearer to six times longer than basal width, and the notaulices are sharply defined. I have<tei:lb/>labelled this specimen as '? nigra Nees or sp. n.'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis zaykovi s$. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 7, 34, 47)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>O" $ , ca 4 mm (excluding ovipositor). Black. Hind femur black throughout.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Head in facial view considerably lengthened (Fig. 7). Malar space 0-66 times as long as longer<tei:lb/>diameter of eye. Between antennal insertions virtually no trace of a keel. A weak, vague V-shaped<tei:lb/>impression, sometimes almost obliterated, in front of anterior ocellus. Galea tapered towards apex but not<tei:lb/>so evenly as in nigra, about 3-5 times longer than its basal width (Fig. 34). Antenna with 26-27 segments; 26<tei:lb/>(8), 27 (4); apical 5-6 segments of flagellum somewhat tapered; two preapical segments hardly longer than<tei:lb/>wide. Thorax in profile somewhat elongate but less so than in nigra (cf . Fig. 38). Notaulices costate, deeply<tei:lb/>impressed throughout. Sternaulus strongly defined, costate throughout and reaching posterior corner of<tei:lb/>mesopleurum. Areolet of fore- wing usually slightly narrowed above but always distinctly 4-sided; distal<tei:lb/>abscissa of postmarginalis hardly shorter than proximal abscissa. Hind claw with large lobe (Fig. 47) ; outer<tei:lb/>side of middle tibia with 6-9 teeth, some of then paired, and forming an irregular row; inner spur of hind<tei:lb/>tibia not quite reaching middle of basal segment of hind tarsus. Gaster of generalised form and broader<tei:lb/>than in nigra (Fig. 40). Tergite 1 with vague traces of rugosity across brow, lacking the highly polished<tei:lb/>appearance of nigra. Ovipositor sheath as long as gaster plus thorax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Antenna almost as long as that of nigra from which it is distinguished by the structure of the claws.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Bulgaria: Rhodopi, Theigovsharu, 9.viii.l979 (A. Zaykov) (ZC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. 12 $ , same data (ZC; 4 in BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Non-paratypic material Bulgaria: 3 cf , Rhodopi, Theigovsharu, 9. viii. 1979; 3 cf , Stointe, 4. viii. 1978 (A.<tei:lb/>Zaykov) (ZC). Greece: 6 $, 8 cf , Macedonia, Korab Mts, Stirovica, 27. vii. -3. viii. (V. Martina) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. The length of the galea together with the relatively large number of teeth on the outer side of<tei:lb/>the middle tibia make zaykovi distinct from all other included species that have a generalised gastral shape.<tei:lb/>The strongly lobed claws at once separate it from nigra to which it may not be closely related in spite of the<tei:lb/>lengthened galea.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis taurica Telenga<tei:lb/>Agathis taurica Telenga, 1955: 260. Lectotype $, U.S.S.R. (AS) designated by Tobias [not examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>My interpretation of this species is based on a paralectotype cf received on loan from AS. I have been<tei:lb/>unable to discover where, or indeed whether, the lectotype designation was published.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$, 5 mm (excluding ovipositor). Like zaykovi in having hind claw with strong lobe though this is slightly<tei:lb/>less well developed than in zaykovi; taurica may be compared with zaykovi as follows.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Antenna with 25 segments (Telenga gives 24 segments for the female). Head in facial view like zaykovi<tei:lb/>(cf. Fig. 7). Mouth-parts longer; galea tapering to fine point, six times as long as basally wide. Head from<tei:lb/>above slightly less transverse and less emarginate behind. Thorax in profile slightly less elongate.</tei:p>

      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE EUROPEAN AGATHIDINAE 205</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Notaulices deeply impressed but smooth throughout. Virtually no trace of a sternaulus. Areolet of<tei:lb/>fore-wing distinctly 4-sided but slightly narrower; distal abscissa of postmarginalis slightly shorter in<tei:lb/>relation to proximal abscissa. Outer side of middle tibia with broad band of close, densely placed teeth,<tei:lb/>about 23 (only 1 ex.!); inner spur of hind tibia about 0-33 times as long as basal segment of hind tarsus.<tei:lb/>Gaster a little longer and narrower. Tergite 1 a little longer than its apical width, shining and with vague<tei:lb/>traces of sculpture across brow. Ovipositor sheath about as long as gaster plus thorax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Turkey: 1 $, Amasya, 1400 ft, 6.vi.l959 (Guichard) (BMNH). U.S.S.R.: 1 cf (paralectotype), Tauria,<tei:lb/>Simferopol (Pliginskij) (AS).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. As far as is known this species is not part of the main European fauna and has an eastern<tei:lb/>Mediterranean distribution. Among the species under review it is the third with greatly lengthened<tei:lb/>mouth-parts. It is distinct from the other two species - nigra and zaykovi- with much lengthened galea (and<tei:lb/>indeed from all other included species) on the dense band of teeth on the outer side of the middle tibia.<tei:lb/>Telenga (1955) records taurica from Simferapol and Sevastopol; Tobias (1976) records it from the Crimea<tei:lb/>and Armenia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis semiaciculata Ivanov</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 13, 43)<tei:lb/>Agathis semiaciculata Ivanov, 1899: 364. Syntypes, U.S.S.R. (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf $,4-5-5-5 mm (excluding ovipositor). Black. Hind femur black throughout; middle and front femora<tei:lb/>blackish on at least basal half.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9 . Head in facial view only moderately elongate (Fig. 13). Malar space very slightly shorter than longer<tei:lb/>diameter of eye, 13 : 15. Galea rather short, distinctly shorter than malar space, slightly more than 2-5 times<tei:lb/>longer than wide. Antenna thin, of even thickness throughout, 26-28-segmented: 26(2), 27 (1), 28 (1).<tei:lb/>Face almost as thickly pubescent as in griseifrons and in two out of four females with distinct traces of<tei:lb/>striate-punctation. Virtually no keel between antennal insertions and no depression in front of anterior<tei:lb/>ocellus. Thorax in profile of generalised shape. Notaulices deeply impressed. Side of pronotum anterior to<tei:lb/>oblique trough as coarsely rugose as in griseifrons. Sternaulus strongly developed, reaching posterior<tei:lb/>corner of mesopleurum. Areolet of fore- wing a little narrowed above but distinctly 4-sided; distal abscissa<tei:lb/>of postmarginalis hardly half as long as proximal abscissa. Propodeum with the usual, two longitudinal<tei:lb/>keels, sometimes obscured by surrounding rugosities. Outer side of middle tibia with 1-2 teeth, difficult to<tei:lb/>see because of infuscation of tibia; hind claw with small tooth at base but no deep cleft between it and claw<tei:lb/>proper (Fig. 43); hind claws longer and more powerfully built than in griseifrons; inner spur of hind tibia<tei:lb/>well developed, two-fifths as long as basal segment of hind tarsus. Tergite 1 hardly longer than its apical<tei:lb/>width, closely, evenly striate all over; striation tending to be broken and confused at middle of segment.<tei:lb/>Basal half of tergites 2+3 closely striate all over, the striation tending to be concentric around basal,<tei:lb/>transverse swelling.          <tei:p>Cf . Like female except for sexual characters.          <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Italy: 1 $ , Bolzano, Seiser-Alm., 1900m, 24.vi.1976 (Zwakhals) (RNH). Switzerland: 2 cf , 3 $ , Arolla,<tei:lb/>7000-8000 ft, 29-30.vi.1935 (Benson) (BMNH); 1 9, Valais, Les Hauderes, vi.1935 (Benson) (BMNH); 1<tei:lb/>Cf , 1 $, Miistairtal, 2400ft, vi.-vii.1960 (Benson) (BMNH); 1 cf , 1 $, Saas-Fee, 7000-8000 ft, 25.vi.1962<tei:lb/>(Benson) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This species has a fairly close affinity with griseifrons from which it can at once be separated on<tei:lb/>the sculpture of the gaster. On the basis of the available material, it seems to be an alpine species.<tei:lb/>According to Telenga (1955) it is wide-spread in south-western regions of the U.S.S.R. with a range<tei:lb/>extending to northern Mongolia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>No other species in this revision has such extensive sculpture on tergites 2+3 though there is sometimes a<tei:lb/>weak approach to this condition in anglica. The head in facial view is hardly different from that of<tei:lb/>griseifrons though slightly wider towards the mouth; also, griseifrons has a distinctly tapered flagellum.</tei:p>

      </tei:div>

         <tei:p>Agathis polita sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 8, 23)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$ , 4-5 mm (excluding ovipositor) . Black with no trace of paler colouring on gaster . Wings almost hyaline .<tei:lb/>Head in facial view markedly elongate and considerably constricted beneath eyes (Fig. 8); seen from<tei:lb/>above, considerably prolonged backwards behind eyes (Fig. 23). A sharp keel between antennal insertions<tei:lb/>unites above with a fairly distinct, V-shaped cavity in front of anterior ocellus. Antenna long, thin with<tei:lb/>26-27 segments. Galea rather broad, not tapered to apex and distinctly a little longer than malar space,<tei:lb/>5:4, and 2-5 times longer than wide. Thorax in profile markedly elongate. Notaulices at first sight wanting,<tei:lb/>indicated by barely visible, linear impressions. Sternaulus represented by short, hardly impressed line.<tei:lb/>Propodeum appearing highly polished, its twin keels virtually obliterated. Areolet of forewing triangular in<tei:lb/>holotype, distinctly 4-sided in paratype; distal abscissa of postmarginalis hardly shorter than proximal<tei:lb/>abscissa. Outer side of middle tibia with 8-9 irregularly spaced teeth; inner spur of hind tibia much less than<tei:lb/>half as long as basal segment of hind tarsus; hind claw with prominent lobe. Gaster decidedly narrow.<tei:lb/>Tergite 1 about 1-33 times longer than apically wide, smooth, polished. Ovipositor sheath a little shorter<tei:lb/>than head plus thorax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Jordan: Zerkatal, b. Romana, 200m, ll.iv.1959 (J. Klapperich) (HNHM).<tei:lb/>Paratype. 1 $, same data (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This is an extra-limital species and strictly has no place in this revision. It is included, however,<tei:lb/>because being virtually without notaulices it allows the following species, persephone, to be defined with<tei:lb/>more accuracy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis persephone sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf 9, 5-5-6-0 mm (excluding ovipositor). Black with no hint of paler colouring on gaster. Hind femur<tei:lb/>black.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9- Head in facial view short, subtriangular; from above, hardly distinguishable from that of polita (cf.<tei:lb/>Fig. 23). Keel between antennal insertions weak to almost absent. In front of anterior ocellus a fairly<tei:lb/>well-defined, somewhat projecting, V-shaped cavity. Galea rather short, twice as long as wide, hardly as<tei:lb/>long as malar space, 10: 11. Mesoscutum without trace of notaulices.<tei:lb/>Mesopleurum with very short, weak sternaulus, separated from posterior corner of mesopleurum by fully<tei:lb/>its own length.          <tei:p>Cf . Like female but head, seen from above, slightly more produced backwards behind eyes. Antenna<tei:lb/>26-27-segmented. Sternaulus absent in one example, hardly indicated in the other. Areolet of fore-wing<tei:lb/>triangular.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, France: Aspin, 680 m, 5.vii.l951 (H. Teunissen) (RNH).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>HOST. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This species is distinct because it lacks notaulices. The short head, in facial view, together with<tei:lb/>the ornamentation of the frons, suggests a probable relationship with varipes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis ariadne sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 1)<tei:lb/>Cf $, co 4-5 mm (excluding ovipositor). Black. Gaster with no trace of red colour on tergites 2+3.</tei:p>
