      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE EUROPEAN AGATHIDINAE 207</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles deep yellow; in the single female (holotype) labrum also deep yellow. Except for weak, basal<tei:lb/>infuscation, hind femur bright reddish yellow in holotype and two out of three males.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Head in facial view moderately elongate, wide across clypeus (Fig. 1), appearing very black and<tei:lb/>shiny, especially across clypeus owing to sparsity of pubescence. A well-defined keel between antennal<tei:lb/>insertions and a fairly deep, V-shaped impression in front of anterior ocellus. Galea about 3 times as long as<tei:lb/>its basal width and 1-5 times longer than malar space. Antenna thin, rather short, not tapering towards<tei:lb/>apex, 26-segmented. Thorax in profile somewhat elongate. Notaulices well defined. Sternaulus short,<tei:lb/>deep, not reaching posterior corner of mesopleurum. Side panels of propodeum polished except towards<tei:lb/>antero-lateral corner. Areolet of fore-wing almost triangular; distal abscissa of postmarginalis about 0-5<tei:lb/>times as long as proximal abscissa; radial cell rather long, much as in varipes (cf. Fig. 50). Outer side of<tei:lb/>middle tibia with 5 teeth arranged more or less in row; inner spur of hind tibia reaching virtually middle of<tei:lb/>basal segment of hind tarsus; hind claw with strong lobe. Gaster of generalised form. Tergite 1 only slightly<tei:lb/>longer than its apical width and with only a very weak indication of sculpture. Ovipositor sheath about as<tei:lb/>long as gaster plus propodeum; hairs of sheath very bristly, those in apical fifth hardly different from those<tei:lb/>proximal to it.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>d". Like female except for sexual differences. Antenna with 23-24 segments, long, rather thin. In one<tei:lb/>male, tergite 6 is fully extruded and shows at base a specialised area (? sex gland), from which arise two<tei:lb/>pencils of hairs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Czechoslovakia: Szlovak, Erchs, Selmecbanya, 600 m, 22.vii.1976 (/. Papp) (HNHM).<tei:lb/>Paratypes. 3 cf , same data (HNHM, one in BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This species certainly has some affinity with varipes but differs in the ornamentation of the<tei:lb/>frons and in having face much widened below. The virtually undifferentiated bristles towards the apex of<tei:lb/>the ovipositor sheath provide an additional, useful character for the recognition of ariadne.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The existence of what could be a sex gland at the base of the 6th tergite in the male needs to be<tei:lb/>investigated in detail; no similar structure is apparent in any of the males of varipes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathisanchisiadessp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 6, 22)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$, ca 4-5 mm long (excluding ovipositor). Black. Gaster with no hint of paler colouring on tergites 2+3.<tei:lb/>Hind femur blackish with a small suffusion of paler colouring at extreme apex; hind tibia obscurely reddish<tei:lb/>yellow, infuscate in apical two-fifths and virtually with no trace of a darkened prebasal ring.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head in facial view characteristically elongate (Fig. 6); from above rather strongly produced backwards<tei:lb/>behind the rather large eyes (Fig. 22). A sharp keel between antennal insertions and a distinct, narrow,<tei:lb/>V-shaped cavity in front of anterior ocellus. Antenna long, tapering, 29-segmented. Galea a little shorter<tei:lb/>than malar space, slightly more than 2-5 times longer than wide. Malar space two-thirds as long as longer<tei:lb/>diameter of eye. Thorax in profile rather short, of generalised form. Notaulices well defined but not sharply<tei:lb/>costate. Sternaulus sharply defined, reaching posterior corner of mesopleurum. Dorsal surface of side<tei:lb/>panels of propodeum showing much intricate rugosity. Areolet of fore- wing almost triangular; distal<tei:lb/>abscissa of postmarginalis almost as long as proximal abscissa. Segments 3-4 of middle tarsus very short, 4<tei:lb/>being not longer than wide; segment 4 of hind tarsus about 1-33 times longer than wide; inner spur of hind<tei:lb/>tibia reaching middle of basal segment of hind tarsus; this spur is margined with a particularly distinct row<tei:lb/>of short bristles on its inner side; hind claw with strong lobe and deep cleft between lobe and claw proper;<tei:lb/>outer side of middle tibia with 7 thick teeth, very irregularly spaced. Gaster of generalised form. Tergite 1<tei:lb/>about as long as its apical width, markedly triangular, striate all over. Ovipositor sheath about as long as<tei:lb/>propodeum plus gaster and, seen from above, as bristly at apex as at middle.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Holotype $, Hungary: Hortobargy, Zam, 2-23.V.1975 (Kaszab) (HNHM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. A. anchisiades is remarkable for the shortness of certain tarsal segments; because of this<tei:lb/>feature it is distinct from all the other species included in this revision, with the exception ofachterbergi. It<tei:lb/>is also to some extent characterised by the appearance of the head in facial view and also by the bristly apex<tei:lb/>of the ovipositor sheaths.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>208 G. E. J. NIXON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis achterbergi sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 14)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$ , ca 4-5 mm long (excluding ovipositor). Black. Hind femur entirely black; hind tibia obscurely yellowish<tei:lb/>on apical half but with heavily blackened apex; a distinct prebasal, infuscate band present. Wings brownish<tei:lb/>but less so than in the related anchisiades.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head in facial view only moderately elongate (Fig. 14). Malar space about 0-66 times as long as longer<tei:lb/>diameter of eye. Galea short, slightly less than twice as long as wide, dull, coriaceous. Between antennal<tei:lb/>insertions a rather sharp keel that is sharply angled before it extends upwards, on a lower level, and unites<tei:lb/>with a deep, narrowly V-shaped cavity in front of anterior ocellus. Antenna long, thin, tapering towards<tei:lb/>apex, 31-segmented; flagellum distinctly more bristly than in anchisiades; segment 4 from apex about 1-66<tei:lb/>times longer than wide. Thorax in profile like that of anchisiades . Notaulices deeply impressed. Sternaulus<tei:lb/>reaching posterior corner of mesopleurum. Side of pronotum anterior to oblique trough coarsely<tei:lb/>rugose-reticulate, especially on upper half. The two longitudinal keels of propodeum obscured by<tei:lb/>longitudinal rugosities; side panels in greater part smooth, polished. Areolet of fore- wing markedly<tei:lb/>4-sided; radial cell rather long; distal abscissa of postmarginalis fully 0-75 times as long as proximal<tei:lb/>abscissa. Middle tarsus short, segment 4 hardly longer than wide; outer side of middle tibia with 5 rather<tei:lb/>weak teeth arranged more or less in a row ; inner spur of hind tibia reaching middle of basal segment of hind<tei:lb/>tarsus; hind claw with strong, pointed lobe. Gaster of generalised form. Tergite 1 about as long as apically<tei:lb/>wide, rugulose but becoming smooth across apical quarter; rest of gaster highly polished. Ovipositor<tei:lb/>sheath hardly longer than gaster, bristly at apex as in anchisiades; ovipositor itself straight, rather thick.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Holotype $, Holland: Waarder (Z-H), Oostende, 18.V.1970 (C. van Achterberg) (RNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This species, as noted under anchisiades, is characterised by the shortness of the middle tarsus.<tei:lb/>The two species are in fact remarkably alike but the difference in the shape of the head in a facial view and<tei:lb/>in the length of the galea is too strong to fall within the range of specific variation. It is probable that<tei:lb/>anchisiades and achterbergi are representatives of a species-group which is characterised essentially by the<tei:lb/>shortness of the middle tarsus and the strong lobe of the hind claw.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis minute Niezabitowski</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 29)<tei:lb/>Agathis minuta Niezabitowski, 1910: 81. Syntypes, POLAND (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf $, 2-5-3-0 mm long (excluding ovipositor). Black. Hind femur infuscate more or less throughout,<tei:lb/>sometimes flushed with paler colouring towards apex; hind tibia pale brownish to pale brownish yellow but<tei:lb/>paler parts of legs dingy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Head in facial view hardly lengthened, subtriangular (Fig. 29). Malar space very short, slightly less<tei:lb/>than half longer diameter of eye, 5:11. Mouth-parts very short; galea hardly longer than wide; preapical<tei:lb/>segment of labial palpus hardly twice as long as wide. A keel present between antennal insertions and<tei:lb/>almost always a rather well-defined V-shaped impression in front of anterior ocellus. Antenna with 23-25<tei:lb/>segments. Thorax of generalised form, much like that of glabricula as seen in profile (cf. Fig. 41).<tei:lb/>Notaulices sharply defined. Sternaulus very short, isolated, not reaching posterior corner of mesopleurum.<tei:lb/>Propodeum tending to be rugose all over, the two medial, longitudinal keels sometimes obscured by<tei:lb/>rugosities. Areolet of fore- wing usually sharply triangular; radial cell rather small, distal abscissa of<tei:lb/>postmarginalis fully 0-66 times as long as proximal abscissa. Hind claw without a lobe; inner spur of hind<tei:lb/>tibia not reaching middle of basal segment of hind tarsus; outer side of middle tibia with 4-5 teeth arranged<tei:lb/>in a row (difficult to see because of infuscation of tibia). Gaster rather short and broad. Tergite 1 about as<tei:lb/>long as wide at apex and vaguely striate to rugose-striate all over. Tergites 2+3 with the usual, transverse,<tei:lb/>blisterrlike swelling at base and sometimes with traces of rugosity to sides of, and apical to, this swelling.<tei:lb/>Ovipositor sheath about as long as body but markedly variable in length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Like female in all essential details. Antenna thin, the preapical segment about twice as long as wide.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>42 Cf , 84 $, Germany, Great Britain, Ireland, Sweden.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE EUROPEAN AGATHIDINAE 209</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Coleophora glaucicolella Wood (Coleophoridae) on Juncus inflexus L. (England: Worcester, nr<tei:lb/>Redditch, 3 $, 1 C? (BMNH)).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This is the most commonly represented species in all the collections examined and is widely<tei:lb/>distributed. Easy to recognise on three main features: the shape of the head in facial view, the shortness of<tei:lb/>the galea and the long distal abscissa of the postmarginalis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis asteris Fischer</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 31, 37)<tei:lb/>Agathis asteris Fischer, 1966: 185. Holotype $, AUSTRIA (NM) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C? $, 2-8-3-5 mm long (excluding ovipositor). Black. Hind femur blackish or at least considerably<tei:lb/>infuscate; general leg-colour much as in minuta.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Head in facial view not much lengthened (Fig. 31). Malar space a little longer than half longer<tei:lb/>diameter of eye, 1:12. Mouth-parts much lengthened in comparison with minuta; galea about 1-5 times<tei:lb/>longer than malar space. Almost no keel between antennal insertions and virtually no impression in front<tei:lb/>of anterior ocellus. Head in dorsal view rather deeply hollowed out behind to receive the somewhat<tei:lb/>strongly narrowed, anterior part of thorax. Antenna with 21-23 segments (2 ex.); flagellum distinctly<tei:lb/>thickened beyond middle; segments at this thickened part varying from being almost square in outline to<tei:lb/>1-25 times longer than wide. Thorax markedly elongate (Fig. 37); in profile almost twice as long as wide; in<tei:lb/>dorsal view considerably narrowed in front, much more so than in minuta. Sternaulus long, groove-like,<tei:lb/>sometimes almost absent. Propodeum with some sort of rugosity almost everywhere. Areolet of fore-wing<tei:lb/>distinctly 4-sided, narrowed above; distal abscissa of postmarginalis virtually absent. Hind claw without<tei:lb/>lobe; outer side of middle tibia with 3-5 teeth, difficult to see in two out of three females because tibia in<tei:lb/>greater part infuscate; hind spurs rather weak; inner one not reaching middle of basal segment of hind<tei:lb/>tarsus. Tergite 1 slightly longer than wide, striate-rugose all over. Basal half of tergites 2+3 without<tei:lb/>rugosity in the three females available. Ovipositor sheath about twice as long as gaster, distinctly a little<tei:lb/>widened at extreme apex; hairs on outer side of expanded part distinctly shorter and less obvious than those<tei:lb/>proximal to it.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C?. Like female. Antenna with 23 segments, thread-like; preapical segment twice as long as wide.<tei:lb/>Sternaulus virtually absent in the single example.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Austria: 1 $ (holotype), Burgenland, Zitzmanns-dorfer Wiesen (Kasy) (NM); 3 $, 1 cf, Illmitz,<tei:lb/>Einsetzlacke, 7.ix.l971, ex Coleophora halophyella Zimmerman (Jackh) (EH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Coleophora halophyella Zimmerman (Coleophoridae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This species is largely characterised by the long mouth-parts (cf. minuta, also a parasite of<tei:lb/>Coleophoridae), undecorated frons, elongate thorax and very short distal abscissa of the postmarginalis.<tei:lb/>Of the three last-mentioned characters it is mainly the elongate thorax that separates asteris from the<tei:lb/>glabricula-complex with its much more generalised thoracic form.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis glabricula Thomson</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 28, 41, 46)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis glabricula Thomson, 1895: 2228. LECTOTYPE $, SWEDEN (ZI), here designated [examined].<tei:lb/>Agathis albicostellae Fischer, 1966: 399. Holotype $, AUSTRIA (NM) [examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf $ , 3-0-3-2 mm long (excluding ovipositor).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Black. Hind femur black; hind tibia blackish on apical third with rather conspicuous, blackish, basal<tei:lb/>ring.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head in facial view rather sharply narrowed below eyes (Fig. 28), strongly transverse in dorsal view.<tei:lb/>Virtually no trace of a keel between antennal insertions, and at most a shallow dimple in front of anterior<tei:lb/>ocellus. Malar space about 0-66 times as long as longer diameter of eye, 7 : 12. Galea 2-0-2-5 times longer<tei:lb/>than wide, about as long as malar space or sometimes a little shorter. Antenna with 25-28 segments;<tei:lb/>flagellum decidedly thin with the three preapical segments considerably longer than wide. Thorax in profile<tei:lb/>of generalised form (Fig. 41). Notaulices deeply impressed. Sternaulus deeply impressed, reaching<tei:lb/>posterior corner of mesopleurum . Sculpture of propodeum variable ; sometimes the normally polished side<tei:lb/>panels (as in lectotype) covered with an intricately rugose sculpture. Areolet of fore- wing variable; mostly</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>210 G. E. J. NIXON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4-sided, more rarely triangular; radial cell short; distal abscissa of postmarginalis hardly 0-33 times as long<tei:lb/>as proximal abscissa; proximal abscissa sometimes distinctly thickened. Outer side of middle tibia with 2-3<tei:lb/>teeth; inner spur of hind tibia not quite reaching middle of basal segment of hind tarsus; hind tarsal claw<tei:lb/>mostly without trace of free lobe but sometimes distal end of weak, basal thickening produced to form a<tei:lb/>slight angulation or tooth (as in lectotype, Fig. 46). Tergite 1 about as long as apically wide, sculptured all<tei:lb/>over, the sculpture varying between even striation and rugose-striation. Basal half of tergites 2+3 with<tei:lb/>transverse, blister-like swelling and apical to this with a variable amount of broken, rugose-striation.<tei:lb/>Ovipositor sheath 1-33-1-50 times longer than gaster.<tei:lb/>Cf . Like female except for sexual differences.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Austria: 1 $ (holotype), Braunsborg bei Hainburg, ex Coleophora albicostella Duponchel (NM).<tei:lb/>Bulgaria: 2 &lt;j&gt;, Rhodopi, Costinbrod, vi. (Zaykov) (ZC); 2 $, Valtshe, vii. (Zaykov) (ZC); 1 $, Plovdiv,<tei:lb/>ix. (Zaykov) (ZC). Great Britain: 3 9, 7 cf, Dorset, Portland Bill, bred viii.1959 ex Coleophora<tei:lb/>troglodytella Duponchel, collected v.1959 (Ford) (BMNH). Ireland: 3 9, 1 d", Co. Clare, The Burren, ex<tei:lb/>Coleophora troglodytella Duponchel (Bradley) (BMNH). Sweden: 1 cf (lectotype), Skane, Ilstorp<tei:lb/>(Thomson) (ZI).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Coleophora troglodytella (Duponchel) (Coleophoridae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Fischer (I951a: 11) examined the syntypes of glabricula and labelled one of them 'Agathis<tei:lb/>glabricula Th.Type' but did not publish the designation; this specimen is here designated lectotype and is<tei:lb/>labelled accordingly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species and the two that follow present a difficult taxonomic problem and only a provisional solution<tei:lb/>is suggested. In certain respects, such as length of ovipositor and perhaps also of galea, the three species<tei:lb/>appear to overlap. They may be forms of a single species whose variation in structure could be due to the<tei:lb/>effect of extrinsic factors. However, since names exist for the three segregates, they are kept separate until<tei:lb/>more material or biological information becomes available.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis meridionellae Fischer</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 27)<tei:lb/>Agathis meridionellae Fischer, 1957&amp;: 1. Holotype $, AUSTRIA: Karawanken (ZSBS) [not examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9 This segregate differs from glabricula only in the following details.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Galea a little shorter. Head in facial view triangular, less narrowed below eyes (Fig. 27). In two females<tei:lb/>(paratypes), ovipositor sheath clearly longer than gaster; in five females from England, Worcester City, it<tei:lb/>is hardly longer, and in one the propodeum is rugose all over, as in some of the females of glabricula<tei:lb/>recorded from England, Portland Bill. The specimens from Sweden have the ovipositor sheath hardly<tei:lb/>longer than the gaster.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Austria: 2 $ , 1 d" (paratypes), Karawanken, Loibtal, ex Coleophora meridionella Klimesch (EH). Great<tei:lb/>Britain: 5 $, Worcester, ex Chrysoesthia hermannella F. (BMNH). Sweden: 17 $, 7 cf, Lund, ex<tei:lb/>Chrysoesthia (Microsetia on label) sexguttella (Thunberg) (ZI, 2 cf , 6 $, in BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Coleophora meridionella Klimesch (Coleophoridae). Chrysoesthia sexguttella (Thunberg); Chry-<tei:lb/>soesthia hermannella (F.) (Gelechiidae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis artemesiana Fischer</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 24)<tei:lb/>Agathis artemesiana Fischer, 1966: 397. Holotype $, AUSTRIA (NM) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species, which may belong to the glabricula-aggregate, differs from glabricula and meridionellae as<tei:lb/>follows.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$ , ca 3-5 mm long (excluding ovipositor); slightly larger than the other two species. Wings slightly more<tei:lb/>darkened. Head in facial view slightly more elongate than in meridionellae, more like that of glabricula (cf.<tei:lb/>fig. 28); in dorsal view (Fig. 24). Flagellum distinctly thickened distal to middle, the thickest segments<tei:lb/>being no more than 1-25 times longer than wide; antenna 24-26-segmented. Areolet triangular or almost<tei:lb/>so. Ovipositor sheath apparently always short, about as long as gaster.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>HOST. Coleophora granulatella Zeller (Coleophoridae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. What characterises this species, if indeed it is distinct, is the shape of the middle segments of the<tei:lb/>flagellum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis pedias sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 15, 39)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$, 4-5-4-8 mm (excluding ovipositor). Black. Hind tibia pale yellowish, almost whitish, with dark basal<tei:lb/>ring and apical infuscation occupying about apical two-fifths. Wings pale compared with other species,<tei:lb/>almost hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head in facial view weakly elongate (Fig. 15). Virtually no keel between antennal insertions and only a<tei:lb/>very feeble impression in front of anterior ocellus. Malar space about 0-66 times as long as longer diameter<tei:lb/>of eye. Mouth-parts rather short; galea as long as malar space, markedly coriaceous. Antenna with 24-25<tei:lb/>segments. Thorax decidedly lengthened, twice as long as wide in profile; hardly different from that of<tei:lb/>fulmeki (cf. Fig. 42). Sternaulus fairly sharply defined but remote from both anterior and posterior margin<tei:lb/>of mesopleurum. Panels of propodeum not extensively polished, sometimes almost obscured by en-<tei:lb/>croaching lateral rugosities. Outer side of middle tibia with 8-10 teeth arranged in a row, some of them<tei:lb/>paired; inner spur of hind tibia hardly more than 0-33 times as long as basal segment of hind tarsus; legs<tei:lb/>long, slender; 3rd segment of hind tarsus very slightly longer than apical segment; hind claw with weak,<tei:lb/>angular pro j ection at base . Areolet of f orewing almost 4-sided ; distal abscissa of postmarginalis about 75<tei:lb/>times as long as proximal abscissa. Gaster somewhat long, narrow (Fig. 39); tergite 1 about 1-33 times<tei:lb/>longer than apically wide, rugose-striate all over. Ovipositor sheath as long as body.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Spain: Cadiz, Villamartin, ll.vi.1960 (RNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Spain: 2 $, same data as holotype (RNH, BMNH); 1 $, Alicante, Puerto de Confrides,<tei:lb/>(H. Teunissen) (RNH). Portugal: 1 9 , Caldes da Rainha, 14.V.1958 (RNH); 2 9 , Trajouce, San Domingos<tei:lb/>de Rana, 15.V.1958 (RNH). Greece: 1 $, Athens, Imittos, 26.iv.1980 (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. The relatively large number of teeth on the outer side of the middle tibia suggests that pedias<tei:lb/>has an affinity with fulmeki, but the latter has shorter legs, a much more clearly defined impression in front<tei:lb/>of the anterior ocellus and a longer galea. A decidedly slender habitus is somewhat characteristic of pedias.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis rostrata Tobias<tei:lb/>Agathis rostrata Tobias, 1963: 881. Holotype $, U.S.S.R. (AS) [not examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>My interpretation of this species is based on an examination of a single female determined by Tobias. This<tei:lb/>specimen bears the label 'W. Russland, Jurburg (Winogradoff- Nikitin)' and is probably that which Tobias<tei:lb/>records from Lithuania, Jurbakas, in his original description. Although the data agree, Tobias does not<tei:lb/>indicate that it is a paratype, merely labelling it as 'Agathis rostrata sp. n., Tobias det.'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9, 3-5-4-0 mm long (excluding ovipositor). Similar to anglica with which it may be compared as follows.<tei:lb/>On the whole darker in colour (this may have little significance) .          <tei:p>Agathis pappeisp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 12)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$, 3-0-3-5 mm (excluding ovipositor). Black. Legs obscurely yellowish where they are pale; hind femur<tei:lb/>infuscate but yellowish at apex; in two out of three examples, including type, pale colour at apex of hind<tei:lb/>femur extends as a pale band along dorsal surface as far as base. Wings almost hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head in facial view only weakly lengthened (Fig. 12). Face very shiny, with variable amount of<tei:lb/>somewhat indistinct punctation, more clearly evident in holotype. Anterior margin of clypeus somewhat<tei:lb/>protuberant. Mouth opening wide and mandibles of powerful build. Malar space 0-66 times as long as<tei:lb/>longer diameter of eye. Galea about twice as long as wide and as long as malar space. No trace of an<tei:lb/>impression or dimple in front of anterior ocellus. Antenna short, thin, with 22-24 segments. Mesoscutum a<tei:lb/>little flattened, its middle lobe, and to a less extent, lateral lobes, with some vague, rather sparse<tei:lb/>punctation. Notaulices deeply impressed, foveate, their outer margin bordered with a row of indistinct<tei:lb/>punctures. Scutellum slightly depressed behind and rugulose here. Areolet of forewing weakly 4-sided;<tei:lb/>stigma rather broad; apical abscissa of postmarginalis almost absent. Hind femur slightly more than twice<tei:lb/>as long as wide, the legs being rather short and thick; inner spur of hind tibia hardly reaching middle of<tei:lb/>basal segment of hind tarsus ; claws rather long , without basal lobe or tooth . Sternaulus in the form of a fine<tei:lb/>groove, not reaching anterior margin of mesopleurum. Gaster somewhat short. Tergite 1 about 1-25 times<tei:lb/>longer than apical width, indistinctly striated more or less all over; rest of gaster smooth, shining.<tei:lb/>Ovipositor sheath as long as gaster plus propodeum.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This aberrant species cannot be confused with any other from the region; it is characterised<tei:lb/>mainly by the shape of the head as seen from in front, the wide mouth-opening and the correspondingly<tei:lb/>large, powerful mandibles.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Agathis melpomenesp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf $, 4-8-5-0 mm long (excluding ovipositor). Black. Hind femur yellowish, contrastingly darkened on<tei:lb/>apical one-third to two-fifths.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$ . Head in facial view elongate and considerably narrowed below eyes; in lateral view, line of face and<tei:lb/>that of clypeus appear virtually in one plane. No keel between antennal insertions and virtually no<tei:lb/>impression in front of anterior ocellus. Galea 1-35-1-50 times longer than malar space, faintly coriaceous<tei:lb/>and rather abruptly narrowed from middle to apex. Sternaulus strongly developed,<tei:lb/>reaching posterior corner of mesopleurum , and in one paratype (Markovo) extending also as far as anterior<tei:lb/>margin of mesopleurum. Propodeum with usual, two longitudinal keels; lateral panels towards anterior<tei:lb/>dorsal surface covered with coarse shiny rugosity. Radial cell rather long; distal abscissa of postmarginalis<tei:lb/>fully 0-75 times longer than proximal abscissa; areolet 4-sided but distinctly narrowed towards edge of<tei:lb/>wing. Outer side of middle tibia (holotype) with a row of 8 rather broad-based teeth, some of them<tei:lb/>overlapping; 6-7 teeth in the two paratypes; these slightly smaller and less close together than in holotype;<tei:lb/>inner spur of hind tibia about two-fifths as long as basal segment of hind tarsus ; hind claw with conspicuous,<tei:lb/>dentiform lobe and wide cleft between this and claw proper. Tergite 1 hardly longer than apically wide;<tei:lb/>almost smooth in the two paratypes but with vague rugosity over middle part in holotype. Tergites 2+3<tei:lb/>polished, smooth (cf. anglicd). Ovipositor sheath hardly as long as gaster plus thorax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Antenna with 25-27 segments; flagellum very thin. In profile clypeus rises slightly above line efface.<tei:lb/>Outer side of middle tibia with 7 teeth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype , Hungary: Taratovar6s, 28.V.1959 (Bajdri) (HNHM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Bulgaria: 1 $, Rhodopi; 1 $, Markovo, 23.vi.1978 (A. Zaykov) (HNHM); 1 $, S. poljana,<tei:lb/>24.vi.1975 (A. Zaykov) (BMNH).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>HOST. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This species is at once separable from anglica by the size of the radial cell, the strongly<tei:lb/>developed, dentiform lobe of the hind claws and the reduction of sculpture on tergite 1. The presence of<tei:lb/>more numerous teeth on the outer side of the middle tibia is also of value though this character is likely to<tei:lb/>vary. The general conformation of the radial cell is like that of varipes, but melpomene is distinguished by<tei:lb/>the shape of the head in facial view. The males are variable, consequently they are excluded from the<tei:lb/>type-series.</tei:p>

There is also a subtle distinctiveness in the shape of the head as<tei:lb/>seen in profile, but it is based on features that are not easily described.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>RHAMPHAGA THIS Tobias<tei:lb/>Rhamphagathis Tobias, 1962: 1195. Type-species: Agathis nasicornis Telenga, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Face very broad across clypeus; latter in profile projecting as a snout. Labrum small,<tei:lb/>transverse. Mandible seen from in front, broadened, flattened, with two blunt, short teeth at apex; thus<tei:lb/>seen, mandible almost lamelliform. Mesoscutum in dorsal view flattened, with strongly produced anterior<tei:lb/>corners. Propleura much flattened in dorso-ventral direction, their posterior margin reflexed to accommo-<tei:lb/>date base of anterior coxae. Wing-venation like that of Agathis. Legs rather short; hind femur very stout.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rhamphagathis nasicornis (Telenga)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis nasicornis Telenga, 1955: 253. Lectotype &lt;J&gt;, U.S.S.R.: Kharkov (AS), designated by Tobias,<tei:lb/>1962: 1195 [not examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf $ , 3-5-4-0 mm long (excluding ovipositor).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9 Black. Hind femur deeply infuscate; hind tibia obscurely yellowish on basal half with faint dark band<tei:lb/>near base.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head in facial view as long as broad; seen from above with occiput deeply emarginate, the margin falling<tei:lb/>away steeply, almost angularly where it reaches posterior ocelli. Galea very slightly longer than malar<tei:lb/>space. In front of anterior ocellus hardly a trace of a dimple but with short keel extending downwards<tei:lb/>between antennal insertions. Antenna thin, thread-like, with 27-28 segments. Thorax in profile markedly<tei:lb/>elongate. Propleura curiously flattened, dull, rugulose all over, densely pubescent and contrasting with<tei:lb/>smooth, highly polished side of pronotum. Middle lobe of mesoscutum projecting far forwards on each side<tei:lb/>to form a conspicuous shoulder; these shoulders coarsely rugose where they join notaulices; in profile,<tei:lb/>flattened mesoscutum falls perpendicularly to pronotum. Notaulices distinct throughout, slightly widened<tei:lb/>in front and here rugose-foveate. Sternaulus in form of thin groove reaching posterior corner of<tei:lb/>mesopleurum but not anterior margin of this. Legs rather short, thick; hind femur twice as long as wide;<tei:lb/>outer side of middle tibia with 6-10 thick, spine-like teeth on apical half; front coxa rather small, flattened<tei:lb/>on lower side and here with sculpture similar to that of propleura and in sharp contrast with smooth, shiny<tei:lb/>surface of middle and posterior coxae; claws with a lobe. Radial cell rather narrow; areolet in female<tei:lb/>almost triangular; distal abscissa of postmarginalis very short, reduced almost to a point. Gaster somewhat</tei:p>

      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE EUROPEAN AGATHIDINAE 215</tei:p>
         <tei:p>short; tergite 1 about 1-25 times longer than apically wide, much widened towards apex; surface finely,<tei:lb/>rather weakly striated. Ovipositor sheath very slightly longer than gaster.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Germany: 2 cf, 2 $, Ruthe coll. (BMNH). U.S.S.R.: 1 $, Melito (Kokujev) (AS).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This is a highly peculiar, quite isolated species. Apart from its generic features, it resembles the<tei:lb/>genus Agathis in general habitus. The curious appearance of the propleura suggests an adaptation to a<tei:lb/>specialised mode of existence. Among the species from the region Rhamphagathis nasicornis is easily<tei:lb/>recognised by its protuberant clypeus and prominent mesoscutal shoulders.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MICRODUS Nees von Esenbeck</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus Nees von Esenbeck, 1814: 184. Type-species: Ichneumon calculator Fabricius, by subsequent<tei:lb/>designation (Haliday in Westwood, 1840: 63, synopsis).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS, cf $. Head in facial view transversely elliptical. Frons in front of anterior ocellus without<tei:lb/>deepened and margined pit or furrow (cf. Agathis). Mouth-parts unmodified, never lengthened to form a<tei:lb/>beak-like structure; galea not longer than wide; maxillary palpus often appearing 3-segmented because<tei:lb/>preapical segment (3rd) sometimes so short as to be hardly noticeable; this segment always conspicuously<tei:lb/>shorter than apical segment. Sternaulus always present. Venation much as in Agathis (cf. Fig. 50); 1st<tei:lb/>discoidal cell and 1st cubital cell not separated by a vein; 2nd cubital cell always in form of small triangular<tei:lb/>or subtriangular areolet; distal abscissa of postmarginalis fully as long as proximal abscissa. Outer side of<tei:lb/>middle tibia with 2-8 teeth, usually 3-4. Ovipositor at least 0-66 times as long as gaster.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holarctic in distribution.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Muesebeck (1927) considered that Microdus could not be retained as a genus separate from Agathis and<tei:lb/>accordingly synonymised them. His opinion was based on a study of North American material and found its<tei:lb/>support in the breakdown of the single character - the shape of the head - traditionally used to separate the<tei:lb/>two genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Telenga (1955: 273) reinstated Microdus without giving reasons for rejecting Muesebeck's opinion. He<tei:lb/>has been followed by Tobias (1976ft: 97) who recognised Microdus on biological rather than morphological<tei:lb/>grounds. Tobias argues that Agathis species, because of their lengthened mouth-parts, tend to inhabit arid,<tei:lb/>steppe-like regions where flowers conceal their nectar in deep corollas, a floral adaptation, Tobias adds,<tei:lb/>that makes the nectar available to long tongued insects inhabiting regions where they are exposed to<tei:lb/>moisture deficiency. Microdus, on the other hand, is considered to be largely dependent on Lepidoptera<tei:lb/>feeding on forest trees and in consequence is well represented in the richly forested regions of the Far East.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tobias' observations are probably pertinent to the biology of the Agathidinae but it is arguable whether<tei:lb/>they provide a foundation for validating genera in a group with so unstable a classification as the<tei:lb/>Braconidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nevertheless, the two genera can be separated on sound morphological characters as follows.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Mouth-parts lengthened in the form of a beak, galea rarely as short as 1-33 times longer than<tei:lb/>wide, nearly always much longer; head in facial view lengthened (Figs 1-6); ocelli in a high<tei:lb/>triangle, the posterior tangent to the anterior ocellus passing freely in front of posterior pair;<tei:lb/>foramen of metasternum accommodating hind coxa not closed on inner side by a sclerotized<tei:lb/>bridge. AGATHIS Latreille</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mouth-parts not lengthened in the form of a beak, the galea not longer than wide; head in facial<tei:lb/>view transversely elliptical; ocelli in a low triangle, the posterior tangent to the anterior<tei:lb/>ocellus usually cutting, or at least touching, posterior pair; foramen of metasternum accom-<tei:lb/>modating hind coxa closed on inner side by a sclerotized bridge.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MICRODUS Nees von Esenbeck</tei:p>

         <tei:p>1 Claws unarmed, without basal lobe; whole of hind leg blackish, except for yellowish band at<tei:lb/>extreme base of tibia.<tei:lb/>Thorax marked with black and red calculator F. (p. 217)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>notaulices deeply impressed throughout; hind tibia whitish, infuscate on rather less than</tei:p>
         <tei:p>apical half and usually with dark basal ring cingulipes Wesmael (p. 221)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Radius less bent inwards towards stigma, darker at middle; notaulices almost absent on disc;<tei:lb/>hind tibia dull reddish with less apical infuscation and with hardly a trace of a basal band</tei:p>
         <tei:p>nugax Reinhard (p. 222)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10 Head in facial view slightly elongate (Fig. 32); internal rim of antennal sockets with distinct</tei:p>
         <tei:p>dentiform projection; hypopygium emarginate at apex, appearing strongly truncate in</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Head in facial view strongly transverse (Fig. 30); internal rim of antennal sockets without such a<tei:lb/>projection; hypopygium not emarginate at apex, appearing pointed in profile.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Usually entire gaster, except tergite 1 , reddish yellow conspicuus Wesmael (p. 225)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Microdus calculator (Fabricius)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichneumon calcula tor Fabricius, 1798: 225. Holotype $, ITALY (ZM) [not examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus calculator (Fabricius) Nees von Esenbeck, 1834: 144.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus abscissas Ratzeburg, 18446: 58. Holotype cf , GERMANY (lost). [Synonymised by Ratzeburg,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1852: 45.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis calculator (Fabricius) Shenefelt, 1970: 323.<tei:lb/>Microdus calculator (Fabricius) Tobias, 1971: 260.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There never has been any doubt about the identity of this species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>O" 9, 6-0-7-5 mm long (excluding ovipositor). At least head, propodeum and gaster black; sometimes<tei:lb/>mesosternum also black; rest of thorax red. Whole of hind leg blackish except for a pale, yellowish band at<tei:lb/>extreme base of tibia. Wings more or less hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9 . Head in facial view like that oilinguarius (cf. Fig. 32), less transverse than in other species; seen from<tei:lb/>above, very short, strongly transverse. A single blunt, almost knob-like keel between antennal sockets.<tei:lb/>Ocelli in a low triangle, the posterior tangent to anterior ocellus just touching posterior pair. Preapical<tei:lb/>segment (3rd) of labial palpus well developed, fully 2-5 times longer than wide. Antenna with 34-35<tei:lb/>segments. Notaulices deeply impressed throughout. Sternaulus broad, costate. Prepectal margin clearly<tei:lb/>defined. Propodeum very coarsely reticulate but without discrete, longitudinal keel or keels. Areolet of<tei:lb/>fore- wing triangular, usually with short stalk; distal abscissa of postmarginalis about as long as proximal<tei:lb/>abscissa; anal cell of hind-wing without anellus. Outer side of middle tibia with 3-4 isolated teeth; claw of<tei:lb/>hind tarsus without trace of either lobe or tooth. Tergite 1 1-33-1-50 times longer than its apical width,<tei:lb/>strongly, evenly striate all over. Basal half of tergites 2+3 with sculpture like that of tergite 1 but sculpture<tei:lb/>less regular and not reaching apical corners of this half of tergites 2+3; sculpture tends to be confined to<tei:lb/>transverse, blister-like basal area. Ovipositor sheath about as long as thorax plus gaster.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf. Like female but frequently darker; mesopleurum sometimes completely blackened.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Great Britain: 1 9&gt; Hampshire, New Forest, Bishop's Dyke, emerged 21.V.1963 from lepidopterous<tei:lb/>larva pupating under dead bark of beech (Fagus) (BMNH); 4 cf , Winchester, flying around dead beech<tei:lb/>tree, viii.1979 (Else) (BMNH); 2 cf , 3 ?, Surrey, Mickleham, ex Scardia boleti, v.1933 (Ford) (BMNH);<tei:lb/>2 Cf , 3 $ , Box Hill, vii.1938, ex Scardia boleti (Ford) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Morophaga boleti (Fabricius) (Tineidae) and probably also Triaxomera parasitella (Hiibner)<tei:lb/>(Tineidae). According to records quoted by Shenefelt (1970), various people have bred calculator from<tei:lb/>these two lepidopterous hosts.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This is an unmistakeable species, at least in the region under consideration, and is readily<tei:lb/>characterised by its red and black colour, large size and, most significantly, by the unique simple claws.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus rugulosus Nees von Esenbeck comb. rev.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus rugulosus Nees von Esenbeck, 1834: 148; Reinhard, 1867: 357. Holotype $, GERMANY (lost).<tei:lb/>Braunsia rugulosa (Nees von Esenbeck) Telenga, 1955: 278; Shenefelt, 1970: 376.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Reinhard was the first reviser of this species and from his excellent treatment of it, the identity of rugulosus<tei:lb/>is not in doubt.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$, 4-5 mm long (excluding ovipositor). Head and thorax black. Gaster usually entirely blackened above<tei:lb/>but frequently pale-marked towards apical corners of tergites 2+3; in such cases, the segments posterior to<tei:lb/>the pale area tend to be entirely pale yellowish brown or reddish brown; in one example (Surrey,<tei:lb/>Mickleham), basal half of tergites 2+3 is bright reddish yellow. Hind femur varying from entirely infuscate<tei:lb/>to entirely reddish yellow; when hind femur is pale, the hind tibia is contrastingly whitish with apical third<tei:lb/>and a basal band infuscate; in examples with darkened hind femur, the tibia is correspondingly darkened;<tei:lb/>hind coxa reddish yellow over most of basal half or entirely infuscate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head in facial view transverse, as in majority of species (cf. Fig. 30). Frons between antennal sockets<tei:lb/>showing as a smooth, weakly rounded boss, laterally compressed to form a single, short, rounded ridge.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>218 G. E. J. NIXON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Segment 3 of labial palpus fully 0-66 times as long as apical segment. In front of anterior ocellus an<tei:lb/>obsolescent, V-shaped depression. Ocelli in a low triangle, the posterior tangent to anterior ocellus<tei:lb/>virtually touching posterior pair. Antenna with 30-34 segments: 30 (5), 31(2), 34(1). Notaulices sharply<tei:lb/>defined but shallow, finely foveate throughout. Sculpture of propodeum variable, tending to fade out on<tei:lb/>each side of convexity, leaving an almost smooth area. Areolet of fore- wing almost always sharply<tei:lb/>triangular; rarely with short stalk. Inner spur of hind tibia not reaching middle of basal segment of hind<tei:lb/>tarsus; hind claw with conspicuous, angular lobe; outer side of middle tibia with 2-3 well-separated teeth.<tei:lb/>Tergite 1 about 1-66 times longer than apically wide, with fine, mostly broken rugose-striation all over;<tei:lb/>where the striation becomes weak, towards apex of tergite, surface shows a considerable amount of weak<tei:lb/>scaly-reticulation. Tergites 2+3 almost 1-5 times longer than apically wide, sculptured almost all over;<tei:lb/>distal to 2nd suture, which shows as a shallow furrow, the surface is weakly scaly-reticulate, the sculpture<tei:lb/>tending to fade out towards apical corners; basal to the suture (the area probably corresponding to the true<tei:lb/>second tergite), a weakly rugose furrow sets off the usual, transverse, slightly raised area; whole of basal<tei:lb/>half of tergites 2+3 vaguely rugose-striate with either the rugose or striate element predominating.<tei:lb/>Hypopygium sharply pointed at apex. Ovipositor sheath about equal to gaster plus thorax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Germany: 3 $, Ruthe coll. (BMNH). Great Britain: 2 $, Bucks., vii., on dead Quercus sp. (BMNH);<tei:lb/>1 $, Essex, Epping Forest, viii.1954 (BMNH); 3 $, Hants., Romsey, vii.-viii.1980, from wood of dead<tei:lb/>Larix (C. Vardy) (BMNH); 1 $, Southsea, coll. 19.iii.1983, em. vi.1983, ex Blastobasis lignea in dead<tei:lb/>twigs of Ulex (BMNH); 1 $, Surrey, Mickleham, vii.1935 (BMNH). Greece: 1 $, Ilia, Olympia, vii.1979<tei:lb/>(Day, Else &amp; Morgan) (BMNH). Ireland: 4 $ , Glengariff , Lodge Woods, vii.1935, on Quercus sp. (A. W.<tei:lb/>Stelfox) (BMNH). Switzerland: 1 $, Wallis, Brig, 2.vii.l959 (E. Bauer) (EH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Blastobasis lignea Walsingham (Blastobasidae). According to Meyrick (1968), the larva of this moth<tei:lb/>feeds on dead leaf-refuse but this may also include dead wood which would explain the data given above.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Though variable both in colour and sculpture, this species is highly distinctive on the sculpture<tei:lb/>of the gaster; it could not be confused with any other Microdus from the region.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus rufipes Nees von Esenbeck</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus rufipes Nees von Esenbeck, 1814: 189. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost).<tei:lb/>Braunsia rufipes (Nees von Esenbeck) Telenga, 1955: 277; Shenefelt, 1970: 375.<tei:lb/>Microdus rufipes Nees von Esenbeck; Tobias, 1971: 260.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C? $, 4-5 mm long (excluding ovipositor). Black; rarely basal third of tergites 2+3 reddish yellow (1 $,<tei:lb/>England: Suffolk, Sudbury). Hind coxa and hind femur bright reddish yellow; hind tibia slightly duskier<tei:lb/>than its femur and darkened on about apical third. A single female from Jugoslavia: Ristovaca has the face,<tei:lb/>mesoscutum and sides of thorax richly marked with paler colouring.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9. Head like that of rugulosus. Structure of frons between antennal sockets like that of rugulosus but<tei:lb/>thickened keel tapering behind and uniting with a distinct V-shaped depression in front of anterior ocellus.<tei:lb/>Ocelli in a low triangle, the tangent to anterior ocellus cutting posterior pair. Antenna with 31-32<tei:lb/>segments. Notaulices deeply impressed, much more so than in rugulosus. Propodeum covered with coarse,<tei:lb/>confused rugosities. Wings like those of rugulosus but distal abscissa of postmarginalis not longer than<tei:lb/>proximal abscissa. Outer side of middle tibia with 6-7 closely spaced teeth near apex; inner spur of hind<tei:lb/>tibia relatively longer than in rugulosus and almost reaching middle of basal segment of hind tarsus. Tergite<tei:lb/>1 considerably widened towards apex, about 1-25 times longer than apically wide, strongly, evenly striate<tei:lb/>all over. Tergites 2+3 showing three transverse furrows of variable definition, its entire surface, except<tei:lb/>across surface distal to third furrow, with shiny, on the whole even, longitudinal striation. Tergites 4 and 5<tei:lb/>sometimes with faint traces of scaly-reticulation. Ovipositor sheath about equal to length of thorax plus<tei:lb/>gaster.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Like female. Rarely the striation at base of tergites 2+3 somewhat broken and transverse in<tei:lb/>direction.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Bulgaria, Great Britain, Sweden, Turkey, Yugoslavia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Cydia pomonella (L.) (Tortricidae); Spilonota ocellana (Denis &amp; Schiffermiiller) (Tortricidae);<tei:lb/>Hedya nubiferana (Haworth) (Tortricidae); Gypsonoma dealbana (Frolich) (Tortricidae). The foregoing<tei:lb/>hosts are from specimens personally examined. Tobias (1971) cites the second two and in addition gives<tei:lb/>Rhyacionia buoliana (Denis &amp; Schiffermiiller) (Tortricidae).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE EUROPEAN AGATHIDINAE 219</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This is probably the most distinct of all European species of Microdus and is easily recognised<tei:lb/>by the even striation of the gaster. It is because of this highly characteristic striation that Telenga (1955)<tei:lb/>transferred rufipes to Braunsia Kriechbaumer but this genus is almost exclusively Afrotropical and though<tei:lb/>characterised by a striated gaster, it has no close affinity with Microdus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus dimidiator Nees von Esenbeck</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus dimidiator Nees von Esenbeck, 1834: 146. Holotype $, POLAND (lost).<tei:lb/>Agathis dimidiator (Nees von Esenbeck) Shenefelt, 1970: 329.<tei:lb/>Microdus dimidiator Nees von Esenbeck; Tobias, 1971: 260.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf 9&gt; 4-5 mm (excluding ovipositor). Black; anterior corners of tergites 2+3 somewhat pale, the pale<tei:lb/>colouring sometimes forming a complete band across base of segment. Hind coxae usually entirely reddish<tei:lb/>yellow but sometimes becoming infuscate towards base; hind femur reddish yellow; hind tibia whitish<tei:lb/>yellow but infuscate on about apical third and with faint to absent darker ring near base. Wings almost<tei:lb/>hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9- Head as in rugulosus. Between antennal sockets a gently rounded hump as in other species with<tei:lb/>sculptured gaster. Segment 3 of labial palpus poorly developed, almost moniliform and much shorter than<tei:lb/>apical segment. Posterior tangent to anterior ocellus virtually touching posterior pair. Antenna with 33-35<tei:lb/>segments: 22 (2), 33 (1), 34 (2), 35 (2). Notaulices deeply impressed. Propodeum more coarsely and<tei:lb/>intricately rugose than in rufipes. Lobes of mesoscutum sometimes showing a weak, sparse punctation.<tei:lb/>Areolet of fore wing smaller than in rufipes and more markedly stalked. Hind spurs more powerfully built<tei:lb/>than in either rugulosus or rufipes, the inner one just reaching middle of basal segment of hind tarsus; outer<tei:lb/>side of middle tibia with 3-4 teeth arranged in a row and well separated from small cluster of teeth at<tei:lb/>extreme apex. Tergite 1 about 1-5 times longer than apically wide, longitudinally striate all over; striation<tei:lb/>close, dense, shiny. Tergites 2+3 with similar striation extending as far as second suture and here ending<tei:lb/>abruptly; distal to second suture, surface (corresponding to area of tergite 3) highly polished and<tei:lb/>sometimes showing the faintest trace of a transverse furrow. Ovipositor sheath about as long as body.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>O". Like female except for sexual differences. Tergite 1 tending to be a little longer than in female and<tei:lb/>striation of tergites 2+3 sometimes broken or obsolescent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>France: 8 O" , 15 9 , Vaucluse, Mont Ventoux, bred vi.-vii. 1970, 1980 ex Tortrix viridana L. , on Quercus<tei:lb/>sp. (P. du Merle) (PdMC, 2 cT, 5 9, BMNH). Germany: 1 $, Ruthe coll.          <tei:p>HOSTS. Tortrix viridana L. (Tortricidae); Spilonota ocellana (Denis &amp; Schiffermuller) (Tortricidae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. The female from Yugoslavia has the hind coxa blackish throughout, and the hind femur<tei:lb/>darkened with the apex almost infuscate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The traditional interpretation of dimidiator is certainly correct, for Nees von Esenbeck has carefully<tei:lb/>drawn attention to its salient features in his description. The essential character for recognising this species<tei:lb/>is the abrupt termination, at the second suture, of whatever sculpture exists on the basal half of tergites<tei:lb/>2+3, i.e. the sculpture is sharply restricted to the surface of what is morphologically the second tergite.<tei:lb/>Further, M. dimidiator is more slenderly built than either rugulosus or rufipes and has noticeably longer<tei:lb/>legs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus lugubrator Ratzeburg comb. rev.<tei:lb/>(Figs 57, 59, 63)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus lugubrator Ratzeburg, 1852: 45. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost).<tei:lb/>Agathis lugubrator (Ratzeburg) Fulmek, 1962: 103; Shenefelt, 1970: 341.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf 9 , 3-5-4-0 mm long (excluding ovipositor).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9 . Black, sometimes with paler colouring on gaster. Hind coxa deeply infuscate; hind femur dull reddish<tei:lb/>yellow; hind tibia much the same colour but faintly darkened at apex. Wings considerably darkened.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head not strongly transverse (Fig. 63). Frons between antennal sockets weakly raised to form a single,<tei:lb/>blunt, almost knob-like keel as in rugulosus and rufipes. Antenna with 28-31 segments: 28(2), 30(2), 31(1);<tei:lb/>scape rather short (Fig. 59). Ocelli in rather a high triangle, the posterior tangent to anterior ocellus not</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>220 G. E. J. NIXON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>touching posterior pair. Notaulices poorly defined, sometimes almost absent on disc. Propodeum coarsely,<tei:lb/>intricately rugose all over; sometimes with 2 fairly distinct, longitudinal keels. Legs rather thick; outer side<tei:lb/>of middle tibia with 3-4 well-spaced teeth in a row; inner spur of hind tibia not quite reaching middle of<tei:lb/>basal segment of hind tarsus. Areolet of fore- wing varying from distinctly triangular to distinctly 4-sided;<tei:lb/>distal abscissa of radius virtually straight, widely separated from stigma (Fig. 57). Gaster shorter and<tei:lb/>broader than in other species of the rugulosus-complex. Tergite 1 much widened to apex, about 1-25 times<tei:lb/>longer than apically wide, densely rugose-striate all over and usually with a clear indication of superim-<tei:lb/>posed scaly-reticulation. Tergites 2+3 with a distinct 2nd suture and usually a curved furrow proximal to<tei:lb/>this; tergites 2+3 proximal to 2nd suture with a fine variable sculpture all over; within the slightly raised,<tei:lb/>basal area, sculpture usually shows distinct striate elements, sometimes transverse in direction; elsewhere<tei:lb/>sculpture a mixture of scaly-reticulation and fine striation; distal to 2nd suture, surface shows traces,<tei:lb/>sometimes very indistinct, of scaly-reticulation. Ovipositor sheath 0-66-0-75 times length of gaster.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Gaster sometimes with dull reddish tinge. Antenna with 26-28 segments: 26(2), 28(1). In the scanty<tei:lb/>material available, gaster rather more coarsely sculptured than in female.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>HOSTS. Evidently a parasite of various species of Coleophora: Coleophora flavipennella (Duponchel),<tei:lb/>Coleophora hemerobiella (Scopoli) and possibly Coleophora lutipennella (Zeller).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This species is mainly characterised by its weak notaulices, sculpture of gaster and short<tei:lb/>ovipositor. Its nearest relative seems to be fortipes (see below).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus fortipes Reinhard</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 65)<tei:lb/>Microdus fortipes Reinhard, 1867: 356. Syntype $. GERMANY (MNHU) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf $ , 4-5 mm long (excluding ovipositor).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$ . Hind femur entirely deep reddish in two females (Munich) but much darkened in single female from<tei:lb/>Witzenhausen; hind tibia much the same colour as hind femur but infuscate at extreme apex. Wings<tei:lb/>markedly infuscate, as in lugubrator. Head from above much more transverse (Fig. 65). Antenna shorter,<tei:lb/>thicker, with 23-25 segments; three preapical segments hardly longer than wide; in lugubrator, they are<tei:lb/>fully 1-25 times longer than wide; scape slightly longer. Thorax in profile much less elongate. Notaulices<tei:lb/>deeply impressed throughout. Propodeum with much coarser reticulate rugosity. Anella of hind wing not<tei:lb/>emitting an anal vein; in this respect markedly different from lugubrator; areolet of fore-wing (3 9 , 2 C?)<tei:lb/>always sharply triangular and sometimes with short stalk. Legs thicker than in lugubrator; outer side of<tei:lb/>middle tibia with a cluster of 8-10 teeth close to apex. Gaster as in lugubrator but tergite 1 and basal half of<tei:lb/>tergites 2+3 as far as second suture with irregular sculpture of shiny, longitudinal striation; on basal part of<tei:lb/>tergites 2+3 the striation tends to be concentric around a mid-basal area and towards sides shows weakly<tei:lb/>superimposed scaly-reticulation; distal to second suture, tergites 2+3 mainly polished with faint traces of<tei:lb/>scaly-reticulation and a transverse linear impression across middle. Ovipositor sheath almost as long as<tei:lb/>gaster plus propodeum; seen from above, hairs of apical fifth of ovipositor sheath shorter and less<tei:lb/>noticeable than in lugubrator.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Like female except for sexual differences. Sculpture of gaster reduced; that on tergites 2+3 almost<tei:lb/>obliterated.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE EUROPEAN AGATHIDINAE 221</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. According to Reinhard this species was bred frequently by Bouche from Spilonota ocellana (Denis &amp;<tei:lb/>Schiffermuller) (Tortricidae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Microdus fortipes is perhaps more closely related to lugubrator than to any other species from<tei:lb/>the region. From lugubrator it is distinguished mainly by the more transverse head, the sculpture of the<tei:lb/>gaster and the much more deeply impressed notaulices. In lugubrator the sculpture of the basal half of<tei:lb/>tergites 2+3 presents a dull, vaguely scaly-reticulate appearance in which longitudinal elements are poorly<tei:lb/>defined; in fortipes, on the other hand, the sculpture here is predominantly strong, longitudinal striation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus pumilus Ratzeburg</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus pumilus Ratzeburg, 1844ft: 57. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost).<tei:lb/>Agathis pumila (Ratzeburg) Shenefelt, 1970: 350.<tei:lb/>Microdus pumilus Ratzeburg: Tobias, 1971: 260.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf $ , ca 2 mm (excluding ovipositor).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Black. Hind femur deeply infuscate; hind tibia whitish on basal half with darkened subbasal band,<tei:lb/>infuscate on apical half.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head rather deep from back to front, as seen from above; much as in lugubrator (cf. Fig. 63). Ocelli in a<tei:lb/>high triangle, the posterior tangent to anterior ocellus passing far in front of posterior pair. Face having a<tei:lb/>shiny, convex, polished appearance. Frons between antennal sockets raised at middle to form a knob that is<tei:lb/>slightly lengthened in direction of anterior ocellus; in this respect similar to the rugulosus-group. Palpi<tei:lb/>short; segment 4 of maxillary palpus much shorter than 5. Notaulices shallow, sometimes fading out before<tei:lb/>reaching posterior fovea. Sternaulus shallow, broken, isolated and not reaching back as far as posterior<tei:lb/>corner of mesopleurum . Hind spurs weak , subequal , the inner one not reaching middle of basal segment of<tei:lb/>hind tarsus. Stigma rather broad; apical abscissa of postmarginalis considerably shorter than proximal<tei:lb/>abscissa. Outer side of middle tibia with 2-3 teeth, difficult to see because of infuscation of tibia; hind claw<tei:lb/>small but with distinct lobe. Gaster somewhat short; tergite 1 triangularly widened to apex, about 1-33<tei:lb/>times longer than its apical width; delicately, somewhat brokenly, longitudinally striate. Ovipositor sheath<tei:lb/>about 0-66 times as long as gaster, shorter than in any other species from the region.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Like female except for sexual differences. Antenna with 27 segments.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Germany: 1 cf , 6 , S.-Holstein, Segeberg, ex Coleophora laricella Hiibner (T. Weber) (EH). Holland:<tei:lb/>1 $, Bergentheim, 9.vii.l975 (B. v. Aartsen) (RNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Coleophora laricella (Hiibner) (Coleophoridae). This host, according to Meyrick (1968), is<tei:lb/>restricted to Larix (see discussion under 'Biology').</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This is the smallest species from the region and is most distinctive on account of its very short<tei:lb/>ovipositor. It stands apart from the other species with polished tergites (except tergite 1) because of the<tei:lb/>structure of the frons between the antennal insertions.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus cingulipes Nees von Esenbeck</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 55)<tei:lb/>Microdus cingulipes Nees von Esenbeck, 1814: 189. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wesmael (1837: 18) was the first reviser of cingulipes; I have based my interpretation of the species on a<tei:lb/>specimen in Wesmael's collection bearing his handwritten identification label.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$, 3-5-4-0 mm (excluding ovipositor). Black. Hind femur black; hind tibia obscurely whitish yellow at<tei:lb/>middle; deeply infuscate on apical two-fifths and with ring of infuscation near base.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head in facial view as transverse as in majority of species; seen from above strongly transverse. Antennal<tei:lb/>sockets on their inner side joined to form a weakly bipartite projection. Ocelli in low triangle, the posterior<tei:lb/>tangent to anterior ocellus virtually touching posterior pair. Labial palpus with only 3 clearly visible<tei:lb/>segments. Antenna with 29-31 segments. Notaulices deeply impressed throughout, sometimes forming<tei:lb/>patch of rugosity where they unite behind. Sternaulus distinct throughout but narrow, linear and at most<tei:lb/>finely rugose. Propodeum rugose all over but showing no special feature. Hind spurs rather weak; inner<tei:lb/>spur of hind tibia falling far short of middle of basal segment of hind tarsus; outer side of middle tibia with<tei:lb/>2-3 teeth just proximal to apical cluster of 3-4 teeth. Radius colourless over middle third, strongly bent<tei:lb/>inwards towards stigma and, where closest to this, separated from it by about thickness of radius itself (Fig.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>222 G. E. J. NIXON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>55); stigma shorter and less wedge-shaped than in tumidulus and close allies. Tergite 1 1-50-1-66 times<tei:lb/>longer than its apical width, somewhat weakly striate all over. Tergites 2+3 basal to 2nd suture with usual,<tei:lb/>curved furrow, delimiting a transversely elliptical area; rarely this furrow finely costate; gaster otherwise<tei:lb/>smooth, polished. Ovipositor sheath about as long as thorax plus gaster.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Belgium: 1 $, Wesmael coll. (IRSNB). Germany: 2 cf, Ruthe coll. (BMNH); 5 $, Oberbayern,<tei:lb/>Hochstadt, vii.-viii. Great Britain: 1 $,<tei:lb/>Hampshire, Havant Thicket, ex Epinotia fraternella Douglas on Abies grandis, collected 10. xi. 1977,<tei:lb/>emerged iii.1978 (Langmaid) (MS); 1 $, Essex, Saffron Walden, ix.1966, ex Coleophora frischella L.<tei:lb/>(Emmet) (AA); 1 9 , Yorkshire, Langdale, on Pinus (Day) (BMNH).          <tei:p>HOSTS. Gary ocolum fraternella Douglas (Gelechiidae) ; Coleophora frischella (L.) (Coleophoridae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This is a very distinctive species, largely characterised by the deeply incurved radius. It seems<tei:lb/>to be closely related to the following species but there is no possibility of confusing the two.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus nugax Reinhard</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 54)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus nugox Reinhard, 1867: 354. Syntype $, GERMANY (MNHU) [examined].<tei:lb/>Agathis nugax (Reinhard) Shenefelt, 1970: 347.<tei:lb/>Microdus nugax Reinhard; Tobias, 1971: 260.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf $ , 3-5-4-0 mm (excluding ovipositor).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$ . Very close to cingulipes with which it may be compared as follows. Paler part of hind tibia obscurely<tei:lb/>brownish red with virtually no trace of a darkened, basal ring; hind femur varying from obscurely brownish<tei:lb/>red to entirely infuscate; hind spurs darker.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head from above slightly less transverse, deeper from back to front. Face polished, convex, virtually<tei:lb/>impunctate. Ocelli slightly smaller; posterior tangent to anterior ocellus passing freely in front of posterior<tei:lb/>pair. Preapical segment (3rd) of labial palpus so small as to be virtually absent. Antenna with fewer<tei:lb/>segments: 23-26; 23 (1), 24 (3), 25 (4), 26 (1). Thorax more elongate. Notaulices characteristically weak,<tei:lb/>sometimes not or hardly indicated posteriorly. Hind spurs less well developed. Radius only slightly bent<tei:lb/>but pale along middle stretch (Fig. 54) as in cingulipes. Tergite 1 a little less elongate, its sculpture<tei:lb/>considerably weaker. Ovipositor sheath a little shorter; seen from above, with denser, more closely set<tei:lb/>hairs that on apical third of sheath do not noticeably project.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Like female except for sexual differences.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Italy: 4 cT, 3 ?, Sudtirol, Algund, 1900 m, 24.vii.1966 (Haeselbarth) (EH; 1 cf , 1 $ in BMNH); 2 cf , 1<tei:lb/>9, Karthaus, 1200 m, 14.vii.1976 (Haeselbarth) (EH); 3 cf, 2 $, Marling, 1200 m, 12.vii.1966 (Haesel-<tei:lb/>barth) (EH; 1 Cf , 1 $ in BMNH); 2 $ , St Peter/ Ahrntal, vii.-viii.          <tei:p>HOST. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. A small, obscurely coloured species, essentially characterised by the weakly developed<tei:lb/>notaulices and the shape of the radial cell.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus eriphyle sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 56, 62, 64)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$ , 4 mm (excluding ovipositor). Black. Hind femur black; hind tibia obscurely whitish yellow, infuscate in<tei:lb/>apical third and with a broad infuscate prebasal band.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head from in front as transverse as in majority of species; seen from above as in Fig. 64. Antennal<tei:lb/>sockets unusually deep; seen from above frons between sockets very slightly concave. Behind frontal ridge<tei:lb/>and towards anterior ocellus a very short, almost tuberculiform keel. Ocelli in a high triangle, the posterior<tei:lb/>tangent to anterior ocellus passing in front of posterior pair. Preapical segment of labial palpus (3rd) well<tei:lb/>developed, clearly longer than wide. Notaulices deeply impressed throughout, smooth, uniting posteriorly</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE EUROPEAN AGATHIDINAE 223</tei:p>
         <tei:p>to form an elongate, smooth furrow. Propodeum appearing smooth, shiny, its sculpture very weak and in<tei:lb/>one female (paratype) almost absent. Radius of fore-wing strongly incurved but not so much as in<tei:lb/>dngulipes (cf. Fig. 55), evenly pigmented throughout. Outer side of middle tibia with a row of 4 teeth,<tei:lb/>widely spaced and linking up with 2 at extreme apex of tibia; inner spur of hind tibia not quite reaching<tei:lb/>middle of basal segment of hind tarsus; claws of all legs powerful; lobe almost as long as claw proper, a very<tei:lb/>deep cleft between it and claw proper (Fig. 54). Caster unusually long and narrow (Fig. 62). Tergite 1 about<tei:lb/>twice as long as its apical width, shiny, with a weak, almost shagreened sculpture in which longitudinal<tei:lb/>elements are virtually absent. Basal half of tergites 2+3 with faint traces of scaly-reticulation distal to the<tei:lb/>hardly indicated curved furrow common to all species. Ovipositor sheath about as long as gaster plus<tei:lb/>propodeum; bristle-like hairs towards apex of sheath not different from those elsewhere. Hypopygium<tei:lb/>long, sharply pointed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Greece: Ilia, Olympia, 4-11. vii. 1979 (Day, Else &amp; Morgan) (BMNH).<tei:lb/>Paratype. 1 $, same data.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This is an elegant species, differing in several significant characters from the other Microdus<tei:lb/>species dealt with in this revision. Particularly characteristic is the sculpture of the first gastral tergite. This,<tei:lb/>and the bend of the radius, suggest some affinity with Baeognatha Kokujev but this genus differs in not<tei:lb/>having a closed areolet in the fore- wing. It is possible that the loss of the second transverse vein in<tei:lb/>Baeognatha is apomorphic and in itself does not preclude a relationship with Microdus eriphyle.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus linguarius Nees von Esenbeck<tei:lb/>(Figs 32, 66)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus linguarius Nees von Esenbeck, 1814: 190. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost).<tei:lb/>Agathis linguarius (Nees von Esenbeck), Shenefelt, 1970: 340.<tei:lb/>Microdus linguarius Nees von Esenbeck, Tobias, 1971: 260.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Marshall (1885: 270) was the first reviser of linguarius and I have no doubt that his interpretation is correct.<tei:lb/>Nees von Esenbeck 's description is also explicit on the details that define linguarius.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf $,5-0-5-5 mm (excluding ovipositor).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$ . Black. Basal half of tergites 2+3 frequently marked with reddish; sometimes whole surface reddish<tei:lb/>except for a large, isolated, elliptical black patch at base; more often pale colouring restricted to a lateral<tei:lb/>mark on each margin and sometimes whole of tergites 2+3 black. Hind femur red; hind tibia reddish but<tei:lb/>infuscate on about apical quarter.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head from in front distinctly lengthened (Fig. 32). Inner margin of each antennal socket produced to<tei:lb/>form an angular tooth. Antenna with 28-31 segments, usually 30. Preapical segment of labial palpus (3rd)<tei:lb/>well developed, slightly longer than wide. Notaulices well defined throughout. Sternaulus of usual form.<tei:lb/>Propodeum coarsely rugose-reticulate all over; in this respect, somewhat uncharacteristic of genus;<tei:lb/>frequently with 2 indistinct, longitudinal keels. Radius of fore- wing slightly bent inwards towards stigma;<tei:lb/>areolet triangular or even stalked; stigma shorter than in clausthalianus but hardly different from that of<tei:lb/>tumidulus. Prepectal margin strongly raised, with knife-like edge. Outer side of middle tibia with 1-3<tei:lb/>isolated teeth in about apical third. Gaster less elongate than in clausthalianus, much as in tumidulus.<tei:lb/>Tergite 1 only a little longer than apically wide, finely striated to within about apical third where striations<tei:lb/>fade and give way to a broad, transverse band of setiferous punctures. Hairs of tergites somewhat<tei:lb/>characteristically short so that gaster has an almost bare, highly polished appearance. Ovipositor sheath<tei:lb/>fully 1-25 times longer than body. Hypopygium widely, moderately deeply emarginate at apex; in profile<tei:lb/>appearing markedly truncate (Fig. 66), rather sparsely hairy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Antenna with 28-29 segments. Gaster sometimes entirely black. Striation of tergite 1 more variable<tei:lb/>in intensity than in female, sometimes almost wanting.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Great Britain: 1 $&gt;, Berkshire, Boxmoor, 29-30.vii.1933 (R. B. Benson) (BMNH); 1 cf, Buckingham-<tei:lb/>shire, Gog Magog Hills, 27.vii.1937 (R. L. E. Ford) (BMNH); 1 $, Devon, Chudleigh, 14.viii.1935 (/. F.<tei:lb/>Perkins) (BMNH); 1 $, Hampshire, Portsdown, 4.viii.l956 (/. Clark) (BMNH); 1 $, I. of Wight, Cowes,<tei:lb/>20.xi.1938 (R. C. L. Perkins) (BMNH); 1 cf , Kent, Shoreham, 15.viii.1958 (R. L. E. Ford) (BMNH); 1 cf ,<tei:lb/>1 $, Surrey, Banstead (D. Clark) (BMNH); 49 , Hackhurst Downs, 27-28. viii. 1982 (A. A. Allen} (AA,</tei:p>
