         <tei:p>224 G. E. J. NIXON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>12 in BMNH); 2 cf, Sussex, Stonecross, 26.vii.1946 (R. L. E. Ford) (BMNH). Hungary: 1 cf, 1 ,<tei:lb/>Baranya-megya, Nagyharsane, vii.1963 (L. Zombori) (HNHM); 1 $, Somberek, 22.vii.1964 (L. Zom-<tei:lb/>bori) (HNHM); 10 $, 3 cT, Kam, Jeli arboretum (J. Papp) (HNHM); 2 , Keszthely, vii.1977 (J. Papp);<tei:lb/>1 Cf , 1 ?, Bajansenye, 16.viii.1977 (/. Papp) (HNHM); 1 $, F6t.Ret, 16.viii.1960 (Mihalyi) (HNHM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This is an easily recognised species and is characterised by the relatively elongate head, as seen<tei:lb/>from in front, the angular projection of the inner margin of the antennal socket and, in the female,<tei:lb/>especially by the emarginate hypopygium. This last feature is diagnostic for linguarius and it is unknown in<tei:lb/>other species from the region.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dates of capture for the numerous examples examined indicate that linguarius occurs only in July and<tei:lb/>August; it is probably single brooded.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus clausthalianus (Ratzeburg)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichneumon (Microdus) clausthalianus Ratzeburg, 1844a: 25. Holotype $, GERMANY (lost).<tei:lb/>Microdus clausthalianus (Ratzeburg) Ratzeburg, 18446: 58.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis clausthalianus (Ratzeburg) Kloet &amp; Hincks, 1945: 234: Shenefelt, 1970: 326.<tei:lb/>Microdus clausthalianus (Ratzeburg) Tobias, 1971: 260.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf $, 6-0-6-2 mm (excluding ovipositor).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9 Black, rarely with a pale mark against and behind eye. Hind femur always entirely reddish; hind tibia<tei:lb/>usually same colour except for weak infuscation in apical quarter; but sometimes hind tibia faintly<tei:lb/>yellowish and contrasting with red femur and, when thus pale, then with faint, prebasal band of<tei:lb/>infuscation; a pale-coloured hind tibia always correlated with an entirely red hind coxa; hind coxa varying<tei:lb/>from entirely red to entirely black. Labrum and mandible varying from entirely yellowish to obscure<tei:lb/>brownish red, or even black (exs. from Sweden: Skane, Fjellfota sjo).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Face punctate but punctation variable in intensity; when weak, face more shiny. Antennal sockets<tei:lb/>almost completely margined behind. Ocelli somewhat variable in size; when largest, they are in a low<tei:lb/>triangle with posterior tangent to the anterior ocellus touching posterior pair and distance between anterior<tei:lb/>and posterior ocellus less than diameter of ocellus. Prepapical segment of labial palpus (3rd) about as long<tei:lb/>as wide. Antenna with 37-40 segments in examples with red hind coxa: 37 (4), 38 (7), 39 (4), 40 (2); with<tei:lb/>33-36 segments in examples with blackened hind coxa; 33 (1), 34 (1), 35 (5), 36 (1). Mesoscutum somewhat<tei:lb/>elongate. Notaulices deeply impressed throughout. Sternaulus extending forwards almost exactly to<tei:lb/>middle of mesopleurum. Radial cell markedly elongate. Outer side of middle tibia with 3-4 teeth in a row.<tei:lb/>Gaster elongate, more so than in the tumidulus-aggregate. Tergite 1 with weak, longitudinal striation<tei:lb/>which is frequently so weak as to be almost absent. Ovipositor sheath fully as long as body.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Like female except for sexual differences.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Germany, Great Britain, Holland, Ireland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Epiblema scutulana (Denis &amp; Schiffermuller) (Tortricidae) (1 $, ex stem of Cirsium, 17. iv. 1979<tei:lb/>(P. R. Sokoloff) (MS); 1 $, Berwick, Oxton, ex stem of thistle sp., 10.iii.1979 (K. Bland) (MS)).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Most specimens of clausthalianus are fairly easily recognised by their slender form and long<tei:lb/>ovipositor. Smaller examples are sometimes hard to separate from tumidulus (s.l.). A prolonged study of<tei:lb/>both species has failed to reveal the limits of the range of variation in either.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus tumidulus Nees von Esenbeck<tei:lb/>(Fig. 58)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus tumidulus Nees von Esenbeck, 1814: 189. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus tegularis Thomson, 1895: 2231. LECTOTYPE $, SWEDEN: Palsjo (ZI), here designated</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathis tumidulus (Nees von Esenbeck) Shenefelt, 1970: 362.<tei:lb/>Microdus tumidulus Nees von Esenbeck; Tobias, 1971: 260.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species is very like clausthalianus. The main differences between the two species have been given in<tei:lb/>the key; there is very little to add.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Hind coxa mostly black, rarely entirely red. Antennal sockets unmargined behind; surface between<tei:lb/>sockets virtually smooth except for a weakly impressed, median, longitudinal groove. Antenna with 27-30</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A REVISION OF THE EUROPEAN AGATHIDINAE 225</tei:p>
         <tei:p>segments. Sternaulus ending at middle of mesopleurum. Hind femur stouter than in clausthalianus , 3 times<tei:lb/>as long as greatest width; outer side of middle tibia with 2-4 teeth towards apex, in addition to small cluster<tei:lb/>of teeth at extreme apex. Fore-wing (Fig. 58). Ovipositor sheath equal to length of gaster plus propodeum.<tei:lb/>Cf . Like female except for sexual differences.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>France, Germany, Great Britain, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Yugoslavia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Dichrorhampha acuminatana (Lienig &amp; Zeller) (Tortricidae). Reinhard (1867: 354) records<tei:lb/>tumidulus as having been bred from the pupae of this moth (under the name Phthoroblastis acuminatana)<tei:lb/>in August on Chrysanthemum leucanthemum L.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This species, which may be an aggregate, has been correctly interpreted (s.l.) by all major<tei:lb/>workers on Microdus. It is easily recognised by the pale mark behind the eyes - a striking example of<tei:lb/>constancy in a colour-character.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The notes given above cover the majority of the specimens examined, including Thomson's tegularis.<tei:lb/>There is, however, a series of 13 specimens in BMNH that, in certain respects, are intermediate between<tei:lb/>tumidulus and clausthalianus. On the whole the habitus is more slender than that of typical tumidulus and<tei:lb/>the ovipositor is longer, almost as long as the whole body. The antennal sockets are sometimes completely<tei:lb/>margined behind, sometimes smooth and evenly hollowed out; the surface between the sockets is usually<tei:lb/>raised in the form of an evenly rugose platform but more often the surface here is weakly bipartite, being<tei:lb/>divided by a feeble channel. Antenna with 29-33 segments. The material is from the following localities.<tei:lb/>Germany: 4 $, Ruthe coll. (BMNH). Great Britain: 1 $, Surrey, Banstead, 29.vi.1952 (BMNH); 1 $,<tei:lb/>Hampshire, Stockbridge, 15.vi.1953 (R. L. E. Ford) (BMNH). France: 1 $, Pyrenees-Orientales,<tei:lb/>Vernet-les-Bains, 20.vi.1963 (BMNH). Sweden: 1 $, Skane, Silvakra, viii.1976 (T. Huddleston &amp; J.<tei:lb/>Quintan) (BMNH); 4 $, Upsala, Solna, viii.1976 (T. H. &amp; J. Q.) (BMNH); these last mentioned 4<tei:lb/>specimens have the hind tarsus markedly blackened and the area between the antennal sockets showing<tei:lb/>maximum rugosity. Switzerland: 1 $, St Gall, Lake Zurich, ix.1951 (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus conspicuus Wesmael<tei:lb/>(Figs 30, 61)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus conspicuus Wesmael, 1837: 17. LECTOTYPE $, BELGIUM: Brussels, Wesmael coll. (IRSNB),</tei:p>
         <tei:p>here designated [examined] .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus arcuatus Reinhard, 1867: 353. Syntype cf , GERMANY (MNHU) [examined]. Syn. n.<tei:lb/>Earinus zonatus Marshall, 1885: 268. Syntypes, GREAT BRITAIN (lost). [Synonymised by Lyle, 1920: 184.]<tei:lb/>Agathis conspicua (Wesmael) Muesebeck &amp; Walkley, 1951: 119.<tei:lb/>Microdus conspicuus Wesmael; Tobias, 19766: 98.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf $, 5-0-5-5 mm long (excluding ovipositor). Black; greater part of gaster bright reddish yellow. Legs<tei:lb/>almost entirely reddish yellow; hind coxa black; hind femur entirely reddish yellow. Antenna of 9 pale<tei:lb/>beneath on more than basal half. In the male, base of tergites 2+3 sometimes with a blackened patch, and<tei:lb/>three apical tergites may also be darkened.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9- Head in facial view strongly transverse. Third segment of labial palpus hardly discernible. Antenna<tei:lb/>with 34-35 segments. Notaulices deeply impressed throughout. Sternaulus rugose. Propodeum usually<tei:lb/>with two discernible keels but these usually obscured by coarse rugosities. Radius of fore- wing markedly<tei:lb/>bent inwards towards stigma and here tending to be colourless (Fig. 61); areolet sharply triangular and<tei:lb/>often with conspicuous stalk. Outer side of middle tibia in apical half with group of 5-8 thick teeth; inner<tei:lb/>spur of hind tibia not quite reaching middle of basal segment of hind tarsus. Gaster as in tumidulus. Tergite<tei:lb/>1 about 1-33 times longer than its apical width; finely, evenly striate all over, the surface appearing very<tei:lb/>shiny; basal half of tergites 2+3 sometimes with traces of fine rugose-striation tending to be concentric<tei:lb/>around the feebly raised, transverse, basal swelling. Apical sternite (hypopygium) evenly pointed at apex.<tei:lb/>Ovipositor sheaths a little shorter than body.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Gaster somewhat darker than in female. Sometimes eye-orbits, both on inner side and temples, paler<tei:lb/>in colour.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Belgium, Finland, France, Great Britain, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Sweden, Switzerland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Shenefelt (1970) lists the following: Conchy Us nitidulana Zeller (?? Gypsonoma nitidulana Lienig<tei:lb/>&amp; Zeller) (Tortricidae); Pammene regiana (Zeller) (Tortricidae); Cydia molesta Busck (Tortricidae), a</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>226 G. E. J. NIXON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>species which, according to Meyrick (1968: 590) has been introduced into North America, Australia and<tei:lb/>Europe.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bred specimens from Cydia pomonella (L.), Pammene regiana (Zeller) and Rhopobota ustomaculana<tei:lb/>(Curtis) (all Tortricidae) have been examined. It seems that Tortricidae are the main, if not the only, hosts.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This species has some economic importance because of its parasitism on Cydia pomonella the<tei:lb/>Codling moth. As a species it is chiefly characterised by its bright colour and bent radius. Nevertheless, it<tei:lb/>bears a strong superficial resemblance to zaykovi but the latter has a differently shaped head, both in facial<tei:lb/>view and profile.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microdus zaykovisp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf 9, 4-5-5-0 mm (excluding ovipositor). Black. Gaster, except for 1st tergite, reddish yellow but surface<tei:lb/>becoming slightly infuscate on posterior half in the paratype. Hind coxa black; hind femur red; hind tibia<tei:lb/>hardly paler than hind femur and faintly darkened only at extreme apex. Wings deeply infuscate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9. Head in facial view like that of linguarius (cf. Fig. 32); in lateral view, hind margin of head deeply<tei:lb/>hollowed out at a point level with lowest point of eye; in same view of head, cheeks behind markedly<tei:lb/>angled. Surface between antennal sockets virtually flat; no trace of a projection on inner side of antennal<tei:lb/>socket as in linguarius. Antennal scrobes broader than in linguarius, reaching close to inner eye-margin and<tei:lb/>much closer to posterior ocellus. Posterior tangent to the anterior ocellus passing far in front of posterior<tei:lb/>pair in the paratype; almost touching them in the holotype. Mesoscutum and notaulices of ordinary form.<tei:lb/>Sternaulus reaching middle of mesopleurum. Radius of fore-wing slightly more strongly curved inwards<tei:lb/>towards stigma than in linguarius, with stigma more narrowed towards apex and radial cell slightly longer<tei:lb/>than in that species. Outer side of middle tibia with one tooth at extreme apex in holotype, just behind the<tei:lb/>2-3 closely spaced teeth at the edge; no preapical teeth in the paratype; hind tarsus with apical lobe smaller<tei:lb/>than in linguarius, the claw itself hence appearing longer and less curved. Gaster rather short and broad;<tei:lb/>tergite 1 considerably widened towards apex, about 1-25 times longer than its apical width; on posterior<tei:lb/>half almost smooth and polished in the two females available. Hypopygium not emarginate at apex and in<tei:lb/>profile angled at about 60 degrees. Ovipositor sheath much shorter than in linguarius, hardly as long as<tei:lb/>thorax and gaster combined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Like the female in all essential details but apical half of gaster blackened. In one of the two paratypes,<tei:lb/>there is a large pale oblong spot behind the eye (much as in tumidulus). Colour probably variable.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Bulgaria: Rhodope, Nikolovo, 19.viii.1976 (Zaykov) (ZC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Bulgaria: 1 $, Rhodopi, 'h.Ruen', 29.vii.1960 (A. Germanov) (BMNH); 1 cf, Nikolovo,<tei:lb/>15.viii.1976 (Zaykov) (ZC); 1 cf , Bojno, 24.vii.1975 (Zaykov) (ZC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. The most characteristic feature of this very dark-winged species is the hollowing out of the back<tei:lb/>of the head when this is seen in profile. In colour it bears a superficial resemblance to conspicuus under<tei:lb/>which the differences are pointed out.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EAjR/M/SWesmael</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Earinus Wesmael, 1837: 8. Type-species: Microdus nitidulus Nees von Esenbeck (= elator (Fabricius)), by<tei:lb/>subsequent designation (Muesebeck &amp; Walkley, 1951: 116).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Head in facial view not lengthened, like that of Microdus. Third segment of labial palpus<tei:lb/>virtually twice as long as wide. Ocelli in low triangle; posterior tangent to anterior ocellus cutting posterior<tei:lb/>pair. Notaulices absent but mesoscutum behind with elongate furrow. Sternaulus absent. First discoidal<tei:lb/>cell separated from 1st cubital cell by a fully pigmented, sclerotised vein; areolet of fore- wing 4-sided.<tei:lb/>Outer side of middle tibia with row of 4-6 teeth; outer side of front tibia with at least one tooth.<tei:lb/>Metasternum behind not completely surrounding hind coxal insertion. Ovipositor in the three species<tei:lb/>under consideration not longer than gaster plus propodeum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species (females)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Head and thorax densely hairy; face strongly, conspicuously punctate, somewhat flattened on<tei:lb/>each side of a broad, longitudinal ridge; mesoscutum usually black but sometimes reddened</tei:p>
         <tei:p>elator (Fabricius) (p. 227)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Head and thorax with ordinary pubescence; face shiny and at most with fine punctation; a</tei:p>
         <tei:p>longitudinal, facial ridge hardly indicated 2</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Earinus elator (Fabricius)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus elator Fabricius, 1804: 128. Lectotype d" , AUSTRIA (ZM), designated by Fitton, 1985 [examined].<tei:lb/>Microdus nitidulus Nees von Esenbeck, 1814: 187. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost). Syn. n.<tei:lb/>Microdus thoracicus Nees von Esenbeck, 1834: 143. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost). Syn. n.<tei:lb/>Earinus nitidulus (Nees von Esenbeck) Reinhard, 1867: 351.<tei:lb/>Earinus thoracicus (Nees von Esenbeck) Shenefelt, 1970: 407.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>O" $ , 7-8 mm long (excluding ovipositor).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$ . Black but mesoscutum sometimes reddened. Legs entirely red except for infuscate hind tarsi. At least<tei:lb/>the two apical segments of maxillary palpus yellowish.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head characteristically clothed with long pubescence. Face conspicuously punctate, the punctures<tei:lb/>tending to be separated by slightly less than their diameter. Antennal sockets united on inner side to form a<tei:lb/>raised, hump-like area, densely punctate. Scrobes with some rugose-punctation. Antenna with 36-40<tei:lb/>segments. Thorax densely hairy. Mesoscutum sharply, distinctly punctate. Mesopleurum closely, sharply<tei:lb/>punctate, thickly pubescent over almost entire surface. Propodeum at middle with 2-3 very irregular,<tei:lb/>longitudinal keels; surface on each side of keels tends to be smooth and polished. Areolet of fore-wing<tei:lb/>subquadrate, large, frequently with extra vein in form of stub arising from middle of outer side of 2nd<tei:lb/>cubital vein; distal abscissa of postmarginalis about 0-5 times as long as proximal abscissa. Outer side of<tei:lb/>middle tibia with 3-4 teeth arranged in row; front tibia with 4-5 teeth along outer side; inner spur of hind<tei:lb/>tibia slightly less than half as long as basal segment of hind tarsus. Gaster, except for tergite 1 which is<tei:lb/>vaguely rugose-punctate to rugose-striate, highly polished and only very sparsely hairy; ventral surface and<tei:lb/>laterotergites by contrast thickly hairy. Ovipositor sheaths about as long as gaster plus propodeum, densely<tei:lb/>beset with thick, bristle-like setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Like female except for sexual differences.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Austria: 2 d 1 (including lectotype), Fabricius coll. (ZM), Germany: 3 d", 2 &lt;j&gt;, Ruthe coll. (BMNH); 2 $,<tei:lb/>Celle, 23. v. 1942 (BMNH). Perkins) (BMNH); 2<tei:lb/>$, Newton Abbott, 28.iv.1928 (R. C. L. Perkins) (BMNH); 1 $, Tiverton (F. H. Lyon) (BMNH); 2 $,<tei:lb/>Hertfordshire, Brickett Wood, 24.iv.1948 (R. B. Benson) (BMNH), 1 cf, Aldbury, 2.iv.l949 (R. B.<tei:lb/>Benson) (BMNH) ; 2 $ , Lancashire , nr Nutford , Hawes Wood , ex Agrochola circellaris (Hufnagel) in Salix<tei:lb/>catkins, coll. 7.iv.l977, em. 19.iii.1978 (M. Shaw) (MS); 1 cf, Shropshire, Church Stretton (D. K.<tei:lb/>Mckevan) (BMNH); 8 cf , 5 $ , Surrey, Salfords, beaten from privet (Ligustrum), 15.iii.1981 (A. A. Allen)<tei:lb/>(AA; BMNH); 1 Cf , 3 $ , Sussex, Plaistow, King's Park Wood, ex Agrochola lota Clerk on Salix caprea,<tei:lb/>coll. 20.V.1978, em. 19.iv.1979 (M. Shaw) (MS); 1 &lt;j&gt;, Sussex (no other loc.), ex Orthosia xerampelina<tei:lb/>Hiibner (BMNH); 2 $, Lothian, Edinburgh, 16.iv.1981 (BMNH). Ireland: 1 cf, Dublin, Glenasmole,<tei:lb/>5.iv.l936 (Stelfox) (USNM); 1 cf, Wicklow, Glencullen, 25.iii.1932 (Stelfox) (USNM). Sweden: 2 $,<tei:lb/>Skane, 28-30.iv.1938 (Perkins) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Agrochola circellaris (Hufnagel); Agrochola lota Clerck on Salix caprea; Atethmia centrago<tei:lb/>(Haworth) (all Noctuidae). The stout cocoon of the parasite is barrel-shaped, white, papery. All the above<tei:lb/>records indicate that elator is single-brooded and occurs from March to May.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This is a very distinct species on account of its unusual hairiness and the thick setae of the<tei:lb/>female ovipositor sheaths. Females with a red mesoscutum are particularly easy to recognise.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Earinus gloriatorius (Panzer)<tei:lb/>(Figs 67, 68)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>designated [examined]. Syn. n.<tei:lb/>Microdus tuberculatus Wesmael, 1837: 13. LECTOTYPE $ , BELGIUM: Brussels, Wesmael coll. (IRSNB),</tei:p>
         <tei:p>here designated [examined]. Syn. n.<tei:lb/>Agathis bicingulatus Thomson, 1895: 2234. LECTOTYPE $, SWEDEN: Ortofta, Thomson coll. (ZI), here</tei:p>

         <tei:p>C? $ , ca 5 mm (excluding ovipositor).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Black. Hind coxa almost always red, sometimes bicoloured, rarely entirely black; hind tibia<tei:lb/>sometimes yellowish with infuscate apex and infuscate basal ring; more often reddish throughout. Face<tei:lb/>smooth, shining, rarely with traces of punctation towards antennal insertions. Antennal scrobes polished,<tei:lb/>smooth. Antenna with 32-36 segments. Mesoscutum with only moderately thick pubescence. Virtually no<tei:lb/>trace of notaulices but usually mesoscutum with a longitudinal furrow posteriorly. Prepectal margin almost<tei:lb/>obliterated medially. Propodeum on the whole smooth, shining and with two longitudinal keels of variable<tei:lb/>strength; lateral panels sparsely hairy. Areolet of fore-wing always distinctly 4-sided; usually somewhat<tei:lb/>narrowed towards stigma (Figs 67, 68); rarely more obviously quadrate and with an accessory vein arising<tei:lb/>from middle of outside of 2nd transverse cubitus as in elator. Claws of hind tarsus more strongly bent than<tei:lb/>in elator and with deeper lobe; middle tibia with 3-4 teeth on outer side; fore tibia with 3-4 teeth on outer<tei:lb/>side . Tergite 1 about 1-33 times longer than its apical width ; vaguely sculptured on apical half but sculpture<tei:lb/>varying much in intensity. Tergites 2+3 with variable sculpture; at base usually with a more or less distinct,<tei:lb/>transversely triangular area that is slightly raised and generally smooth and shining; distal to this area and<tei:lb/>as far as second suture, the amount of sculpture is highly variable; sometimes it appears as fine rugosity,<tei:lb/>sometimes as rugose-striation; sometimes whole of tergites 2+3 entirely smooth. Ovipositor sheath about<tei:lb/>as long as gaster plus propodeum; its setae much less thickened than in elator and, towards apex, shorter,<tei:lb/>finer and more adpressed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Like female except for sexual differences.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Belgium, Germany, Great Britain, Holland, Hungary, Ireland, Sweden, Switzerland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST. Agonopteryx ciliella (Stainton) or Agonopteryx heradiana (L.) (Oecophoridae) on Angelica<tei:lb/>sylvestrisL. (MS).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Earinus gloriatorius is an abundant species but shows a confusing variation in the colour of the<tei:lb/>hind legs and the rugosity of the gaster. Like elator, with which it could not be confused, it occurs in spring.<tei:lb/>Wesmael's three species synonymised above and about whose separate validity he had some misgivings are<tei:lb/>recorded by him as having been captured towards the end of April.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Earinus transversus Lyle</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Earinus transversus Lyle, 1920: 249. LECTOTYPE $; GREAT BRITAIN (Dale) (UM), here designated<tei:lb/>[examined] .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$, 6-5 mm long (excluding ovipositor). Black. Hind coxa and hind femur red; hind tibia bright yellow,<tei:lb/>deeply infuscate in apical third and with faint post-basal infuscate spot; hind tarsus deeply infuscate<tei:lb/>throughout.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Face smooth, shining, finely punctate. Antennal scrobes polished. Antenna with 38 segments. Pubesc-<tei:lb/>ence of mesoscutum thicker than in gloriatorius but less so than in elator. Mesoscutum with some vague,<tei:lb/>indistinct punctation. No trace of notaulices. Propodeum shorter than in gloriatorius, with denser<tei:lb/>pubescence, more even and somewhat characteristically directed backwards; lateral panels appearing<tei:lb/>duller because of fine punctation. Areolet of fore-wing markedly 4-sided, narrowed towards stigma. Front<tei:lb/>tibia with a single tooth on outer side; middle tibia with 3 teeth on outer side; hind claw much as in elator,<tei:lb/>less bent than in gloriatorius . Tergite 1 about 1-25 times longer than its apical width, with shining, indefinite<tei:lb/>sculpture much as in gloriatorius. Tergites 2+3 shining, with rather coarse, variable rugosity extending<tei:lb/>virtually to apex of segment; at base with weakly defined, transverse, subtriangular area. Ovipositor sheath<tei:lb/>0-66 times as long as gaster, beset with bristly hairs, thicker than in gloriatorius and almost as thick as those<tei:lb/>of elator.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>BAEOGNATHA Kokujev</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Baeognatha Kokujev, 1903: 243. Type-species: Baeognatha turanica Kokujev, by monotypy.<tei:lb/>CamptothlipsisEnderlein, 1920: 166. Type-species: Camp tothlipsiscostalisEnder\ein, by original designa-<tei:lb/>tion. [Synonymised by Tobias, 1976a: 214.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Head in facial view like that of Microdus, transversely elliptical. Surface between antennal<tei:lb/>insertions slightly raised in the form of a weak hump or tubercle in longitudinal direction or simply rounded<tei:lb/>from back to front. Mouth parts not lengthened. Notaulices distinct throughout. Sternaulus very distinct.<tei:lb/>Outer side of middle tibia with at least 2 teeth remote from apical margin; inner spur of hind tibia not<tei:lb/>reaching middle of basal segment of hind tarsus; claws lobed. Areolet of fore-wing open (Fig. 60). Tergite 1<tei:lb/>and basal half of tergites 2+3 with or without sculpture. Ovipositor at least as long as gaster.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The genus is typically Microdus-like in habitus but differs essentially in that the 2nd submarginal cell is<tei:lb/>not closed externally by a vein (r-rri) so that an areolet is absent. Microdus eriphyle approaches Baeognatha<tei:lb/>in the kind of sculpture on the basal tergites of the gaster.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species (females)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Ovipositor sheath about as long as gaster; basal segment of hind tarsus slightly shorter than</tei:p>
         <tei:p>following segments together; hind femur blackish nigra Telenga (p. 230)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Ovipositor sheath about as long as body; basal segment of hind tarsus distinctly longer than</tei:p>
         <tei:p>following segments together; hind femur bright yellow armeniaca Telenga (p. 229)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Baeognatha armeniaca Telenga</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 60)<tei:lb/>Baeognatha armeniaca Telenga, 1955: 300. Holotype $, U.S.S.R.: Armenia (AS) [not examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$, 4 mm long (excluding ovipositor). Head mainly bright yellowish. Thorax variable in colour but with<tei:lb/>much pale marking; sometimes only mesoscutum and pronotum pale with rest of thorax infuscate. Gaster<tei:lb/>varying from entirely reddish yellow (except tergite 1) to almost black. Legs bright reddish yellow except<tei:lb/>for hind coxa which may show darkening at base. Wings virtually hyaline; medius colourless proximal to<tei:lb/>basalis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head in facial view transverse, only very weakly narrowed towards mouth. Face smooth, shining.<tei:lb/>Between antennal sockets a smooth, blunt keel. Preapical segment (3rd) of labial palpus very small, hardly<tei:lb/>longer than wide. Ocelli in rather low triangle with posterior tangent to anterior ocellus virtually touching<tei:lb/>posterior pair. Notaulices deeply impressed throughtout. Sternaulus deeply impressed, reaching posterior<tei:lb/>corner of mesopleurum. Propodeum coarsely rugose-reticulate with only the faintest indication of two<tei:lb/>broken, longitudinal keels. Distal abscissa of postmarginalis about 1-5 times longer than proximal abscissa<tei:lb/>(Fig. 60). Outer side of middle tibia with 1-2 teeth at middle and two close teeth at apex; inner spur of hind<tei:lb/>tibia not quite reaching middle of basal segment of hind tarsus; basal segment of hind tarsus distinctly<tei:lb/>longer than remaining segments together, 6:5; claws small, with large, basal lobe. Tergite 1 about twice as<tei:lb/>long as apically wide, with a dull, even sculpture of scaly-reticulation, the surface having almost a<tei:lb/>shagreened appearance with only a few weak, longitudinal ridges towards sides. Basal half of tergites 2+3<tei:lb/>with a sculpture similar to that of tergite 1 but weaker and more vague; rest of gaster polished, shining.<tei:lb/>Ovipositor sheath about as long as body, less head.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Austria: 1 $, Neusiedlersee, 20.viii.1960 (G. J. Kerrich) (BMNH). Turkey: 1 $, Ankara, Kavaklidere,<tei:lb/>6.viii.l960 (Guichard &amp; Harvey) (BMNH). U.S.S.R.: 3 $, ? Armenia, exAnarsia eleagnella Kuznetzov<tei:lb/>(AS; one in BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Anarsia eleagnella Kuznetzov (Gelechiidae); Cydiafunebrana Treitschke (Tortricidae) ; Recurvar-<tei:lb/>ia nanella (Denis &amp; Schiffermiiller) (Gelechiidae). It<tei:lb/>differs from the more eastern specimens in being a little larger and much darker in colour, the head being<tei:lb/>mainly reddish yellow with darkened occiput and a dark patch in the middle of the face; the thorax and</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>

         <tei:p>230 G. E. J. NIXON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>gaster above are entirely blackened and the hind coxa is pale only on the apical third; the relation between<tei:lb/>length of basal segment of hind tarsus and combined length of remaining segments has not been checked<tei:lb/>because the legs are broken.<tei:lb/>The specific differences between armeniaca and nigra have been given in the key.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Baeognatha nigra Telenga</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Baeognatha nigra Telenga, 1955: 300. Syntypes &lt;j&gt;, U.S.S.R. (AS) [not examined].<tei:lb/>The interpretation of this species is based on a single female , identified by Tobias and borrowed from him.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$, 3 mm long (excluding ovipositor). Black. Inner orbits brownish yellow, the yellow colour reaching<tei:lb/>antennal sockets. Hind femur infuscate; hind tibia infuscate on apical third, with faint, dark ring near base;<tei:lb/>hind coxa blackish.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head in facial view slightly more narrowed below than in armeniaca. Face smooth, shining. Between<tei:lb/>antennal sockets a smooth, blunt ridge as in armeniaca. In dorsal view head slightly less transverse than in<tei:lb/>armeniaca. Antenna broken in both examples. Notaulices and sternaulus as in armeniaca. Radial cell<tei:lb/>slightly narrower than in armeniaca; distal abscissa of postmarginalis only slightly longer than proximal<tei:lb/>abscissa. Teeth of middle tibia and spur of hind tibia as in armeniaca; basal segment of hind tarsus slightly<tei:lb/>shorter than following segments together, 9:11. Gaster slightly less elongate than in armeniaca but<tei:lb/>sculpture of tergite 1 and basal half of tergites 2+3 similar, though that on tergites 2+3 is sharper and better<tei:lb/>defined than in armeniaca and the curved furrow is slightly deeper and more distinct. Ovipositor as long as<tei:lb/>gaster.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>U.S.S.R.: 1 $, Kazachstan, Urals, Ganvartsjevo (AS). France: 2 $, Mulhouse, Bois de Nonnenbruch,<tei:lb/>vi.1977, ex larvae of Coleophora ? flavipennella (Duponchel) on Quercus (S. E. Whitbread) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Coleophora ? flavipennella (Duponchel). The cocoon of the parasite is spun within the case of the<tei:lb/>host.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The distributional data on this species are scant but suggest that Baeognatha nigra is widespread.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Species inquirendae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type-material of the following species is not available for examination.<tei:lb/>Microdus abbreviator Ratzeburg, 1852: 45.<tei:lb/>Microdus brevicaudis Reinhard, 1867: 356.<tei:lb/>Microdus cingulator Ratzeburg, 1852: 46.<tei:lb/>Agathis initiator Fonscolombe, 1846: 40.<tei:lb/>Vipio insularis Snellen van Vollenhoven, 1873: 192.<tei:lb/>Agathis major Fonscolombe, 1846: 39.<tei:lb/>Ichneumon purgatorFabricius, 1793: 156.</tei:p>

      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>Occasional Papers on Systematic Entomology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>New Series</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The economic importance of insects, and the enormous number of species, have resulted in a<tei:lb/>vast literature written in many languages; that which is of direct economic importance and<tei:lb/>recently published can, to an increasing extent, be searched by using computerized data bases,<tei:lb/>but a great amount of more general information is unlikely to be available so readily in the<tei:lb/>near future. The objective of this new occasional series is to make available in hard copy some<tei:lb/>of the basic data that is essential to the preparation of comprehensive accounts of the world<tei:lb/>insect fauna. The papers have been fully researched bibliographically and consist of checklists<tei:lb/>of nominal taxa, and faunal lists with information on host plants and localities, based mainly<tei:lb/>on the collections and libraries of the British Museum (Natural History).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>No. 1. Catalogue of the Neotropical Tiger-moths.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A. Watson &amp; D. T. Goodger</tei:p>
         <tei:p>72pp. inc. 4 colour plates 27 February 1986</tei:p>
         <tei:p>No. 2. An annotated checklist of the Carabidae (including Cicindelinae, Rhysodinae and</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paussinae) recorded from Borneo.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>N. E. Stork</tei:p>
         <tei:p>26pp . , 1 map 27 March 1 986</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Bulletin of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A key to the Afrotropical genera of<tei:lb/>Eucoilidae (Hymenoptera) , with a<tei:lb/>revision of certain genera</tei:p>
         <tei:p>J. Quinlan</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Entomology series</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vol 52 No 4 26 June 1986</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>The Bulletin of the British Museum (Natural History), instituted in 1949, is issued in four<tei:lb/>scientific series, Botany, Entomology, Geology (incorporating Mineralogy) and Zoology,<tei:lb/>and an Historical series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Papers in the Bulletin are primarily the results of research carried out on the unique and<tei:lb/>ever-growing collections of the Museum, both by the scientific staff of the Museum and by<tei:lb/>specialists from elsewhere who make use of the Museum's resources. Many of the papers are<tei:lb/>works of reference that will remain indispensable for years to come.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parts are published at irregular intervals as they become ready, each is complete in itself,<tei:lb/>available separately, and individually priced. Volumes contain about 300 pages and several<tei:lb/>volumes may appear within a calendar year. Subscriptions may be placed for one or more of<tei:lb/>the series on either an Annual or Per Volume basis. Prices vary according to the contents of<tei:lb/>the individual parts. Orders and enquiries should be sent to:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Publications Sales,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History),<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>London SW75BD,<tei:lb/>England.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>World List abbreviation: Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Ent.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trustees of the British Museum (Natural History), 1986</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Entomology series is produced under the general editorship of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Keeper of Entomology: Laurence A. Mound</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Assistant Editor: W. Gerald Tremewan</tei:p>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p>ISBN 565 06018 X<tei:lb/>ISSN 0524-6431</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road<tei:lb/>London SW7 5BD</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Entomology series<tei:lb/>Vol 52 No 4 pp 243-366</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Issued 26 June 1986</tei:p>

      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A key to the Afrotropical genera of Eucoilidae<tei:lb/>(Hymenoptera), with a revision of certain genera</tei:p>
         <tei:p>J. Quintan</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Department of Entomology, British Museum (Natural History), Cromwell Road, London<tei:lb/>SW7 5BD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contents</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis 243</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction 243</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Material examined and terminology 244</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Depositories 244</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Affinities of Eucoilidae with other Cynipoidea 245</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxonomic characters 246</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The generic classification of Eucoilidae and discussion of relationships 247</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Checklist of the Afrotropical Eucoilidae included in this paper 249</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eucoilidae Thomson 250</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to the genera of Afrotropical Eucoilidae 250</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Afrodontasp Weld 253</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cothonaspis Hartig 255</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ealatagen.n 257</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eucoilidea Ashmead 259</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hexacola Foerster 272</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Kleidotoma Westwood 280</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nordlanderia gen . n 288</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rhoptromeris Foerster 290</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stentorceps Quinlan 309</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TrichoplastaEenoit 310</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements 322</tei:p>
         <tei:p>References 322</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Index... 365</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A key to the 19 genera of Afrotropical Eucoilidae is provided, together with keys to the species of ten<tei:lb/>genera. Two genera (Ealata, Nordlanderia) and 98 species are newly described; the primary types of eight<tei:lb/>nominal species have been examined, of which two are newly synonymized. A checklist of the ten genera<tei:lb/>and 111 species dealt with is included.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The virtually cosmopolitan family Eucoilidae is one of the largest and most distinctive groups of<tei:lb/>Cynipoidea. These small, mostly blackish insects are easily recognizable by the presence of a<tei:lb/>highly modified scutellum (Fig. 2) . They occur wherever their dipteran hosts are found. As far as<tei:lb/>is known (and the biology of many species has never been investigated) eucoilids are protelean<tei:lb/>endoparasites of the larvae and puparia of cyclorrhaphous Diptera. A number of species attack<tei:lb/>various phytophagous Diptera in the families Agromyzidae, Anthomyiidae, Chloropidae,<tei:lb/>Drosophilidae and Tephritidae (Thompson, 1955), families that include a variety of serious<tei:lb/>agricultural pests. Consequently several eucoilids are of considerable economic importance as<tei:lb/>potential biological control agents. A number of species in the genera Hexacola, Trybliographa,<tei:lb/>Rhoptromeris, Kleidotoma and Ganaspidium are of interest since they parasitize species of</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bull. Br. Mus. not. Hist. (Ent.) 52 (4): 243-366 Issued 26 June 1986</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>244 J. QUINLAN</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Liriomyza, Oscinella and Hylemyia which attack cereal and related crops. Trybliographa dad<tei:lb/>Weld is parasitic on the oriental fruit-fly (Dacus dorsalis Hendel) which is a well-known pest of a<tei:lb/>variety of fruit and vegetable crops. Probably the most extensively studied eucoilid is Tryblio-<tei:lb/>grapha rapae, a common parasite of Hylemyia species which attack brassicas (Wishart &amp;<tei:lb/>Monteith, 1954). In Europe Rhoptromeris heptoma (Hartig) is an important parasite of the frit<tei:lb/>fly (Oscinella frit (L.)) (Nordlander, 19786).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A variety of other species of Eucoilidae attack dipterous larvae inhabiting dung and carcasses,<tei:lb/>including species of the families Calliphoridae, Muscidae, Sepsidae and Sphaeroceridae<tei:lb/>(Thompson, 1955). For example, the European eucoilid Kleidotoma marshalli Cameron is<tei:lb/>known to parasitize larvae of a variety of Calliphora, Lucilia and Musca species, whilst Eutrias<tei:lb/>tritoma (Thomson) has been reared in the U.S.A. from sepsid puparia in cow dung (Weld,<tei:lb/>1952).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Various authors have published papers on the Afrotropical Eucoilidae: Benoit (1956),<tei:lb/>Bridwell (1919), Cameron (1904), Hedicke (19280, 19286), Kieffer (1919, 1913), Masner (I960)<tei:lb/>and Risbec (1950, 1956). Some have described new genera and species, others only species.<tei:lb/>Apart from Kieffer (1910) and Weld (1952), who give keys to genera on a world basis, no one has<tei:lb/>attempted to key genera and species of the Afrotropical Eucoilidae. During the preparation of<tei:lb/>this paper all available type-material has been examined and redescribed. When type-material<tei:lb/>of a taxon was not available its presumed taxonomic position is discussed in the text. A key to the<tei:lb/>genera of Afrotropical Eucoilidae is given and ten of these genera are revised with keys to<tei:lb/>species; two genera and 98 species are described as new. One genus, Stentorceps, is included in a<tei:lb/>generic key for the first time. A further nine genera remain to be revised.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Material examined and terminology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I have been fortunate to have on loan large amounts of material from Dr J. Decelle, Musee<tei:lb/>Royal de 1'Afrique Centrale, Tervuren. This material, together with R. E. Turner's collection<tei:lb/>and other more recently obtained specimens (principally from Malaise traps) in the British<tei:lb/>Museum (Natural History), has formed the basis for this revision. Very large areas of the<tei:lb/>Afrotropical region remain from which material has not been available for examination. In very<tei:lb/>few instances are host data given and then only from the labels attached to the specimens. The<tei:lb/>terminology follows Richards (1977) but some older names are used, particularly in reference to<tei:lb/>wing venation. I have, where pertinent, related older terminology to the more recently<tei:lb/>introduced terminology of Nordlander (19826). The term Afrotropical Region used in this<tei:lb/>paper was coined by Crosskey &amp; White (1977) but was not employed in my earlier paper of 1979.<tei:lb/>Figures 1 and 2 have their respective parts labelled in abbreviated form, as follows:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>anterior parallel lines - apl; hairy ring - hr; hypopygium - hy; lateral bar - Ib; lateral lines - 11;<tei:lb/>lateral ridges - Ir; mesoscutum - m; mesopleurae - mp; mesopleural suture - mps; malar ridge -<tei:lb/>mr; metapleurae - mt; notaulices - nt; nucha - nu; propodeum - pd; pronotal plate - pp;<tei:lb/>pronotum - pr; scutellum - sc; scutellar cup - sec; scutellar disc - scd; scutellar foveae - sf;<tei:lb/>tegulae - tg.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The following terms are used for the lines or furrows on the mesoscutum, anterior parallel lines,<tei:lb/>notaulices and lateral lines. Nordlander (1982) used the terms antero-admedian lines, notaulices<tei:lb/>and parapsidial furrows respectively.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Depositories</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type depositories are abbreviated in the text as follows.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BMNH British Museum (Natural History), London.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GERDAT Groupement D'Etudes et de Recherches pour le developpment de L' Agronomic Tropi-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>cale, Montpellier.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MNHN Museum National d'Histoire Naturelle, Paris.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MRAC Musee Royale de 1'Afrique Centrale, Tervuren.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NCISA National Collection of Insects, Division of Entomology, Pretoria.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL EUCOILIDAE 245</tei:p>
         <tei:p>USNM United States National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ZMC Zoologisk Museum, Copenhagen.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ZSBS Zoologische Sammlung des Bayerischen Staates, Munich.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Affinities of Eucoilidae with other Cynipoidea</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amongst the Cynipoidea many of the higher taxa are definable in terms of biological as well as<tei:lb/>structural differences. Known biologies may be summarized thus:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FAMILY-GROUP TAXON HOST</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ibaliidae Siricoidea (Chrystal, 1930; Spradberry, 1970)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Liopteridae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Oberthuerellinae Unknown</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Liopterinae Unknown</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mesocynipinae ? Cerambycidae (Diaz, 1973)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eucoilidae Cyclorrhaphous Diptera<tei:lb/>Figitidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figitinae Cyclorrhaphous Diptera (Askew, 1971)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Aspicerinae Syrphidae (Weld, 1952)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anacharitinae Hemerobioidea (Selhime &amp; Kanavel, 1968)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Himalocynipinae Unknown</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cynipidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cynipinae Phytophagous gall-causers and gall inquilines (Eady &amp; Quinlan, 1963)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Austrocynipinae Reared from seeds ofAraucaria (Araucariaceae) (Riek, 1971)<tei:lb/>Charipidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Alloxystinae Aphidiinae and Aphelinidae (as hyperparasites through Homoptera)<tei:lb/>(Quinlan &amp; Evenhuis, 1980)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Charipinae Psylloidea (Kierych, 1979)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Eucoilidae is distinguished from the five other families of Cynipoidea by the highly modified<tei:lb/>scutellum. This comprises an outer disc surmounted by a cup- or tear-drop-shaped elevation in<tei:lb/>the centre with a foveolate depression posteriorly. The family is apparently most closely related<tei:lb/>to the Figitidae which, except for the form of the scutellum, they resemble in structure. The two<tei:lb/>families have rather similar life-histories, in that most species are endoparasites of larvae and<tei:lb/>puparia of Cyclorrhaphous Diptera, although the morphologically distinctive Anacharitinae<tei:lb/>parasitize hemerobioid lacewing larvae (Selhime &amp; Kanavel, 1968; Lipkow, 1969). The<tei:lb/>Eucoilidae and Figitidae, together with the Cynipidae and Charipidae, have segments 2 and/or 3<tei:lb/>of the gaster enlarged, whilst the more posterior segments (4+) are the largest in other cynipoids<tei:lb/>(Quinlan, 1979). Tergite 1 is variable in shape from a long petiolate structure to an almost<tei:lb/>obscured crescent-shape, wider than long. The elongate petiolate form does not occur in the<tei:lb/>Cynipidae or Charipidae, but is found in the Eucoilidae and Figitidae. Males of most families<tei:lb/>have much less specialized gasters. Whilst the Eucoilidae are easily separated from other<tei:lb/>families by the form of the scutellum, some eucoilid genera do show apomorphic features<tei:lb/>exhibited by genera in other families. For example, a strongly indicated ring of hairs is present at<tei:lb/>the base of tergite 2 in many eucoilid genera (e.g., Trybliographa, Rhoptromeris and Kleido-<tei:lb/>toma), whilst a less conspicuous ring of hairs is found in certain genera of Cynipidae (e.g.,<tei:lb/>Aulacidea and the related genera Ay lax and Isocolus). A sparser ring of pubescence is also found<tei:lb/>in some Charipidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The plant-feeding habits of the Cynipidae are in contrast to the endoparasitic entomophagy of<tei:lb/>the Eucoilidae and Figitidae. At first sight, therefore, the shared characteristics of the gaster of<tei:lb/>these taxa would appear to be the result of convergence, though it is possible that the Cynipidae<tei:lb/>adapted to their herbivorous mode of life from a figitid ancestor consuming the larvae of leaf- or<tei:lb/>stem-mining Diptera.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>246 J. QUINLAN</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxonomic characters</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The female antenna is 13-segmented (occasionally 11, 12 or 14) and the overall shape is of<tei:lb/>importance, both at generic and specific level, but must be used in combination with other<tei:lb/>characters. Some species have filiform antenna, others are distinctly clavate. In those species<tei:lb/>with filiform antenna the term 'club' refers specifically to those apical segments of the antenna<tei:lb/>that bear rhinaria (Figs 229, 230), even though they may not appear swollen. In those species<tei:lb/>with clavate antenna the club is very clearly swollen as well as each segment having rhinaria (Figs<tei:lb/>237, 256). The male antenna is 15-segmented, filiform and in some species the third or fourth<tei:lb/>segment is modified. This is of major importance at generic and specific level. The characters of<tei:lb/>the head have not been used to any great extent at the generic level although the sculpture of the<tei:lb/>occiput and the presence of striations around the malar area, the size and shape of the compound<tei:lb/>eye (the distance between them in relation to the height of an eye), the variation in the shape of<tei:lb/>the vertex viewed posteriorly, and the occipital carina are important, particularly at species<tei:lb/>level.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thorax</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The thorax (including the first abdominal segment of the propodeum, vide Richards, 1977) has<tei:lb/>many important characters. As mentioned above, the pronotal plate is extremely diverse in<tei:lb/>shape and form. The mesoscutum is invariably polished; notaulices, anterior parallel lines and<tei:lb/>lateral lines are either present, partially present or completely absent. Sometimes a line of hairs<tei:lb/>is present and replaces the notaulices. These structures are referred to under different names by<tei:lb/>Nordlander (19826). The mesopleuron exhibits a wide variety of shapes and in the majority of<tei:lb/>genera the mesopleural carina or suture is present, either partly or completely. This structure<tei:lb/>has also been referred to as the mesopleural furrow (Eady &amp; Quinlan, 1963). In some genera the<tei:lb/>subalar pit is very distinct whilst it is absent in others. The metapleuron varies in the number of<tei:lb/>transverse ridges present and in some species an anteroventral cavity is present, either with or<tei:lb/>without setae. The scutellum viewed dorsally comprises a central plate and an outer margin,<tei:lb/>'cup' and 'disc' of earlier authors, termed scutellar plate and dorsal surface of the scutellum<tei:lb/>respectively by Nordlander (19826). As indicated earlier, the cup varies in size and shape and in<tei:lb/>the number of foveae (if any) present around the outer margins. In most genera a single large<tei:lb/>fovea is present medially on the apical half of the cup. The scutellar disc is variable in both dorsal<tei:lb/>and, in some genera, lateral views, its surface is sometimes smooth and polished or in others a<tei:lb/>variety of sculpture is present. The shape of the scutellar disc at the apex is either rounded,<tei:lb/>conical or spine-shaped; in a few genera the apex is bicuspid. Many earlier authors have placed<tei:lb/>those species with a conical or spine-shaped scutellar disc in the same genera without regard to<tei:lb/>more fundamental characters. The propodeum in dorsal view invariably has carinae varying in<tei:lb/>shape and alignment to each other, with varying densities of sculpture medially, and pubescence<tei:lb/>on either side of the carinae. The nucha at the posterior end of the propodeum is obscure but<tei:lb/>generally ridged.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gaster</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The gaster comprises eight segments and has spiracles on segments 1 and 8 (Richards, 1977).<tei:lb/>The number of segments visible in lateral view varies from genus to genus. Segment 1 of the<tei:lb/>gaster is short, about as broad as long, normally smooth or crenulate, except for a few<tei:lb/>Neotropical genera in which it is long and narrow, in some cases longer than the combined<tei:lb/>lengths of the remaining segments. The second segment is always the largest, generally as large<tei:lb/>as the remaining visible segments combined. In some genera the base of the second tergite has a<tei:lb/>ring of pubescence obscuring the first tergite, either in lateral view or completely on the dorsal<tei:lb/>surface as well. The overall shape of the gaster is variable within genera and it is laterally<tei:lb/>compressed to a lesser or greater extent. The hypopygium of the female is moderately to</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL EUCOILIDAE 247</tei:p>
         <tei:p>strongly projecting. The legs vary little within the Eucqilidae except that the size ratio of coxae,<tei:lb/>femora, tibiae and tarsi varies from species to species. In some genera the presence of hair<tei:lb/>patches on the mid-coxae has proved to be of value at species level (Nordlander, 1982a).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wings</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The venation of the fore wing of Cynipoidea has been used extensively at family, generic and<tei:lb/>specific level. Earlier authors gave much emphasis, particularly with eucoilids, to the radial cell,<tei:lb/>placing great reliance on whether it was closed or open on the wing margin. In many instances it<tei:lb/>is hard to decide one way or the other, the venation being vestigial (Day, 1984), having linear<tei:lb/>convexity in dorsal view, being concave ventrally, thus showing no clear or distinct longitudinal<tei:lb/>boundary when viewed with transmitted light, being only pigmented and not sclerotised.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Size</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The overall size of Eucoilidae varies from genus to genus, ranging from 1-5-5-0 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The generic classification of Eucoilidae and discussion of relationships</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Earlier authors (Dalla Torre &amp; Kieffer, 1910; Weld, 1952) tried to delimit genera on superficial<tei:lb/>characters, such as the radial cell being either open or closed, the presence or absence of a ring of<tei:lb/>hairs at the base of tergite two of the gaster, the scutellum either with or without a spine on the<tei:lb/>apical margin or the apex rounded, truncate, "conical or emarginate. This resulted in an<tei:lb/>assemblage of genera containing species not necessarily related to each other.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nordlander (19826) in his phylogenetic classification of the Eucoilidae, recognised 28 valid<tei:lb/>genera which he divided into the following monophyletic groups.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1. Gronotoma-group comprising Zaeucoila, Gronotoma, Diglyphosema, Disorygma, Micro-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>stilba.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2. Trybliographa-group comprising Trybliographa, Eucoila, Bothrochacis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3. Rhoptromeris-group comprising Leptopilina, Cothonaspis, Rhoptromeris, Trichoplasta.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4. Chrestosema-group comprising Chrestosema, Glauraspidia, Pseudopsichacra, Odon-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>teucoila, Dieucoila, Leptolamina.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5. Ganaspis-group comprising Ganaspis, Tetramerocera, Paramiomoea, Pentamerocera,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coneucoela, Didyctium, Hexacola, Hypodiranchis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6. Kleidotoma-group comprising Eutrias, Kleidotoma.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>At present I recognise 19 of these genera as occurring in the Afrotropical region. It is impossible<tei:lb/>to elucidate Nordlander's generic parameters from his five papers sufficiently well to recognise<tei:lb/>generic relationships precisely. Quinlan (1978) established the significance of the pronotal plate<tei:lb/>at species level. In the present work further emphasis is placed on this feature at generic level,<tei:lb/>particularly as to whether or not the pronotal plate projects forward when viewed dorsally and<tei:lb/>laterally, and to the presence of either enclosed or open lateral foveae either side of the medial<tei:lb/>area of the plate. The present key to genera attempts to indicate the phylogenetic relationships.<tei:lb/>The genera Nordlanderia, Disorygma, Diglyphosema, Ealata and Eucoilidea all have a plesio-<tei:lb/>morphic form of pronotal plate, i.e. it does not project forward, being similar in many<tei:lb/>respects to that found in the Figitinae and the cynipine genera Aulacidea and Ay lax. Coupled<tei:lb/>with this form of pronotal plate, the base of tergite two of the gaster never has a ring of dense<tei:lb/>pubescence, at the most only a few sparse hairs on the lateral margins. The remaining genera,<tei:lb/>the majority, form a monophyletic group characterized by the apomorphic form of pronotal<tei:lb/>plate: In these genera the plate projects forward and is visible in dorsal and lateral view. Within<tei:lb/>this group, the genera Trichoplasta, Rhoptromeris and Stentorceps have the plate further<tei:lb/>modified, in that there is lateral fusion of the anterior and posterior parts so that the fovea either<tei:lb/>side of the pronotal plate are closed on the lateral margins (Figs 246, 351). Nordlander (1982a)<tei:lb/>was the first to draw attention to this shared character of Trichoplasta and Rhoptromeris. In<tei:lb/>some species of this group the medial bridge between the foveae is obscure or in the form of a</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>248 J. QUINLAN</tei:p>
         <tei:p>transverse groove (Fig. 250). Stentorceps differs remarkably from Trichoplasta and Rhop-<tei:lb/>tromeris in having extraordinary protuberances on the head, a trumpet-shaped protrusion on the<tei:lb/>supraclypeal area of the face (Figs 31, 32) and elongate mandibles (Fig. 290). Trichoplasta is<tei:lb/>primarily separated from Rhoptromeris and Stentorceps by the elongated, almost spine-shaped<tei:lb/>apex of the scutellum. Rhoptromeris is further distinguished from Trichoplasta by the forewing<tei:lb/>venation. All other genera with a projecting pronotal plate have the foveae either side of the<tei:lb/>medial area of the pronotal plate open and form separate groups of genera. Nordlander (1982a)<tei:lb/>published a cladistic analysis of Trybliographa, Leptopilina, Cothonaspis, Rhoptromeris and<tei:lb/>Trichoplasta using a matrix of 16 characters; the characters were divided into plesiomorphic<tei:lb/>(primitive) and apomorphic (derived) states and the character polarity determined through<tei:lb/>outgroup comparisons using the operational rule of Watrous &amp; Wheeler (1981). Nordlander<tei:lb/>concluded that Leptopilina, Cothonaspis, Rhoptromeris and Trichoplasta had seven synapomor-<tei:lb/>phies in common and constitute a monophyletic group. I believe that the form of the pronotal<tei:lb/>plate clearly separates Rhoptromeris and Trichoplasta from Leptopilina and Cothonaspis.<tei:lb/>Masner (1958), in discussing the genus Ganaspis, relates it to Leptopilina, Rhoptromeris,<tei:lb/>Pseudeucoila (now a synonym of Trybliographa) and Odonteucoila. Masner (1960) included in<tei:lb/>his key to Odonteucoila three species now recognised as Trichoplasta from the Afrotropical<tei:lb/>Region, the significance of the pronotal plate not being noted. I have included both Odon-<tei:lb/>teucoila and Coneucoela in the generic key although both genera appear to be restricted to the<tei:lb/>Neotropical Region; species originally described in both genera from the Afrotropical Region<tei:lb/>have recently been transferred to Trichoplasta (Nordlander, 19820). Weld (1952), as did<tei:lb/>Masner, characterised Ganaspis by the flat, mirror-like, elliptical scutellar cup. Quinlan (1978)<tei:lb/>erroneously based his interpretation of the genus on one of the species included in Masner's key,<tei:lb/>the holotype of the type-species, Ganaspis mundata Foerster not being available. Nordlander<tei:lb/>(1980), however, placed G. subnuda with Leptopilina heterotoma (Thomson) as a junior<tei:lb/>synonym. A female of the type-species was redescribed by Weld (1952). Ganaspis is a complex<tei:lb/>genus and needs more research at species level before deciding its relationship to other genera.<tei:lb/>At present it is defined by the mirror-like, almost flat scutellar cup and the weakly conical apex of<tei:lb/>the scutellum. Leptopilina shares a number of characters with Cothonaspis, Rhoptromeris and<tei:lb/>Trichoplasta, and this is illustrated in Nordlander's cladogram referred to above. Prior to<tei:lb/>Nordlander (1980), Leptopilina had hardly been referred to in the literature. Weld (1952) had<tei:lb/>doubts about the placement of Leptopilina, the holotype of the type-species being a male, and<tei:lb/>suggested that it could be a Ganaspis species. However, Leptopilina, although dissimilar,<tei:lb/>appears to be closest to Cothonaspis in the shape of the thorax and in the petiole (first segment of<tei:lb/>the gaster) which is widened posteriorly although it has a denser ring of hairs (sometimes thin) at<tei:lb/>the base of tergite two. Cothonaspis (one of the earliest described genera in the Eucoilidae) has<tei:lb/>many characters in common with Rhoptromeris and Trichoplasta. It differs (apart from the<tei:lb/>pronotal plate character referred to above) primarily by the form of the first segment of the<tei:lb/>gaster, which is virtually hairless and carinate, and the base of tergite two which has only very<tei:lb/>sparse pubescence on the lower lateral margins. Hexacola and Kleidotoma have a number of<tei:lb/>characters in common, such as, for example, the shape and sculpture of the scutellum. In both<tei:lb/>genera the cup is small and the scutellar disc is either longitudinally striate or reticulate-striate,<tei:lb/>but exceptionally it can be almost smooth. They differ mainly in the wing characters. In<tei:lb/>Kleidotoma the apex of the wing is either incised or arcuate, and the radial cell of the forewing is<tei:lb/>open on the margin and distinctively shaped (Fig. 8). In Hexacola the apex of the wing is<tei:lb/>rounded and the radial cell is decidedly closed on the margin (Fig. 164). Nordlander (19826)<tei:lb/>regards Hexacola as being in the Ganaspis group of genera (p. 247). Afrodontaspis has a number<tei:lb/>of unique characters that do not indicate a clear relationship with any other group of genera, i.e. ,<tei:lb/>the scutellar cup is declined posteriorly so that it is not completely visible in dorsal view (Fig. 50) .<tei:lb/>The sides of the pronotum, mesoscutum, lateral bars of the scutellum and scutellar disc are<tei:lb/>striate (Fig. 50). The scutellum is sharply pointed apically and the wing surfaces are dotted with<tei:lb/>hair bases similar to those found in Bothrochacis and Eucoila. In Weld's key (1952) it would run<tei:lb/>close to Trissodontaspis , a Neotropical genus. It is distinguished from it, however, by the radial<tei:lb/>cell of the forewing being open and by the structure of the scutellum. Eucoila and Bothrochacis</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL EUCOILIDAE 249</tei:p>
         <tei:p>both have almost bare wing surfaces (only a few hairs are present) and are separated from each<tei:lb/>other by the striking apomorphic cup of Bothrochacis in which the scutellar cup itself is sharply<tei:lb/>declined apically . The surface of the cup is elevated in front of the posterior fovea so that, when<tei:lb/>viewed dorsally, it appears declined apically. Trybliographa has world-wide distribution and is<tei:lb/>extremely rich in numbers of species; they are slightly larger in size than those of other genera<tei:lb/>except Bothrochacis and Eucoila. Nordlander (1981) synonomized eight Foerster genera,<tei:lb/>previously regarded as distinct, with Trybliographa. No keys are given to genera but from his<tei:lb/>remarks on the generic relationships, Bothrochacis and Eucoila are related by a series of<tei:lb/>characters regarded as symplesiomorphic. In common with Eucoila and Bothrochacis, the<tei:lb/>scutellar plate is large, almost circular in some species and well elevated, depressed in the centre<tei:lb/>with a large apical fovea. The scutellar disc varies in degree and intensity of sculpture, from<tei:lb/>punctate-reticulate-rugose. In a large number of species the lateral bars of the scutellum are<tei:lb/>striate in part. The ring of pubescence at the base of tergite two of the gaster is dense and<tei:lb/>complete on the dorsal surface. The radial cell of the forewing can be open or closed.<tei:lb/>Nordlander (1982a) places Glauraspidia in the Chrestosema-group. Glauraspidia itself is<tei:lb/>characterized and distinguished from related genera by the absence of a mesopleural suture,<tei:lb/>although in some species it may be weakly indicated. The dense pubescence either side of the<tei:lb/>pronotal plate and on the entire metapleuron, and the density of the pubescence on the<tei:lb/>propodeum together with a dense felt-like ring of pubescence at the base of tergite two of the<tei:lb/>gaster further distinguish this genus. Benoit (1956) described a monotypic genus Daruna,<tei:lb/>relating it to Rhoptromeris but distinguishing it by the rather unusual form of the scutellar cup<tei:lb/>which has two large foveae, one centrally and almost round, the other on the apex and<tei:lb/>transverse. The surface of the scutellar disc is smooth and shining, the apex rounded. The<tei:lb/>pronotal plate projects forward and the foveae are open on the lateral margins. The systematic<tei:lb/>position of Daruna is unclear, but the form of the pronotal plate suggests that it is not closely<tei:lb/>related to Rhoptromeris.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Checklist of the Afrotropical Eucoilidae included in this paper</tei:p>

         <tei:p>unicolora sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>zeussp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EUCOILIDAE Thomson</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eucoilidae Thomson, 1862: 397; Eady &amp; Quinlan, 1963: 7. Type-genus: Eucoila Westwood [emended].<tei:lb/>Eucoilinae Thomson; Foerster, 1869: 186.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Eucoilidae is the largest and most widely distributed of the parasitic families in the Cynipoidea. The<tei:lb/>species form a distinctive group, distinguished from other Cynipoidea by the presence of a raised cup or<tei:lb/>plate (Fig. 359), which varies in shape and sculpture. They are internal parasites of dipterous larvae,<tei:lb/>emerging from the puparia (Quinlan, 1978). A number of them are parasites of cereal crop pests and are of<tei:lb/>sufficient economic importance to warrant close studies of their life histories (James, 1928; Imms, 1930,<tei:lb/>1932; Jenni, 1951; Nostvik, 1954; Kerrich &amp; Quinlan, 1960; Masner, 1958, 1960; Carton, 1977; Carton,<tei:lb/>Roualt &amp; Kitano, 1977; Nordlander, 19786; Barbotin, Carton &amp; Kelner Pillault, 1979; Tsacas, 1979).<tei:lb/>Nineteen genera are at present known to occur in the Afrotropical Region.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to the genera of Afrotropical Eucoilidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Pronotal plate either distinct in anterodorsal view but not strongly projected forward (Fig. 18) ,<tei:lb/>or indistinct viewed dorsally , see Nordlanderia (Fig. 11), Eucoilidea (Fig. 83) . First tergite of<tei:lb/>gaster, if visible, in form of a narrow ring, sometimes obscured by tergite 2 which never has a<tei:lb/>hairy ring at base, at most only a few sparse hairs on lower lateral margins; mesopleuron with<tei:lb/>a distinct suture, or weakly striate (Microstilba); mesoscutum shiny, notaulices present</tei:p>
         <tei:p>though sometimes aberrant or indicated by lines of hairs 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotal plate distinct both in anterodorsal and lateral views, i.e. projected forward from<tei:lb/>pronotum (Fig. 2). First tergite of gaster, if visible, sometimes in the form of a crenulate ring,<tei:lb/>without a dense ring of hairs (visible in Cothonaspis, Leptopilina etc.), or tergite 2 with a</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL EUCOILIDAE 251</tei:p>
         <tei:p>dense ring of pubescence at base, not always complete on dorsal surface or sometimes with<tei:lb/>only a few sparse hairs in place of hairy ring; mesopleuron generally with a suture though this<tei:lb/>cari be aberrant or absent; mesoscutum smooth and shiny, satiny or granulate; notaulices<tei:lb/>generally absent 6</tei:p>
         <tei:p>First tergite of gaster not wholly visible in dry-mounted specimens either in dorsal or lateral<tei:lb/>view, at most in the form of a crescent, obscured by tergite 2 (Fig. 220); notaulices either<tei:lb/>faintly indicated or with a row of hairs in their place, if visible, at junction with scutellum<tei:lb/>either converging or parallel (Figs 17, 217) 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>First tergite of gaster usually visible in dorsal and lateral views, distinctly crenulate (Fig. 22);<tei:lb/>notaulices distinct, sometimes converging sharply on approaching scutellum (Figs 217, 218) 5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Malar space area and supraclypeal area with short protrusions (Fig. 16); area below mesopleu-<tei:lb/>ral suture coriaceous (Fig. 214); scutellar cup large, oval, excavate on lower half with a<tei:lb/>number of smaller fovea round outer edge (Fig. 15), scutellar disc reticulate, scutellar foveae<tei:lb/>aberrant; notaulices distinct, radial cell closed, almost as deep as wide; $ antenna clavate, cf<tei:lb/>antenna filiform, segment 3 curved, swollen distally NORDLANDERIA gen. n. (p. 288)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>AFRODONTASPIS Weld</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Afrodontaspis Weld, 1961: 280. Type-species: Coneucoela striatissima Benoit, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. $ antenna 13-segmented, subclavate, cf antenna 15-segmented. Pronotum, mesoscutum,<tei:lb/>mesopleura and lateral bars striate (Figs 10, 49, 50, 51). Scutellum with a long narrow cup extending almost<tei:lb/>to apex of scutellar disc, the usual large basal fovea on cup declined (not visible in dorsal view), scutellar<tei:lb/>disc falling sharply away from cup, with crenulate sculpture (Fig. 10); either side of pronotal plate with a<tei:lb/>tuft of dense yellow-white pubescence; base of tergite 2 of gaster with dense hairy ring obscuring tergite 1.<tei:lb/>Wings clear, not ciliate, dotted with hair bases, lower margins with a weak fringe of hairs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Zaire; Uganda.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Afrodontaspis lanatus sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 10, 49, 51, 52, 53, 54)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. $ . Antenna 13-segmented, clavate, 7-13 with rhinaria forming a weak club, 3-6 subequal in<tei:lb/>length and breadth, 7-13 each weakly swollen, 7-10 each same length as segments 3-6, 11-13 each longer<tei:lb/>than 7 (Fig. 52). Head, viewed frontally, longer than wide, vertex coriaceous, eyes further apart measured<tei:lb/>medially than height of an eye, face with closely spaced radiating striate sculpture converging towards<tei:lb/>frontal line area which is coriaceous (Fig. 53), malar groove not conspicuous in the striate sculpture,<tei:lb/>clypeus coriaceous, mandibles tri-dentate, occiput and vertex strigose-coriaceous. Pronotal plate pro-<tei:lb/>duced forward, medial bridge between anterior and posterior parts narrow, fovea or lateral cavities open<tei:lb/>laterally (Fig. 49), these cavities filled with dense pubescence extending out from and on sides of fovea.<tei:lb/>Pronotum, viewed dorsally, striated; mesoscutum longitudinally striated, weakly so medially (Fig. 51);<tei:lb/>lateral bars of scutellum striate, scutellar fovea large, deep, separated by a long thin ridge with scutellar cup<tei:lb/>declined posteriorly, scutellar disc coriaceous in dorsal view, tongue-shaped apically, lateral margins of<tei:lb/>apex of disc crenulate (Fig. 10); carinae of propodeum bowed medially, pubescent on outer margins.<tei:lb/>Mesopleura completely transversely striate. Segment 1 of gaster completely obscured by dense ring of<tei:lb/>pubescence at base of tergite 2, woolly in appearance, tergites 2-3 of gaster visible in lateral view, segment</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 the largest, occupying most of visible area, ventral spine and hypoygium barely visible; coxae and femora<tei:lb/>finely coriaceous, tibiae and tarsi finely and densely strigose, pubescent, tibiae with two apical setae. Wings<tei:lb/>not ciliate, without apical hair fringe, surface of wings dotted with hair bases, radial cell of forewing open<tei:lb/>on wing margin (vein RI not reaching margin of wing, but indicated by pigmentation), Rs+M and M very<tei:lb/>weakly indicated by a trace of pigmentation (Fig. 54). Colour: antenna yellowish brown, head and thorax<tei:lb/>blackish, gaster chestnut-red.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Zaire: Kaziba, affl.g. Senze s. affi. dr. Lufira, 1140 m, 15-27.ii.1948 (G. F. de Witte)<tei:lb/>(MRAC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Zaire: 4 $ (MRAC). Kenya: 1 $ (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is closely related to striatissima but separated by the different sculpturing on the<tei:lb/>head and mesoscutum. A larger and darker species. Size 3 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Afrodontaspis striatissima (Benoit)<tei:lb/>(Figs 10, 50, 56)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coneucoela striatissima Benoit, 1956: 533. Holotype &lt;j&gt;, ZAIRE (MRAC) [examined].<tei:lb/>Afrodontaspis striatissima (Benoit) Weld, 1961: 280.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. $. Antenna 13-segmented with 3-segmented club, club segments with rhinaria, remainder<tei:lb/>with granulate sculpture, segments 3-10 subequal in length, each wider apically than at base. Head, viewed<tei:lb/>frontally, strongly coriaceous, frontal area raised with weak impressed sculpture extending to base of<tei:lb/>clypeus, mandibles tridentate, head, viewed dorsally, finely coriaceous, back of head strigose. Pronotal<tei:lb/>plate large; pronotum longitudinally striate (with a dense tuft of pubescence on medial margins) (Fig. 50).<tei:lb/>Mesopleura strongly and broadly striated on lateral margins, weakly strigose to smooth medially. Lateral<tei:lb/>bars of scutellum striate. Scutellar disc ending in a blunt spine, scutellar fovea large, half as long as entire<tei:lb/>scutellum, scutellar cup very narrow, extending to base of scutellar spine, the usual large basal fovea on cup<tei:lb/>declined, dorsal surface of scutellar disc coriaceous, lateral margins sharply declined with large adpressed<tei:lb/>crenulations (cf. Fig. 10); carinae of propodeum bowed. Base of tergite 2 of gaster with dense ring of<tei:lb/>pubescence obscuring tergite 1 from view, tergites 2-5 visible in lateral view, the apical margins finely</tei:p>

         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL EUCOILIDAE 255</tei:p>
         <tei:p>punctate, tergite 2 the largest (Fig. 48). Femur and tibia with reticulate-coriaceous sculpture, tibia with<tei:lb/>striated sculpture, tarsus 5-segmented. Wings with hair fringe on hind margin only, surface dotted with hair<tei:lb/>bases, not ciliate, radial cell of forewing open basally (vein RI not reaching margin of wing), Rs+M and M<tei:lb/>not indicated (Fig. 56).          <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Zaire: 1 $ (holotype), Rutshuro, xii.1937 (/. Ghesquiere) (MRAC).<tei:lb/>Uganda: 1 $, 20 cf (BMNH); Zaire: 44 $ (MRAC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is separated from lanatus by the sculpture of the head and thorax. A much smaller<tei:lb/>species. Size 2 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COTHONASPIS Hartig</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cothonaspis Hartig, 1840: 201. Type-species: Cothonaspis pentatoma Hartig, by original designation. P-<tei:lb/>silosema Keiffer, 1901: 160. Type-species: Psilosema giraudi Dalla Torre &amp; Keiffer, by subsequent<tei:lb/>designation, Rowher &amp; Pagan, 1917: 374. [Synonomy by Weld, 1952: 243.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. $ antenna 13-segmented with apical segments forming a club (Fig. 57), cf antenna 15-<tei:lb/>segmented, the fourth segment swollen, longer than third or fifth. Head, viewed frontally, spherical, as<tei:lb/>wide almost as thorax, genae broad, eyes round, further apart measured medially than height of an eye.<tei:lb/>Pronotal plate projected forward, anterior and posterior parts not fused laterally, i.e. fovea or cavities<tei:lb/>open (Fig. 34). Mesoscutum smooth, polished, notaulices absent, in some species long scattered hairs<tei:lb/>present; scutellar cup elongate, narrow, broader basally, scutellar disc with radiating striae, lateral bars<tei:lb/>smooth, polished, scutellar foveae ovoid, smooth. Propodeal carinae parallel, propodeum produced to<tei:lb/>form a neck-shaped nucha, hairless laterally. Segment 1 of gaster short, broad, in form of a crenulate ring,<tei:lb/>base of tergite 1 without a ring of pubescence, at most a few sparse hairs present, gaster compressed<tei:lb/>laterally. Wings narrow, rounded apically, surface normally pubescent, with a longish hair fringe on apical<tei:lb/>margins, radial cell of forewing closed on distal margin though in a few species it appears open due to<tei:lb/>absence of a complete vein, i.e. pigmentation only present.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Europe; South Africa; North and South America.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. Cothonaspis is separated from the closely related Leptopilina by the form of the thorax and<tei:lb/>the lateral margins of the propodeum. In Cothonaspis the thorax is elongate and the lateral margins of the<tei:lb/>propodeum are not noticeably hairy. Two Afrotropical species have at one time or another been assigned<tei:lb/>to the supposed subgenera of Cothonaspis. Erisphagia mahensis Kieffer was placed in Cothonaspis<tei:lb/>(Erisphagia) by Weld (1952: 244), and Nordlander (1980) transferred it to Leptopilina Foerster. Psilosema<tei:lb/>fenerivae Kieffer, a species based on a male from Madagascar but not located, is not accounted for in this<tei:lb/>paper. Two further species are described and compared with Cothonaspis pentatoma, the type-species of<tei:lb/>the genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY. The European species of Cothonaspis are associated with Sepsidae in cow dung (Nordlander,<tei:lb/>1976; Quinlan, 1978).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to the species of Cothonaspis Hartig</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Females</tei:p>

         <tei:p>scutellar cup not extending to apex of disc, apex of disc rounded (Fig. 57) 2</tei:p>
